DOC.HEAD: Japan Opposes Log-Export Limits
DOC.TEXT: Japan is putting pressure on the Bush administration to ease restrictions on log exports, a newspaper reported Tuesday. According to The Oregonian, Ryohei Murata, Japanese ambassador to the United States, wrote a letter to U.S. Trade Representative Carla A. Hills on June 15 asking the government to oppose tougher export restrictions. The newspaper, which obtained a copy of the letter, said Murata wrote that the restrictions ``seriously impede trade between the two countries.'' ``We are especially concerned with the fact that there are active movements in the U.S. Congress to further strengthen log export restrictions,'' Murata wrote. ``We strongly request that the U.S. government take effective actions to oppose such legislation.'' Japan, the biggest foreign buyer of U.S. logs, imported 4.7 billion board feet of logs from the United States last year. China imported about 1.7 billion board feet and South Korea imported less than half that amount. Legislation is moving through Congress that would make permanent the annual ban on exporting federal logs from the West, except Alaskan logs, and ban log exports from most state lands. The Bush administration supported such measures June 19 in a statement about declining timber supplies and the listing of the northern spotted owl as a threatened species. Some proponents of a log export ban believe it would encourage overseas buyers to use U.S. sawmills. Japan's foreign ministry says the existing ban on exports of federal logs in the West violates the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the international agreement governing most trade, as would further restrictions. U.S. forest products industry leaders also oppose the legislation, fearing losses to Japanese sawmills. Hills said in a reply to Murata that the administration had told Congress of concerns about the effects of trade restrictions. ``We will continue to seek to ensure that any actions taken in this area, especially in the context of domestic conservation programs, are to the maximum extent possible consistent with our international obligations,'' Hills said. Shotaro Yachi, economic counselor at the Japanese Embassy in Washington, called Hills' letter vague. ``We wanted a strong commitment,'' Yachi said. ``We have been importing logs from your country, and we'd like to continue.'' Japan has about 17,500 sawmills, which employ 131,000 workers. Nishitani could not estimate the number of jobs that depend on U.S. log imports. Japan imports logs duty-free, but levies tariffs on many processed wood products. Washington persuaded Tokyo during the yearlong wood products talks to lower some tariffs to boost exports of finished lumber to Japan.

DOC.HEAD: British Transport Secretary Meets Man Who Fooled Guards With Fake Bomb
DOC.TEXT: Transport Secretary Cecil Parkinson says his department will investigate how a man testing security at London's Heathrow airport was able to check a fake bomb aboard a British Airways flight to the United States. The man, Dr. Jim Swire, whose daughter Flora was among those killed in the Dec. 21, 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 met with Parkinson earlier Monday and detailed how he managed to fool guards at Heathrow in the May test. Swire heads a group of British relatives of the disaster's victims called U.K. Families-Flight 103. The bomb aboard Flight 103 exploded as the passenger jet flew over Lockerbie, Scotland on its way to New York, killing all 259 people aboard the Boeing 747 and 11 others on the ground. Flight 103 originated in Frankfurt in West Germany, changing planes at Heathrow. Swire told reporters after his 90-minute meeting with Parkinson and other aviation officials that he would continue to press British authorities to improve airline security. ``I think you will find we will not go away until they have,'' he said. Swire disclosed details of his privately organized security test in a radio interview Sunday. He said the device he used was a non-explosive replica of the one that exploded over Lockerbie. British and U.S. investigators have said they believe the bomb that downed Flight 103 was placed by Palestinian terrorists and had a barometric trigger set to detonate at a predetermined altitude. Swire said in the interview Sunday that the fake device he used at Heathrow in May was packed in a radio-cassette recorder, like the Lockerbie bomb, but used marzipan icing instead of Semtex plastic explosives. ``It had a dummy detonator which would have shown up on X-ray, an extra printed circuit board, extra batteries, pressure transducer and so on, all wired up in a form that would have worked if the marzipan had been replaced with Semtex,'' he said in the interview. ``Our flight was selected for what they call special security, and our cases were opened and searched in front of us. The radio-cassette recorder was picked up, and I was asked whether I had taken the batteries out, and I correctly replied, `Yes, I had taken the batteries out.' It was then replaced in the suitcase and is now in America.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Proposal Revives Debate Over Use of Nuclear Arms
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is suggesting a change in NATO's nuclear doctrine that is a modest shift away from atomic brinkmanship, analysts say. But the Cold War question remains: when would the West use its deadly nuclear arms? That question has confounded allied leaders for most of NATO's 41-year history. The answer has never been clear. But the issue is regaining a policy spotlight as the Western allies try to overhaul the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and adjust their defense strategies to political changes in Eastern Europe. Administration sources said Monday that Bush will propose at a NATO summit Thursday that alliance doctrine be revised to declare that nuclear arms are ``weapons of last resort.'' Such a statement, if endorsed as official NATO policy, would be at least a small step away from the existing doctrine, known as ``flexible response,'' according to private analysts interviewed Monday. ``Flexible response'' holds that U.S. nuclear arms could be fired during the early stages of a European ground war started by Soviet non-nuclear forces, if NATO troops were being overrun. By calling U.S. nuclear forces in Europe ``weapons of last resort,'' Bush is suggesting the United States would wait longer to initiate a nuclear battle than it would under existing NATO doctrine, said John Steinbruner, director of foreign policy studies at the Brookings Institution, a liberal-oriented Washington think tank. It's unclear how Bush or the allies would define a ``last resort.'' The weapons in question are called battlefield nuclear weapons because they cannot reach beyond central Europe, long considered the most likely war theater. Only if use of these weapons failed to end the conflict would the United States consider resorting to use of strategic, or long-range, nuclear weapons. Steinbruner said the use of the term ``last resort'' seemed to suggest the administration was contemplating only a moderate shift in NATO doctrine, since Bush apparently would not rule out that NATO could be the first to fire battlefield nuclear weapons. ``They're dancing rhetorically around the subject,'' Steinbruner said. The topic is particularly touchy for NATO governments because while the demise of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact is making nuclear weapons less important in Europe, no member of the Western alliance is yet willing to abandon nuclear defenses altogether. The London NATO summit is expected to launch a major review of nuclear strategy. Details of a revised military stance are unlikely to be worked out for months. Frank J. Gaffney, director of the conservative Center for Security Policy, said he interpreted Bush's proposal as an attempt to placate the Soviet Union, which argues that the reunification of Germany requires that NATO drop its military role. Gaffney said Bush's proposal would erode the credibility of NATO, since it would bring the alliance closer to renouncing all use of nuclear weapons in Europe. ``We are, in the name of trying to alleviate Soviet concerns, going to accede to radical changes in the character of NATO's traditional security arrangement,'' he said. David Shorr, associate director of the British American Security Information Council, a private organization based in London and Washington, said Bush's proposal amounts to a rhetorical device with little substantive meaning. He said the proposal was unlikely to help resolve the issue within NATO regarding when, in a conventional war against the Soviets, the West would resort to nuclear weapons. ``It shows what a delicate dance NATO has had to do around exactly what `flexible response' means,'' Shorr said.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Finds Support Among Black Activists on Political Fringe
DOC.TEXT: His once-solid support shaken by lurid courtroom tales of drugs, sex and abuse, Mayor Marion Barry is finding comfort in the public embrace of black activists on the political fringe. While the murky videotape image of Barry filling his lungs with crack cocaine replays on the television screens and in the minds of his city, Washington's mayor has been anything but reclusive. He joined Louis Farrakhan, the controversial Nation of Islam leader, on a stage before thousands of people last week. On Sunday, he bathed in ovation and song from the Imani Temple congregation of Bishop George Augustus Stallings Jr., a flamboyant black priest who broke from the Roman Catholic church to form his own denomination. Barry also has appeared in recent weeks with Rep. Gus Savage, D-Ill., a virulent critic of the ``white press.'' Even Tawana Brawley, whose allegations of kidnap, rape and defilement by whites were discounted by authorities after creating controversy in New York, shared a stage with him recently. ``He's trying to reach out to whomever will accept him at this point,'' said Linda Williams, a veteran observer of black politics and a fellow at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government center for press and politics. ``Many, if not most, of the standard middle-class black leaders in the nation and in the D.C. area are keeping their distance,'' Williams said. ``Therefore, these are really the only elements that are openly coming to him at this point.'' Barry, 54, is a former civil rights leader and street activist once considered on the political fringes himself. He moved into the majority-black capital city's political mainstream, however, and rose through elective offices to mayor, where he is serving his 12th year. He now is on trial in federal court on drug and perjury charges that followed years of investigation. Prosecutors last week played the videotape of their hotel room sting of Barry. Rasheeda Moore, a girlfriend-turned-FBI-informer and a key prosecution witness, has alleged she and Barry shared illegal drugs more than 100 times, and that they had a sexual relationship that ended when Barry slapped her to a hotel room floor. In a sideshow that has kept the city's radio talk shows abuzz, Farrakhan and Stallings tried separately to enter the crowded courtroom at Barry's invitation. U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson barred both, ruling that their presence could be disruptive and intimidating. He said Farrakhan ``is a persona non grata'' in the courtroom. The American Civil Liberties Union filed papers with the federal appeals court asking to overturn Jackson's ruling. In Farrakhan, Barry has found an ally with whom he previously has been at odds. Farrakhan, who has created controversy for calling Judaism a ``dirty religion,'' delivered a strong attack two months ago on local political leaders for moral corruption and said they should be replaced by Muslims. But last week, Farrakhan declared Barry a ``repentant soul'' who is under attack and urged him to run for re-election. During a break in the trial Monday, Barry appeared before a crowd that gathered on a plaza across from City Hall to cheer him. Also speaking was Abdul Alim Muhammad, Farrakhan's national spokesman, who called the trial a ``subversion of justice'' and a ``lynching'' conducted because Barry could not be defeated at the polls. Barry said in a television interview on Monday that the crowds and Farrakhan's embrace at the rally last week have helped sustain him. ``Got a lot of spiritual feeling, a lot of love there,'' Barry said. ``About 10 to 15,000 people cheered us. Genuine love. That made us go through the night. ... There's a lot of love in this city for me.'' Barry's jury is sequestered and thus insulated from the activity outside the courtroom. But Ron Walters, chairman of the political science department at Howard University, said, ``I would be surprised if some of that didn't get to the jury in some way.'' Walters said Barry is using the displays to tap a feeling among many blacks that he has been unfairly pursued by white prosecutors. Although Barry has said he won't seek another term, speculation persists that he might still run as an independent if he is acquitted or there is a hung jury. The deadline for independents to file as candidates isn't until late August. ``I don't think he has accepted that he is dead politically,'' Williams said.

DOC.HEAD: WALTER MEARS: Lots of Facts, But What's the Truth?
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Substitutes for the regular column by Walter R. Mears, vacationing; moved July 2 as b0198, PM-Walter Mears, for use today
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: This is a town that is drowning in words, swimming in information but parched for facts. When decisions have to be made, the decision-makers, in Congress, in the White House, in the agencies of government, afloat in data and analysis, still yearn for the decisive fact that will tell them what to do. Would reducing the tax on capital gains give the economy a booster shot, as President Bush claims, or merely deepen the deficit gap, as his Democratic opponents say? If the House Ways and Means Committee were to announce hearings on that question today, the corridors would be crowded tomorrow with experts carrying briefcases loaded with facts to prove indisputably both sides of the argument. Predictive facts _ what would happen if _ are not the only kind that are hard to come by. So are contemporary facts. Homelessness is a gnawing social problem, high in the public consciousness, the subject of strenuous government effort, yet no one knows how many homeless people are out there, or who they are, or how long they have been homeless. Back in 1971, President Richard Nixon, concerned by inflation, took the unprecedented step of imposing peacetime wage and price controls on the economy. Overnight, it became illegal to raise the price of a Buick or a bagel. It was a radical move for a Republican president, intended to stem inflation that he saw as threatening to the economy and his re-election prospects. And yet, says Herbert J. Stein, who was one of Nixon's economic advisers, ``there was a lot of uncertainty about what the rate of inflation actually was.'' Inflation was, and is, measured in dozens of ways and no one can say which measurement most accurately reflects the rise in the price of goods and services. That's not all, says Stein: ``We still don't know what caused the depression in 1929. There's still disagreement over whether some international thing was moving the whole world or whether it was the way the monetary system was being managed. ``It's hard to get information on a lot of subjects,'' he says. ``Take all the talk on the S&L business. It is hard to find where all the estimates of losses (which seem to change monthly) come from. We have very little information about what happened in the first place.'' When President Franklin D. Roosevelt died in 1945 and Vice President Harry S. Truman suddenly became president, he learned about the secret work on the atomic bomb and one of the first decisions he had to make was whether to use it against Japan. Fleet Adm. William D. Leahy, chief of staff to Roosevelt, came to him, Truman recalls in his memoirs, and in absolute certainty advised him not to use the bomb. ```That is the biggest fool thing we have ever done,' he observed in his sturdy, salty manner,'' Truman writes. ```The bomb will never go off, and I speak as an expert in explosives.''' That's the trouble with experts, of which this town is also full. Their opinions always parade as facts. Says Charles Schultze, who played the same role for President Jimmy Carter that Stein played for Nixon: ``There are zillions of facts. ... The question is, having all those facts, what do you conclude? ``If you ask me what a reduction in capital gains taxation would do to federal revenues, I can get you two highly quantitative reports, full of numbers, one saying it will go up and one saying it will go down. Sometimes the `facts' come from people who want them to be true.'' As long ago as 1931, Charles Evans Hughes, then chief justice, reflected in a speech on the potency of facts. Said Hughes: ``An unscrupulous administrator might be tempted to say, `Let me find the facts for the people of my country, and I care little who lays down the general principles.''' Says Jim Jaffe, a savvy aide on Capitol Hill since 1976: ``Look at what's happening behind what we used to call the Iron Curtain. You can say one of two things. You can say the Reagan plan of spending like a madman, figure they'd run out of money before we would, has been wildly successful. Or you can say the communist world was deteriorating anyhow and look at all the domestic concerns we ignored while we were wasting all this money on missiles we had no need for. ... It's an intellectual game, it's not a factual game.'' There are lots of facts in Washington, but judgment is always scarce. That's a fact.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Mike Feinsilber has been reporting in Washington since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Customs Takes $22 Million in Cash From Money Launderers
DOC.TEXT: Agents stacked cash 3 feet high atop a 60-foot banquet table and along the floor in announcing the seizure of $22.07 million from drug dealers who thought they were turning their profits over to money launderers. The dealers actually were giving their money to undercover agents taking part in a 13-month sting, Customs Commissioner Carol Hallett said Monday. A dozen agents wearing bulletproof vests and carrying machine guns stood watch as Hallett spoke with more than $18 million stacked on tables at the Doral Country Club and in boxes on the floor. The rest of the money is in New York. ``This was a money-laundering operation of unprecedented proportions,'' Ms. Hallett said. ``And this record seizure should warn the drug smuggler that as each day passes, we're getting closer and closer to them and their drug money.'' Only one person, a driver, has been arrested. Hallet refused to disclose whether the sting was aimed at Colombia's cocaine cartels, saying more arrests are expected. But she said the drug ring involved Colombians and Cuban-Americans working out of Miami, with connections in New York. A bank gave the original tip that the traffickers wanted to ship the money to banks in the Caribbean and in Europe, authorities said. Thirty-five undercover Customs agents stepped in. The dealers collected money from street drug sales, she said, then gave it to couriers. The agents received the money from the couriers, who left cash-stuffed cars at pre-arranged spots, such as shopping centers, for pickup. The money, much of it in small bills, was so heavy cars had to be equipped with special pneumatic shocks. The cash, containing large numbers of $20, $10 and $5 bills, weighed more than 1{ tons, Ms. Hallett said. Guillermo Felix Hernandez-Castillo was arrested Thursday after being stopped here with $421,000 in his car, authorities said. He was jailed on $50,000 bail and must prove the money he posts as bail is not drug-related. The $22 million seizure was a Customs record, but in a four-year Drug Enforcement Administration money-laundering probe that ended last year, agents seized $80.9 million in cash, said Miami DEA spokesmn John Fernandes. The largest one-day seizure of cash was $19.6 million confiscated in January 1989 by the DEA from New York dealers connected to Colombia's Cali drug cartel.

DOC.HEAD: Patch of Farmland to Join Antietam National Battlefield
DOC.TEXT: The Cornfield is partly a barley field now and there aren't any trees in the North Woods, but both are becoming federal property more than a century and a quarter after the Blue and the Grey fought fiercely for them in the Battle of Antietam. The Richard King Mellon Foundation and the Conservation Fund deeded 148 acres of Maryland farmland, including the two Civil War sites, to the Interior Department on Monday as part of what was billed as the largest-ever land donation to the government. The farm near Antietam Creek is one of 10 properties that the Pittsburgh-based foundation has purchased at a cost of more than $21 million for donation to the government by way of the Conservation Fund, a land and water conservation organization. Also handed over on Monday were 93,000 acres of wildlife habitat in North Carolina. The tract between Albemarle and Pamlico sounds will be administered by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. Gifts scheduled for transfer later in the year are: Five Forks at Dinwiddie, Va., site of a battle known as the Waterloo of the Confederacy; Forked Lightning Ranch, N.M., surrounding the Pecos National Monument; 130 acres of upland adjoining the marshes and open water of Mackay Island National Wildlife Refuge, N.C.; a 122-acre addition to the Rachel Carson National Wildlife Refuge, Maine. Also, two tracts totaling 468 acres to be added to Rocky Mountain National Park, Colo.; two parcels of land on and near Skyline Drive in Shenandoah National Park, Va.; and a 135-acre addition to the Wilderness Area of Fredericksburg and Spotsylvania Memorial National Military Park, Va. The Antietam farm contained a 30-acre cornfield when the Battle of Antietam, the bloodiest single day of fighting in American history, was fought on Sept. 17, 1862. Of the 23,000 killed and wounded, 55 percent were struck in and around the Cornfield, as the site became known. Some were buried there, said Edwin C. Bearss, chief historian of the National Park Service. From 1865 to 1867, the dead were removed to a Union cemetery in Sharpsburg, Md., and to Confederate burial places in Shepherdstown, W.Va., and Hagerstown, Md. The foundation bought the property from Paul Culler, who, with his son Lynn, has farmed it for 37 years. They plant it in corn some years and in barley, oats and hay at other times, in accordance with modern crop rotation. This year, said Lynn Culler, they have 18 acres in corn and the rest in barley. Richard Rambur, superintendent of Antietam National Battlefield in Sharpsburg, said the Cornfield would be returned to its original size and configuration on the basis of contemporary maps. He said trees would be planted in the woods from which Union troops advanced into the field. The Cullers will continue to farm the property for three or four years under a lease arrangement with the Park Service, as guaranteed by their arrangement with the Conservation Fund, Rambur said. After that, it will be put up for lease by the highest bidder, like other farmland in national parks. The farm includes not only the Cornfield, but most of the North Woods, the wood lot from which Union troops advanced into the tall corn. There are no trees in the North Woods now, and Rambur said trees will be planted to make it the way it was in 1862. In addition to the farm, the foundation bought two other pieces of property, outside the park boundary, that will be held for possible donation later. Altogether, the 280 acres of land sold for $1.1 million, Conservation Fund spokesman Jack Lynn said.

DOC.HEAD: Economists See Fed Leaning Toward Lower Interest Rates
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve policymakers meeting today are probably tilting toward nudging interest rates lower this summer, many economists predict. The move, if it comes, would occur at an ideal time for President Bush. He is looking for a rate cut and renewed economic growth as a reward for abandoning his ``no new taxes'' pledge and reaching out to Democrats for a deficit-reduction pact. The Federal Open Market Committee, which began its closed-door, two-day, mid-year policy review on Monday, likely will decide to cut rates in coming weeks as signs of economic softness emerge, analysts said. It may even decide to push rates down immediately by a quarter of a percentage point. Although many economists believe the administration has a good chance of getting what it wants, they say it will not be because of the political pressure Bush and other top officials have been trying to apply. ``The Fed never wants to be seen as caving in to politics, but my feeling is for separate reasons ... they're going to move,'' said economist David Jones of Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a New York government securities dealer. ``The economy is in danger of slipping into a recession by the end of the year and I think the Fed will recognize it at this meeting,'' he said. Minutes of the meeting will be made public in six weeks. Evidence of economic sluggishness is much more pronounced since the Open Market Committee's last meeting May 15, Jones said. Until recently, the softness seemed to be confined to just a few sectors of the economy, such as automobiles and construction. Now, consumers _ who represent two-thirds of the nation's economic activity _ are pulling back. Retail sales fell from March through May, the first triple decline since the 1982 recession. The economy has virtually stopped producing new jobs. Excluding the temporary hiring of census workers, the economy created only 105,000 jobs from March through May _ scarcely more than one-tenth the rate of a few years ago. Adding to the pressure for lower rates are reports of a credit crunch _ not from monetary policy, but from bank examiners. Business people are complaining that loans are harder to get because examiners, spooked by the S&L crisis, are forcing banks to be more careful. Although many economists predict a series of interest rate cuts through the summer, others argue that the persistence of inflation will prevent the Fed from acting precipitously. Excluding volatile food and energy prices, consumer inflation was 4.8 percent in the 12 months ended in May, compared with 4.6 percent in the preceding 12-month period. ``It's going to be a tough call. I think they may end up having a conditional directive ... which says if the unemployment rate rises, the Fed should ease,'' said economist Paul Boltz of T. Rowe Price in Baltimore. The Open Market Committee consists of the seven governors of the Federal Reserve Board and the presidents of the 12 regional Federal Reserve banks. Only five of the presidents vote. The committee controls the so-called federal funds rate, the interest charged among banks for overnight loans.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Concern High About Terror Attack
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: This story was submitted to the Israeli military censor who ordered a deletion.

Pointing to a map of Lebanon's coast, the captain of the Israeli patrol boat Dvora says the possibility of a Palestinian guerrilla attack has seldom been greater. ``In the eight years I have been on these boats, I don't remember a time when there was such certainty in the air that something was going to happen,'' said Capt. Chen. He spoke as the 69-foot craft sliced through the waters a few hundred yards off the south Lebanon coast, sweeping the coastline with radar and occasionally stabbing through the darkness with a powerful searchlight. The tension felt by Chen and his eight-member crew is reflected throughout Israel at a time when efforts to arrange Palestinian-Israeli negotiations are at a standstill. Palestinian guerrillas, including hard-liners who oppose PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat's diplomatic initiative, have mounted two recent seaborne raids, using speedboats for the first time and finding a chink in Israel's armor. On the Jewish holiday of Shavuot on May 30, boats with heavily armed Palestinians from Abul Abbas' Palestine Liberation Front were launched from a mother ship that had set sail from Libya. One outran Israeli defenders and reached the shore near a crowded beach resort before four Arabs were killed and seven captured. The attack prompted the United States to suspend its political dialogue with the PLO. On June 23, Chen's Dvora _ Bee in Hebrew _ ran down a speedboat heading toward the Israeli border settlement of Rosh Haniqra and killed two guerrillas armed with rocket-propelled grenades and automatic rifles. Responsibility was claimed by a fundamentalist faction of Lebanese Sunni Moslems, traditional allies of the PLO. Ariel Merari, a terror expert at Tel Aviv University, says a successful raid could set off a chain reaction that could end in a new Middle East war. He notes that terror raids were a contributing factor to the 1956, 1967 and 1982 wars between Israel and its Arab neighbors. ``A single dramatic terror attack or series of smaller ones change the atmosphere and trigger a war,'' he said. For example, he said, if Abul Abbas' heavily armed guerrillas had slain Israelis on beaches and in hotels as reportedly planned ``the public outcry in Israel would have made it necessary for the government to carry out a spectacular retaliatory strike ... I presume against Libya.'' That in turn could have prompted Iraq's Saddam Hussein to make good on pledges to help Arab states attacked by Israel. At night along the rocky coast of south Lebanon, the defense against guerrilla raids seems fragile indeed. The Israeli craft, based on a U.S. patrol boat designed for Vietnam's Mekong River, seems to have little more firepower and speed than most of its guerrilla adversaries. Its weaponry consists mainly of World War II-era 20mm cannons and light machine guns plus some rocket-fired munitions. Its top speed is about 40 knots. ``It's like soccer. We can't let them get past us and head for the goal,'' explained Chen, who spent much of a recent night hunched over, trying to sort out suspect ships from birds, waves and friendlies on a plate-sized radar screen swarming with a Rorschach of dots. Chen, whose full name could not be used in keeping with military regulations, was surrounded by a bank of squawking radios linking him to other Israeli patrol craft as well as radar and other shore installations. Overriding everything, however, is the driving beat of ``Won't Back Down,'' a Tom Petty song being played by Israel's armed forces radio. The crew breaks the boredom by microwaving a series of snacks including pizza and a soybean chicken substitute made in a factory on Chen's kibbutz in northern Israel. About 3:30 a.m., a bell sounds for battle stations and the crew scrambles from the air-conditioned bunk-rooms to the slippery decks of the lurching and rolling Dvora. Moments later they stand down. ``It was just a flock of birds,'' said Eldad, a crew member who was steering the craft on the exposed fly bridge within rifle range of the coast. The jumpiness is both an outgrowth of the proximity to Israel's border and the variety of threats the guerrillas pose. Chen said guerrillas have tried to sneak past Israeli defenses by sending lone frogmen underwater or rubber dinghies that hug the shore line and are difficult to see with nightvision scopes and radar. They have also planted mines or tried suicide attacks. ``The political situation is such that the Palestinians are returning to the use of arms. They are trying from the shore, from the sea and from the air,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Allowing Rest Improves Pilot Performance, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: If pilots on long-haul flights are allowed to take a brief snooze in the cockpit, they're more alert for the landing, a federal study concludes. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration study of 10 Boeing 747 crews produced the first scientific evidence that short rest periods act as a ``safety valve'' to reduce fatigue and improve alertness during the most critical stage of a long flight, investigators said Monday. The Federal Aviation Administration, which cosponsored the study, is reviewing the results, officials said. Currently, only military transport crews are allowed regular rest periods during flights. Some airlines in other countries also have adopted the practice, investigators said. The volunteer crews on Northwest and United flights across the Pacific were divided into a rest group and a non-rest group, with two NASA investigators monitoring each crew on the flight deck. ``The researchers found that given the opportunity to rest in their seats, the pilots generally were able to fall asleep easily and sleep well,'' the report said. ``Later, these crew members demonstrated significantly higher levels of vigilance than their no-rest counterparts.'' The report said the differences were especially dramatic near the end of the cruise phase of the flights, just before the pilot starts the descent for landing. Pilots who took the preplanned rests on four successive flights also were less affected by having to make consecutive flights and flying at night, the report said. Crew members who were allowed to rest each were given 40-minute rest periods on a rotation basis, so two pilots were always controlling the plane. Crew reaction was measured both by observations recorded in a log book by the NASA investigators and by portable monitoring equipment hooked to the pilot's wrist. Previous research has shown that repeated time zone crossings often produce poor sleeping patterns, particularly on eastbound flights when days are shortened. NASA and FAA studies also have found that pilots themselves often cannot accurately predict their own sleepiness.

DOC.HEAD: Centennial Wagon Train Ends its Journey
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of well-wishers whooped and hollered as a wagon train that covered 260 dusty miles over 30 days rolled into town to celebrate the state's centennial. Spectators jammed streets and rooftops in this frontier town founded by showman Buffalo Bill Cody to watch the 4-mile-long procession of some 200 wagons and 1,600 riders on horseback Monday. Kayne Pyatt, the trail boss who oversaw the odyssey, compared the journey to an ``Alice in Wonderland'' experience. ``It's sort of like I've lived a great childhood adventure, a fantasy,'' she said, having braved wind, dust and thunderstorms, righted wrecked wagons and even broken a few ribs. ``If I died tomorrow, I'd be satisfied.'' Organized as a tribute to Wyoming's birthday on July 10, the wagon train left Fort Caspar June 2. It attracted Western aficionados from throughout the country who joined at various parts of the Bridger Trail, which was one of the splinters of the Oregon Trail leading west from Missouri. Sen. Alan Simpson rode the last few miles. ``There'll be as many people saying they rode the Wyoming Centennial Wagon Train as said they saw Babe Ruth's last game at Yankee Stadium _ about 7 million,'' said the Republican, who grew up in Cody. The riders started the day Monday about 16 miles east of Cody. They traveled alongside a highway, passing sugar beet and barley fields, crossing the raging Shoshone River and encountering a torrential downpour about a mile out. The sun broke through just as they reached the edge of town, distant thunder and lightning adding to the drama. Horses reared and bucked, riders waved and hollered and a few wagon passengers played their fiddles to the crowd. ``Cody loves you!'' some spectators yelled. ``Happy birthday, Wyoming!'' On Monday's final leg, Simpson and his wife, Ann, were joined on horseback by Gov. Mike Sullivan and his wife, Jane. Montana Gov. Stan Stephens rode in a red surrey. ``I wouldn't have bet there were this many horses in this whole United States,'' said lifelong Cody resident Frank McJunkin, 70, as he watched the covered wagons and riders ramble by.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Insurance Tied to Loans in Some Cases
DOC.TEXT: At least one of every six farmers who take out federal crop insurance does so in order to get a loan to stay in business, according to a recent survey by the Agriculture Department. The survey also showed that crop insurance was more likely to be a requirement if loans were sought from the Farm Credit System, FCS, or the Farmers Home Administration, FmHA. Merritt Hughes of the department's Economic Research Service said the findings were based on the annual Farm Cost and Returns Survey for the 1988-89 crop year and a recent follow-up survey of 3,000 farms that focused on insurance. Writing in the July issue of Agriculture Outlook magazine, Hughes said roughly half of the farms represented by the survey had some form of debt and that 23 percent of the indebted farms carried federal crop insurance in 1988-89. ``Commercial banks and the FCS have stated that they never require crop insurance as a prerequisite for lending,'' the report said. ``FmHA has required federal crop insurance participation for some loan contracts in some years.'' The latest survey questioned borrowers, rather than the lenders. About 17 percent of all farm operators represented by the survey who bought insurance did so because it was required by lenders. ``Considering just the three major lenders (FCS, FmHA and commercial banks), almost 31 percent of their borrowers represented by the survey who bought federal crop insurance said they did so because of a requirement by their lender,'' the report said. The three institutions accounted for about 80 percent of the nation's farm loan volume in 1988. Of the total number of borrowers who said they were required to buy insurance, almost half were required to do so by banks. Roughly one-third said they were required by FmHA, and one out of seven by the FCS.

Some consumer groups and others want the Agriculture Department to disclose more test information about a proposed new beef inspection plan before a scientific panel completes its review. The Government Accountability Project, a leader in the coalition's demands, said Monday it planned to file a lawsuit in U.S. District Court here asking that the USDA data be released under the Freedom of Information Act. At the heart of the controversy is the department's long-pending plan for a ``streamlined inspection system'' for beef that has been undergoing pilot tests in preparation for final review by the National Academy of Sciences. The NAS was contracted by USDA for $170,000 to review the proposal. The plan, called SIS-Beef, would require participating meat plants to take greater responsibility for some of the chores traditionally done by federal inspectors. Agency officials contend that the inspectors would then concentrate more on checking for disease and other defects that can affect meat in the consumer pipeline. Each participating plant would have to submit a quality control plan in advance for USDA approval. Critics claim that under the plan fewer inspectors would monitor plants and that beef would be turned out under speeded-up, slipshod, dirty conditions as a result of companies taking over some of the duties previously performed by federal inspectors. Tom Devine of the Government Accountability Project said the NAS review should be delayed until the department releases more information. GAP is a non-profit public interest group that provides legal support for government whistle blowers. ``It's our contention that serious public health decisions shouldn't be made on the basis of secret reports,'' Devine said in a telephone interview. ``The reason these things aren't being released is they couldn't withstand scrutiny.'' But the USDA's Food Safety and Inspection Service, which oversees the program, said results at the pilot plants show the SIS system ``compares favorably with the traditional system'' of federal inspection. Spokesman Jim Greene said the agency denied the request by Devine and others for more information on the ground that ``some of it is proprietary'' and not allowed to be made public. ``Some of it has a direct bearing on the ongoing agency contract with NAS, and release of that information to a third party would interfere with the scientific process and possibly compromise the results of that contract (with NAS), he said.

The Agriculture Department is sending a team of scientists to the Soviet Union this fall to help set up a computer bank for Russian plants. Information about seeds and other plant reproductive material _ germplasm _ will be stored in a Soviet data base modeled after a Germplasm Resources Information Network, called GRIN, developed by the department's Agricultural Research Service. James H. Elgin Jr., the agency's national program leader for forage and pasture crops, said Monday that GRIN stores more than 1.5 million entries on about 8,100 different plant species worldwide. He will lead the USDA team to Leningrad in September. Elgin said the goal is to have the Soviet data base compatible with the GRIN system, thus allowing both countries to have access to each other's information.

DOC.HEAD: Weak Opening for `Days of Thunder' Highlights Summer Movie Doldrums
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The summer movie season is more than a month old and still there is no sign of a runaway hit. The latest lackluster opening was delivered over the weekend by the Tom Cruise race car film ``Days of Thunder.'' The movie, which received mostly mixed and a few positive reviews, finished atop the box-office charts, but earned only $15.5 million in its first three days, according to figures released Monday by Entertainment Data Inc. Although it was one of the season's most heavily promoted titles, it made about as much money in its debut as did this summer's lightly regarded ``RoboCop 2'' and ``Bird on a Wire.'' Falling out of first place after two weeks was ``Dick Tracy.'' The Warren Beatty project collected $10.1 million and has now made $68.4 million. So far, no summer title has emerged as a smash to rival last season's ``Batman,'' ``Honey, I Shrunk the Kids,'' ``Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade'' or ``Back to the Future Part II.'' A number of this summer's films _ including ``Gremlins 2'' and the ``RoboCop'' sequel _ look like bombs. The true test for ``Days of Thunder'' comes over the next few weeks, when the film's ``legs,'' or longevity, will be tested by ``Die Hard 2,'' ``The Adventures of Ford Fairlane,'' ``Ghost,'' ``Presumed Innocent'' and ``Arachnophobia.'' In third place, plunging 55 percent, was ``RoboCop 2'' with ticket sales of $6.4 million. Fourth was Arnold Schwarzenegger's ``Total Recall,'' with $6 million. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Monday as tallied by Entertainment Data, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Days of Thunder,'' Paramount, $15.5 million, 2,307 screens, $6,714 per screen, $21.5 million, one week. 2. ``Dick Tracy,'' Disney, $10.1 million, 2,332 screens, $4,331 per screen, $68.4 million, three weeks. 3. ``RoboCop 2,'' Orion, $6.4 million, 1,772 screens, $3,597 per screen, $25.8 million, two weeks. 4. ``Total Recall,'' Tri-Star, $6 million, 1,961 screens, $3,060 per screen, $91.5 million, five weeks. 5. ``Another 48 HRS.,'' Paramount, $5.4 million, 2,063 screens, $2,621 per screen, $59.2 million, four weeks. 6. ``Ghost Dad,'' Universal, $4.8 million, 1,213 screens, $3,960 per screen, $4.8 million, one week. 7. ``Gremlins 2,'' Warner Bros., $4.6 million, 2,137 screens, $2,146 per screen, $29.4 million, three weeks. 8. ``Betsy's Wedding,'' Disney, $3.2 million, 1,058 screens, $3,069 per screen, $10.1 million, two weeks. 9. ``Pretty Woman,'' Disney, $3.1 million, 1,305 screens, $2,381 per screen, $149.1 million, 15 weeks. 10. ``Back to the Future Part III,'' Universal, $2.9 million, 1,546 screens, $1,890 per screen, $68.9 million, six weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Man Electrocuted By Own Prespiration
DOC.TEXT: A man apparently was electrocuted when his sweat dripped into the drill he was using to build a swing set in his back yard, the coroner said. Richard Muller, 54, was pronounced dead Sunday at St. Charles Hospital, said David Vial, St. Charles Parish coroner. Muller had been using an electric drill in 90-degree heat, Vial said Monday. ``Apparently the man was sweating profusely,'' Vial said. ``He probably was pushing against the drill with his chest. And his perspiration went into the drill itself and made a contact.''

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Football Players Get Whipped 61-0
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Soviets losing 61-0. PICKS UP 5th graf pvs, `For the ...'; A version also moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: A few hours before the Moscow Bears played the first football game involving a Soviet team on American soil, coach John Ralston was still explaining to his players how to suit up in full pads. ``Don't forget, you need your thigh pads, your knee pads and your elbow pads. You don't want to land on that AstroTurf without your elbow pads,'' Ralston told the 39 players on the Soviet national champion team in a meeting before their exhibition game Monday with the minor-league Tacoma Express. Ralston, speaking through an interpreter, didn't go over game strategy or try to give them a fiery pep talk. The former Denver Broncos head coach said he mainly wanted to ensure his players finished the game intact _ especially his starting tight end, since both backups had been held back in the Soviet Union by the KGB the night before departure. The final score justified Ralston's limited expectations. The Tacoma Express rolled over the Bears 61-0. For the past eight weeks, Ralston has been attempting to mold a group of Soviet rugby players, shot-putters, javelin throwers and decathletes into a professional football team. The starting quarterback first touched a football seven months ago _ he's the veteran. Ralston's biggest player tips the scales at 250 pounds. ``We have one linebacker, tough little guy, but I don't think he weighs 175 pounds,'' Ralston said. The team is playing four American exhibition games arranged by the International Sports Connection, a sports promotion company based in Gadsen, Ala. Besides Tacoma, the team is scheduled to play in Fresno, Calif.; Oklahoma City and Macon, Ga., with a possible match in Charlotte, N.C. American football is catching on fast in the Soviet Union, with 24 teams and more athletes from other sports interested in playing, said International Sports Connection Vice President Kent Dunston. He said the tour was designed to expose the Soviet players to a higher level of competition than they would see in their home country or Europe. The players don't harbor any longshot dreams about rolling over American teams. Starting quarterback Yuri Boldin, who hurled the javelin for years before he touched a pigskin, said the Bears hoped only to show they understand the game. ``The main thing is to show what we have been taught by Coach Ralston, just to show that we will be able to play,'' he said through an interpreter. Special teams player Vladimir Skordcov, whose broad shoulders, bulging arms and severe crew cut might land him movie roles as a Russian army commando when his playing days end, said the Soviets would be easily overmatched by the Americans' size. But he wasn't afraid to find out how hard the Americans could hit. ``So far we have seen them eating, but do not know how they can play,'' he said. Team President Mikhail Zakharyan predicted it would take five or six years for Soviet teams to be competitive with the American minor leagues. And the National Football League? ``Maybe our children will be able to play NFL teams,'' he said through an interpreter. Zakharyan thought the Bears would improve enough by next season to beat some of the hundreds of teams in 14 European nations. The Moscow team lost a recent game to a French team by a score of 67-0, Ralston said. They lost by more than 80 points to a West Berlin team. Ralston, who coached some of the world's best football players at Denver from 1972 to 1976, said the Soviet receivers still don't catch the ball when it's thrown to them, and often the quarterback can't get the ball to them. But they don't lack for enthusiasm, he said. ``And they do everything through an interpreter.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Katharine Hepburn is auctioning off one of her paintings to benefit a wildlife organization. It is the only painting she has ever offered for public sale or view, said the Oscar-winning actress, who has been painting since the 1930s. The 16-by-20-inch work is an impressionistic look at the Beverly Hills valley, somewhat hidden by tall trees and framed by a white rail fence. ``I do hope it will bring a price, although I wouldn't give you a nickel for it,'' joked the lifelong summer resident of this shoreline community. Hepburn painted the work while staying at actor John Barrymore's California home. She guessed she completed it in the 1960s. The painting will be among works of art to be auctioned this fall to benefit the North American Wildlife Association Inc., which is seeking to buy the house that serves as its headquarters.

Willie Nelson's not-quite-annual Fourth of July ``picnic'' is on again this year. But organizers are promising a somewhat tamer event than past concerts. ``We're all older, the performers are older. That's the evolution of the picnic, placing it in 1990. But I hope it's not too restrained,'' said organizer Tim O'Connor. ``The mellowness is there,'' said singer Steve Fromholz. ``Neither Willie nor I party as hard as we did 10 years ago, but I believe the music has gotten better for all of us.'' O'Connor predicted a crowd of 25,000 to 35,000 for this year's picnic, which will be held in Austin's Zilker Park. Nelson lives near Austin. The first Willie Nelson picnic was on July 4, 1973. Since then, the concerts have been marked by memorable music. But they have also drawn complaints about drinking and drugs, traffic jams and nudity. The last picnic was held in 1987 near Dallas. Only about 8,400 people showed up for a concert planned for 80,000.

Composer Andrew Lloyd Webber is ending his six-year marriage to singer Sarah Brightman. Lloyd Webber, the 42-year-old composer of such hits as ``Phantom of the Opera'' and ``Cats,'' issued a statement Monday saying he had become ``close friends'' with another woman, Madeleine Gurdon. ``It is clear to me that, with the greatest sadness, I have to face the fact that my marriage to Sarah Brightman is at an end,'' he said. It did not say whether they would divorce. Lloyd Webber met Miss Brightman nine years ago and cast her in ``Cats.'' They had no children. LLoyd Webber has two children by a previous marriage. ``I am deeply saddened that our marriage should end like this,'' said Miss Brightman, 30. ``It is not something I either wish for or have sought.'' Miss Gurdon, a 27-year-old businesswoman, would not comment on the announcement.

Noel Blanc, who has taken over doing the voices of Porky Pig, Elmer Fudd and Bugs Bunny since his father's death a year ago, says he learned to do them as a toddler. ``At 2 and 3 years old, I used to sit on my father's knee and make him read me the Sunday features and any comic books I could find,'' Mel Blanc's son said in the July 7 issue of TV Guide. ``Not only would we have to do the voices of Bugs and Tweety and Sylvester, but I'd have him make up voices for Prince Valiant, Batman, the Katzenjammer Kids _ characters he didn't even know how to do. And I would mimic him,'' he said. Blanc said he did not have professional training until after his father's near-fatal car accident in 1961.

DOC.HEAD: Witnesses, Diplomats: 1,400 Killed In Stampede During Religious Pilgrimage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATEs with King Fahd citing large casualties, though without giving a death count. CORRECTS style thruout on hajj, making it lower-case. No pickup. ^With LaserGraphic, LaserPhotos WCX3,NY64
DOC.TEXT: About 1,400 Moslem pilgrims suffocated or were trampled to death Monday in a stampede in a pedestrian tunnel leading to the holy city of Mecca, witnesses and diplomats said. Almost a day after the disaster, which occurred during the annual hajj pilgrimage, Saudi officials had still not given a death count. King Fahd was quoted by the official Saudi news agency SPA as saying that the accident occurred because a large number of pilgrims thronged the tunnel beyond capacity. ``If the hajis had followed the instructions, the accident would have been averted,'' he was quoted as saying. ``One reason why the number (of casualties) was so big is the fact that it is the first big accident of its kind. Caution cannot preclude fate.'' Witnesses and diplomats said the stampede began Monday morning when some pilgrims stopped in the middle of the air-conditioned tunnel and there was a rush outside with people pushing each other to escape the 112-degree heat. They also said the ventilation appeared to have stopped. One Asian diplomat who refused to be identified put the death toll at 1,400 and said many of the victims were Indonesian and Malaysian pilgrims. Four Middle Eastern diplomats as well as witnesses gave the same death toll. The stampede shattered what had been a peaceful observance of the hajj, or pilgrimage, and was the worst pilgrimage tragedy in recent years. In previous years, terrorist attacks and riots marred the celebration. It came at the end of the Moslem holiday Eid Al-Adha, or the Feast of Sacrifice, for which 2 million Moslems, including 800,000 foreigners, came to the holy city of Mecca. Ambulances and security forces rushed to the exits of the 500-yard-long tunnel that joins Mecca and the tent city of Mina, according to state-run Riyadh radio, which quoted an Interior Ministry spokeman in Mina. Witnesses said people stampeded, crushing hundreds of people and suffocating hundreds others. People were smothered ``as thousands of the pilgrims thronged through the tunnel of Mo'essem, causing severe congestion within the tunnel as the pressure was beyond its capacity,'' the radio said. ``This led to some deaths and some cases of fainting.'' A witness, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the flow of people through the tunnel suddenly stopped. The air-conditioned tunnel can hold up to 1,000 pedestrians, but the crowd inside quickly swelled to 5,000, he said. ``With the lack of oxygen, a good number collapsed unconscious, and some died. There was also a stampede,'' the witness said. ``There always should be movement within the tunnel, but the entire crowd suddenly stopped, and no one yet knows why,'' he said. The witness said he helped carry victims to the ambulances waiting by the tunnel's exits, but it was impossible to determine how many people were dead or simply unconscious. The tunnel is part of massive $15 billion development plan for the holy sites to move pilgrims in a more orderly fashion for the hajj, the world's largest religious gathering. The plan includes other tunnels and overhead bridges. The tent city was set up in Mina to house visiting pilgrims. About 2 million Moslems were at Islam's holy sites in the Mecca area for the hajj. The celebration climaxed Sunday with prayers on Mount Arafat, about eight miles from Mecca. At the time of the tunnel disaster Monday morning, the pilgrims were taking part in post-hajj rituals or preparing to leave. Thousands of the pilgrims left Mecca later Monday. These rituals of Eid Al-Adha, or the Feast of Sacrifice, commemorate the Prophet Abraham's offering of his son in sacrifice to God. Moslems celebrate the feast by slaughtering sheep to emulate the sacrifice of Abraham, who is also revered by Christians and Jews. The Moslem faith requires that each worshiper attempt to attend the pilgrimage. Before Monday, only a small fire at Mina and a few cases of heat fatigue marred an otherwise calm pilgrimage season. Terrorism blamed on Iranian or Shiite Moslems has occurred in the past three years. The worst incident was in 1987, when Iranians clashed with security forces, leading to the death of more than 400 pilgrims. The year before, the Saudis confiscated large quantities of explosives from members of the Iranian contingent. The Saudis have since set a quota of 1,000 per million of population for each Islamic nation. Angered by the quotas, the Iranians have boycotted the hajj since 1988. Last year, some small bombs went off during the hajj, killing one pilgrim and injuring 16. The Saudis tried and convicted Kuwaiti Shiite Moslems and beheaded 16 of them.

DOC.HEAD: Unconvinced Jury Acquits Marcos and Khashoggi
LaserPhotos NY4, NY6, NY9
DOC.TEXT: Jurors unconvinced Imelda Marcos knew of her husband's alleged corrupt practices cleared her of charges she looted $222 million from the Philippines and hid the money by sinking it into art and real estate. Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi also was acquitted of helping Mrs. Marcos and her husband conceal ownership of four New York buildings. ``I am in great awe and respect for the jury system that symbolizes the soul of the American people,'' the widow of former Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos said after the verdict Monday on her 61st birthday. ``This is the best birthday present I ever had,'' she said. The verdict reduced Mrs. Marcos to tears and elated supporters. She went directly to St. Patrick's Cathedral, where she walked on her knees down the aisle to the altar, then bowed her head to the floor and prayed. Friends and supporters celebrated with her into the evening at an apartment where she stayed during the trial. She later emerged, reportedly headed for a party with Khashoggi as host. Asked about her plans, she said, ``Home.'' Philippines President Corazon Aquino expressed disappointment over the acquittal and said the former first lady still was barred from returning home for national security reasons. Philippine officials said they are ready to file charges against Mrs. Marcos _ if the president lets her return. The constitution bans criminal trials in absentia. Jurors, announcing their verdict on the fifth day of deliberations after a three-month trial, told reporters they were not convinced Mrs. Marcos knew of her husband's alleged wrongdoing or the source of his wealth. The prosecution had argued that even though its evidence was heavily circumstantial, it proved that Mrs. Marcos, as a cabinet minister and mayor of Manila, knew the millions of dollars they invested were accumulated illegally. ``Just because she was married to him doesn't make her guilty,'' said jury forewoman Catherine Balton. Juror Thomas O'Rourke said the case did not belong in the U.S. courts. ``We are not big brothers to the people overseas,'' he said, adding that the prosecution had relied on ``half-truths and not the right witnesses.'' ``For three years they have made this poor woman's life miserable,'' he said. ``It may have been a conspiracy, but not a conspiracy by Marcos.'' In a statement, the office of U.S. Attorney Otto Obermaier praised the work of the prosecutors and said: ``The jury has rendered its verdict. Our system of justice has spoken.'' The prosecutor's office said an estimate of how much the case cost the U.S. government was not available. The jury acquitted both defendants of all charges _ racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice against Mrs. Marcos, and mail fraud and obstruction against Khashoggi. Mrs. Marcos had faced up to 50 years in prison and $1 million in fines. Khashoggi could have drawn 10 years and a $500,000 fine. Mrs. Marcos had been accused of conspiring with her husband to buy art, jewelry and real estate with $222 million stolen from their country's treasury. Witnesses testified the money was funneled to the United States through bank accounts in Switzerland, Hong Kong, Manila and Los Angeles and was used to secretly buy the buildings for the Marcoses. Marcos was indicted with his wife in 1988, 2{ years after he was deposed in a popular uprising. The couple fled to exile in Hawaii, where Marcos died in September. Marcos attorney Gerry Spence, a flashy Wyoming native who wore a cowboy hat and boots to court, said in closing arguments that Mrs. Marcos was a ``world-class shopper'' who was guilty only of loving and supporting her husband. During the trial, U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan called the case unprecedented because it involved a former head of state who was a major U.S. ally, and he wondered whether the case belonged in a U.S. court. Testimony included accounts of Mrs. Marcos' shopping habits, such as spending sprees at Bloomingdale's and numerous New York jewelry stores. Khashoggi, 54, an arms dealer and jet-set financier once described as the world's richest man, said of the verdict, ``I feel very happy for myself and my family and for the United States.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,414.60, up 254.37 points, or 0.79 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Greek Orthodox Patriarch Arrives, First to Visit US
DOC.TEXT: Dimitrios I, the first Greek Orthodox patriarch to visit the United States, says civilization is threatened by a turn away from morality and spirituality. ``The world today, precisely because of technological achievements and its material well-being, has immense problems of a moral and spiritual nature,'' the leader of the Orthodox Church said. ``These threaten to shatter the very structure of our civilization and even the planet itself. This nation must lead a moral and spiritual rebirth for the good of mankind.'' The spiritual leader of 250 million Orthodox faithful, most of them residents of the Soviet Union and eastern Europe, came to the United States with an entourage of 14 on the ``Olympic Flame,'' a plane put at his disposal by the Greek national airline. One of the objects of his trip is to promote a meeting in Geneva, Switzerland, of all Orthodox leaders. A Turkish citizen, Dimitrios, 75, lives in Istanbul where tradition holds that Orthodox Christianity was founded by St. Andrew the Apostle nearly 2,000 years ago. He will spend most of this month in the United States, including 10 days in Washington. He will meet President Bush and leaders of Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Two-Thirds of Cities Report Budget Squeeze
DOC.TEXT: Two thirds of the nation's cities say they are having a tougher time paying their bills than a year ago, and 54 percent say the crunch is so severe they expect spending to exceed revenues in their current budget year, according to a survey. The National League of Cities survey of 576 communities said the budget pressures are greatest in the Northeast _ where the regional economy is slumping. Five of six cities and towns surveyed in that region reported that their financial problems were worse than a year ago. Leaders of the organization, whose membership is open to cities and towns with populations of at least 10,000, said a major factor in the growing municipal budget problems is the lack of help from Washington. Forty-one percent of the municipalities surveyed have raised local property taxes, and 76 percent increased fees and other charges, the League of Cities said.
DOC.HEAD: Government Strongly Warns Against Use of Aspirin By Pregnant Women
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration is requiring strengthened warnings against use of aspirin products by women in the last three months of pregnancy. The agency said the stronger warning, being published today in the Federal Register, is needed because aspirin can affect fetal circulation and uterine contraction. Manufacturers have one year to add the stronger warning to all oral and rectal over-the-counter products containing aspirin, the FDA said. The warning must read: ``It is especially important not to use aspirin during the last three months of pregnancy unless specifically directed to do so by a doctor because it may cause problems in the unborn child or complications during delivery.'' Aspirin products now carry a general warning that says: ``As with any drug, if you are pregnant or nursing a baby, seek the advice of a health professional before using this product.'' An advisory panel of medical experts had recommended the stronger warning. A similar warning is already required on nonprescription products containing the pain-reliever ibuprofen.
DOC.HEAD: New Medicare Coverage for Pap Smears Takes Effect
DOC.TEXT: Pap smears to screen for early detection of cervical cancer have been added to the list of Medicare-reimbursed medical expenses. The new coverage took effect Sunday, allowing Medicare to help pay the cost of Pap smear screenings once every three years or more often if the patient is at high risk for developing cervical cancer. Previously, Medicare would paid for Pap smears only if the patient were being treated for an existing gynecological cancer or disorder or showed signs of some abnormality. Congress added the expanded benefit in legislation passed last year.
DOC.HEAD: Council Recommends Truck Weight Policy To Save $4.3 Billion.
DOC.TEXT: A federal research group is calling for a more liberal policy on truck weights that it says could save $4.3 billion a year in transport costs and cost railroads $750 million in lost revenue. The National Research Council committee said all states should be given the option of exempting some trucks from a federal limit of 80,000 pounds on the nation's interstate highways. It also recommended changes in the rules for bridge use that would allow heavier concrete mixers, dump trucks and other trucks with shorter wheelbases. The weight exemptions would be on the condition that they include fees to cover pavement and bridge wear, said the committee, which is made up of transportation experts from universities, the industry and government. The research council is linked to the National Academy of Sciences and the National Academy of Engineering. The committee report recommends that heavy trucks still be restricted to designated routes, comply with all other federal weight restrictions and comply with strict safety standards. The exemptions would still be up to individual states, but the report said it was not fair to prevent about half the states from allowing exemptions while the others who had exemptions before the current law can keep theirs. If all states adopted the exemptions, annual transportation savings for truckers could total $1.9 billion because of the use of more productive vehicles, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: East German Joblesssness Up by Half
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's unemployment has jumped by 50 percent in the last month, East Germany's labor minister says. The minister, Regine Hildebrandt, said Monday that the latest figures show 150,000 East Germans are out of work, compared to 100,000 jobless at the beginning of June. In mid-April, 45,000 of East Germany's 8 million workers were unemployed. However, Ms. Hildebrandt said in an interview broadcast on West Berlin's RIAS radio that 50,000 jobs were open. She blamed slow Western investment for the increase in joblessness. Some economists have predicted up to 4 million East Germans will lose their jobs as inefficient state-owned companies are forced to lay off workers. One-third of all East German companies are not expected to survive.

DOC.HEAD: Motel Carbon Monoxide Caused by Birds' Nests Clogging Ducts
DOC.TEXT: Swallows' nests clogging a propane swimming pool heater's ventilation ducts apparently caused a buildup of carbon monoxide that sent 136 motel guests and rescue workers to the hospital, authorities say. All those treated after Sunday's poisoning were released later in the day. The Cazador Inn reopened Monday after tests showed no traces of the fumes, said Sharon Smith, Kandiyohi County environmental health inspector. Inspectors found that the buildup of the fumes, which can be fatal, resulted from poor ventilation at the two-story, 33-room motel. In the swimming pool area, investigators found some of the ventilation ducts plugged with swallows' nests, said Fire Chief Tony Rime. The obstructions caused fumes to spread down the halls and into guest rooms, he said. The motel was evacuated after guests began complaining of illness. Some guests were found passed out. Dozens were treated initially on the motel lawn. Up to 30 people had symptoms usually associated with carbon monoxide poisoning, which include grogginess, headaches and nausea. Almost everyone at the motel was taken to the hospital, even those with no symptoms. ``It was kind of like being drunk,'' said a guest, Chad Schuler of Granite Falls. Smith said she has inspected the pool area, including the propane heater, annually since 1987, when the county began routine inspections. She last inspected the pool area Nov. 15 and gave the heater a clean bill of health. Smith said she could not recall any problems with the system in previous inspections but said she usually does not inspect the ducts. Bob James, code specialist with the state fire marshal, said blockage is not uncommon for indoor pool heaters. He said heaters that are used year-around, as is the one at the motel, probably should be inspected twice a year.

DOC.HEAD: Key Quotes From Opening of Soviet Party Congress
With PM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some key quotes from Monday's session of the 28th Communist Party congress:
``Let us remember that not only empty store shelves forced perestroika, but empty souls as well.'' _ Alexander N. Yakovlev, Politburo member and close Gorbachev adviser.

``Big changes are under way in Eastern Europe. And when it is said, `It is the failure of socialism,' we ask in reply: `What kind of socialism?' The kind that was in fact a Stalinist version. Well, we are getting rid of that ourselves.'' _ Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
``It's difficult for such people to stay in the same party, but it will be reality for now,'' Alexander Buzgalin, a hard-liner who believes conservatives and reformers should band together.

DOC.HEAD: Master Puppeteer Jim Henson Mourned in Britain
DOC.TEXT: Big Bird was there, and Fozzie Bear, and Oscar the Grouch, as more than 1,400 colleagues, family and fans paid tribute to Muppet creator Jim Henson in a verdant St. Paul's Cathedral. England was a second home to Henson, who died in May at the age of 53. ``He loved England and the English; we claim him as ours,'' said Duncan Kenworthy, chief of Henson Productions in Britain. For the tribute, the cathedral was transformed to resemble a north London parkland Henson loved. The 17th-century building was festooned with greenery, its aisles full of Henson's creatures and portraits of their creator. Friends and colleagues of Henson had worked into the night adorning the cathedral with garlands, plants and birches. A May 21 memorial for Henson at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York included a Dixieland band and Muppets singing their way through the crowd. Henson died May 16 in New York of pneumonia. Henson's family asked well-wishers not to wear black, saying the event would be as much a celebration and thanksgiving for Henson's life as a traditional memorial service. ``He has left a heritage that will never be forgotten. Jim Henson will always be with us,'' said Lord Lew Grade. It was Grade who contracted Henson in 1976 to make 24 half-hour episodes of ``The Muppet Show'' after the Muppeteer failed to find American backing for the variety show. The show became one of the most widely seen television programs in the world, with an estimated 235 million viewers in 100 countries. Most of Henson's films were made in Britain as well. Henson owned a home in north London's leafy Hampstead district, across the street from the onetime Victorian post office housing the Creature Shop where his puppets are made. Muppet performer Richard Hunt led a quartet in a medley of Henson's favorite songs. Henson's wife Jane and four of his five children attended. ```When I was young, my ambition was to be one of the people who makes a difference in this world,''' daughter Cheryl, 29, recited from an essay written by her father. ```My hope still is to leave this world a little bit better than it was when I got here.''' ``We really feel he did leave the world a bit better,'' she told the congregation. ``So, thanks.''

DOC.HEAD: FAA Defends Air Show Regulations After Six Fatal Crashes
DOC.TEXT: Stunt fliers and air show enthusiasts doubt the deaths of six stunt pilots in the past month are related but say the industry should take another look at how it operates. ``If there is something that's a common denominator, we've got to find it,'' said Rick Nadeau, executive director of the International Council of Air Shows, based in Michigan. People in the industry said Monday that the crashes, which are under investigation, apparently are unrelated because they involved different aircraft, locations and flying conditions. A Vietnam veteran flying loops in a World War II training plane slammed into the Niagara River near Buffalo on Sunday. A crash in Ottawa the same day also involved a stunt plane dating to World War II. On Saturday, a man died when his biplane crashed during a stunt takeoff. Three more stunt pilots died at air shows in crashes in Oklahoma City, Abilene, Texas, and Zeeland, Mich. Stunt flier Tom Poberezny, president of the Experimental Aircraft Association, said the accidents seem unconnected. But he added, ``We wouldn't want to be so flippant as to say it's just luck.'' Poberezny said it is important that the crashes are thoroughly studied ``to make sure there's no underlying cause as to why they happened.'' A spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration said it is too early to draw conclusions, but there is ``no reason to suspect the regulations are at fault or anything else is at fault'' in the crashes. ``If there's a common thread in these accidents,'' said spokesman Dick Stafford, ``you can bet the FAA will do something about it.'' Stafford said FAA regulations deal with the pilot, the plane, the stunts and the proximity of spectators. No spectators were hurt in any of the crashes.

DOC.HEAD: City, Homeless Reach Agreement in Hotel Takeover
DOC.TEXT: Homeless people who seized an abandoned hotel two weeks ago agreed to leave today after Mayor Maynard Jackson promised to build thousands of single-room apartments for the homeless by 1994. Jackson and homeless leader Bill Jones announced their agreement Monday night after hours of negotiations, bringing cheers from about 50 of the street people who have been living in the ramshackle Imperial Hotel. The city had set a midnight deadline for an end to the occupation. The mayor promised the city will build 3,500 units of single-room occupancy housing over the next 3{ years. In return, the squatters said they would leave the Imperial today and move to a 200-bed shelter opened Monday. The city said the shelter would have more lenient rules about entering and leaving than most other city shelters. On Monday, Jackson's administration rushed two proposals before the City Council that would provide $638,000 to build or renovate nearly 300 units of SRO housing. The mayor offered no cost estimate for the overall plan or indication of where the 3,500 units of housing might be built. ``The point is we've got a problem here and Atlanta is in the forefront of trying to solve it,'' Jackson said. The agreement averted a confrontation between the homeless and police. It also avoided the possibility of a demonstration by the squatters as the Independence Day parade passes the Imperial on Wednesday. Eight demonstrators took over the hotel June 18, protesting the lack of apartments and the closing of several shelters for summer. They renamed the hotel Welcome House and began cleaning it up, welcoming other homeless people. The squatters had refused to move to shelters until they had a promise of more permanent housing. ``It's been a crisis for a long time, but their demonstration has made us sit up and take notice,'' said Shirley Franklin, the city's chief negotiator, who spent a night with the squatters. Jones said the takeover has done more in two weeks for the homeless than ``committees have done in seven years.'' Atlanta has 10,000 homeless people, according to the Task Force for the Homeless.

DOC.HEAD: Tom Cruise Proud of Race Car Movie
With PM-Box Office
DOC.TEXT: Even though the film trade considered the opening weekend receipts for ``Days of Thunder'' less than thundering, Tom Cruise says he's happy with the results. ``You can `buy' yourself an opening by putting your picture in 3,500 theaters and spending a lot of money. The important thing is to have `legs,''' the star of the racing movie said, using the industry term for staying power. ``Days of Thunder'' finished atop the box-office charts but grossed just $15.5 million, a weaker opening than ``Dick Tracy,'' ``Total Recall,'' ``Another 48 HRS.,'' ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles'' and ``Back to the Future Part III.'' The figures released Monday by Entertainment Data Inc. showed the $55 million movie could be headed for trouble. The lightly regarded ``RoboCop 2,'' by comparison, grossed $14.1 million in its first weekend. ``The exit polls for `Days of Thunder' have been fantastic,'' Cruise countered in a telephone interview Monday. ``I'm very happy with the reaction to the film when I've seen it in theaters. It plays well with an audience. They laugh in certain areas that I don't expect.'' He said the mixed-to-tepid reviews didn't bother him either. ``I don't read reviews, even the good ones,'' he declared. ``They don't affect me or the film. A lot of filmmakers whom I respect have called me to say how much they liked the movie. ``They were actually surprised,'' he said, laughing heartily. A stock car racer himself, Cruise formulated a story four years ago, and Robert Towne turned it into a script. ``I studied all the past race movies I could find,'' said the actor. ``I found different things in each of them but none of them took the spirit of the driver and developed it. That's what we tried to do. ``The important thing is to stretch the genre. Even my entrance is set up as a `wink,' like the arrival of the hero in a Western.'' Cruise said he has no new project and is looking at a lot of scripts. He added ruefully, ``Putting together a film today is like assembling a Super Bowl team.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I am in great awe and respect for the jury system that symbolizes the soul of the American people.'' _ Imelda Marcos, after she was cleared of charges she looted $222 million from the Philippines and hid the money by sinking it into art and real estate.

``Six months from now, a year from now, I expect you all to ooh and ahh over the picture that Hubble is going to produce and, of course, compliment the current management of NASA for their success in pulling it off.'' _ Lennard Fisk, chief scientist for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, announcing that fuzzy images from the Hubble Space Telescope may be improved to sharp, crisp pictures through the same computer process that cleaned up photos taken by the Voyager spacecraft.
``If I died tomorrow, I'd be satisfied.'' _ Trail boss Kayne Pyatt, as a wagon train that covered 260 dusty miles over 30 days rolled into Cody, Wyo., to celebrate the state's centennial.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Hajj Is World's Largest Religious Gathering
With PM-Mecca-Deaths, Bjt
