DOC.TEXT: Each year, hundreds of thousands of Moslems from around the world travel to the holy city of Mecca by land, sea or even on foot for the annual pilgrimage known as the hajj. It is the world's largest religious gathering. The pilgrimage to Islam's holiest shrines in Saudi Arabia brings together Arabian princes, merchants from Indonesia, peasants from Soviet Uzbekistan, and paupers from Bangladesh. The hajj must be made at least once in a lifetime by all Moslems who can afford it. A Moslem who performs the pilgrimage is called a hajji. During the hajj, pilgrims must abstain from sex and may not quarrel, cut their hair, or even kill a fly. Hajjis start the pilgrimage by praying at the Grand Mosque in Mecca. They then circle seven times around the Kaaba, a granite cube draped with gold-embroidered black brocade. Moslems honor the Kaaba as the house of Allah, where the Prophet Abraham offered his first prayers to God. Hajjis are then required to run back and forth seven times between two rocks about half-a-mile apart, called al-Safa and al-Marwa. This ceremony is meant to relive the agony of Hagar, Abraham's second wife, when she was looking for water for her son Ishmael, considered the ancestor of the Arabs. The main center of the pilgrimage then moves to Mina, a meeting place for the hajjis to gather before they climb Mount Arafat for the climax of the observances. Moslems believe Arafat is where Abraham showed his devotion to God by offering to sacrifice his son. At Mount Arafat, each pilgrim throws seven stones at each of the three ``devil pillars,'' a spot where Moslems believe the devil tried to tempt Abraham to disobey Allah and refuse to sacrifice his son. At twilight, pilgrims offer the Eid Al-Adha, or Feast of Sacrifice, prayers before slaughtering hundreds of thousands of sheep, cows and camels. Over the years, the hajj has been beset by tragedy. In 1979, religious extremists seized the Grand Mosque in Mecca and held it for two weeks before Saudi forces stormed it. More than 250 people were killed and Saudi authorities later beheaded 63 more. In 1987, clashes with Saudi security forces in Mecca killed 402 people during the hajj, 275 of them Iranians. It was the most serious of a series of incidents during pilgrimages since Iran's 1979 Islamic revolution. After that carnage, Saudi Arabia restricted the number of pilgrims and later broke off diplomatic ties with Iran. The incidents were fired by Iranian efforts to politicize the hajj and encourage other Moslem nations to seize shrines at Mecca and Medina from the control of the kingdom's Saud royal family. Iran denied in September 1989 that it was involved in two bomb blasts in Mecca two months earlier, and Tehran-supported terrorists vowed to avenge Saudi Arabia's execution of 16 Shiite Moslems convicted of setting the explosions. The bombs exploded as thousands of people took part in the hajj, killing one person and injuring 16. The attacks were believed connected to the centuries-old feud between Sunni and Shiite Moslems. The Saudi royal family is Sunni, while Shiites are an overwhelming majority among Iran's nearly 50 million people. Last year, an estimated 1.8 million Moslems from more than 80 nations went on the annual pilgrimage. An estimated 2 million people attended this year.

DOC.HEAD: American Miner Returns Home After Kidnapping
LaserPhoto PE1
DOC.TEXT: Scott Heimdal got a hero's welcome in his hometown from friends and strangers who helped raise the $60,000 ransom his South American kidnappers demanded for the release of the American gold miner. ``It's a great feeling'' to be home, said Heimdal, 27, upon arriving in this western Illinois city. Except for a celebration Saturday, Heimdal said his only plans for this week were to ``take it easy.'' Wearing an ``I Love Peoria'' T-shirt, Heimdal stepped off a plane late Monday with his mother, Marge, who had flown to Ecuador June 18 to negotiate his release after the Colombian guerrillas refused to free him even though they had been given the money. Heimdal had been working as a miner in Ecuador when he was kidnapped April 28 near the Colombian border. His family raised $60,000 in four days of public appeals. Bars and banks took up collections, children sold lemonade and nursing homes held bake sales. Heimdal said he intends to return to Ecuador. ``It's really a wonderful country,'' he said. Earlier Monday during a stopover in Miami, he identified his captors as members of the communist People's Liberation Army. He said they treated him with ``great respect'' and wished him ``good luck'' on his release. TV camera lights, reporters' questions and a jubilant crowd of about 100 well-wishers deluged the Heimdals as they entered Peoria airport. ``This has been the longest day of our lives,'' said Linda Heimdal, one of his sisters. Heimdal received a bouquet of roses from Trudy Maloof, wife of the town's mayor, a family friend. Outside, a blue van was decorated with balloons and a sign saying, ``Welcome home Scott and Marge.'' Those welcoming Heimdal included Ruby Culess, who said she didn't know the family but had prayed for his release. She carried a sign that read, ``God hears our prayers.'' ``We don't know the family, but it's wonderful that's he's coming home,'' said Jo Frederick. In Miami, Heimdal recounted his kidnapping, which took place while he was returning to the Ecuadoran capital of Quito. ``We were going down river in a 30-foot Indian dugout canoe when three men attacked us. They killed the driver, wounded the other guy and took me hostage. They were looking to kidnap a North American,'' he said. Heimdal said that he initially feared for his life but that his captors treated him well. He said he was often moved about and was guarded by up to 25 guerrillas. The group kidnapped him to finance its war with the government of Colombia. Originally his captors wanted far more money for his release, but Heimdal said he convinced them his parents could not afford it. ``In Latin America there is a misconception that being from North America means being rich,'' he said. Heimdal said his father, Roy, stayed in Quito to withdraw the remainder of the family's money from a bank there and to bring his son's fiancee, Sandra Durango, to the United States. Mrs. Heimdal said she did not know exactly how much was raised for her son's release but that any money that might be left would go to charity. ``Everybody's been so supportive _ even strangers, people who don't know the family,'' Heimdal said. ``I owe a debt I probably will never be able to repay.''

DOC.HEAD: Heat, Thunderstorms Batter Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Most of the nation enjoyed fair weather early today, while thunderstorms developed over North Dakota. Sunshine was predicted over most of the nation today, with a mix of showers and thunderstorms expected in Minnesota and Wisconsin. Thunderstorms also were forecast for Arizona and New Mexico. Temperatures were in the 70s and low 80s early today throughout much of the Plains, where hours earlier scorching heat set records for the date Monday in 18 cities. Valentine, Neb., the hottest spot in nation Monday, had an all-time high of 114. Readings soared above 100 in Texas, Oklahoma, Kansas, Colorado, Nebraska, South Dakota, Wyoming and Montana. In Colorado, the high of 101 degrees Monday at Grand Junction marked a record 10 straight days of 100-degree heat. Thunderstorms helped break up the heat wave in the Plains, but brought with them hail and high winds. In Montana, winds gusted to 60 mph and golf ball-size hail fell at Great Falls. More than 2{ inches of rain fell in less than two hours at Westby. Golf ball-size hail also fell west of Kenaston, N.D. Thunderstorms developing along and ahead of a cold front extended from Mississippi to Florida Monday evening. Winds gusted to 70 mph at Birmingham, Ala., and dime-size hail and 2\ inches of rail fell in Jacksonville, Fla. Showers and thunderstorms also developed over New Mexico and Arizona and the Pacific Northwest. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation. Thunderstorms kept temperatures in the 70s and 80s in some parts of the Southeast on Monday. Miami equaled its record low for the date of 71 degrees in the midst of an afternoon thunderstorm. High temperatures were only in the 60s along the central Pacific Coast but climbed well above 100 in the desert Southwest. DOC.HEAD: Much Work Remains Before Germany Becomes One Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with East German government calling for joint elections Dec. 2, state elections Oct. 14. Picks up 5th pvs, `Officials in ...''
DOC.TEXT: The fall and winter brought East Germany's revolution. Summer saw the economic merger of the two Germanys. Now, people are predicting a ``hot autumn'' as the two states stride toward political unity. So far, the moves toward unification have been charged with symbolism _ the tearing down of the Berlin Wall, the establishment of a single currency, the elimination of internal border controls. The next stage looks to be more prosaic: long and difficult negotiations toward the political treaty that will iron out constitutional and legal obstacles to unification. Government negotiators hope to be able to present a unity treaty to their respective parliaments in September. On Monday night, the East German government called for joint elections in both countries on Dec. 2, one of two December dates proposed by the Bonn government. Guenther Krause, a leader of East Germany's dominant Christian Democratic Union, said the East German proposal also calls for state elections in East Germany on Oct. 14. Officials in Bonn have said they want to change only those parts of the West German Constitution absolutely necessary for unification. But one of the biggest legal differences between the two Germanys _ their opposing abortion laws _ will probably be left unresolved before unification. In West Germany, a woman must prove medical or financial necessity to have an abortion. In East Germany, abortions on demand are legal in the first trimester. A West German government spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the differing laws would probably continue for a transitional period, meaning West German women could travel East for abortions. Another point of contention is what city _ Berlin or Bonn _ will be the capital of a united Germany. East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere has said he wants Berlin stipulated as the capital in the final unification treaty, but politicians in the West have balked, and Kohl's government has said the decision must come from a united German parliament. How to conduct all-German elections for a united parliament has also become a point of debate. West German law requires political parties to have a minimum 5 percent election showing for representation in parliament. There is no such minimum in East Germany, and politicians there have said it would be unfair to require East German parties to attain 5 percent of the vote in a united Germany. As a compromise, West German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble has suggested that the balloting be conducted separately in East and West Germany. Domestic financial issues also need resolving. East German Finance Minister Walter Romberg has demanded negotiations to include East Germany in a West German financial program that redistributes funds from rich areas to poorer ones. But according to a West German draft of the unity treaty, the five new states in what is now East Germany would not be eligible for such revenue-sharing until after 1994. The $70 billion German Unity Fund established to help with East German reconstruction would be the sole source of financing until then, the draft says. Unification is also contingent on international approval, but that is expected to come in November at a meeting of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Last week, West Germany addressed some of Moscow's concerns about German unification by announcing that $780 million would go to help finance the cost of the 380,000 Soviet troops in East Germany for the second half of 1990. The status of Soviet troops in East Germany, the military posture of a united Germany and the size of a combined German army have been the Kremlin's main worries about a reunited Germany. The Soviets have opposed a united Germany's membership in NATO. But Chancellor Helmut Kohl plans to visit Moscow July 15-16 for talks that are expected to focus on winning Soviet approval for German NATO membership by providing Western aid to the moribund Soviet economy. West Germany has already backed a $3 billion bank credit to the Soviet Union and has been pressing the European Economic Community to support an even larger aid package.

DOC.HEAD: Five Killed in Mount Rainier Plane Crash
DOC.TEXT: A small plane crashed on a glacier high up on Mount Rainier, killing the pilot and four passengers en route to a rodeo in Canada. The single-engine Cessna 210 disappeared from radar screens Monday about two miles from the mountain, and an emergency locator signal was picked up a short time later. The cause of the crash was not immediately known. Clouds and drizzle were reported on the lower slopes of the mountain. Rescue workers planned to bring the bodies down today from Kautz Glacier at the 12,500-foot level of the 14,410-foot peak, authorities said. The plane was en route from Portland, Ore., to Penticton, British Colombia. The passengers were bound for a rodeo in Ponoka, Alberta, said the pilot's son, Brian Card.

DOC.HEAD: Chernobyl Pilot Dies; Was Hailed as a Hero
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with comment from hospital spokeswoman, wife at bedside, minor editing. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Anatoly Grishchenko, a Soviet helicopter pilot who contracted leukemia after what was hailed as a heroic effort to try to douse the fire at the Chernobyl nuclear plant, has died at age 53. Grishchenko had been in critical condition with a lung infection for more than two weeks at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, where he had received a bone-marrow transplant April 27 in an attempt to conquer his leukemia. He died late Monday of cardiopulmonary failure, said spokeswoman Susan Edmonds. Grishchenko in 1986 repeatedly flew his heavy-lift copter through the intensely radioactive gases spewing from the Chernobyl plant, dumping sand and cement in an overmatched effort to cap the crippled reactor. He and a handful of others in the operation were designated heroes of the Soviet Union, that country's highest honor. Despite lead shielding on the aircraft and other protective gear, Grishchenko suffered radiation sickness and was found to have radiation-related leukemia last year. He arrived in Seattle on April 11 for the marrow transplant, which was performed after chemotherapy and radiation treatment to kill off his own marrow. The transplant went smoothly, but Grischenko's condition suddenly deteriorated in mid-June. Antibiotics had failed to knock out the lung infection, which Grishchenko developed before coming to Seattle. The pre-transplant therapy leaves patients with no natural immunity against disease until the new marrow, which is transplanted intravenously, takes hold. ``There's a lot of sadness. It's been difficult watching him not progress, and as with all our patients, we hope they come here, be treated and go home and have a long life,'' Edmonds said. ``It was very sad to watch him have problems and grow worse.'' Grishchenko's wife of 27 years, Galina, was at his bedside, Edmonds said. At least 31 deaths are officially blamed on the April 26, 1986, explosion and fire at the plant in the Ukraine. Scientists say many more people may eventually be stricken with radiation-related diseases.

DOC.HEAD: Al Sharpton Cleared in Fraud Case
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Al Sharpton was cleared of charges he stole some $250,000 from a civil rights organization. He declared the verdict proved he was targeted by prosecutors for his role in the Tawana Brawley case. The jury that sat through the three-month trial deliberated less than six hours Monday before acquitting him of 67 counts of fraud and larceny. At a victory party at the Cotton Club in Harlem, Sharpton said of state Attorney General Robert Abrams: ``When he can't get one out of 67 counts, not one, to stick, then it's clear it was a vendetta.'' Two years ago, Sharpton had served as a spokesman for Miss Brawley, the black teen-ager who was found by a grand jury to have concocted a story of rape and abduction at the hands of a gang of white men. During the Brawley investigation, Sharpton had accused law enforcement authorities of a racist cover-up. The flamboyant Sharpton has taken part in other racially charged cases, acting as spokesman earlier this year for the family of a black teen-ager slain by a white mob in the city's Bensonhurst section. Abrams spokesman Ed Barbini said: ``We accept the verdict of the jury. We could not ignore the body of evidence that pointed to improprieties at the National Youth Movement, and we felt it was our obligation to take these allegations before a jury.'' Sharpton had been charged with stealing from the National Youth Movement, an organization he started at age 16. He faced up to seven years in prison if convicted. Assistant Attorney General Victor Genecin had charged that Sharpton ``sold ideals'' and then cheated the very people he was supposed to be helping. The defense called no witnesses; the state called more than 80. Defense attorney Alton Maddox had said Abrams brought the charges out of vindictiveness because of Sharpton's role in the Brawley case. Sharpton still faces tax fraud charges in a separate case in Albany.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers Hot Under Collar After Air Conditioning Turned Off
DOC.TEXT: County commissioners turned up the heat on state authorities they accuse of paying too little rent for space in the Berkshire County courthouse. They shut off the air conditioning. Lawyers in Chief Administrative Justice Arthur Mason's office, not surprisingly, are hot under the collar. They're considering appealing to the state Supreme Court, asking that the air conditioning be restored to the 19th-century courthouse in this western Massachusetts city. ``We've had both phone calls and correspondence ... indicating that the situation is very uncomfortable,'' Michael Edgerton, a lawyer for the Massachusetts Trial Court in Boston, said Monday. Massachusetts pays rent to counties for space in local courthouses for state courts and offices. County Commissioner Peter F. Menard said the state plans to pay $305,000, about $100,000 less than the amount the county believes is owed. A dozen other counties are unhappy with the amount of rent they are getting from the state and all 13 are appealing the issue, Menard said. Commissioners don't plan to turn the air conditioning back on ``unless there's a court order or court rent,'' Menard said. State officials, facing a budget deficit of more than $1 billion, say they don't have the money. ``Our position is that we've paid out all the money that's been appropriated to the counties and we certainly can't pay out more than the state has,'' Edgerton said. Menard said he doesn't know why lawyers and other state office employees are complaining. The courthouse has only had air conditioning in all rooms for about a year, he said. The electric bill jumped $10,000 to $45,000 last year and commissioners decided they had to cut back, he said. Courthouse employees said the temperature is comfortable in basement offices but can get a little sultry in upstairs courtrooms. Temperatures in the Berkshires rarely break out of the 80s.

DOC.HEAD: Activists Attach Condoms to Newspapers in Protest over AIDS Cartoon
DOC.TEXT: AIDS activists attached condoms to 2,000 coin-box copies of The Arizona Republic to protest an editorial cartoon that one protester claimed amounted to ``AIDS hate-mongering.'' The June 26 cartoon by the newspaper's editorial cartoonist Scott Stantis showed two men walking into a bathhouse and one saying, ``It puts me in a tizzie to think the government hasn't done a thing to stop the spread of AIDS.'' The Phoenix chapter of the national AIDS Coalition To Unleash Power, or ACT UP, said it attached the condoms in packages emblazoned with the group's name to Monday's editions of the newspaper on sale in Phoenix and three suburbs. ``That cartoon presents such misinformation, it's a heinous crime to the Valley,'' said the chapter's vice chairman, Jeff Ofstedahl, 26. ``It was AIDS hate-mongering. ... It's been the gay community that's been chiefly responsible for closing down the bathhouses.'' Stantis said the cartoon was inspired by the ``abominable'' disruption of last month's Sixth International Conference on AIDS in San Francisco by AIDS activists who drowned out a speech by Health Secretary Louis Sullivan. The activists have criticized U.S. immigration restrictions on people with AIDS and say more money needs to be put toward the fight against AIDS. David Hume, a spokesman for Phoenix Newspapers Inc., said those who disagree with an editorial commentary ``can promote their views through letters to the editor, opposite-editorial columns and discussions with our editorial page writers. We hope that those with objections to anything we publish would do so in a civil manner.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar fell against most other major currencies today in early European trading. Gold prices were lower. Dealers predicted the dollar would trade in a narrow range ahead of Wednesday's Independence Day holiday in the United States and ahead of Friday's release of U.S. unemployment data. Traders said European markets were focussing on the British pound. Monday's comments by Deutsche Bundesbank President Karl Otto Poehl that he expects the pound to enter the European monetary system's exchange rate mechanism ``soon'' have sent the British currency soaring. ``The pound has very little downside potential,'' said Paul Brewer, senior dealer at Salomon Brothers International in London. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.28 yen to a closing 151.68 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 151.81 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: _ 1.6567 West German marks, down from 1.6580 _ 1.3990 Swiss francs, down from 1.4030 _ 5.5580 French francs, down from 5.5635 _ 1.8635 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8650 _ 1,215.85 Italian lire, down from 1,217.00 _ 1.1635 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1616 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.7718, compared with $1.7635 late Monday. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $357.40 a troy ounce this morning, down from $357.55 bid late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $357.35, down from $357.80 late Monday. Gold in Hong Kong rose 15 cents to close at a bid $358.54. Silver was unchanged in London at a bid price of $4.95 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Full Sovereignty Proclaimed by Slovenian Parliament
DOC.TEXT: The lawmakers who replaced the Communists as leaders of the prosperous northern republic of Slovenia have proclaimed the state's full sovereignty, but stopped short of calling for secession. There was no immediate reaction to the Slovenian declaration from federal authorities or from rival Serbia. Monday's parliamentary declaration provides for establishing an independent legal system that would take precedence over federal laws and for Slovenian control over armed forces stationed in the republic, state media said. The document said Slovenia should adopt a new democratic constitution within the next 12 months, but made no mention of earlier calls for the republic to secede from the troubled Yugoslav federation. The media said a joint session of the republic's 240-seat legislature voted unanimously to adopt the Declaration of Sovereignty of the State of Slovenia. Slovenia contains 2 million of Yugoslavia's total population of 23 million. The Ljubljana nightly television news said the declaration asked Slovenian authorities to ``assume control over units of the (Yugoslav) armed forces stationed on Slovenian territory,'' and said a 30 percent cut in defense spending would be implemented. A coalition of center-right parties formed a new government last month in Slovenia, the most prosperous of Yugoslavia's six republics, after trouncing reform Communists in the first free state elections held in Communist-ruled Yugoslavia in 45 years. The republic's new authorities demand that Yugoslavia transform itself into a loose confederation of sovereign states. They threaten that Slovenia will declare full independence from Yugoslavia if the remaining republics do not accept its proposals for a confederation. Yugoslavia, including Slovenia, was created in 1918. Premier Lojze Peterle and other Slovenian leaders also say Slovenia should take urgent steps to join the European Community, no matter what Yugoslavia's Communist-ruled southern states say. The demands have been echoed in Croatia, the country's second-largest state. A center-right party came to power there last month in free elections. The hard-line Communist government in the largest state of Serbia vehemently opposes turning Yugoslavia into a confederation. Serbia rejects Western-style democracy and does not plan to hold free elections for at least another year. The Slovenian declaration also said police should take over control of frontiers with neighboring Italy and Austria, replacing border guards deployed for the past 45 years by Yugoslavia's Communist government, Ljubljana TV said. It said the state would establish its own intelligence and counter-intelligence services, that would be independent of their Communist-controlled federal counterparts. The adoption of a declaration of sovereignty has been under discussion in the new Parliament since the new government was installed in May. Slovenia's president, Milan Kucan, has said that Slovenia intends to proclaim sovereignty as part of its drive for liberal political and economic reform in Yugoslavia. The timing of Monday's proclamation by Slovenia may have been affected by Serbia's sudden decision last week to hold a special referendum Sunday and Monday on adopting consitutional reforms that would virtually destroy any remaining autonomy for its troubled province of Kosovo. Slovenia and Croatia increasingly have sided with Kosovo's ethnic Albanian majority in its drive for autonomy from Serbia. In Kosovo's capital of Pristina, after Serbian police on Monday barred about 100 ethnic Albanian deputies from entering the province's Parliament, about 40 deputies proclaimed Kosovo equal to the six Yugoslav republics. The deputies want to revoke a constitutional amendment that gave Serbia almost total control over Kosovo.

DOC.HEAD: Former Prime Minister Breaks Hip in Fall
DOC.TEXT: Former Prime Minister Menachem Begin was hospitalized in good condition today after breaking his right hip in a fall at his home, a hospital spokeswoman said. The spokeswoman, Dvorah Weissman, said Begin was undergoing surgery: ``He was fully conscious when he came in and was aware of his injury.'' It was the second time the 76-year-old Begin was taken to Shaarei Tzedek Hospital in Jerusalem this year. He was admitted with pneumonia on May 16 and released two weeks later. Begin became prime minister in May 1977 when the left-of-center Labor Party fell from 30 years in power during national elections. He stepped down as prime minister in September 1983 without giving a public explanation. He was believed to be depressed about Israel's military involvement in Lebanon, which had begun with a June 1982 invasion launched under his leadership. His wife, Aliza, had died a year earlier. Since resigning, Begin has lived in seclusion, rarely emerging from his apartment at the edge of the Jerusalem Forest. He receives visits only from a small circle of aides and former colleagues. Begin has a history of a heart condition from his early days in office. He also underwent prostate surgery several years ago. Begin was the founder of the right-wing Herut Party, precursor to the Likud bloc that now heads the Israeli Cabinet.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Pioneer Dead at 75
DOC.TEXT: J.C.R. Licklider, a psychologist and a pioneer in computer use who believed computers could help people think and make decisions, has died of complications of an asthma attack. He was 75. Licklider died at Symmes Hospital June 26, and his death was announced Monday by Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he was a professor emeritus in electrical engineering. Licklider was among the first to recognize that the full potential of computers could be reached only by improving users' ability to interact with them. He believed computers need not only be used to generate information. His views were supported by the Defense Departments' Advanced Research Projects Agency, which established large-scale experimental computer science research projects at universities around the country. Licklider headed the first one, Project MAC, from 1968 to 1970. It now is the MIT Laboratory for Computer Science. He contributed to the application of computers in libraries, introducing the concepts of digital computers and telecommunications into the processes of storing and retrieving information.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Prime Minister Says Baltics Will Forge Common Strategy
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene of Lithuania says leaders of the three Baltic republics will meet next week to devise a strategy for independence talks with the Kremlin. Mrs. Prunskiene, who returned from a visit to Finland and Estonia on Monday night, said she wanted all three Baltic states to be involved in negotiations with the Kremlin but that the Moscow leadership was opposed to the idea. The official Tass news agency quoted her as saying at a news conference in the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius that Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia would work together on Lithuania's approach to negotiations with the Kremlin. Meanwhile, Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov said the initial phase of the independence talks would be the most difficult as Lithuania offers its ideas about its future course. ``If the republic remains a part of the U.S.S.R. with some special status, this will call for one scenario,'' he said. ``If they categorically insist on seceding from the U.S.S.R., negotiations will have a completely different scenario.'' Ryzhkov also told the unofficial Interfax news agency that talks between the Kremlin and Lithuania should be held at the prime ministerial level. But he said ``unfortunately, we have received no answer yet from the Lithuanian leaders as to who will negotiate with Soviet officials, on the level of prime minister or otherwise.'' The Soviet government, responding to Lithuania's agreement to a moratorium on its declaration of independence, resumed pumping oil to Lithuania's largest refinery at Mazhiekia on Saturday. But motorists in Lithuania are still finding it difficult to buy gasoline for their personal use, a parliamentary spokesman in Vilnius said. Gasoline is going mainly to agricultural concerns, said Haris Subacius, a spokesman for the Supreme Council legislature. ``The blockade is being lifted, but we cannot feel it yet,'' Subacius said. He said it would probably be two or three weeks before the situation was normal. The Soviet government cut off shipment of all oil, most natural gas and numerous other items to Lithuania on April 18 in an attempt to force it to rescind its March 11 declaration of independence. Natural gas shipments were to be resumed today, the news agency Postfactum said, but there was no information on supplies of other raw materials that were blocked by the Kremlin. On Friday, the Lithuanian parliament accepted a compromise which traded a 100-day moratorium on the independence decree for an immediate end to the blockade and the start of negotiations. Subacius said the negotiations between Vilnius and Moscow could begin within two weeks.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS dropped first name of lawyer in 7th graf, `The Salvation ... '; DELETES his first name in 12th graf.
DOC.TEXT: A West German chemical company has agreed to pay $3.75 million to a woman who claimed her leukemia was caused by a detergent used to launder her diapers 23 years ago. Fawna Wright, 23, of Mound City, Ill., reached the settlement with BASF Wyandotte Corp. on Monday. Her lawyers contended chemicals in Loxene may have harmed thousands of infants before the detergent was pulled from the market in the 1960s. ``I'm amazed by it,'' said Wright, whose leukemia is in remission. ``Something that happened as a baby took part of my life.'' Wright had sued in 1985, maintaining her illness was caused by chemicals in Loxene that included pentachlorophenol, a substance more widely used as a pesticide and wood preservative. The trial was to have begun Monday. Despite being warned as early as 1959 that pentachlorophenol was unsafe, the company instructed Booth Memorial Hospital in St. Louis, where Wright was born, in how to use Loxene on diapers, crib sheets and other linens, the lawsuit charged. The now-defunct hospital was operated by the Salvation Army for unwed mothers. The Salvation Army agreed to pay Wright $5,000, and Dow Chemical Co. setttled for $60,000, said her lawyer, Robert S. Bogard. Dow and Monsanto Co. were accused of manufacturing chemicals in the detergent. Monsanto was dropped as a defendant. In a statement, BASF said that it is ``not directly responsible for her condition'' because the hospitals ``disregarded clearly stated use instructions and warnings.'' Wright became gravely ill when she was 5 days old but recovered. At age 12, she was diagnosed as having leukemia, the lawsuit said. Because of sealed records, Wright's lawyers said they were able to trace only eight other babies born at Booth during the time the hospital used Loxene. Two died as infants and a third suffers from a learning disability, the lawyers said. In 1966, an outbreak of illness attributed to Loxene at Pembina County Hospital in Cavalier, N.D., left one infant dead, they said. Bogard said Wyandotte Chemical, as the company was known at the time, should have removed Loxene after the North Dakota outbreak instead of waiting until the product's registration was revoked more than a year later. ``We now have hundreds of persons exposed at Booth or other hospitals using Loxene during the 1960s who may be suffering from problems,'' Bogard said.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard: Spill's Environmental Impact Minimal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Hearing convenes at 11 a.m. EDT. Late PMs lead likely.
DOC.TEXT: The oil spill in the Chesapeake Bay probably will have a minimal effect on the environment, the Coast Guard says. Officials said about 30,000 gallons of fuel oil went into the bay and the Elizabeth River when two cargo ships collided at the mouth of the estuary on Sunday. A Coast Guard board of investigation was to convene today to take testimony from the ships' crews. Capt. Eugene K. Johnson, commander of the Coast Guard Marine Safety Office, said aerial surveys showed that the oil in the bay was dissipating but that some had washed ashore on Norfolk beaches. He said most of the oil was in the river. ``I think the environmental impact on the bay will be minimal,'' Johnson said Monday. The bridge crews and pilots of both ships were given drug and alcohol tests, a standard procedure after such accidents, but the results were not yet available, he said. Environmentalists were concerned that the spill could contaminate spawning blue crabs in the mouth of the bay. But Robert Byrne, associate director of research at the Virginia Institute of Marine Science, said it appeared the crabs might be spared because most of the oil was in the river. Johnson said the cleanup would take several days. About 150 people and five oil skimmers collected about 1,500 gallons Monday, he said. The outbound Columbus America, en route to Melbourne, Australia, sustained extensive damage, the Coast Guard said. Johnson said the ship's owner, Columbus America Inc. of Hamburg, West Germany, has agreed to pay for the cleanup. Officials had no estimate of what the cleanup would cost. The Singapore-registered Neptune Jade, which was inbound, received minor damage, the Coast Guard said. The Columbus America's 140,000-gallon fuel oil tank ruptured in the collision. The ship's captain immediately returned to port, heading for a ship repair yard and leaking fuel along the way, the Coast Guard said. ``It was his determination that the problem could not be fixed at sea, and he chose to return to port. We concurred,'' Johnson said.

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo Wants To Study Dwarf Tossing Bill
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo said he doesn't know much about the Australian barroom sport of dwarf tossing, but he's treating seriously a bill that would outlaw it in New York state. ``These are human beings,'' Cuomo said Monday. ``This disturbs me, I don't know why.'' The bill, approved by the Legislature on Saturday, would ban the barroom games of dwarf tossing and dwarf bowling. ``I can't anticipate not signing it,'' said Cuomo, although he said he wasn't making any promises. ``If they said you could toss female dwarfs, but not male dwarfs, then I wouldn't sign it,'' he said. ``I would like the option of reading it.'' People compete to throw a dwarf the farthest in dwarf tossing. In dwarf bowling, a dwarf is strapped to a skateboard and pushed toward bowling pins. Both activities have been banned in Florida. Under the New York bill, any bar or restaurant permitting the games could lose its liquor licence. Sponsors said the games have been played in bars in New York City, Long Island and Schenectady. Dwarfs have been paid for taking part.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Football Team Gets Whipped 61-0
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to RESTORE dropped words in 5th graf and ADD background on Soviet American football league. Pick up 8th graf, `After Monday...'. A version also moved on the sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: It started looking bad for the first Soviet football team to play on American soil when the players heard the Turkish national anthem played in their honor. It went downhill from there. The Soviet national champion Moscow Bears were whipped 61-0 Monday night by the year-old Tacoma Express, a minor-league football team, in an exhibition game before 1,300 spectators in the Tacoma Dome. The game was billed by promoters as Glasnost on the Gridiron. Bears coach John Ralston, a former Denver Broncos head coach, didn't talk game strategy or give his players a fiery pep talk before the game. He explained to them how to suit up in full pads. ``Don't forget, you need your thigh pads, your knee pads and your elbow pads,'' he said through an interpreter. ``You don't want to land on that AstroTurf without your elbow pads.'' The Moscow Bears are among some 20 teams in the fledgling Soviet Union American Football League founded a year ago. For the past eight weeks, Ralston has been trying to mold the group of onetime rugby players, shot-putters, javelin throwers and decathletes into a professional football team. After Monday night, it was clear he still has a ways to go. ``I'm disappointed in our fundamentals,'' he said after the game. ``I don't think we do the fundamentals very well.'' The Bears are playing at least four American exhibition games arranged by an Alabama sports promotion company. The team is to play in Fresno, Calif., Oklahoma City and Macon, Ga., with a possible match in Charlotte, N.C. The starting quarterback first touched a football seven months ago, and he's the veteran. Ralston's biggest player tips the scales at 250 pounds. Ralston had said he mainly wanted to ensure his players finished the game intact _ especially his starting tight end, since both backups had been detained in the Soviet Union by the KGB the night before departure. The Bears suffered no major injuries. The anthem mixup wasn't the only glitch. Fans found their programs carried no numbers for the Soviet players. The announcer searched in vain for starting lineups while waiting for a Soviet interpreter who never got to the booth. She stayed on the field to relay Ralston's play calls and other assignments. ``I had a dream three weeks ago that I was calling a football game and that I didn't know the players or what was going on. The dream came true. What a nightmare!'' said Tim Harrington, a play-by-play announcer for radio station KKMO. When it came time for national anthems, the Soviets appeared stunned when they heard the selection played for them. Organizers discovered their mistake while the American anthem was being sung. Fans and players then stood a third time to listen to the real Soviet anthem. Tacoma built a 13-0 lead after one quarter and a 34-0 advantage by halftime. With the Express leading 48-0 after three quarters, the fans began to chant: ``Go, Bears!'' Ralston said earlier that competition, or the lack of it, could be a hurdle. ``In the whole Communist system, there's no incentive for being better than somebody else,'' he said. ``There's no competition, and that hurts.'' Until this week, the players were outfitted in whatever castoff equipment they could find, he said. He told of watching games where a team had equipment for only two dozen players, and players had to trade helmets and pads when they went in as substitutes. But thanks to American corporate sponsors who have donated 100 pairs of shoes and enough helmets and pads for the whole team, the Bears will return to Moscow as well dressed as most minor-league American teams.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Rejects Pravda Idea on Kuril Islands Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Japan today rejected as premature a Soviet proposal to share ownership of Soviet-held islands in the Kuril chain, which Japan claims as its own. ``We insist that they do belong to Japan ... and that subject should be cleared up first,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said at a news conference. But he said the proposal was ``interesting.'' The issue is a longstanding sore point that has prevented the Soviet Union and Japan from signing a peace treaty to formally end World War II. Earlier this week, political commentator Vsevolod Ovchinnikov wrote in Pravda, the Soviet Communist Party newspaper, that the dispute over the islands could be settled if Tokyo and Moscow agreed to place the islands under United Nations trusteeship as a special economic zone jointly owned by the Soviet Union and Japan. Soviet troops occupied the islands in the closing days of World War II. Japan insists that the islands were Japanese by longstanding agreement and that they were not ``war booty'' to be taken from Japanese rule. The Soviets have said repeatedly that the issue was settled long ago, and they refuse to consider Japan's demand. Japan has been cool to suggestions by other Western countries to give financial help to the Soviets to help bolster President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic liberalization. Watanabe, asked about such proposals to aid Moscow, said Japan does not stand in the way of other countries' giving money, but the lack of a peace treaty prevents Tokyo from supplying aid. ``That is a problem we've got to solve first before we can go into large-scale economic cooperation with that country,'' he told foreign journalists. Later this year, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze is expected to visit Tokyo for talks preparing for an official visit Gorbachev has announced for next year. The territorial issue would be high on the agenda for the Gorbachev visit. The islands, off the coast of northernmost Japan, lie in waters rich with fish, and have some strategic importance in controlling sea lanes between the Pacific Ocean and the Sea of Okhotsk.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf of CINCINNATI-dated first item in rdp to CORRECT name of town to Silver Spring sted Springs. SUBS last graf of PALM SPRINGS, Calif.-dated Coogan obit to CORRECT year of Jackie Coogan's death to 1984 sted 1985. Separate moved for PMs on Grishchenko as a0457.
DOC.TEXT: Dick Thornburg, editor of The Cincinnati Post from 1953 to 1969, died Saturday in Prescott, Ariz., at age 86. The cause of death was not disclosed. Thornburg began his career in 1929 as a copy boy with the old Columbus (Ohio) Citizen. He was managing editor of the Scripps Howard Newspaper Alliance in Washington before being named editor of the Post in 1953. He is survived by a sister, Virginia Dungan of Silver Spring, Md.

Jeffrey Sprung, an ABC Radio executive, died Sunday of a heart attack at age 50. Sprung joined the network in 1968 as manager of public relations and press information. He moved on to work as a radio news writer and editor for five years before being named news manager for the ABC FM Radio Network. In 1982, Sprung was named director of entertainment and direction radio networks for ABC News.

Christopher Coogan, youngest son of the actor Jackie Coogan, was killed Friday in a motorcycle accident at age 22. Jackie Coogan, who as a child appeared in Charlie Chaplin's 1921 film ``The Kid'' and as an adult played Uncle Fester in television's ``The Addams Family,'' died in 1984.

Anatoly Grishchenko, a Soviet helicopter pilot who contracted leukemia after trying to douse the fire at the Chernobyl nuclear plant, died late Monday of cardiopulmonary failure. He was 53. Grishchenko had been in critical condition with a lung infection for more than two weeks at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, where he had received a bone-marrow transplant April 27. Grishchenko in 1986 repeatedly flew his heavy-lift copter through the intensely radioactive gases spewing from the Chernobyl plant, dumping sand and cement in an overmatched effort to cap the crippled reactor. He and a handful of others in the operation were designated heroes of the Soviet Union, that country's highest honor.

DOC.HEAD: Despite U.S. Ruling, Marcos Case Can Continue in Switzerland
With PM-Marcos, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Philippines can pursue its legal effort to recover assets purportedly hidden by the late President Ferdinand Marcos, despite his wife's acquittal by a New York court, a Swiss official said today. However, Marcos attorneys in Switzerland said the New York verdict appeared to back their argument that Imelda Marcos cannot be held responsible for alleged crimes by her late husband. They spoke on condition of anonymity. The verdict, reached Monday, cleared Mrs. Marcos of looting $222 million from the Philippine treasury and sinking it into Manhattan real estate and other investments. The New York jurors told reporters they were unconvinced that Mrs. Marcos knew of her husband's alleged wrongdoings. Swiss Justice Department spokesman Joerg Kistler, however, said the acquittal has no legal effect on the Swiss proceedings. ``It would be wrong to conclude from the acquittal in New York that Swiss judicial aid to the Philippines is not permissible,'' he said. Switzerland is helping the Philippines government of President Corazon Aquino in its quest for Swiss courts to order the return of assets the Marcos clan purportedly deposited in accounts here. The Philippines claims the asserts were ``ill-gotten gains.'' But appeals by Marcos' lawyers have blocked any return of money or handing over of bank documents since Marcos was ousted and forced to flee his country in February 1986. At that time, Mrs. Aquino was swept to power by what became known as the ``people power'' rebellion. The Swiss accounts involved in the case are believed to contain several hundred million dollars, although the new Philippine government originally spoke of billions. Moritz Leuenberger, one of the Aquino government's Swiss lawyers, had said earlier a guilty verdict for Mrs. Marcos would provide only ``a psychological edge'' in the Swiss proceedings.

DOC.HEAD: Former Coca-Cola Bottlers Owner Dead at 65
DOC.TEXT: Chapman Shaw Root, one of America's wealthiest people and a former chairman of the country's largest Coca-Cola bottling company, died after a long illness. He was 65. Root, a longtime resident of Ormond Beach, died Monday at Atlanta's Emory Hospital. The cause of death was not disclosed. Root headed Associated Coca-Cola Bottlers from 1951 until 1982, when he sold his 57.5 percent interest to the parent company of Coca-Cola for $417.5 million. The company had plants in Pennsylvania, Florida, New York and New Jersey. Last October, Forbes magazine listed Root as the 386th richest person in America with a net worth of $290 million. In 1966, he formed the Root Co. as parent company of his expanding financial holdings. At the time of his death, Root's also owned such businesses as the Daytona Hilton and radio stations WNDB and WWLV. A native of Terre Haute, Ind., Root was the grandson of Chapman J. Root, founder and owner of Root Glass Co., the company that designed and patented the distinctive wasp-waist Coca-Cola bottle in the early 1900s. Chapman J. Root acquired several Coca-Cola bottling franchises, which later became the Terre Haute-based Associated Coca-Cola Bottlers. He is survived by his wife, Susan Spear Root; a daughter; five sons; and 12 grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Factory Orders Rebound 2.1 Percent in May
DOC.TEXT: Orders to factories for manufactured goods rebounded 2.1 percent in May, the government said today in another report indicating the economy's weak industrial sector may be bouncing back. The Commerce Department said orders for both durable and non-durable goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $240.9 billion and regained their 2.1 percent loss in April. The size of the May increase had been expected by many analysts. At the same time, the April decline was smaller than the 2.3 percent drop initially reported last month. It was the third gain in orders since they dropped 5.5 percent in January, their steepest decline since a 7.0 percent decrease in December 1974. All major categories advanced except non-durable orders which were unchanged at $112.4 billion. There have been other recent signs of an improving manufacturing sector, including a 0.6 percent jump in industrial production in May. Factory orders are a key economic barometer of manufacturing industry plans for production. A decrease in orders could result in a slump in that sector and subsequent layoffs. But much of the improvement has been attributed to exports. American consumers, on the other hand, have slowed their purchases, which had been a major driving force during the 7{ years of economic expansion. And the construction industry remains stalled. Commerce reported on Monday that spending fell 0.4 percent in May for its second straight monthly decline. Commerce said the increase in new factory orders was concentrated in durables _ big-ticket items expected to last at least three years. They were up 4.0 percent to $128.6 billion and nearly regained their 4.1 percent decline in April. Durable goods orders had been reported up 3.9 percent in the department's initial report on June 22. Most of the increase was in transportation orders, up 10.1 percent to $35.5 billion. Automobiles accounted for most of the gain, although defense aircraft orders also were up. Excluding transportation, orders rose 0.8 percent. In the key category of non-defense capital goods, a barometer of business investment plans, orders slipped 1.5 percent to $36.0 billion. They had fallen 10.6 percent in April after a March gain of 13.3 percent. Shipments rose 2.0 percent to $238.9 billion, more than offsetting April's 1.3 percent decline and exceeding the previous record of $238.2 billion set last August. Unfilled orders increased 0.4 percent to $520.3 billion and inventories were unchanged at $372.4 billion. Inventories have been relatively flat since last July. Among the durable sector, non-electrical machinery orders rose 3.5 percent to $22.3 billion, nearly erasing April's 3.7 percent loss. Electrical machinery orders advanced 0.8 percent to $20.6 billion after a 4.4 percent gain. Primary metals orders were up 1.7 percent to $11.8 billion, nearly matching April's 1.6 percent drop. The volatile defense category posted a 19.2 percent gain to $10.0 billion on top of increases of 4.8 percent and 4.5 percent the previous two months. Excluding defense, orders were up 1.5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Estates Left to Pets in Iowa
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `The 150-pound ..., to CORRECT dog's name to Calamity Jane, sted Bob; picks up 3rd graf: `Chico the ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DC1
DOC.TEXT: Mr. Pig is rolling in it. The 150-pound gray-rumped hog, along with a German shepherd named Calamity Jane, will be taken care of for the rest of their lives after inheriting part of a $600,000-plus estate left by Margo Lamp of Davenport, who died in February at 81. Chico the Amazon parrot is also living comfortably, despite losing a large chunk of an inheritance to its late owner's godchildren. But the fate of four cats _ Clementine, Martha, Gene and Smudge _ hinges on what happens in probate court. The animals belonged to three Iowans who stipulated in their wills that money from their estates be used for the well-being of their pets. The owners all died over the last eight months. ``I don't think it's strange at all,'' said Susan Halberstadt of the American Humane Association in Denver. ``It's a very special bond that exists between people and their animals.'' ``Many people are doing this,'' she said. ``Obviously these people had a very deep, profound love for their pets.'' Ms. Lamp willed the bulk of her estate to the Scott County Humane Society but set aside money for her dog and her hog, Mr. Pig. She had no close relatives and left $1,000 to a distant cousin and $1,000 to a friend, said her lawyer, George Goebel. ``I think that what you have is older people, that because of advanced age, their sphere of friends die _ disappear. Their pets become close companions to them,'' he said. Chico's owner, Ellen ``Goldie'' Bengston of Clinton, left most of her $70,000 estate in a trust for her parrot and a poodle named Pipi. Pipi died soon after and Harold Bengston, the executor of his sister's estate, asked a judge to reduce the amount set aside for the bird. The amount was lowered to $18,000, with the rest of the money going to two of Ms. Bengston's godchildren. Melody Stanton of Camanche willed her $12,000 estate to the four cats. Her mother, Eleanor Hodge, said it was stipulated that the money be used ``for the care and comfort of the only possessions I have in my life _ my animals, my cats.'' But Ms. Hodge said a number of debts will have to be paid out of the estate, which is being contested by a man who lived with her daughter. A hearing is set for July 17.

DOC.HEAD: Arson Investigators Report Progress in California Blazes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 6th, `The New ..., to UPDATE with Santa Barbara fire under control; picks up 7th graf: `Orr said .. .
DOC.TEXT: Arson investigators have received hundreds of tips since Gov. George Deukmejian posted $50,000 rewards for information leading to the culprits in two wildfires that destroyed nearly 500 homes. No arrests have been made, but authorities reported progress in Glendale, where 46 homes were destroyed and 26 damaged by a fire set Wednesday in 105-degree, windy weather. Fire Capt John Orr said Monday that Glendale officials had tracked down the owners of two cars who were nearby when the fire was started by a butane lighter rigged with a pin to keep burning. A third car was being sought. ``At this point they're witnesses as far as we're concerned,'' Orr said. In Santa Barbara, where a fire destroyed 430 homes and 28 apartment buildings and killed a woman, investigators found what they described as an incendiary device in a remote area. The New York Times reported the device was a match, and the Los Angeles Times said the device was sent to the FBI for analysis. Officials declared the 4,500-acre fire fully controlled at 6 a.m. today, said Maeton Freel, a U.S. Forest Service spokesman. Some of the 710 firefighters planned to remain several days on mop-up operations, he said. Orr said the fires were believed set by so-called vanity pyromaniacs, who want attention or perhaps to become firefighters, or by true pyromaniacs, who are thrilled, sometimes sexually, by watching the destruction. Investigators are concentrating on interviewing anyone who was on hand when the fire began, officials said. ``Arson is the only crime where the suspect sticks around,'' Orr said. Even after a fire is out, investigators haunt the area where it began. ``Sometimes these firebugs will come back,'' said Maeton Freel, Forest Service information officer for the Santa Barbara fire. ``If they can catch them coming back, even if they can't arrest them right away sometimes they can backtrack.''

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Ask: Why Was Imelda Marcos Tried in New York?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Although U.S...', to add detail on legal basis for prosecution in U.S.
DOC.TEXT: When she reported for jury selection three months ago, Imelda Marcos posed the question: Why was she being tried here instead of in her homeland? After the prosecution had called its 95th and final witness, the judge was equally curious to ask why a U.S. court was trying a case involving the theft of money from the Philippines. The jury was puzzled, too, and on Monday it settled the issue. ``We are not big brothers to the people overseas,'' juror Thomas O'Rourke said. ``It was a totally silly case.'' The jury acquitted the former Philippines first lady of charges she helped her husband loot $222 million from their homeland and hide the money in art and U.S. real estate. Co-defendant Adnan Khashoggi also was acquitted of helping the Marcoses hide ownership of their investments. In a statement, U.S. Attorney Otto Obermaier's office praised the work of the prosecutors and said: ``The jury has rendered its verdict. Our system of justice has spoken.'' In Manila, President Corazon Aquino said she was disappointed by the acquittal and said Mrs. Marcos was still barred from returning home for security reasons. Her officials said they are ready to file charges against Mrs. Marcos if she is allowed to return. U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan ruled that U.S. courts properly had jurisdiction, citing a precedent set in an earlier case and the fact that the disputed real estate purchases had occurred in New York. But the judge had wondered why the United States was prosecuting a former ally. ``I want to find out what the frauds were here in America, because Mrs. Aquino can enforce her own laws,'' he said last month. ``I don't want to enforce her laws here.'' Legal experts who watched the case said the jury could follow standards different from those Keenan was required to adhere to by legal precedent. ``The jury probably said, `We don't care. It's the Philippines' problem if it's anybody's,''' said Vivian Berger, a professor at Columbia University Law School. Whether Mrs. Marcos was properly tried in the United States was not the only reason for acquittal, jurors said. A sympathy factor and what they saw as a weak government case also played a role. ``We thought the government did a terrible, terrible job,'' said O'Rourke. ``They had half-truths and not the right witnesses. It was a terrible case.'' ``It was a poorly prepared case,'' said jury forewoman Catherine Balton. ``There was nothing to convince any of them that there was a case.'' O'Rourke said the U.S. government should have dropped the case when Marcos died in September, three years after the couple fled to exile in Hawaii. ``For three years they have made this poor woman's life miserable,'' he said. The trial was interrupted three times because Mrs. Marcos fell ill. On one occasion, she collapsed in front of the jury and coughed up blood. Witnesses testified that the Marcoses, through associates and friends, secretly funneled millions of dollars out of their country and bought four New York buildings, jewelry for Mrs. Marcos and art. The central issue jurors had to decide was how much Mrs. Marcos knew about her husband's alleged corrupt practices. They were unconvinced of her involvement, clearing her of racketeering, conspiracy, fraud and obstruction. ``Just because she was married to him doesn't make her guilty,'' Ms. Balton said.

DOC.HEAD: Founder of Hazleton Laboratories Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4-6th grafs, bgng `The company...', to CORRECT spelling of Hazleton. Picks up 7th graf, `His first...'.
DOC.TEXT: Lloyd W. Hazleton, founder of Hazleton Laboratories, one of the world's largest biological testing services, has died. Hazleton, 79, died of cancer Saturday at his McLean home. Hazleton, who had a doctorate in pharmacology, founded the biotechnology research company with his wife, Harriet Rosenzweig Hazleton, in 1946 on the grounds of an old country schoolhouse in Fairfax. The company, originally known as Hazleton Laboratories America Inc., became one of the world's largest biological testing services, doing pre-tests of new chemicals for virtually every major chemical, cosmetic and pharmaceutical manufacturer. He sold the company in 1968 and retired as president. The company is now known as the Hazleton Corp. and is based in Herndon, Va. Hazleton, a native of Washington state, moved to the Washington, D.C., area in 1939 when he joined the faculty of Georgetown University medical school as a pharmacology professor. He left Georgetown two years later and taught at George Washington until he founded Hazleton Laboratories. His first wife, Harriet Hazleton, died in 1986. Survivors include his wife, Grace Murphy Hazleton; three children; a sister; and six grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Propose Major Strategic Changes in NATO
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 8-13, The disclosures ... to UPDATE with quotes from Warnke, other critics; picks up 8th graf pvs, The change...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will urge the NATO allies this week to adjust to changing times by adopting new strategies for repelling a Soviet attack with fewer nuclear weapons and fewer troops along Europe's East-West divide, U.S. officials say. The most dramatic aspect of the change will be to make the use of nuclear weapons a highly unlikely last resort. Quietly, however, the NATO allies also will respond to a diminished Soviet threat by thinning out their ground forces along the East-West frontier. Instead, the officials told The Associated Press on Monday, a heavy proportion of NATO troops will be deployed at various points behind the East-West line, prepared to rush to any breach in Western defenses. A pending treaty to sharply reduce U.S. and Soviet troops, tanks, artillery and other non-nuclear arms in Europe is contributing to the revision in strategy that Bush and the leaders of the 15 other NATO countries will undertake in London on Thursday and Friday. There simply will be fewer U.S. troops in Europe, and fewer Soviet soldiers to defend against. Moreover, East Germany is about to be absorbed by West Germany, removing the one-time staunch Soviet ally from the front line and requiring a tactical shift in the alignment of NATO troops. As part of the new Western approach, Bush is ready to consider scrapping the 1,470 U.S. nuclear-tipped artillery shells now based mostly in West Germany and reducing or eliminating an arsenal of 1,560 U.S. nuclear bombs deployed in seven NATO countries, the officials said. The disclosures left at least some American liberals unimpressed. Paul Warnke, the chief arms control negotiator in the Carter administration, said the administration was stalling while trying to make NATO look ``a little less threatening.'' Warnke said the anticipated withdrawal of some nuclear weapons was only cosmetic, and that the 700 U.S. nuclear-tipped Lance missile still in Western Europe should be pulled out as well. At a news conference, Warnke said the missiles were aimed at East Germany, and could also be used against Poland and Czechoslovakia. ``There is no purpose, there is no targeting sense to their being there anymore,'' Warnke said. But, Warnke said, the Bush administration intends to replace the withdrawn tactical nuclear weapons with sea-launched cruise missiles and a new air-to-surface missiles. And David Shorr, assistant director of The British American Security Information Council, a private research group, said ``there has been scant recognition in the Bush administration that the security situation in Europe has changed radically.'' The change in nuclear policy is prompted by a vastly reduced Soviet threat and the crumbling of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. For instance, Hungary, whose parliament last week voted in a non-binding resolution to leave the alliance, has quietly proposed to NATO participating as ``observers'' in political, or non-military, committees, a U.S. official said. The revision in NATO strategy would not strip the Western alliance of all nuclear weapons, however. In fact, the Bush administration has made sure in its arms control talks with the Soviets to clear the way for production of a new short-range nuclear weapon, the air-to-surface TASM. But the officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, stressed that the likelihood of an attack by the Red Army and other Warsaw Pact forces, or a blitzkrieg that NATO could only push back with nuclear weapons, was becoming very remote. Some of the changes Bush and the 15 other allied leaders will approve will appear in the communique issued at the end of the summit on Friday. Others, officials said, will be implemented in the field with the pace partly determined by what the East does about its forces. The shift in NATO thinking varies among the allies. Britain and France are the least inclined to relax the nuclear deterrent, while West Germany, Italy and the Scandinavian countries want to de-emphasize nuclear weapons without abandoning them, an official said. That places Bush somewhere in the middle of the debate, but also prepared to scrub the concept of ``early first use'' of nuclear weapons in the event of attack, the officials said. That theory was adopted in the 1960s over the opposition of Robert S. McNamara, defense secretary in the Kennedy and Johnson administrations. It calls for threatening _ and actually using _ nuclear weapons if NATO's forces are incapable of halting an invasion of the Warsaw Pact, which has an edge of 2 to 1 in tanks and artillery. But now, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is committed to withdrawing tens of thousands of tanks and troops from Eastern and Central Europe while most of the countries in the Warsaw Pact are gradually leaving the Soviet orbit. Meanwhile, NATO and the Warsaw Pact are in the midst of negotiating a treaty in Vienna that would limit Soviet troops in Europe to 195,000, U.S. troops to 225,000, and set ceilings on tanks, artillery and other categories of non-nuclear weapons. Bush responded in May by abandoning plans to replace the 88 U.S. short-range Lance nuclear missile launchers in West Germany, the Netherlands and Italy with a more powerful version. And now, according to the officials, he is ready to withdraw the 1,350 nuclear-tipped artillery shells deployed in West Germany and 120 others based in Germany, Turkey and Italy, if the allies concur.

DOC.HEAD: Koreas Ready for Historic High-level Meetings
DOC.TEXT: In a major breakthrough toward reconciliation of the two Koreas, the North and South today completed negotiations on terms for a historic summit by prime ministers of the rival nations. The meeting would be the first talks between top government leaders of the Koreas since the 1945 division of the peninsula into the Communist North and capitalist South. The talks could be held as early as August. South Korean negotiator Song Han-ho told delegates at today's session that the summit will open ``a new chapter for realizing peaceful unification of the peninsula.'' ``We cannot stick to the logic of the Cold War and ignore changes in the world any longer,'' he said. The North's delegate, Paik Nam Jun, said today's talks ``marked a new milestone in the history of the North-South Korea dialogue.'' The delegates agreed to meet in the border village of Panmunjom on July 26 to sign a negotiated accord that would outline a proposed agenda for the top-level talks. The agreement calls for those talks to be held in alternating capitals, starting with the South Korean city of Seoul. Today's decision to sign the accord was reached during a meeting that lasted less than an hour. Unlike most dialogue between the two countries, it was free of rancor. The session was the first in five months. The North suspended dialogue to protest joint U.S.-South Korean military maneuvers. Although today's developments were hailed as a milestone in Korean dialogue, some longtime observers cautioned the talks could still falter. Years of hostility have bred distrust on both sides. The two countries are still technically at war because no peace treaty was signed after the Korean war from 1950 to 1953.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Aquino Isolated on Marcos Ban
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with congressional leaders calling for Mrs. Marcos' return, Mrs. Aquino accusing her of supporting coup attempt, new quote from Mrs. Marcos; TRIMS pvs; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of both houses of Congress urged President Corazon Aquino today to reverse herself and let Imelda Marcos come home after her New York acquittal on charges of looting this nation's treasury. But Mrs. Aquino refused to relax the ban and accused Mrs. Marcos of supporting a coup attempt in December. The president found herself politically isolated, with longtime supporters joining Marcos loyalists in calling for the former first lady's return. The constitution prevents her from being tried by a Philippines court in abstentia. On Monday, a federal jury in New York cleared Mrs. Marcos of allegations that she used $222 million in government funds to buy real estate, art and jewelry. Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi was acquitted of helping her conceal ownership. ``The acquittal does not alter the national interest and security grounds on which we have premised our decision not to allow the return of Mrs. Marcos at the present time,'' Mrs. Aquino said. In a second statement later, Mrs. Aquino said intelligence reports also showed that Mrs. Marcos ``encouraged and supported those who wanted to grab power'' during the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt. The fighting left 113 people dead and more than 600 injured. ``The return of Mrs. Marcos would enable her to mobilize the underground network of the Marcos dictatorship, which is designed to overthrow this government and endanger our democratic gains and economic momentum,'' Mrs. Aquino said. In a telephone interview with Manila radio station DZBB, Mrs. Marcos said: ``I am not opposing Mrs. Aquino. ``I am not going to fight her. What I will do is just pray to the Lord that I be allowed to come home. I know that He will grant me this, just like my acquittal,'' she added. Despite Mrs. Aquino's stand, most key leaders of the Senate and House of Representatives said Mrs. Marcos should be allowed to return, if only to stand trial. House Speaker Ramon Mitra said Mrs. Marcos should never have been tried abroad and that ``it is important that the arm of the law gets hold of her and she gets her day in court.'' ``In my view, Mrs. Marcos should be allowed to present her defense before Philippine courts,'' said Senate President Jovito Salonga, who was once jailed by Marcos. Senate Majority Leader Teofisto Guingona said that ``unless I am shown specific proof that there is really danger to national security, I would back allowing Mrs. Marcos to defend herself personally here.'' Philippine officials said today they were ready to file criminal charges against Mrs. Marcos if the president allows the former first lady to return. The Aquino government claims Marcos and his associates stole $10 billion before he was ousted in 1986. The issue of Mrs. Marcos is, however, especially difficult for Mrs. Aquino because they share such a long and bitter history. Mrs. Marcos' husband, Ferdinand, was toppled by the 1986 popular revolt that brought Mrs. Aquino to power. He died in September in Hawaii. Mrs. Aquino's husband, Benigno, was slain upon returning home in 1983 to challenge Marcos. Some people suspect that personal bitterness between the two widows plays a more important role than national security in the decision to bar Mrs. Marcos. In addition, allowing Mrs. Marcos to return home now could be perilous for Mrs. Aquino, whose own popularity is at a low ebb. Recent public opinion surveys point to dissatisfaction over high prices, deteriorating infrastructure and perceived inefficiency in the Aquino administration. The recent withdrawal of all U.S. Peace Corps members from the country and reports that one of them has been kidnapped by Communist rebels heightened concern about a deterioration of law and order. Meanwhile, the military says renegade leaders of the December coup attempt are again recruiting followers for another putsch. Mrs. Aquino has said she does not plan to run for re-election in 1992, and no clear favorite has emerged. Some political commentators believe that if Mrs. Marcos were allowed to return, she could wield considerable influence in the elections either by endorsing a candidate or running herself.

DOC.HEAD: Average Teacher Pay Tops $31,000
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 4th graf, `Average teacher...', to CLARIFY that statistics are for academic year, not full year; UPDATE with quotes from news conference. Picks up 5th graf pvs: ``With the...'. Should stand for PMs.
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Public school teachers earn the highest salaries in Alaska and the lowest in South Dakota, according to a survey that put the national average at $31,315. The average salary for U.S. public school teachers in 1989-90 rose 5.7 percent from a year ago, said the survey issued Monday at the annual convention of the 744,000-member American Federation of Teachers. Alaska had the highest average salary, $43,097, South Dakota the lowest, $21,300. Average teacher salaries are nearly double 1980 levels of $16,100 and more than triple the $9,705 earned in 1972. But after adjusting for inflation, salaries have gone up a scant $68 a year since 1972, the survey said. The statistics covered pay rates for the regular school year, excluding extra pay for such things as working during the summer or supervising extracurricular activities. Teacher salary increases exceeded inflation for the eighth straight year and average starting salaries topped $20,000 for the first time, AFT research director Jewell Gould told reporters today. But starting teacher pay remains $5,000 to $10,000 below most other professions, Gould said. Starting engineers, for example, earn $32,304 on average, according to the union statistics. Liberal arts majors average $26,244, and beginning accountants average $27,408. ``With the lousy working conditions most teachers face _ and the lower salary levels _ it's no wonder people are choosing other professions,'' said AFT president Albert Shanker. Teacher pay lags behind that of most other professions, he said. Lawyers average $57,172, auditors $36,007 and chemists $47,081. ``The investment we are making in education, as it's reflected in teachers' salaries, is simply not sufficient to meet the needs of public education or our nation's work force,'' Shanker said. Starting teacher salaries averaged $20,476 in 1989-90, up 5.8 percent, according to the survey. Alaska's beginning pay topped the list at $29,763; West Virginia's was lowest at $15,778. DOC.HEAD: Three Palestinians Killed, Nine Wounded In PLO Clash
DOC.TEXT: Rival factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization clashed in this West Bank village, and three Palestinians were killed and nine wounded when a grenade was thrown, witnesses said today. The toll in the battle Monday was one of the worst in an internal PLO dispute since the Palestinian uprising began more than 30 months ago. Villagers said it was between rival factions of the Fatah wing of the PLO. Witnesses said the battle broke out during a memorial march for a youth killed last year. They said hundreds of villagers fought for several hours with rocks, firebombs and guns before the battle ended with the grenade blast. The three dead were between the ages of 12 to 14 and the injured were all youths or teen-agers, hospital officials and Palestinian reporters said. The army confirmed the deaths and injuries, but said the clash appeared to have been the result a clan feud. It said no troops were involved. The army closed off the village today, but witnesses to the clash told a reporter on Idna's outskirts that the clans involved represent two groups within Fatah. Each side accuses the other of collaborating with Israeli authorities, they said. Imad Batran, 16, told a reporter that one side in the village's Fatah faction was staging a march for a 12-year-old killed by soldiers a year ago, when a villager from the rival faction pulled a knife on one of the marchers. He said the intruder was pushed aside but later tried to drive into the marchers with a car, setting off a melee. Batran called the intruder an Israeli informer but refused to give the man's name. ``I know his name but I will not say it,'' he said. Ahmad Rashid Tmaize, a 45-year-old villager from the other faction, said the driver of the car was from his family but was only driving near the march and accidentally got caught up in it. He said the organizers of the march were four young villagers and referred to them as ``the gang of four ... the other Fatah who are doing irresponsible things'' in the village. He said they had argued with other PLO factions and extorting money from villagers.

DOC.HEAD: China, Indonesia Resuming Diplomatic Relations
DOC.TEXT: China and Indonesia today agreed to restore diplomatic relations suspended 23 years ago when the island nation accused Beijing of supporting a Communist coup attempt there. The accord gives Beijing a diplomatic victory after a year of being shunned by the West for calling in troops to put down pro-democracy demonstrators last year. Hundreds of people were killed. Relations between China and Indonesia will formally resume Aug. 8, said a brief communique issued today in Beijing. It was signed by Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas and his Chinese counterpart, Qian Qichen. Chinese Premier Li Peng is to visit Indonesia for the official resumption of relations in August. Today's agreement caps more than a year of talks. ``What we have achieved today ... signifies the turning of a new page in our bilateral relations,'' Alatas told reporters after the signing ceremony at the Diaoyutai State Guesthouse. Qian called the communique ``a document of historical significance.'' Relations were suspended in 1967, when Indonesia accused China of having sent weapons to Indonesian Communist Party rebels. The Indonesian army crushed their 1965 coup attempt. Alatas said last week in Tokyo that China had promised not to interfere in Indonesia's internal affairs _ Indonesia's main condition for resuming ties. China's chief concern was addressed Monday with the signing of an agreement for repayment of $84 million that Indonesia borrowed from China before relations were frozen.

DOC.HEAD: Rap Group Members and Store Owner Formally Charged
DOC.TEXT: Three members of the 2 Live Crew rap group and a store owner who sold their album were formally charged today with obsenity. Band members Luther Campbell, Mark Ross and Chris Wongwon were charged with participating in an obscene performance, a first degree misdemeanor with a maximum penalty of one year in jail and a $1,000 fine, according to the Broward State Attorney's Office.
