They were arrested after an adults-only concert in Hollywood on June 10. E-C Records owner Charles Freeman of Fort Lauderdale was formally charged with selling copies of the album, ``As Nasty as They Wanna Be,'' which a federal judge ruled was obscene. But there may be problems for the prosecution, The Miami Herald reported today. The videotape of the performance is too garbled to understand, the band's defense attorney told the newspaper. ``It's terrible, and you can't make out the words,'' said Allen Jacobi, the group's attorney. Broward County sheriff's deputies made the recording last month, two days after U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez's ruled that their lyrics were obscene. Assistant State Attorney Leslie Robson said the quality of the recording was not great but it was clear enough to support the court case. The group's fourth member, David Hobbs, has not been charged. He serves as 2 Live Crew's ``disc jockey'' _ the member of a rap group who plays records _ and does not have a role in vocalizing the lyrics.

DOC.HEAD: East German Prosecutor Investigating Shoot-To-Kill Cases
DOC.TEXT: The chief military prosecutor has opened investigations into the deaths of 11 people who were shot by East German border guards as they attempted to flee to West Germany, the state-run news agency reported today. But the prosecutor, Col. Karlheinz Boesel, said he would only look into whether the guards were obeying orders, the ADN news agency said. Since the Berlin Wall went up on Aug. 13, 1961, 192 people are known to have died while trying to cross the heavily fortified border in Berlin or between the two Germanys. Most were shot to death by East German border guards under the notorious shoot-to-kill policy that was canceled only last year. There have been widespread public demands that border guards be prosecuted for the killings. Boesel said he would not act in any of the 192 cases unless specific charges were pressed by the victims' relatives. He spoke in an interview scheduled to be broadcast this evening by the West German ARD television network. ADN was quoting from an advance text. ADN gave no details on any of the 11 cases being investigated, except to say that relatives had filed murder or homicide charges. Border guards correctly obeying the shoot-to-kill order were ``no violent criminals,'' Boesel said. He argued for issuing ``some kind of exemption from prosecution so that border troops who used their firearms in the line of duty are offered a way out and a chance to make themselves known.'' ADN said the shoot-to-kill order was issued in 1961 by Gen. Heinz Hoffmann, who was East Germany's defense minister until his death in 1985. Former Communist leader Erich Honecker is the target of an East German murder probe stemming from the deaths of would-be escapees. The ADN report came two days after the final removal of all existing border checks between the two German states. On Sunday, the two nations took their biggest step yet toward unification by merging their economies.

DOC.HEAD: DOE Raises Ante in Estimated Cost of Nuke Waste Cleanup
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 12 grafs details on costs, congressional reaction; picks up graf 7th graf pvs, ``The more...
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department said today it will cost about $6 billion in each of the next five years to store and clean up waste from nuclear weapons plants, nearly 50 percent more than earlier was projected. The agency blamed the higher cost estimates primarily on the discovery of additional wastes at DOE sites and stricter government regulations that make the department and its contractors more susceptible to lawsuits. It predicts that a doubling of cleanup staff may be necessary to meet the goals of DOE's new five-year waste management plan through 1996. The revised five-year total through fiscal year 1995 will exceed $28.6 billion, compared with the $19.5 billion DOE estimated six months ago, according to a copy of the report summary made available Monday by aides to Rep. Norm Dicks, D-Wash. ``Such growth cannot now be managed responsibly and effectively, given the inadequacy of the DOE, contractor, industry and regulator infrastructure,'' the report said. ``Preliminary estimates indicate that DOE and its contractors must increase staff to at least two and one-half times present levels,'' it said. A key member of Congress said today he expected some increase in the cost estimates. ``I always expect them to be higher, but that is a mighty big difference between the estimate and the revised estimate,'' said Rep. Tom Bevill, D-Ala., chairman of the House Appropriations Energy and Water subcommittee. Bevill said the new numbers will be closely scrutinized, but he anticipates Congress will support efforts to dispose of nuclear waste given the nation's growing environmental concerns. ``I think Congress will be very supportive of anything dealing with the environment in this decade because our track record has not been so good in the past and people are now starting to realize it. We are not getting very far very fast. So far, we've just talked about it,'' he said. Dicks said the new figures demonstrate a need to finance research that will yield technology capable of disposing of the waste in a cheaper way. The costs ``are going up, we expected that,'' said Paul Grimm, assistant secretary for defense programs and director of the department's environmental, safety and health coordination staff. ``The more remediation we do the more we find that is going to have to be dealt with,'' he said in confirming totals mentioned in the summary. ``Cost growth is to be expected as a normal consequence of this process; however, the cost estimates used in developing this (fiscal year) 1992-96 plan exceed what is considered a manageable growth rate,'' the summary said. ``These amounts challenge and almost certainly exceed the resources that can be brought to bear by DOE, its principal contractors, the environmental restoration and waste management industries and state and federal regulators.'' Grimm said that in addition to new problems discovered at waste sites, the increased costs are the result of stricter state and federal regulations governing waste disposal and cleanup. ``Perhaps the most significant (and troubling) factor in driving up cost estimates has been increased awareness of and exposure to civil and criminal liabilities for DOE and contractor employees,'' the report said. Grimm said some costs are expected to decline in the future as new technology uncovers cheaper ways to store and neutralize radioactive waste. He said the new five-year plan through 1996 projects consecutive annual spending of $5.9 billion, $6.4 billion, $6.8 billion, $6.3 billion and $6 billion, for a total of $31.4 billion. The projections are consistent with earlier estimates that it would cost between $150 billion and $200 billion to clean up and store wastes at nuclear weapons plants nationwide over the next 30 years, Grimm said. The report stipulated that the estimates include unvalidated figures, but it concluded that the costs have ``increased significantly'' since the last five-year plan was completed. ``I don't think anyone was really caught by surprise,'' said George Behan, Dicks' press secretary.

DOC.HEAD: Four Members of Communist Party Politburo Submit Resignations
With PM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT to Eduard sted Edward; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev told the Communist Party congress today that four senior party officials had submitted their resignations, although they had not yet been accepted. None of the names mentioned by Gorbachev was a major player at the 28th Soviet Communist Party Congress, where the Soviet leader's reform policies are under fire from hard-liners. The four included two members of the ruling Politburo, Nikolai N. Slyunkov and Vitaly I. Vorotnikov; non-voting Politburo member Alexandra Biryukova; and one member of the second-most powerful body, Gumer I. Usmanov, who sits on the party secretariat. Slyunkov and Vorotnikov were two of 12 voting members of the Politburo, and Biryukova was one of seven non-voting members. Gorbachev said that Slyunkov, 61, was very ill and in the hospital. He had not attended the party session, which opened Monday in the Kremlin Palace of Congresses. Gorbachev said that Usmanov, 58, also was resigning for health reasons. He did not give reasons for the resignations submitted by Vorotnikov, 64, and Biryukova, 61, although Vorotnikov recently lost a job that carried nearly automatic inclusion on the Politburo, that of president of the Russian Federation, the largest Soviet republic. The office of the Russian presidency was drastically changed this year, and Communist maverick Boris N. Yeltsin was elected to the job on May 29. He is not a Politburo member. When Gorbachev announced Biryukova's name, there was a pause, and a considerable hum of surprise among the delegates. Biryukova, the only woman on the Politburo, was in charge of consumer goods. The shortage of consumer goods has been one of the main complaints about Gorbachev's policies. Word of her resignation came the day after Gorbachev told the congress he would like to see more women elected to senior party positions. Gorbachev made the announcement reluctantly, after he was pressed several times by delegates, who asked from the floor whether rumors of impending Politburo resignations were correct. The resignations have not been accepted yet, said Gorbachev. ``I think we should deal with personnel questions after the party's rules'' because they call for new positions and a new structure in the party leadership, he said. One proposal would rename the Politburo as the Presidium and expand the membership to 30. Asked whether any other Politburo members had submitted their resignations, Gorbachev said, ``That's all so far.'' Another Politburo member, Alexander Yakovlev, told The Associated Press last week that he had submitted his resignation to the secretariat when he was named to the Presidential Council, an advisory board to Gorbachev. He did not indicate whether the resignation had been accepted. Another Politburo member, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, told the Congress on Tuesday he did not see any need for senior government officials to sit on the Politburo.

DOC.HEAD: Rioting Reported In Albania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Albanian govt saying rioting occurred, details, quotes. Pick up 5th graf pvs, `The wave...'
DOC.TEXT: Rioting broke out in the Albanian capital when hundreds of people tried to enter a foreign embassy, and an unspecified number of people were wounded, the Albanian government said today. The Greek government said there were reports of deaths. Western diplomats said about 200 refugees had sought sanctuary in foreign embassies since late last week in an apparent attempt to flee Albania's repressive regime. A statement by the official Albanian news agency ATA said 300 to 400 people, including ``vagabonds, former prisoners ... as well as some deceived adolescents,'' tried to enter a foreign embassy in Tirana, the capital, Monday night. They clashed with ``forces of order,'' throwing stones, bricks and breaking shop windows, and some people ``were slightly wounded,'' it said. The Greek government released a statement saying: ``According to other reports which have been impossible to confirm up to now, shots were heard last night and it is rumored that there were victims among the population.'' The Albanian news agency said: ``With the immediate interference of the forces of order and the working people of the capital, the persons who violated order and tranquility dispersed. There were slightly wounded on both parties.'' A number had been detained, it said. The news agency called the disturbances ``alarming'' and said they were aimed at distorting ``the image of Albania in the world.'' A Western diplomat in Tirana, who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity, said other Western diplomats told him of rioting in central Tirana Monday night. ``I didn't see it myself but I heard shouting and shots,'' the diplomat said. Earlier, a West German Foreign Ministry spokesman said 83 refugees were in the West German Embassy compound, and 60 to 80 others were scattered in other foreign embassies. The spokesman, Hanns Schumacher, would not specify which embassies were involved. The West German Bild newspaper said they included the embassies of Greece, Italy, Algeria and Egypt. A Western diplomat in Tirana, speaking on condition of anonymity, said about 200 Albanians had sought refuge in at least 11 embassies. ``The wave started last week, especially on Thursday and Friday, when 25 Albanians entered the Polish Embassy'' the diplomat said. He declined to say why so many Albanians had suddenly rushed to the embassies. The incident was reminiscent of events last year in which East Germans crowded Western embassies in Eastern Europe, triggering the popular revolution in their country. Schumacher said one person was wounded in the leg late Sunday night as Albanian guards fired at refugees at the West German compound. Seventy-nine people fled into the compound Monday night and early today; four sought refuge the night before, Schumacher said. He said the 79 refugees succeeded in entering the compound either by climbing the wall or by breaking it down with a truck. ``In both cases, the Albanian security guards tried to hinder them by using their weapons,'' the spokesman said. He said the refugees' motives were not clear, but he assumed ``this is the outbreak of dissatisfaction with the existing political realities in Albania.'' He added: ``Nobody will be expelled from the embassy against his will.'' The West German government summoned the Albanian ambassador to the foreign office in Bonn today and formally protested ``the brutal behavior' of the Albanian security guards, Schumacher said. The Foreign Ministry also set up a crisis task force, and Schumacher said a meeting of the foreign policy arm of the European Economic Community was scheduled for Wednesday in Brussels to coordinate a response to the situation. ``The situation is extremely difficult,'' the Bild newspaper quoted an unidentified West German embassy staff member on the scene as saying. The report said the embassy apparently has been ringed by members of the Albanian militia. Last August, Hungary opened its borders to the West and thousands of East Germans began taking refuge in Western embassies in Warsaw Pact nations or fleeing across the Hungarian border. East Germany eventually was forced to open its borders, and its Communist government fell. Albania, a hard-line Stalinist state, has been vigorously resisting the types of pro-democracy reforms that have been sweeping other Eastern European countries. However, the Communist leadership has signaled some willingness to increase foreign ties and grant citizens freedoms long denied under the rigid regime imposed by the late leader Enver Hoxha. The Albanian state news agency ATA reported last month that under new travel regulations, all Albanians age 16 and over would be entitled to apply for a passport valid for five years. ATA had indicated the decree would take effect this month. Travel for Albania's 3 million citizens has been difficult, if not impossible, for decades. Last month, Albania also pledged to adopt basic reforms and seek full membership in the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Albania is the only nation in Europe that refused to sign the 1975 Helsinki agreements on security and human rights. Other moderate reforms announced in recent weeks had included the abolition of the death penalty for those trying to flee the country and the acceptance of religion, officially banned for decades. Albanian leaders had also announced they were seeking to mend relations with the superpowers.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Defends IRA Remarks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CLARIFY that two-day visit began late Monday night and will continue into Thursday, SUB 5th graf pvs, `Mandela's two-day...' Pickup 6th graf pvs, `Instead, the...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON1
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela was put on the defensive today over his calls for Britain to reverse its policy of refusing to negotiate with the IRA. The black nationalist, trying to calm the uproar he created with remarks in Ireland on Monday, insisted he was only promoting peace _ not interfering in the Northern Ireland conflict. The controversy developed after Mandela, on an otherwise triumphant 14-nation trip to promote his anti-apartheid efforts, said in Dublin that the British government should negotiate with the Irish Republican Army. British officials have refused to do so, saying it is a terrorist group. The deputy president of the African National Congress has drawn bipartisan British criticism over his comments. He was challenged to clarify his statement today when he spoke to about 200 members of Parliament at the House of Commons. Mandela's two-day visit to London, which began late Monday night, was expected to focus on Britain's stand that European sanctions on South Africa should be lifted to encourage the reforms launched by President F.W. de Klerk. Instead, the IRA dispute has attracted the most attention. Both the British and Irish governments oppose involving the outlawed IRA in negotiations as long as it uses violence in its quest to end British rule in Northern Ireland. ``I expressed no opinion whatsoever on the actual conflict between the IRA and the British government,'' Mandela told today's meeting of Parliament's all-party Southern Africa Committee. He said his group believes ``that all conflicts, wherever in the world ... should be settled peacefully.'' ``What is the use in the parties involved killing one another and killing innocent civilians when they could sit down and address their opponents by peaceful means?'' Mandela's African National Congress is the leading group challenging South Africa's white government and its racist system of apartheid. The ANC has refused to renounce violence, but de Klerk has opened talks with that group and others. Ivor Stanbrook of the governing Conservative Party introduced Mandela today with words of praise but then chided him for appearing to equate the IRA with the ANC. ``There is all the difference in the world between the struggle of a liberating movement against an oppressive, despotic regime and violence carried out for political ends in a parliamentary democracy,'' Stanbrook said. However, several lawmakers greeted Stanbrook's remarks with shouts of ``rubbish'' and ``disgrace.'' Mandela then delivered a 25-minute speech appealing to Britons to support international sanctions until there is ``irreversible progress'' toward ending apartheid. South Africa's white government has launched a program to dismantle some of the apartheid system of racial discrimination. De Klerk also says he wants to negotiate a new constitution that will bring blacks into the national government but allow whites to maintain veto power over major policy decisions. However, he opposes the one-person, one-vote system the ANC is demanding. In his remarks to lawmakers, Mandela said he had tried to avoid commenting on internal problems of the countries he visited during his tour. He added he took great pains not to comment on racism during his eight-city U.S. tour last month. Mandela, 71, was freed from prison earlier this year. He had been jailed since 1962 and was serving a life term for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who narrowly survived an IRA bomb in 1984, was expected to defend Britain's policy barring talks with the IRA during a meeting with Mandela on Thursday. However, the Thatcher-Mandela meeting will reflect a turnaround in another British policy. Britain had refused with talk to the ANC, branding it a terrorist group as well.

DOC.HEAD: Floods, Landslides Kill 24
DOC.TEXT: Floods and landslides in four days of heavy rain have killed 24 people and injured 26 others on Japan's southernmost main island of Kyushu, the National Police Agency said Tuesday. Three others were missing, an agency official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Two were in Kumamoto, where more than 20 houses were washed away Monday by a swollen river and 14 people so far have been found dead. Weather officials said 22.4 inches of rain had fallen in Kumamoto between Friday and 6 a.m. Tuesday. An additional 2 inches of rain was expected in parts of Kyushu because of a hovering storm. In Fukuoka, four people were killed, including three in a landslide that crushed a home Monday, the official said. Two people were killed in Saga and four in Oita. The official said about 660 local firefighters, joined by Ground Self-Defense Force and police, were searching for the three missing people. He said 208 houses were destroyed and 30,640 were flooded in Kumamoto, Oita, Fukuoka, Saga, Nagasaki, Kagoshima and Miyazaki prefectures on Kyushu. The landslides and flooding also forced railway officials to cancel nearly 500 train runs scheduled Monday and Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Security Breach at Royals' House Investigated
DOC.TEXT: An apparent security breach at the house being built for the Duke and Duchess of York is under investigation, Buckingham Palace said Tuesday. The Daily Mirror said a part-time security guard escorted a reporter through the house in Sunninghill Park adjoining Windsor Great Park, 22 miles west of London. It said the guard had approached the paper asking for a $12,000 payment in exchange for a tour of the house and security system. The paper said it refused to pay him anything. The Mirror said the $9 million house included a bulletproof room for emergencies, electronic monitors inside and outside, and alarm buttons installed throughout. Queen Elizabeth II's second son, Prince Andrew, and his wife, the former Sarah Ferguson, are expected to move into the two-story house in October. ``The matter is being looked into. Obviously we don't discuss security,'' said a Buckingham Palace spokesman, who was not named in keeping with British custom. Carterton Security Services, which employed the guard who allegedly gave the newspaper the tour, refused to comment on the report. Thames Valley police, responsible for security at the house, and Scotland Yard, which provides personal protection for the Duke and Duchess, also refused to comment.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Urged to Contribute to Welfare Rather Than Coronation Gifts
DOC.TEXT: Emperor Akihito wants Japanese to contribute to charity or the environment rather than sending him coronation gifts, and no gifts will be accepted from non-Japanese, officials said Tuesday. Only certain Japanese may send gifts, and the type of item also is limited, they added. Akihito, 56, who became emperor in January 1989 upon the death of his father, Emperor Hirohito, is to be formally enthroned on Nov. 12. The ceremony had to await the end of a yearlong formal mourning period. An official of the Imperial Household Agency, which oversees palace affairs, said many people had been reported hoping to send coronation gifts. He noted, however, that Chief Cabinet Secretary Misoji Sakamoto declared after a regular Cabinet meeting Tuesday that the emperor ``appreciates the desire of people to offer presents, but he strongly wishes contributions to the promotion of public welfare and maintenance of a green environment instead.'' The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said gifts will be accepted only from the Cabinet, the two houses of Parliament, local governments and groups of Japanese living abroad. Gifts will not be accepted from any foreigners or foreign governments. Unacceptable gifts, he said, would include high-priced items, gold, silver, cash, bonds, antiques and family treasures, daily necessities, swords, guns, food and drink, animals and plants. The gifts will be accepted between Nov. 1 and Dec. 20, the official said.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Fighter Plane Crashes, Pilot Killed
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese Air Self-Defense Force F-15 jet fighter crashed in the Pacific during nighttime interception training, killing the pilot, a Defense Agency official said Tuesday. The official identified the pilot as 2nd Lt. Naoyuki Kurita of the force's Hyakuri base in Ibaraki prefecture, about 60 miles northeast of Tokyo. The plane disappeared from radar screens Monday night and the pilot's body was recovered Tuesday, the official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The cause of the crash was being investigated. It was the fourth crash of a defense force F-15 fighter since it introduced the U.S.-designed aircraft in the 1980s, the official said. The defense force maintains 115 F-15s, its mainstay fighter.

DOC.HEAD: Report: 10 Executed in Northeast China
DOC.TEXT: Ten people convicted of robbery, rape and murder were publicly sentenced and immediately executed in the northeast Chinese city of Dalian, an official report said. The report by Liaoning provincial radio of last Wednesday's rally was carried by the British Broadcasting Co. monitering service, seen in Beijing on Tuesday. Those executed included a 25-year-old man who had previously been imprisoned for hooliganism. After his release, he burned several cars in the Xinjin county government office, causing $8,454 in damage. The report did not say why he committed the arson. It was the latest in a recent spate of reports of public sentencings and executions reflecting an anti-crime campaign launched in late May. China periodically cracks down on crime before major events like Chinese New Year and the annual meeting of the national legislature. The latest anti-crime campaign comes just months before Beijing welcomes the 11th Asian Games.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives Launch Offensive at Party Congress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with quotes, color, details, trims outdated material. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Conservatives mounted a counteroffensive against some of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms today at a crucial Communist Party congress that could help determine the fate of the Soviet president's ambitious program. Hard-line Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev won thunderous applause from the 4,567 delegates at the 28th party congress when he angrily denounced what he described as a media campaign against conservative party members and their allies in the military. ``In our day, there are forces going against socialism and the Communist Party ... and they have great influence in the mass media,'' Ligachev said. Gorbachev, who is general secretary of the party, sat stone-faced as Ligachev and other conservatives criticized reforms that they said were weakening the authority of the party. The session was broadcast nationally after an eight-hour delay. Monday's congress opening was broadcast live. Ligachev, leading the conservatives' attack, was followed to the podium by two other prominent conservatives, KGB chairman Vladimir A. Kryuchkov and Defense Minister Marshal Dmitri T. Yazov. A Gorbachev ally, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, answered with a strong defense of reform, or perestroika, and of Gorbachev's efforts to shift power from the party to government and legislative bodies. Shevardnadze, who has been the point man in arms deals with the United States, fended off criticism of ``concessions in the security arena.'' ``Squandering a quarter of our budget on military expenditures, we have ruined the country,'' he said. ``We shall have no need for defense, because a ruined country and an impoverished people have no need for an army.'' He praised Soviet policy toward Eastern Europe, where since last August new, more democratic governments have replaced what he called ``totalitarian regimes that had been imposed on them and were alien to them.'' ``We forecast this. We sensed that if there were not changes, there would be tragedy,'' he said. In a remark that ran counter to Soviet tradition, Shevardandaze said he did not see why the foreign minister should also sit on the Politburo, the top party body consisting of 12 voting and seven non-voting members. Shevardnadze was applauded, but not nearly as much as Ligachev, who later told reporters that the loss of Eastern Europe ``doesn't strengthen our position, but weakens it.'' Yazov, wearing his green marshal's uniform emblazoned with several rows of medals, sharply opposed calls by progressive Communists to eliminate party cells in the Soviet armed forces. ``That would be very harmful,'' he told the delegates, including some military officers. Kryuchkov urged Communists, in their search for new political ideas, not to ape the West, which he said was plagued by materialism, crime, drug use and high unemployment. ``Very recently it was written here that in the West everything was bad and here everything was good,'' Kryuchkov said. ``Now we hear assertions that in the West everything is good and here everything is bad.'' None of the conservatives criticized Gorbachev by name, but they attacked some of his policies. Ligachev harshly criticized three of Gorbachev's programs: the anti-alcoholism campaign that has since been abandoned and two emerging policies, private ownership of factories and a move toward private ownership of land. Ligachev has been mentioned as a possible challenger to Gorbachev when the 28th party congress elects the party leader. He refused to say today whether he would be a candidate, but he has said Gorbachev should not hold the top party job and the country's presidency at the same time. Ligachev received strong applause when he charged that putting factories in private hands will not help socialism. But the audience was quiet when he said, ``Communal land unites, while private property separates the interests of the people.'' Two weeks ago, Ligachev said Gorbachev should not hold the top job in the party and the presidency at the same time. But he received a restrained final ovation, perhaps reflecting the sentiment that Gorbachev retain both posts. The congress has the power to elected a new Central Committee, and major changes are expected in the personnel and structure of the Politbuo. Those changes began to emerge during the afternoon session, when Gorbachev announced that four senior party officials had submitted their resignations. None of the resignations had been accepted, he said. The four included two full members of the ruling Politburo, Nikolai N. Slyunkov and Vitaly I. Vorotnikov; non-voting Politburo member Alexandra Biryukova; and one member of the second most powerful body, Gumer I. Usmanov, who sits on the party secretariat. They have not been major players at the congress. Slyunkov and Vorotnikov were two of 12 voting members of the Politburo, and Biryukova was one of seven non-voting members.

DOC.HEAD: Parziale Named Assistant Bureau Chief in Kansas City
DOC.TEXT: Eva M. Parziale, Associated Press news editor in Columbia, S.C., has been named assistant chief of bureau in Kansas City. Paul Stevens, chief of bureau for Kansas and Missouri, announced the appointment Tuesday. She succeeds Mercer G. Bailey, who retires next month after a 47-year AP career. Parziale, 29, joined the AP in San Francisco in 1984. After earning a master's degree in journalism at Columbia University, she returned to the AP in Miami in 1985. Two years later Parziale was named correspondent in charge of the Portland, Maine, bureau. She has been news editor in Columbia since March 1989. Parziale, a native of Euclid, Ohio, received her undergraduate degree from Bowling Green State University. Bailey, 63, began his AP career in Atlanta. The West Palm Beach, Fla., native also worked in Mobile and Montgomery, Ala., and Miami before transferring to the AP's General Desk in New York as a supervisor in 1963. He became St. Louis correspondent in 1968 and assumed the Kansas City post two years later.

DOC.HEAD: Snooky Lanson, `Hit Parade' Singer, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Snooky Lanson, singing star of the popular 1950s show ``Your Hit Parade,'' has died at the age of 76. Lanson died Monday night at Saint Thomas Hospital, according to the Martin's & Bracey-Welsh Funeral Home. The cause of death was not released. Lanson sang on the show from 1950 to 1957 as a replacement for Frank Sinatra. The TV version of the legendary radio ``Lucky Strike Hit Parade,'' the show counted down the top tunes of the week and featured ``extras.'' The show was a forerunner to today's ``countdown'' radio and music video programs. After Lanson and other regulars on the Saturday night show were dropped from the cast in 1957, he sang in nightclubs and was host of TV variety shows in Atlanta and in Shreveport, La. The show continued until 1959 and was revived briefly in 1974. ``The show didn't have any stars per se and we all got along well,'' Lanson recalled in a 1979 interview with The Associated Press. ``It was very clean and there was no suggestive dancing. A 5- or 6-year-old could watch it. And of course a lot of people watched it to see what song was No. 1 that week.'' Among the songs Lanson sang were ``Ebb Tide,'' ``He'' and ``Mr. Sandman.'' ``I sang `Mona Lisa' 13 straight weeks because it was a man's song and I was the only man on the show then,'' Lanson said. Lanson also said he was lucky to have been on the hit program. ``I have no illusions of grandeur,'' he said in 1979. ``I know that 99 percent of the singers roaming the country then were better than me. ``I know my time has come and gone. I had my time.'' He had lived in Nashville since 1967 where he sang at tea dances and similar functions. He also had a syndicated radio show that played ``big band'' music and sold cars and outdoor advertising. In 1941, he recorded the hit record ``By the Light of the Silvery Moon'' with the Ray Noble Band. A later hit, ``The Old Master Painter,'' helped him land the ``Hit Parade'' job. He was born Roy Landman in Memphis and began singing in a church choir there as a boy. He was nicknamed ``Snooky'' at age 2 for the Irving Berlin tune ``Snooky-Ookums.'' Survivors include his wife, Florence; a daughter; two sons; and eight grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: After Acquittal, Just Another Subway Ride
With AM-Marcos, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: When the trial ended with his acquittal, Adnan Khashoggi did what he's done every day since it began last March: He took the subway home. Smiling broadly, surrounded by family and aides, the man once considered the world's richest person led a pack of photographers down the stairs, plunked a token in the turnstile, and boarded the No. 6 local for the ride uptown. Minutes earlier, on the steps of Manhattan's federal courthouse where he and former Philippine first lady Imelda Marcos had just been acquitted of all charges, Khashoggi told reporters: ``I am very happy for myself, I am happy for my family. and I am happy for America. With your system of justice, you should be very proud of yourselves.'' Khashoggi, 54, had been accused of obstructing justice and mail fraud by faking documents to help Mrs. Marcos and her late husband conceal their ownership of four New York office buildings and some paintings after a 1986 court order froze their assets. Throughout the three-month trial he told reporters, well wishers and anyone who would listen that he had done nothing wrong and trusted the American jury system to clear up the misunderstanding. ``But this woman,'' he would say, referring to his co-defendant. ``She is sick, and why are they treating her like this?'' Short, portly and balding, Khashoggi looks like the consummate middle man that he has been for more than 30 years _ bringing together people who need something with those who have it, and taking his cut for services rendered. In that role he built an investment portfolio that once reached into 35 countries and earned him $80 million to $100 million a year. Although business setbacks have shrunk that empire and slightly crimped his jet-set lifestyle in recent years, he still has homes and offices in his native Saudi Arabia, and in France, Switzerland, Britain and the United States, a private DC-8 and a yacht. A devout Moslem who only occasionally sips wine, he loves night life and is likely to turn up in the local hot spots whenever he travels. In the late 1980s he came under fire for his go-between role in the Iran-Contra affair, in which the Reagan adminstration secretly sold weapons to Iran and diverted the funds to the U.S.-backed Contra rebels in Nicaragua. But Khashoggi insists that everything he did had the approval of the U.S. and Saudi governments. Although he is acquainted with presidents and kings _ King Fahd of Saudi Arabian guaranteed the $10 million bond that got him released from a New York jail _ intimates say that Khashoggi retains a generous nature and common touch. One friend, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Khashoggi once wrote a check for a distant relative who needed money, and after the recipient doctored the check to increase the amount, Khashoggi instructed the bank to cash it anyway. James Linn, Khashoggi's attorney, said his client rode the subway to the trial because he had a habit of being late and it was faster than a limousine. Riding uptown on Monday, Khashoggi sat between his son, Hussein, and his daughter Nabila, posing for photographers and signing autographs for other riders. And later, as his entourage of 25 trooped across town toward his apartment at Olympic Towers, Adnan Khashoggi took a cellular phone from his pocket and began calling the good news to relatives and friends in London, Paris and Santa Barbara, Calif.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Newspapers which published a0779, AM-Exerciser-Recalled, which moved June 28 under a Washington dateline, are asked to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: The Consumer Product Safety Commission on June 28 released an erroneous telephone number for consumers seeking more information about the recall of the ``New Gym Stomach Eliminator.'' The wrong number was published in an Associated Press story. The correct telephone number is 516-473-7308. The CPSC said the manufacturer, Harrison-Hoge Industries Inc., will accept collect calls.

DOC.HEAD: Man Charged in Soviet Doctor's Death
DOC.TEXT: A man already in custody for auto theft has been charged with killing a Soviet cardiologist on vacation in New York, police said. Eric Wilson, 22, of Brooklyn, was ordered held without bail after his arraignment Sunday night on charges he fatally shot Dr. Arkady Novikov, said police spokesman Sgt. Nick Vreeland. Novikov, 47, of Moscow, was shot to death in the early morning hours of June 24 while trying to protect his wife from a gunman who tried to steal her purse in an apartment building lobby in the Forest Hills section of Queens. Wilson was caught fleeing from a stolen car in Brooklyn 16 hours after the slaying, authorities said. Jewelry that belonged to Novikov's wife, Galina, was recovered from the car, as were a sawed-off .30-caliber rifle and ammunition, Vreeland said. Ballistic tests have linked the weapon to Novikov's slaying, he said. Wilson's alleged accomplice in the slaying was still being sought, according to Vreeland.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Parliament Restores Old Coat of Arms
DOC.TEXT: The National Assembly voted overwhelmingly Tuesday to replace the Marxist state emblem with Hungary's traditional coat of arms. Lawmakers then burst into a spontaneous singing of the national anthem. It was the nation's latest move to erase the legacy of four decades of Communist rule. Of the 386 legislators, 258 voted in favor, 28 against, 35 abstained and the rest were absent. There was considerable debate over two versions, with and without the crown of St. Stephen, the king who ruled between 997 and 1038. Ultimately, the version with the crown was approved. The largest opposition party, the League of Free Democrats, expressed fears that neighboring countries could misinterpret a national emblem containing the crown because the same coat of arms was used by the rightist prewar regime of Admiral Nicholas Horthy. Supporters of the crown argued that it was the symbol of Hungarian statehood. It was King Stephen who welded the Hungarian tribes into a nation and christianized the people.

DOC.HEAD: Bensonhurst Defendant Acquitted of One Murder Count; Hung Jury on Second
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES pvs; recasts first 7 grafs to add possible sentence, sentencing date, retrial date. Picks up 3rd graf of a0553, `State Supreme...'. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Bensonhurst racial attack defendant John Vento was found innocent this morning of one count of murder, but the sharply divided jury could not reach a verdict on a second murder charge against him. The jury, which was in its ninth day of deliberations, convicted Vento of two counts of unlawful imprisonment and four counts of menacing for his role in the attack which left 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins dead on a Brooklyn sidewalk. Vento, who backed out of a deal to testify against his co-defendants in the case, faces one and one-third to four years on the unlawful imprisonment counts and 90 days on each menacing count. Sentencing was set for Aug. 14. The 21-year-old sat silently as the verdicts were read. Vento was acquitted of the first murder count; a weapons possession charge; one count of unlawful imprisonment; and five counts of discrimination. The jury was also was hung on a count of first-degree riot. Prosecutors said Vento would be retried in September on the charges for which there was a hung jury. The Vento case was the second trial stemming from the attack by a white gang on Hawkins, who was shot and killed in the predominantly white neighborhood last year. Hawkins was in the area to look at a used car. The first trial, actually two trials held simultaneously with separate juries, resulted in a murder conviction against Joseph Fama, 19, and a conviction on lesser charges against Keith Mondello, also 19. State Supreme Court Justice Thaddeus Owens, who also presided over the earlier trials, told the jurors judging Vento's case that he knew it was not an easy case to decide. ``I can understand your chagrin, and I can also understand your anguish,'' Owens told the panel before dismissing them. Hawkins, a black high school student, was fatally shot last Aug. 23 as he and three friends walked through the south Brooklyn neighborhood of Bensonhurst. The four blacks crossed paths with a gang of bat-wielding whites, which Vento allegedly helped organize. The attack was widely viewed as one of the worst racial incidents in New York in years. The murder was a shock for a city trying to heal from the wounds of the racial killing in another predominantly white neighborhood, Howard Beach, as well as allegations of police attacks on blacks and other racially charged incidents in the late 1980s. Fama, named as the triggerman by several of the defendants, was sentenced to 32 and two-thirds years to life. Ringleader Mondello, 19, was acquitted of homicide charges but sentenced to five and one-third to 16 years in prison for his other convictions. Five other young Bensonhurst whites accused of being part of the mob are to stand trial later. The day after Hawkins' murder, Vento fled upstate, but he soon called prosecutors to admit his role. He also agreed to cooperate in the investigation and to testify against his friends in exchange for immunity from prosecution. When he appeared before a grand jury in September, Vento gave a complete and graphic account of the attack. He said he watched from just several feet away as Fama pulled an automatic pistol and fired into Hawkins' chest. Vento told of seeing the ``sparks coming out of the gun, pop, the fire.'' As Hawkins collapsed to the sidewalk fatally wounded, the whites ran without stopping to help him. Around Christmas, with the scheduled start of the first Bensonhurst trial a little more than two months away, Vento again fled the city. He surrendered to FBI agents in Dayton, Ohio, in March, but announced he would no longer cooperate. He was indicted by a grand jury a week later. While there's no evidence Vento even touched a gun the night of shooting prosecutors accused him of being a key player who helped his friend Mondello call together the gang. ``Like a good general, John Vento marshals his troops just before the fray,'' assistant district attorney Martin Hershey said in his final arguments. Vento was as guilty of murder as the shooter, prosecutors charged, because he continued to pursue the blacks after hearing Fama say he was going to shoot one of them. But defense lawyer Gerald DiChiara said Fama acted independently and without warning in killing Hawkins. He also accused prosecutors of creating a racial issue for political purposes and going after Vento out of vengeance because he reneged on his agreement to testify against the others.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Ready to Evacuate Americans, Possibly Doe
DOC.TEXT: A Navy task force was standing ``over the horizon'' off Liberia today ready to evacuate Americans or Liberian President Samuel Doe if requested to do so by the State Department in the wake of renewed fighting, the Pentagon said. Defense Department spokesman Pete Williams said the Navy ships sent to the area May 31 were ``still in international waters, over the horizon'' from the coast of the troubled West African nation. Williams said about 800 Americans, including 70 embassy personnel, remained in the Liberian capital of Monrovia. Rebels attacked Monrovia on Monday in a two-pronged offensive that cut all major land routes from the capital, according to a pool report filed by journalists there. The Pentagon spokesman said the primary purpose of the Navy ships, which have about 2,500 sailors and Marines on board, is to evacuate Americans if needed. The State Department advised U.S. citizens on May 31 to leave Liberia because of deteriorating conditions, and some departed on chartered airline flights last month. In response to a question about possible evacuation of Doe, Williams said, ``If the State Department were to ask us to assist in moving President Doe, we would certainly be prepared to do what they asked us.'' The State Department has said it is prepared to help Doe depart the country if he so requests. A rebel source in Ivory Coast, across the border from Liberia, said today that several thousand rebel troops were approaching Monrovia to ``put an end'' to Doe. The United States and other governments have urged Doe to resign and leave the country, a condition the rebels have set for accepting a cease-fire. Several countries have offered Doe asylum, including Nigeria and Togo. Doe, 40, a former master sergeant, has ruled Liberia since a bloody coup in April 1980. He ousted the descendants of freed American slaves who had ruled the West African country for more than a century. Bush ordered the amphibious task force to the area on May 31. It is made up of the amphibious assault ship USS Saipan and the supporting ships USS ponce, USS Sumter and USS Peterson. The ships arrived off the coast June 3. The Navy said the Saipan's secondary missions include being ready to evacuate civilians or delivering supplies to victims of natural disaster. It carries enough supplies to sustain 500 evacuees for 10 days, the Navy said.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Seek Ways to Improve Pictures From Space Telescope
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs comment from scientist on prospect of improving Hubble's misfocused images; picks up 4th graf pvs, NASA engineers, meanwhile. Lennard is cq in graf 9.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Some fuzzy images from the Hubble Space Telescope may be improved through the same computer process that cleaned up photos taken by the Voyager spacecraft. But the pictures will still be less clear than originally expected, a scientist said today. Ed Weiler, a Hubble project scientist, said a team of experts was being selected to determine how much of the ``fuzz ball'' now being seen by the space telescope can be turned into crisp pictures through computer techniques. Improving poor pictures through computers, Weiler told a news conference, is ``something of a black art,'' but experts in the field believe some Hubble views, such as those of bright objects, can be improved. ``I'll believe it when I see it,'' Weiler told a news conference. ``We'll let the experts play with the images. People in the field say there is a lot of hope there.'' Weiler emphasized, however, that the computer-enhancing technique is only an effort to salvage some good from a fundamentally flawed telescope. ``This is not a cure-all for the problem,'' he said, noting that the picture computer processing would recover less than 50 percent of the visual photo science that was expected from the $1.5 billion telescope. Hubble's basic problem is that a mistake was made in the grinding and polishing of either the primary or the secondary mirror on the telescope. Weiler said one of the reflecting surfaces was not cut to the correct prescription and, as a result, the two mirrors do not work together properly. The result is a fuzzy view of the universe from the telescope. Lennard Fisk, chief scientist for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said on Monday that the computer enhanced photos from Hubble would be so good that ``you are all going to be delighted with the kind of results that the telescope produces in the next few years.'' NASA engineers, meanwhile, stepped up tests designed to find and isolate a hydrogen leak that has grounded the nation's three space shuttles. Helium under 30 pounds of pressure was forced into the hydrogen rocket fuel system of space shuttle Atlantis as it sat Monday on a launch pad at the Kennedy Space Center. A similar test, using supercold liquid hydrogen, revealed a leak last week. Plumbing and valves from Columbia, which was grounded last month when a hydrogen leak was found, are now being tested at the shuttle manufacturer's plant in California. Engineers hope the tests will pinpoint precisely how the hydrogen leaks from the shuttle and fuel tank while the supercold liquid rocket fuel is being loaded. The leaks, occurring within weeks of each other from the same area of two different shuttles, led NASA last Friday to ground the fleet until the problem is corrected. Fisk said the Hubble focusing problem is absolutely consistent and that this reliable symmetry will enable scientists to correct the fuzzy view through a computer program. ``There is growing optimism that because of the nature of the signal ... that we will be able to do image reconstruction ... and produce clear, exciting views of the universe,'' he said. Such techniques were used at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory to improve the quality of pictures returned from the two Voyager spacecraft that explored the outer planets and radioed views back to Earth. ``If you've seen pictures from Voyager you know how capable we are of doing image reconstruction when the signals are not precisely in the focus that you want,'' said Fisk. ``I think you will discover that Hubble in its current capability produces exciting and very dramatic pictures of the universe.'' Engineers learned last week that one of the two main mirrors f the $1.5 billion space telescope contained a manufactured flaw that kept the telescope from seeing the universe clearly. The Hubble, in effect, is like a person who needs glasses and is trying to see the world without them. Fisk said the true focus of the Hubble view is missed by a tiny measure _ about one-fiftieth of the width of a human hair _ and that this makes the flaw easier to correct. ``Six months from now, a year from now, I expect you all to ooh and ahh over the picture that Hubble is going to produce and of course, compliment the current management of NASA for their success in pulling it off,'' he told reporters. At the same news conference, NASA space flight director William B. Lenoir said the space shuttle mystery leak must be solved within a few weeks to keep the agency anywhre near its ambitious flight schedule. Columbia's leak forced postponement of an astronomy mission in May and Atlantis' leak is delaying a secret military mission. Columbia had been scheduled to fly twice more this year and Atlantis once more. The third shuttle, Discovery, must be launched in October to take advantage of a planetary alignment that occurs only once every two years. The shuttle's cargo is the Ulysses science probe that is to study the sun. Lenoir said tests now under way may provide answers to the leak problem by Thursday and allow the agency to re-establish a launch schedule.

DOC.HEAD: N.J. Supreme Court Says Princeton Eating Clubs Discriminated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to CORRECT that appeals court had NOT suggested severing ties with university but had ordered new hearing on procedural errors; ADDS comment from Frank, background on case and vote by two clubs to admit women. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Two male-only eating clubs at Princeton University discriminate against women and must open their membership to females, the state Supreme Court ruled today. The high court ruled unanimously in an 11-year-old sex discrimination case brought by Sally Frank, a former Princeton University student who is now a law professor at New York Law School in New York City. The court rejected the clubs' argument that men-only clubs are permitted as long as they sever their relationship with the Ivy League university. ``I'm really thrilled,'' Ms. Frank said from Washington, D.C. ``I'm glad that the court decided to stop discrimination at Princeton.'' Lawyers for the eating clubs could not be immediately reached for comment. Ms. Frank's suit was against the Ivy Club and the Tiger Inn, the only two among the university's 13 private eating clubs that exclude women. Princeton began admitting women in 1969. Earlier this year, the two clubs voted to admit women, but two more rounds of voting must be conducted next year before women can join. Most juniors and seniors eat at the clubs, housed near the Princeton campus. ``It is undisputed that the clubs had a general policy that excluded females from consideration as members,'' the high court said. ``It is also undisputed that the clubs applied this policy to Frank'' when she tried to join the clubs. In arguing the case before the Supreme Court, attorneys for the two clubs had maintained that the clubs were private and not part of Princeton University. They said that gave the clubs the right to choose their membership. But Ms. Frank argued that the university has promoted the clubs in its publications, and added that Princeton has relied on them since more than 75 percent of the upperclassmen at the school eat at the clubs. The Supreme Court ruling upheld a 1987 decision by the New Jersey Division on Civil Rights which ordered the clubs to begin admitting women. That decision had been overturned by the Appellate Division of Superior Court, which granted the clubs' request for a new hearing because of prodecural errors. But the Supreme Court said the clubs had already been afforded their administrative due process and it did not see any disputed facts. Frank had sued a third eating club but that club began admitting women in 1986 and settled with Ms. Frank for $20,000. The university was also named in the suit but also settled in 1986, paying Ms. Frank $27,500 in legal fees and pledging to dissociate itself from sexually segregated clubs. Ms. Frank said she pursued the case because its outcome has implications beyond Princeton. ``For better or for worse, people who graduate from Princeton tend to take positions in leadership,'' Ms. Frank said. ``If they learn while they are students at Princeton that discrimination is acceptable then they are going to take that lesson with them. I don't want them to learn that lesson.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He'll Discuss Changes in NATO Nuclear Strategy
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today that he would discuss a proposal to use NATO nuclear forces only as a last resort when the allies meet in London later this week. Bush refused to confirm that the United States was offering such a proposal. But when asked about reports that a change in nuclear strategy was on the agenda, he said, ``I'm ready to discuss that with them.'' ``As things change we want to be sure that evrybody understands that NATO is the stabilizing factor that we think it should be and will be,'' he told reporters after meeting with top advisers at his seaside vacation home. Continuing the pre-summit talks with allied leaders in advance of the NATO, Bush said that he had talked this morning to the prime ministers of Denmark and Belgium. He said he didn't talk to them about the matter of NATO's so-called flexible response strategy of using nuclear weapons in a mix with conventional arms. ``I didn't go into that specific,'' he said. ``But I think the general approach that we're proposing seems to be getting wide acceptance.'' He said he wants to underscore that a unified Germany belonging to NATO is not a threat to the Soviet Union. ``If there are certain things that we can do to expand NATO's role that drives that point home, so much the better,'' he said. In a briefing with top aides and Cabinet members today, Bush shifted gears from the NATO meeting to next week's economic summit of seven industrialized nations. Bush said ``we're in good shape for that meeting,'' and that trade issues would be particularly prominent. He said he also expected a ``good discussion of the environment,'' and that he would continue to reject U.S. participation in economic aid programs for the Soviet Union until it reforms its own market practices and halts aid to Marxist Cuba. Bush spent much of Monday preparing for the two-day NATO summit meeting in London, which begins Thursday. Bush said after a briefing session with Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, Vice President Dan Quayle and others, that ``we're in pretty good shape on it now.'' According to administration officials, Bush intends to urge the allies to overhaul the NATO defense strategy by using nuclear weapons only as a last resort in a war situation. Bush also is ready to consider scrapping the 1,470 U.S. nuclear-tipped artillery shells now based mostly in West Germany and reducing or eliminating an arsenal of 1,560 U.S. nuclear bombs deployed in seven NATO countries, the officials told The Associated Press. He said Monday before setting out to play golf with Quayle that, ``there will be some very interesting developments'' at the NATO meeting this week, but nothing he considers of ``bombshell dimension.'' National security adviser Brent Scowcroft told reporters that arms control issues will be on the agenda in London. The administration intends to propose that the allies eliminate nuclear stockpiles, including artillery shells now deployed in West Germany, from Europe if the Soviets completely withdraw their troops from foreign soil, according to administration officials who insisted on anonymity. Today's session included Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, Trade Representative Carla Hills, Quayle and other officials who are preparing for the economic summit July 9-11. The participants intended to review with Bush the draft communique they want to issue at the end of the economic summit. It has been prepared in consultations with the other participating nations. Among the topics they will prepare is how to address the matter of Western economic aid to help the Soviet Union's flagging economy. Bush has said he is not particularly interested in that idea, but has no objections if the other nations want to help. Leaders of the 12-member European Community already have agreed in principle to provide some form of financial help to Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev on the basis that his efforts to reform his economy help the Western world as well. Bush told reporters last week he has a hard time seeing large aid packages going to the Soviet Union ``when they're spending 18 percent of their gross national product on military and when they're spending an estimated $5 billion (annually) in Cuba?'' Bush and his aides today also were to discuss prospects for environmental agreements at the economic summit. Several European nations have committed themselves to reducing or stabilizing carbon dioxide emissions by the end of the decade to cut down on the global warming trend. The Bush administration has maintained that more research is needed on the warming of the earth before taking such measures. Also up for possible discussion on the environmental front is how to deal with worldwide deforestation and the destruction of tropical rain forests due to development. Bush is spending a six-day long holiday weekend at his Maine vacation home before departing Wednesday night for London. He was to watch early fireworks tonight from a Coast Guard cutter offshore from his Walker's Point home.

DOC.HEAD: May Contain Remains of 40,000 Communist Victims, Newspaper Says
DOC.TEXT: A mass grave discovered last week in northern Yugoslavia may contain the remains of 40,000 people executed by victorious Communists in 1945, a newspaper reported Tuesday. Most appear to have been Ustasha soldiers of the defeated Nazi puppet state of Croatia, Vjesnik said. The victims apparently were executed after surrendering to Communist partisans or being deported to Yugoslavia by the Western allies from Austria, where many had sought refuge at the end of World War II. The Ustashas were an elite, SS-type military unit accused of murdering hundreds of thousands of Jews, Serbs and Gypsies after the so-called Independent State of Croatia was created under German auspices in 1941. Piles of bones, estimated to be up to 10 yards deep in places, were found in a 40-yard-long pit near the village of Sosice, about 45 miles west of the Croatian capital of Zagreb. The Vjesnik story was illustrated with large photographs of a cave at the bottom of the pit filled with skulls and human bones. Townspeople and former partisans quoted by the daily said that truckloads of wounded Croatian soldiers, members of the Ustasha youth movement, army nurses and other people were brought to the site. They then were shot and thrown one by one into the narrow pit. Earlier reports had estimated the dead in the thousands but the Vjesnik account was the first to put a possible figure on remains in the grave. While not clarifying how it arrived at 40,000 victims, Vjesnik quoted townspeople as saying that for months trucks loaded with captives drove toward the pit and returned empty. A center-right party, the Croatian Democratic Union, assumed power in Croatia last month after trouncing the ruling Communists in the first multiparty elections in 45 years. Authorities are investigating reports of mass executions at several sites in 1945 of Ustashas and Chetniks, royalist guerrillas who fought both the Germans and the Communists in a three-sided war.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Money: $7 Million and Counting
With AM-Mandela-Money
DOC.TEXT: Here is a city-by-city list of estimated fund-raising by the Nelson Mandela tour:

NEW YORK: Fund-raising income: $1.75 million, expected to rise to nearly $2 million. Major events: Stadium rally, $700,000 in ticket sales; celebrity reception, $497,000 in donations; ecumenical donations, $250,000; business reception, $180,000. Local fund-raising expenses: About $150,000. Municipal expenses: $2.6 million, including $2 million in police overtime. BOSTON: Fund-raising income: About $500,000. Major events: $350,000 at a $5,000 per-couple reception; $30,000 in T-shirt sales; about $20,000 at a walk-a-thon. Local fund-raising expenses: About $150,000. Municipal expenses: About $130,000, including $110,000 in police overtime. WASHINGTON: Fund-raising income: About $150,000. Local fund-raising expenses: Less than income. Municipal expenses: Undetermined. ATLANTA: Fund-raising income: Projected at about $400,000. Major events: stadium rally, about $200,000; luncheon, about $100,000; reception, about $100,000. Local fund-raising expenses: Undetermined, expected to be low. Municipal expenses: Perhaps $100,000 in police overtime. MIAMI: Fund-raising income: About $300,000 donated by members of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, which Mandela addressed. (Union earlier gave $150,000 to help fund tour). Municipal expenses: About $20,000 in police overtime. DETROIT: Fund-raising income: About $1.4 million. Local fund-raising expenses: Less than $250,000. Municipal expenses: Undetermined. LOS ANGELES: Fund-raising income: About $1.7 million. Major events: $1.2 million at celebrity fund-raiser; $500,000 at Coliseum rally. Municipal expenses: Undetermined. OAKLAND, Calif.: Fund-raising income: About $900,000. Major events: $300,000 at $100-per-plate dinner; $295,000 at $2,500-per person reception; $290,000 at Coliseum rally. Municipal expenses: Undetermined.

DOC.HEAD: Alaska Officials Dispute Environmental Group's Claims
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `It was...', to CORRECT that takeover covers all federally owned land, which comprises two-thirds of the state, sted two-thirds of federal land. SUBS last graf to CORRECT that refuge includes a coastal plan sted is a coastal plain.
DOC.TEXT: Alaska officials angrily rejected an environmental group's call for more federal restrictions to protect the state's wilderness. The Wilderness Society issued a report Monday that called the decade-old Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act a ``great disappointment.'' It accused the Bush administration of putting development interests ahead of the act's mandate to protect wildlife. The report proposed congressional hearings, a ban on oil and gas exploration in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge and passage of federal oil-spill legislation. ``From what I've seen of it, this report appears to be a cursory look by people who don't live in Alaska at a law which Alaskans have to live with every day,'' Gov. Steve Cowper said. ``We appreciate the Wilderness Society joining the call for federal oil-spill legislation. But we don't agree that the federal government needs to be even more involved in the lives of Alaskans.'' When the act was signed into law by President Carter in 1980, it was praised by environmentalists as one of the most ambitious preservation laws ever. It set aside 104.3 million acres of national parks, wildlife refuges and other protected areas in the nation's largest state. The report also urged a permanent federal takeover of fish and game management on Alaska's public lands. It was released one day after Washington took over game management on all federally owned land in Alaska _ two-thirds of the state. The takeover resulted from a conflict between state law and the federal act, which required the state to give rural Alaskans priority for subsistence use of fish and game. ``I'm not surprised by any of the allegations by this organization,'' said Rep. Don Young, R-Alaska. ``They want more wilderness, more federal enforcement of regulations as they interpret the laws, more restrictions on every type of land use,'' he said. ``The only thing these environmental elitists want less of is access by Alaskans to federal lands.'' The report says oil development in the refuge and logging in the Tongass National Forest are the most serious threats to Alaska's public lands. The group wants Congress to designate the refuge a wilderness to prevent development. The refuge, in the state's remote northeastern corner, includes a coastal plain oil companies see as a potential source of oil to replace the diminishing flow from Alaska's huge Prudhoe Bay field. Congress was considering authorizing further exploration and development there before the Exxon Valdez oil spill last year.

DOC.HEAD: Lost City Contract After Turned Down Sexual Favor: Moore
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Combines pvs with editing.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Barry's Allies, Bjt
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Rasheeda Moore, who participated in an FBI sting against Mayor Marion Barry, testified today that she lost a city contract in 1988 because she refused his request for a sexual favor. Testifying for the fifth day at the mayor's drug and perjury trial, Moore said that when she rejected Barry's overture, he said, ``you refuse, therefore you refuse the contract.'' Moore testified that in 1986, when she was romantically involved with Barry, her city contract for a summer youth program was approved speedily ``after the mayor told me it would be.'' The city spent more than $180,000 on ``Project Me,'' a modeling program designed by Moore to build self-esteem. But in 1988, just after her affair with Barry had ended, she went to a room at the Vista Hotel where she met with Barry and another woman, Maria McCarthy, Moore testified. ``Mr. Barry suggested I put Maria McCarthy in charge of the administrative end'' of Project Me, Moore said in response to questions by assistant U.S. attorney Judith Retchin. ``We were using drugs,'' testified Moore. After McCarthy left, Barry asked Moore to join him. ``Was there a sexual request?'' said Retchin. ``Yes,'' Moore said on re-direct examination by the prosecution. ``Did you comply?'' asked Retchin. ``No,'' said Moore. Barry at that point said ``you refuse, therefore you refuse the contract,'' Moore testified. She said that Barry told her that ``because I refused'' his request for a sexual favor, he would be unable to ``promise (her) the contract this year. The program was not renewed. Moore's testimony about the contract followed her cross-examination by Barry's lawyer, R. Kenneth Mundy, that began last Thursday. Mundy said Moore, who participated in an FBI sting against the mayor, has received more than $32,000 in government aid. He suggested she may be lying for the FBI. Moore testified she and Barry had used drugs together more than 100 times, but ``can you give me a month, a day and a year for ... these ... episodes?'' asked Mundy. ``Tell us a date that you're positive of,'' he challenged. Mundy suggested Moore was being vague about dates of the alleged drug use because she is afraid the defense will find that she is giving perjured testimony. Barry travels a lot and Moore is ``concerned that he was not even in town'' on days when she said the two used drugs together in Washington, said Mundy. ``No, I am not,'' said Moore. The mayor has ``a very busy schedule, being out of town and being on trips and is that a reason you cannot be more precise?'' asked Mundy. ``No,'' insisted Moore. She said, as she has since last Thursday when her cross-examination began, that she is just ``not good with dates.'' Mundy maintained that Moore, who is in the government's witness protection program, has received $32,000 from the government since January. ``I haven't,'' said Moore. But she said the FBI paid for her and her three children to come to Washington, put her up in hotels and paid for her clothes. She said she ``has no idea'' how much the government has spent on her. On Monday, Barry's lawyer said Moore provided ``the pipe ... the light and the know-how'' for Barry to use crack. He made the assertion as he replayed at the trial a videotape of the FBI sting. Barry's lawyer is using the government's videotaped evidence in an attempt to show that the mayor was entrapped by the FBI into smoking crack cocaine. The tape was first played publicly last week by the prosecution. It pertains to one of the 10 misdemeanor charges accusing Barry of cocaine possession. He also is accused of conspiracy and three counts of lying to a federal grand jury about his involvement with drugs. Barry seven times declined Moore's offer to use drugs during the sting, Mundy said as he went over the transcript of the Jan. 18 hotel room meeting between the mayor and Moore. ``You provided the encouragement by bringing the subject up ad nauseam,'' Mundy told Moore, a former Barry girlfriend. Moore didn't deny Mundy's suggestion that she kept bringing up the subject of drugs. But she said Barry readily engaged in discussing drugs and initiated talk about them himself on more than one occasion in the hotel room. Any hesitance on Barry's part stemmed from his suspicions that something was amiss, she said. On the videotape, Barry said he didn't know how the crack pipe worked and that he had never smoked crack before, Mundy pointed out. Barry was suspicious of a ``hotel room situation'' and ``he felt intuitively something was going on'' when he walked into the hotel room, said Moore. ``He was guarding his conversation.'' Then ``why did he go on and hit the pipe?'' Mundy asked. ``Because he had a desire to,'' Moore replied. Barry, who was treated at two clinics following his arrest in the sting, said outside the courtroom that he has been free of any substance abuse for 163 days. He declined to say whether he was treated for cocaine abuse. He has admitted to having problems with alcohol and prescription drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Latest Tensions in Albania Follow Reform Moves
With AM-Albania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The shootings reported in the Albanian capital come at a time when that hard-line Communist nation has sought to implement cautious reforms and pledged to respect human rights. Reforms were initiated in May, following a year of popular upheaval that ousted orthodox Communist governments from most Eastern European nations. Now, scores of Albanians, apparently unimpressed with the scope of the reforms, have fled to Western embassies in the last few days in the largest known show of defiance against 45 years of Stalinist rule. The Albanian government on Tuesday acknowledged that rioting had broken out. Barely two weeks ago, the Albanian parliament, a rubber-stamp body for Communist policy, approved new travel regulations under which all citizens over 16 were gven the right to own a passport, valid for five years. Such a concession would have been impossible under the late Communist leader, Enver Hoxha, whose 40-year rule ended with his death in 1985. The Tirana government, firmly committed to Marxism-Leninism as interpreted by Soviet dictator Josef Stalin, broke diplomatic ties with the Soviet Union and China after those countries moved away from what it considered orthodox communism. Britain and the United States severed ties with Tirana after Hoxha's Communist Party won elections in 1945 following a purge of anti-Communists. Ramiz Alia, who took over after Hoxha's death, slowly began to open up the tiny Balkan nation of 3 million, establishing diplomatic ties with dozens of countries while ruling out renewed ties with the superpowers. In May, after the changes in the Soviet bloc, Albania's Communist leaders began announcing cautious political, economic and foreign policy reforms and signaled willingness to re-establish ties with Washington and Moscow. Last month, the isolated nation indicated its wish to rejoin Europe, saying it would seek full membership in the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe that it had boycotted since its inception in 1975. In another sign of moderate change, a family of Albanians who had spent more than four years in the Italian Embassy in Tirana were allowed in May to travel to Rome. The economic changes in ALbania have largely been designed to improve food and energy supplies and beef up trade. But other reforms, such as the liberalized travel regulations, the abolition of the death penalty for defectors and the lifting of a ban on religious propaganda, appeared aimed both at appeasing the population and impressing foreign governments. Albanian officials have pledged to honor the tenets of the European Security Conference, including its human rights provisions. But despite the pledge of some reforms, Albanian leaders have so far remained opposed to any form of political pluralism. The latest tensions follow Yugoslav and Greek newspaper reports in January of unrest in the northern city of Shkoder and in the capital of Tirana. These could not be independently confirmed and were vehemently denied by high-ranking Albanian officials.

DOC.HEAD: Orders for Manufactured Goods Rebound from April Loss
DOC.TEXT: Orders to factories for manufactured goods in May regained their 2.1 percent loss of a month earlier, the government reported Tuesday, and analysts said industry may be starting to recover from its slump. ``The manufacturing sector seems to have gone through the worst and has a slight upward tilt,'' said Robert G. Dederick, chief economist with the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. ``But the real question is whether it's a false dawn and whether it will fade again.'' The Commerce Department said orders for both durable and non-durable goods rebounded 2.1 percent to a seasonally adjusted $240.9 billion. The size of the May increase had been expected by many analysts. At the same time, the size of the April decline was a slight improvement from the 2.3 percent drop first reported. It was the third gain in orders since they dropped 5.5 percent in January and their steepest decline since a 7.0 percent decrease in December 1974. All major categories advanced in May except non-durable orders, which were unchanged at $112.4 billion after inching up 0.2 percent in April. But analysts expressed concern over the strength of any manufacturing turnaround, saying much of it is coming from U.S. exports while demand from American consumers has weakened recently. Exports represented just 14.2 percent of the 1989 gross national product _ the nation's total output of goods and services _ while personal consumption contributed 64.2 percent. ``Another weakness that has really been making the industrial sector go sideways is capital spending,'' said Priscilla Trumbull, an economist with the WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. ``But we seem to be seeing a little bit of improvement there.'' Non-defense capital spending excluding aircraft edged up 0.1 percent in May after back-to-back 1.1 percent declines in the preceding two months. This category often is often viewed as a barometer of business investment plans. ``If this is part of a turnaround, it's still pretty much in the embryonic stage,'' said Gordon Richards, director of economic policy at the National Association of Manufacturers. Nevertheless, Richards and other analysts said the factory orders report was the latest of several suggesting the manufacturing slump may be about to reverse itself. Orders for durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last at least three years _ jumped 4.0 percent to $128.6 billion, nearly recovering the 4.1 percent decline in April. The often volatile defense orders also rose, up 19.2 percent to $10.0 billion after gains of 4.8 percent and 4.5 percent. Excluding the defense category, orders were up 1.5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Avoids Trap, Claims Bush Won
DOC.TEXT: It was apparently just a typical case of trying to make the boss look good when expert golfer Dan Quayle spread the word that President Bush had beat him on the links. ``He was just being pleasant, I'll bet,'' Bush said of his vice president on Tuesday. Quayle somewhat sheepishly told reporters. ``He won on the first tee.'' ``Won one hole. That's what he meant,'' Bush clarified. Quayle had told reporters on Monday when setting out to golf near Bush's seaside vacation home that he was ``destined to lose.'' Quayle is renowned in Washington for his expertise on the golf course. Bush on the other hand, is trying to improve his somewhat ragged game. When asked later Monday who won the game at the Cape Arundel Golf Course, Quayle said, ``The president won.'' Suspicion was widespread that he was speaking tongue in cheek. Asked about that by reporters Tuesday during a photo session outside Bush's seaside home, Quayle insisted ``the president won, as he should.''
