But Bush interjected that Quayle had played well, with six birdies _ ``that's pretty good golf.'' Told that Quayle had said he won, Bush said ``He was just being pleasant, I'll bet.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Say 800 in Assault on Liberian Capital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs with radio report that Monrovia quiet, streets empty; pickup 7th graf pvs, `The United...'
DOC.TEXT: About 800 Liberian rebels have attacked their capital and several thousand more were approaching to ``put an end'' to Liberian President Samuel Doe, a rebel source said today. The source, based near the Liberian border, said rebel leader Charles Taylor was at the front directing attacks on Monrovia, the Liberian capital. In Washington, officials said the United States was prepared to evacuate Doe if requested to do so. The rebel source said the fighters were preparing to attack the city center but so far had only taken areas on Monrovia's outskirts. The Christian missionary radio station ELWA, in its 5 p.m. news broadcast, said armed soldiers were stationed throughout Monrovia, but it made no mention of fresh fighting. The broadcast was monitored in Abidjan. Most city streets and public places were empty, the radio said, because people were afraid of fighting breaking out. The report said rebels controlled all roads in and out of Monrovia. Some of the advancing rebels were bringing up heavy artillery and mortars in case Doe put up a last stand in his heavily fortified executive mansion, the rebel source said. The source was reached by telephone from Abidjan and spoke on condition of anonymity. Rebels attacked Monrovia on Monday in a two-pronged offensive that cut all major land routes from the capital, according to a pool report filed by journalists there. International telephone and telex lines into the city were cut on Monday morning. The city's water and electricity supply also were cut after rebels captured their main facilities. The United States and other governments urged Doe to resign and leave the country, a condition the rebels have set for accepting a cease-fire. Four U.S. warships remained ``over the horizon'' off Liberia ready to evacuate Americans or Doe if requested to do so by the State Department, officials in Washington said. Defense Department spokesman Pete Williams said the Navy ships sent to the area May 31 were still in international waters. The Pentagon spokesman said the primary purpose of the Navy ships, which have about 2,500 sailors and Marines on board, is to evacuate Americans if needed. The State Department advised U.S. citizens on May 31 to leave Liberia because of deteriorating conditions, and some departed on chartered airline flights last month. In response to a question about possible evacuation of Doe, Williams said, ``If the State Department were to ask us to assist in moving President Doe, we would certainly be prepared to do what they asked us.'' Several countries have offered Doe asylum, including Nigeria and Togo. Doe, 40, a former master sergeant, has ruled Liberia since a bloody coup in April 1980. He ousted the descendents of freed American slaves who had ruled the West African country for more than a century. Doe initially won wide support, but subsequently was accused of brutal oppression of critics, suppressing the country's free press and mismanagement and corruption. The rebels, of the National Patriotic Front, invaded Liberia from the Ivory Coast Dec. 24, sweeping across the country with little resistance from Doe's forces. Government troops were accused of killing hundreds of kinsmen of the rebels in an effort to put down the invasion. The deaths increased support for the rebels, said reporters who visited the war zone. The rebels in turn were accused of killing members of tribes seen as supporting the president in revenge for the attacks on their kinsmen. Government resistance stiffened when the rebels got within 35 miles of Monrovia four weeks ago. But the rebels broke through to attack the capital in the last week, after refusing to attend a second round of church-mediated peace talks aimed at ending the war.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts From Ligachev Speech
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from the speech of Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev at the 28th Communist Party congress on Tuesday, as translated by The Associated Press. ``If everything remains at the current level, the situation with food supplies in the country will become even more critical. I am aware of the difficulty of finding a solution to the problem.'' ``We need to stick to public property as I think that it unites people's interests while private property separates them and without doubt leads to social differentiation in society.'' ``What was the original goal of perestroika (reform)? It was to use the full potential of socialism. I want to ask you, Does the selling of factories to private owners really help to uncover all possibilities of the socialist order? Of course not.'' ``We are not justified in forgetting about the class approach, which leads to our underestimating the class representation in the soviets (elected legislatures), underestimating the workers' and peasants' movement.'' ``There are forces in our country fighting against socialist order, against the Communist Party. They are acting with energy and drive. They have strong influence on some of the mass media. They applaud things that are directed toward the break-up of socialism in our country, at undermining the party, present them as innovations, as real perestroika. And often they shout about things directed toward renovation and consolidation of socialism, saying they are actions by conservative forces. ``My open, perhaps uncompromising position on true socialism and the role of the party, my principles (I am not afraid of looking immodest) have become the reason why I was placed in the center of the political struggle and portrayed as a conservative and almost an opponent of perestroika (reform). All means were used, as you know, including libel and horrible charges. ``It seems there are commands from some center to start abusing people on the principle that those who are not with us are against us. They have ... started attacks on the army which has finally started to defend itself. ``Comrades, I see no alternative to perestroika, renewal of the society. I do not think of myself as a conservative or a radical. I am just a realist and any limitless radicalism, improvisations, .. have done little for us in the five years of perestroika.'' ``The country really needs political stability. But there is talk lately that (Communist) party or no party, perestroika will continue. I think differently. ... I believe deeply that the party will remain a Marxist-Leninist, democratic, viable force.''

DOC.HEAD: Study Urges End to Military Blocs, Creation of Pan-European Group
With AM-West to the Rescue, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The NATO alliance is no longer needed to keep the peace in Europe and should be replaced by a ``security community'' of all European nations plus the United States, the Soviet Union and Canada, a private group said Tuesday. The proposal by the British American Security Information Council would do away with the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization and its Cold War rival, the Warsaw Pact, which has been fractured by the democracy movements in Eastern Europe. Replacing these military blocs would be a pan-European body based on the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, or CSCE, an existing organization comprised of the two superpowers, Canada and all European nations except Albania. Its main role now is to consider human rights and economic issues. The report said the CSCE should be broadened and given an explicit link to the United Nations. France and some other European governments already have suggested this, but the Bush administration says CSCE should not be a replacement for NATO. Questions about reshaping NATO's military and political roles are to be discussed at an alliance summit meeting Thursday and Friday in London. The leaders are not expected to take any steps toward dissolving the alliance; they are likely to say NATO will change but will remain the central security body for Europe. At a meeting last month, leaders of the seven-nation Warsaw Pact agreed to keep that alliance intact at least until the conclusion this fall of a study on ways of transforming its role. The proposal unveiled Tuesday has been endorsed by numerous European and American politicians, military experts and former government officials, said David Shorr, associated director of the group that published the report. Paul Warnke, a former director of the U.S. Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, told a news conference the proposal was ``a sensible blueprint for the future.'' Warnke said he believed NATO should be preserved only until a pan-European replacement organization is in place. He argued that the alliance will not be needed because the threat of a Soviet attack on Europe no longer exists. Among those endorsing the proposal, according to Shorr, is Pierre Harmel, the former Belgian foreign minister who initiated a landmark NATO study in 1967 that established the foundation for Western relations with the Soviet bloc through the 1980s. The new report said a pan-European security organization would have a permanent headquarters, perhaps in Berlin or Prague, Czechoslovakia, and an ``inner security council'' consisting of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and a reunified Germany. The organization would mediate disputes among European countries, serve as a negotiating forum for European disarmament and verify and monitor agreed arms reductions. Members would sign a treaty disavowing any threat or use of force against each other.

DOC.HEAD: UN Survey: Global Economy Slowing, But Industrial Economies Expanding
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Already sluggish global economic growth is likely to slow further in 1990, and growth in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union is virtually at a standstill, according to a U.N. report released Tuesday. The 1990 World Economic Survey by the U.N. Department of International Economic and Social Affairs said world economic output increased by 3.1 percent in 1989, compared with 4.4 percent in 1988. It noted diversity in economic performance and said that industrialized market economies continued to expand, growing by 3.5 percent. Although that was lower than the 4.3 percent in 1988, it was stronger than had been expected, the report said. But the developing world as a whole, it said, suffered a downturn in economic growth in 1989, dropping from 4.5 percent in 1988 to 3.4 percent in 1989. Economic performance varied greatly by region. The report agreed in general with the findings of the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, which said last week that the economies of the industrialized world remain on a steady course. Like the OECD report, it warned against inflation, especially in East European countries that are changing from state-controlled to market economies. ``Economic growth in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union came to a virtual halt in 1989,'' it said, adding that output increased by only 1.2 percent. U.N. economists said they did not expect a bright picture for the immediate future in countries restructuring their economies, although the long-term prospects could improve with painful reform. ``The danger of rapid inflation in the reforming socialist countries is a major concern,'' it said, ``requiring prudent monetary and fiscal policies during the transition to more market-oriented economies.'' World trade, it said, maintained considerable buoyance and increased by 6.7 percent in 1989. It was the fifth consecutive year in which the increase in world trade exceeded the increase in world output, the report said. It observed that the ``Brady Plan,'' named for former Treasury Secretary Nicolas Brady, ``is not solving the debt problem of the heavily indebted countries.'' In 1989, it said, Latin America made a net transfer of $28 billion in financial resources to other countries. Africa's net receipts of financial resources amounted to only $3 billion in 1989, a decline of $1 billion from the previous year. In several Latin American countries hyperinflation is a serious problem, it said, and stabilization policies are likely to prove costly in the short term. Long-term prospects are uncertain. The U.N. survey also predicted that world oil consumption will reach a record high in 1990 and the gap between sustainable production capacity and demand will narrow. The survey said developing countries as a group experienced a sharp slowdown in economic growth in 1989. Their increase in output declined from 4.5 percent in 1988 to 3.4 percent in 1989. The economies of South and East Asia grew by 6.2 percent, compared with 8.2 percent in 1988, the survey said. China's growth rate delined sharply, from 11.4 percent in 1988 to 3.9 percent in 1989. Latin America and the Caribbean saw only a 0.7 percent increase and per capita output fell for the second consecutive year. Inflation was unprecedented in the region. In Africa, economies expanded by 2.8 percent in 1989, below the rate of population growth, and per capita output fell as a result. In West Asia, economic recovery continued with a 2.5 percent growth rate. Economic stabilization measures stalled growth in Mediterranean countries. The survey proposed establishment of a Central European Payments Union, similar to the European Payments Union established after World War II, as a temporary measure to assist reforming Eastern European countries in their transition to market-oriented economies with convertible currencies. ``Inflation is an inevitable consequence of the market-oriented economic reform under way in the socialist countries,'' the survey said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used AM-Panama-Noriega, a0698, a0707 or a0758, of July 2 under a Panama City dateline, are asked to use the following.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press erroneously reported July 2 that Panamanian news reports said the government of Panama is suing former Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega for more than $5 million. In fact, the reports estimated the figure at over $5 billion. In addition, the name of a law firm was misspelled in the story. The correct name of the firm is Williams and Connolly.

DOC.HEAD: Technicians Reject AP Contract Offer
DOC.TEXT: Technical employees of The Associated Press have rejected a proposed two-year contract with the news agency, their union said Tuesday. The union and the AP agreed to meet again Monday. James Peecook, president of Local 1314 of the Communications Workers of America, said members overwhelmingly rejected the contract. He said the vote count would not be released. AP technicians have been working under a contract extension since early last month, when negotiators agreed to submit a two-year contract proposal to a ratification vote. The union, however, described the pact as inadequate and urged members to reject it. D. Byron Yake, AP's director of human resources, said the company would extend the terms of the expired contract through Monday's meeting. Local 1314 represents about 300 AP technicians. The contract calls for a ``managed care'' approach to control the cost of the medical plan. It also proposes weekly pay increases of $23.50 for top-scale technicians in the first year and $24 in the second, bringing weekly top-scale technician salaries to $612 in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Fighting Rages in Liberia; US Officials See Early Demise for Doe
DOC.TEXT: As heavy fighting raged northeast of the Liberian capital of Monrovia on Tuesday, U.S. officials said they believed that the government of President Samuel K. Doe could collapse in a matter of days. The officials, asking not to be identified, said that there had been a number of desertions from the elite unit that protects Doe and that his hold on power was becoming more precarious by the day. Two officials said Doe's demise could come before the weekend. He has ruled Liberia for more than a decade. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said there was fighting on both sides of the St. Paul River in addition to the combat northeast of Monrovia. The fighting was inhibiting communications out of Liberia. Meanwhile, a rebel source reached by telephone from neighboring Ivory Coast said about 800 rebels of Liberia's National Patriotic Front have begun an attack on Monrovia and several thousand more were approaching to ``put an end'' to Doe and his government. The source, based near the Liberian border, said rebel leader Charles Taylor was at the front directing attacks on the Liberian capital. Taylor launched his rebellion last Christmas eve, reportedly with help from Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi. It is not known whether Gadhafi has provided any assistance recently. At the Pentagon, spokesman Pete Williams said a Navy task force was standing ``over the horizon'' off Liberia ready to evacuate the estimated 795 Americans in Liberia if requested to do so by the State Department. ``We're considering all options, but a decision to evacuate has not yet been made,'' said Boucher at the State Department. There were no reports of injury to any Americans. Officials have said that the U.S. government is prepared to evacuate Doe if it is asked to do so. They said Togo, also in West Africa, has agreed to receive Doe if he is forced out of Liberia. Boucher said Monrovia was without water, electricity or telephone service. All main roads out of the capital were cut. Most of Doe's Cabinet and other senior administration officials have fled. Liberian and diplomatic sources said army chief of staff Lt. Gen. Henry Dubar resigned during the weekend. A dusk to dawn curfew was in effect. Boucher said a Voice of America transmitter is located behind rebel lines, but the rebel forces have not interfered with its operations. The new U.S. ambassador to Liberia, Peter De Vos, met with Doe on Sunday. On Monday, he met with the Vice President Harry Moniba and three other senior legislators, Boucher said. U.S. policy has been to support the formation through political negotiations of an interim government that would oversee a transition to democratic rule. Doe has offered a national unity government with participation by Taylor's group but the rebel leader has rejected the proposal. Taylor has repeatedly demanded that Doe resign before he and the rebels will stop their advance. There also have been official U.S. contacts with Taylor, a former Liberian government official who infiltrated the country six months ago with a small band of followers. Taylor has informed the U.S. envoys that if his movement ousts Doe, he will promote democracy and respect human rights. But officials have said they are not certain that Taylor will abide by those pledges. Taylor also has offered assurances that his forces will not harm Americans or other foreigners in Liberia, Boucher said. Other officials have said that U.S. envoys have called on Taylor to exercise maximum restraint because a bloodbath could have an impact on U.S. aid to Liberia, historically the largest recipients of American assistance in sub-Saharan Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Disappoints First-Time Delegate From Provinces
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The road from Minsk to Moscow proved longer than expected for Nikolai Shchesternev, who came to his first Communist Party congress seeking direction. He was disappointed. ``I expected an analysis of the situation, but it hasn't happened yet. It's all gray. I am not happy at all so far,'' Shchesternev told a reporter during a break Tuesday in the 28th congress of the Soviet Communist Party. The 38-year-old computer specialist from the capital of Byelorussia said in a wide-ranging interview that he came to the Kremlin Palace of Congresses hoping to find ideas on improving the lives of the employees in his enterprise, ideas that he said had been lacking in five years of perestroika. And he hoped for a chance to tell the Kremlin leadership some of the ideas bubbling up from the 4,400 members of the Communist Party cell that selected him from among 21 candidates. Shchesternev said party leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reform policies of glasnost and perestroika have not helped him as party secretary in the Consortium for Computer Production in the Byelorussian capital of Minsk. ``In five years we have not found the idea that allows us to pay people better or improve their living conditions and the speeches so far don't indicate that we have found it yet,'' Shchesternev complained. ``I am very pessimistic. I thought the report (Gorbachev's report to the congress) would concentrate on philosophical and economic principles, on how to lead the society, but there was none of that,'' he said. With his red-and-gold congress badge pinned to the lapel of his light grey suit, Shchesternev ressembles many of the other 4,656 delegates to the congress, although he is younger than most delegates. The average age is 46. He spends most of his time during breaks at the congress and in the evening at a nearby hotel with the other three delegates from his cell and the rest of the 171-member Byelorussian delegation. Shchesternev said many members of his delegation believe party policy should be formed on the basis of the experience of its members and not dictated from the top. ``If the leadership doesn't draw on the resources of those on the bottom, then the finale of this party is going to be a sorrowful affair,'' he said. He said he had closely followed events in neighboring Poland, where the Communist Party simply fell apart last year after failing to meet society's political and economic aspirations. Shchesternev doesn't believe he will ever have a chance to speak at this congress even though it will last at least eight more days. More than 400 delegates had deposited a white slip of paper in wooden urns scattered throughout the massive Palace of Congresses where the meeting is held saying they would like to speak. ``Unfortunately, I have no possibility to express myself, so we are going to choose somebody from our delegation to represent us to get the possibility to make ourselves heard,'' he said. Although the party has paid for Shchesternev's train tickets and his hotel room in Moscow, the congress appears to be a pretty sober affair even after the formal sessions are over. ``We spend the evening meeting in our delegations and work on the results and look toward the future. There isn't much time for anything else,'' Shchesternev said.

DOC.HEAD: American Indians Pleased But Cautious About Mandela Offer to Return
DOC.TEXT: American Indian leaders say they're pleased by Nelson Mandela's promise to return to the United States this fall and visit them, but some also say he shouldn't assume their situation is the same as that of South African blacks. ``Before Mr. Mandela can help the Indians, he's got to understand the Indian tribes and their relation to the United States,'' Mescalero Apache President Wendell Chino said after hearing about Mandela's offer. ``It's not as simple as it looks,'' Chino said. ``The situation of the Indian people is totally different.'' Mandela made his announcement Saturday, on the last day of his 11-day U.S. trip. He told 58,000 people at a rally in Oakland, Calif., that he would return in October to visit Indian reservations and ``exchange views as to what I can do to help them in their struggle.'' ``The Indian people have written to me and explained their problems, and it is but natural that I should respond to that by seeing them as I proposed to do,'' Mandela said. The offer apparently had its origins in an invitation from two women who met him at the Oakland airport and delivered an invitation and gifts _ a sacred blanket, a shawl for Mandela's wife, Winnie, and some traditional medicine. ``We told him that we share many of the same problems of his country and would like to have the opportunity to share them with him,'' said Betty Cooper, director of the non-profit Native American Alcoholism Program in Oakland. Sally Gallegos, the executive director of the Oakland-based Consortium of United Indian Nations, said the two weren't prepared for Mandela to take them up on the offer. ``It was a shock,'' Gallegos said. ``The tribes had a concern to make known to Mandela _ that we are here.'' Gallegos and Cooper were attending a conference in San Francisco sponsored by Families in Recovery, an organization that mainly serves Indian drug addicts and alcoholics and their families. They and others at the meeting said Indians were dismayed that they were not invited to officially receive the South African leader despite the parallels between their plight and that of blacks under the South African system of apartheid. ``Nelson Mandela is as much a symbol as a reality, and that symbol for us is one of disenfranchisement, oppression and his ultimate victory,'' said John Perez, an Apache representing the Life Plus Foundation. American-Indian leaders generally agreed that a visit by Mandela could help them highlight problems in their communities _ poverty and poor education among them. ``The problems are so serious that I think any kind of public attention will be helpful,'' said Gary Kimble, director of the Association on American Indian Affairs, an Indian rights organization based in New York. Chino, the Mescalaro Apache leader, agreed that a Mandela visit would be good for Indians. ``I think what's going to happen is the United States is going to be grossly embarrassed if Mandela comes back and exposes the paternalism, broken promises and the erosion of various treaty obligations,'' Chino said Monday. But some Indian leaders also agreed with Chino's point that there are vast differences between Indians and South African blacks. ``The difference I think is that nobody is intentionally preventing Indians from becoming part of the legislature,'' said Rep. Ben Nighthorse Campbell, D-Colo., the only American Indian in Congress. ``In South Africa, they virtually lock black people out of running from office.'' And others have taken a skeptical approach to the entire matter. ``Mr. Mandela's going to have enough problems of his own in South Africa to just come back here and help us,'' said Wayne Ducheneaux of Eagle Butte, S.D., president of the National Congress of American Indians. ``We'll wait to see what this means.''

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Blame Pilot in USAir Crash
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New with editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Federal safety investigators said today that the captain of USAir Flight 5050 probably caused the crash of his jetliner by failing to respond adequately to problems during takeoff. The National Transportation Safety Board, in a 4-0 vote, also said the plane's problems began with an erroneously set rudder control that the pilot failed to detect. It said it could not determine how the control was wrongly set. The board said the probable cause of the crash was ``the captain's failure to exercise his command authority in a timely manner to reject the takeoff or take sufficient control to continue the takeoff.'' It also cited his failure to detect the rudder problem. Two of the 57 passengers aboard the plane were killed when it skidded off the end of the LaGuardia airport runway Sept. 20. All six crew members survived. Board member Jim Burnett moved to also blame USAir for failing to staff the plane with an ``adequately prepared and seasoned flight crew.'' But other board members rejected that proposal, saying the crew members met all regulatory requirements. ``We are putting a tremendous burden on one individual in a very complex system,'' said board member John Lauber. But he said this was justified because there were so many lapses in the pilot's performance, including his decision to let an inexperienced co-pilot control the takeoff. Bob Benzon, staff investigator in charge of the crash, said earlier the plane's rudder trim was set for full left rudder. But, he said, ``Enough rudder authority remained to fully control the aircraft during takeoff and in the air.'' The Federal Aviation Administration suspended the flight certificates of USAir pilot Michael Martin and copilot Constantine Kleissas, who was controlling the takeoff of a Boeing 737 passenger flight for the first time. The Air Line Pilots Association protested the actions as ``totally unwarranted.'' ALPA official Tom Kraemer said later the decision was a ``total travesty'' and the board should have blamed the design of the rudder control of the Boeing 737. But both Martin and Kleissas dropped appeals of the suspension and can fly again if they pass recertification tests. The FAA said Martin ``does not possess the care, skill, judgment and responsibility'' of a commercial pilot and cited his failure to fully complete a pre-takeoff checklist and perform other required actions on the taxiway before he ordered the takeoff aborted. Crash investigators said the rudder was erroneously set all the way to the left, causing the plane to drift to the side during the takeoff attempt, although cockpit communication tapes showed the pilots made all the proper checks. In February, the FAA ordered a Boeing-designed change in the control panels of 737s to prevent accidental movement of a rudder trim control knob that could reduce the pilot's ability to control the plane. The changes cost about $830 per plane and affected 641 Boeing 737-300 and 737-400 models worldwide. Although FAA safety orders are not mandatory for foreign carriers, they usually comply. Boeing began work to redesign the cockpit controls before the crash, following reports that the rudder-trim knobs could be affected by visitors in the cockpit placing their feet on the console or a pilot throwing down a manual. The NTSB conducted a hearing in New York on the USAir crash, taking testimony on rudder control design, cockpit crew training, crew coordination, the effects of the USAir-Piedmont merger, runway design, and FAA scrutiny of USAir operations.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: The Boy Scouts of America will honor singer-songwriter Michael Jackson with a new humanitarian award in his name. ``The prestigious award was created and named for Michael Jackson in recognition of his humanitarian effort for all mankind,'' the Los Angeles Area Council of the Boy Scouts of America said Monday. Jackson, 31, has raised thousands of dollars for such charities as the Make-A-Wish Foundation, The Prince's Trust, the United Negro College Fund and Child Help USA. Michael Eisner, chairman of the Walt Disney Co., will preside over a Sept. 14 dinner at which the reclusive pop star will receive the Michael Jackson Good Scout Humanitarian Award. Future candidates for the award will be selected by the Boy Scouts and officials at Jackson's company, MJJ Productions.

Less than thunderous reviews for the stock car racing movie ``Days of Thunder'' haven't diminished Tom Cruise's pride in his starring vehicle. ``I don't read reviews, even the good ones. They don't affect me or the film,'' he said Monday. ``A lot of filmmakers whom I respect have called me to say how much they liked the movie. They were actually surprised.'' ``Days of Thunder'' was No. 1 at the weekend box office but grossed $15.5 million, a slower start than ``Dick Tracy,'' ``Total Recall,'' ``Another 48 HRS.,'' ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles'' and ``Back to the Future Part III.'' ``You can buy yourself an opening by putting your picture in 3,500 theaters and spending a lot of money,'' Cruise said. ``The important thing is to have `legs,''' the industry term for staying power. ``The exit polls for `Days of Thunder' have been fantastic,'' he said. ``I'm very happy with the reaction to the film when I've seen it in theaters.'' Cruise, an amateur stock car racer who has a financial interest in the film, conceived the story four years ago. ``I studied all the past race movies I could find,'' he said. ``I found different things in each of them but none of them took the spirit of the driver and developed it. That's what we tried to do.''

Former Prime Minister Menachem Begin was in good condition Tuesday after a two-hour operation on a broken right hip, hospital officials said. Devorah Weissman, spokeswoman for Jerusalem's Shaarei Tzedek Hospital, said Begin would be moved to the orthopedic ward on Wednesday. He is expected to make a complete recovery, said the hospital's director, Dr. Yonathon Halevy. Begin, 76, tripped and fell in his living room, Ms. Weissman said. The bone was vulnerable from a earlier break, when Begin fell in the bathroom of his home while he was prime minister in 1981. Tuesday's hospitalization was the second for the former prime minister at Shaarei Tzedek this year. He was admitted with pneumonia on May 16 and released two weeks later. Begin, who founded the right-wing Herut Party, the precursor to the Likud bloc that now heads the government, stepped down as premier in September 1983 without explanation. Since his resignation, Begin has lived in seclusion.

Prince Felipe, the crown prince of Spain, was left alone at the helm of a racing yacht Tuesday when his mischievous crew suddenly scurried below deck. Felipe, 22, showed no concern, but his bemused smile delighted the contingent of Spanish photographers snapping the prince's every move from an accompanying news media boat. ``It certainly caught His Highness by surprise,'' said David Barnes, the skipper of KZ7, a 12-meter yacht that challenged for the America's Cup off western Australia 3{ years ago. ``He thought it was a great joke, and called out that he would give us a yell if he got into trouble.'' Felipe, heir to the throne, hopes to compete in the 1992 Olympic Games at Barcelona. His father, King Juan Carlos, has twice represented Spain as an Olympic yachtsman and has competed in two Fastnet races off England.

The prosecution of the 2 Live Crew rappers charged with participating in an obscene performance has hit a snag, a defense lawyer says: The videotape of their show is too garbled to understand. ``It's terrible, and you can't make out the words,'' said Allen Jacobi, the group's attorney. Broward County deputies made the tape last month, two days after U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez ruled that their album ``As Nasty as They Wanna Be'' was obscene. Band members Luther Campbell, Mark Ross and Chris Wongwon, and Fort Lauderdale record store owner Charles Freeman, who sold their album, were formally charged Tuesday. The rappers, arrested after an adults-only concert on June 10, face up to one year in jail and a $1,000 fine if convicted, prosecutors said. David Hobbs, 2 Live Crew's disc jockey, does not vocalize the group's lyrics and was not charged.

DOC.HEAD: Descendants Tip Coonskin Cap to Memory of Famed Frontiersman
LaserPhoto DN2
DOC.TEXT: Davy Crockett probably wasn't born on a mountaintop in Tennessee. And nobody really thinks he shot a bear when he was only 3. But that doesn't take anything away from the legend, at least for the 180 Crockett descendants gathering in Texas this week. ``Those kinds of things are interesting to read about, but they don't necessarily reflect the real David Crockett,'' said Leonard Stasney, one of the Crockett descendants holding their fifth biennial reunion at this town, 30 miles southwest of Fort Worth. Davy's widow settled in Granbury after his death at the battle of the Alamo in San Antonio in 1836. ``The myth was bigger than the man,'' said descendant Sandra Weaver of Granbury, who wore a cloth Crockett doll with a real coon tail on the cap, the whole thing pinned to her shoulder like a huge corsage. Ms. Weaver and Crockett kin traded tales about their famous ancestor Tuesday at the clan picnic, swapped gossip and argued over the best place to get a genuine coonskin cap. They debated how often a fighter could fire the muskets of Davy's day and whether Crockett was killed in action or, as some historians say, executed by the Mexicans after surrendering the Alamo. ``Davy Crockett went down swinging a rifle _ he wasn't no coward,'' insisted Charles Edward Crockett Sr. of Falls City, Ore. ``It just doesn't matter,'' Ms. Weaver said. ``All the men who died at the Alamo were heroes.'' For the descendants gathered at Granbury's Plantation Inn, it's the search for a ``real'' Davy Crockett that matters most. And according to them, that's not the Davy Crockett a generation of Americans knew from the Disney TV series that made the buckskin-clad actor Fess Parker an instant celebrity and prompted millions of youngsters to buy coonskin caps. The show became one of the biggest overnight hits in television history. Ninety million people watched the TV Davy swing his rifle as Santa Anna's troops attacked the Alamo, according to Disney productions. ``The Ballad of Davy Crockett,'' the theme song of the series, sold 18 million copies in 1955, Billboard said. Joy Bland, the new president of the descendants' group, dismisses all that as Hollywood glamour. ``They don't stick to the real facts. I never could sit through the whole program. It was awful,'' said Ms. Bland, of Paris, Tenn. ``The clothing was too modern; the story line was unrealistic.'' Only one descendant donned a coonskin cap for the reunion, and he was in period costume to demonstrate the rifles and muskets of Crockett's era. About 200 people belong to the non-profit corporation Descendants of David Crockett, based in Tennessee. Members must be blood relations to Crockett. Associate memberships are extended to cousins, historians and others who revere the pioneer. ``It's kind of exciting to talk to all the people that you are related to that you don't really know,'' Stasney said. ``It's just exciting to know that we can share the little bits and pieces of information and learn a little more about who we are.'' Some said it's simply a relief to tell people they're Crockett descendants and be believed. Toni Daigle of Whitecastle, La., said she takes pictures and documents to her children's school to convince classmates they really are related to the famous frontiersman. ``It's hard,'' Ms. Daigle said, ``because some other kids come up and say, ``Oh yeah _ I'm kin to Abraham Lincoln, too.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Gets 3-Year Sentence in IRA Gun-Running Conspiracy
LaserPhoto MY1
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge sentenced a print shop owner Tuesday to three years in prison for plotting to ship arms to Ireland. Brian Joseph Fleming, 32, was caught in a ``sting'' after he and another man tried to purchase restricted weapons, including M-16s, from undercover agents. Evidence linked the two to a group called Fianna Eireann, which Northern Ireland's top police officer testified is the youth brigade of the outlawed Irish Republican Army. Fleming's co-conspirator, Charles Farrell Malone, 63, of San Francisco, was sentenced June 25 to a 2{-year prison term and three years' probation. In addition to the three-year prison term, Fleming, of Enterprise, was fined $6,000 and placed on three years' probation. At the sentencing hearing, U.S. District Judge Robert Varner told Fleming that ``if enough people in the country are shipping arms to any revolutionary forces, it's the sort of thing that could involve this country in a war.'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Charles Niven said authorities never traced any weapons from Fleming to groups associated with the IRA. ``He was attempting to do it,'' Niven said. Fleming was questioned by federal agents earlier this year in connection with an investigation into the mail-bomb slaying of a federal judge in Birmingham and a civil rights lawyer in Savannah, Ga. Federal agents later said there was no connection between the two cases. No one has been charged in the mail bombings.

DOC.HEAD: Geese Tagged to Monitor Radiation
With AM-Nuclear Waste, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Scientists have tagged about 500 geese in a program to reduce the chances a hunter will bag a goose contaminated with radiation near the Oak Ridge nuclear installation. Some geese have staked their claim at several ponds on the Department of Energy's Oak Ridge National Laboratory compound, said Gordon Blaylock, an Oak Ridge environmental scientist. Several ponds were used at one time as collection basins for nuclear waste, and Blaylock says those still are hot with radioactivity. Those ponds are getting a closer look from Oak Ridge staffers, who tagged more than 300 geese last week in an effort to track their movement. ``As long as we control the small ponds, I don't think you're going to get a goose with a serious problem,'' Blaylock said. In some cases, fences were put up to keep geese from walking into an area, while streamers attacked to rows of fishing line strung across the ponds are meant to deter geese. During the past two years scientists have collared about about 500, or one-fourth, of the estimated 2,000 non-migratory Canada geese living near the government nuclear complex, Blaylock said. The geese, introduced several years ago by the Tennessee Valley Authority, are mostly non-migratory but move within a limited area, he said. The birds' movement patterns are of interest to scientists, Blaylock said. The tags can be seen with viewing scopes, letting staffers track the birds' movement without having to capture them again. Other geese are tagged with leg bands, which direct that hunters return the metal bands to Oak Ridge and include information on the bird's location. Blaylock said Monday that six geese found living on a hot pond near the High Flux Isotope Reactor at Oak Ridge were presumed to be contaminated with radioactive cobalt-60. Those geese were killed for study rather than risking the possibility of contaminated birds leaving the area, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Fireworks Set Fire to Stadium Flag
With AM-Mr Fireworks, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Old Glory burned before a thousands of people in the birthplace of American independence, but it wasn't a free speech demonstration. The flag was accidentally ignited by fireworks over Veterans Stadium after a Philadelphia Phillies baseball game Monday night. The cloth Stars and Stripes, flown about 50 feet above the stands in center field, swiftly went up in flames. Phillies spokesman Larry Shenk said the flag has been replaced, but with more fireworks planned after a Wednesday night baseball game, it was moved temporarily to another pole. ``It's never happened before, but we're not taking any chances,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: North, South Koreans Agree To Arrange Summit
DOC.TEXT: North Korea and South Korea took a major step toward reconciliation Tuesday and agreed to a historic meeting between their top government leaders. The talks could be held as early as August, officials said. Delegates from the countries met at the border truce village of Panmunjom and agreed to sign an accord July 26 that would outline a proposed agenda and procedures for the first meeting of prime ministers. It would be the first such meeting since the division of the peninsula in 1945 into the communist North and capitalist South. In earlier talks, both sides agreed the summit would be held alternately in the countries' capitals. Each side would have seven representatives, including the prime minister and two military delegates. The breakthrough on a summit came after South Korea accepted North Korea's proposal to place political and military topics ahead of humanitarian and other exchanges on the agenda. Seoul had insisted on the opposite. Tuesday's meeting was the seventh of a series since February 1989. The talks had been suspended for five months. Unlike most dialogue between the countries, Tuesday's was largely free of acrimony and tension. South Korea's chief delegate, Song Han-ho, later said he expected no problems in signing a procedural agreement for the summit. His communist counterpart, Paik Nam Jun, expressed similar views at a separate news conference. Song said he hoped the prime ministers talks would open ``a new chapter for realizing peaceful unification of the peninsula.'' ``We cannot stick to the logic of the Cold War and ignore changes in the world any longer,'' he said. Paik said Tuesday's talks ``marked a new milestone in the history of the North-South Korea dialogue.'' Tuesday's agreement was widely seen as a major breakthrough in that dialogue. But observers cautioned that the talks could still falter, pointing to decades of hostility and distrust on both sides. During a previous border meeting, North Korea once asked South Korea to end the joint U.S.-South Koran military exercises called Team Spirit. North Korea called off talks with South Korea in January to protest the exercises and demanded the withdrawal of all U.S. troops based in South Korea. South Korean officials said arms reduction and other measures easing tensions could be discussed at the prime ministers' meeting as a first step toward eventual unification. Buoyed by its economic success, Seoul has improved relations with the Soviet Union and other North Korean allies and also has urged Pyongyang to open its doors. Talks have been held sporadically between the two Koreas, but little progress had been made until recently. The border on both sides is heavily fortified and sealed, blocking exchanges of mail and transportation. North Korea is one of the last totalitarian Communist states, and sweeping changes in East Europe and its socialist allies have made little impact. Paik, the chief North Korean delegate, told the meeting Tuesday that unification should be carried out independently with no interference from other countries. He chided the South for ``soliciting help from outsiders on reunification,'' referring to South Korean President Roh Tae-woo's recent meeting with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev in San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: Interior Ministry Says 1,426 Died in Stampede
LaserPhoto LON3
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with saying tunnel was packed with 50,000 people at the time of the disaster. Pickup 5th pvs, `The disaster...'
DOC.TEXT: Interior Minister Prince Nayef said today 1,426 Moslem pilgrims died in a stampede in a 1,500-foot-long pedestrian tunnel that was crowded with 50,000 people. Prince Nayef said the disaster was caused when seven pilgrims fell from an overhead bridge near the tunnel, which linked this holy city with a tent city. Other sources said a power failure caused the air conditioning in the 60-foot-wide tunnel to switch off in 112-degree heat Monday morning, setting off the stampede. ``It was God's will, which is above everything,'' King Fahd said of the disaster. ``It was fate.'' Prince Nayef, who is the Saudi monarch's brother, did not give the nationalities of the victims. He said that a number of other pilgrims fainted and were treated on the spot, but he did not provide a figure. ``The fall of the seven spread terror, and the tremendous throngs of the pilgrims caused them all to tumble onto each other,'' he said. He explained that the tunnel itself was packed ``multiple times beyond its capacity, with some 50,000 people inside.'' The disaster occurred during the hajj, one of the world's largest religious gatherings, which draws about 2 million Moslems. Observances had largely ended, and pilgrims were observing post-hajj rituals or preparing to leave. Diplomats told The Associated Press on Monday night that about 1,400 pilgrims were killed. Asian and Middle Eastern diplomats, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said most of the victims were Malaysian and Indonesian pilgrims. Doctors at hospitals said today that large numbers of Egyptians and Pakistanis were among the dead. King Fahd acknowledged indirectly that there had been a large loss of life. He called the dead ``martyrs of the Islamic world.'' ``Had they not died there, they would have died elsewhere and at the same predestined moment,'' the king said at a meeting Monday night with pilgrimage security officials. The deaths shattered what had been a peaceful observance of the annual haff and was the worst pilgrimage tragedy in recent years. In previous years, the celebration has been marred by terrorist attacks and riots. Diplomats said the tunnel became packed beyond capacity when some pilgrims stopped in the middle while people outside continued to push their way in. A witness said the tunnel became clogged with the crush of people. ``With the lack of oxygen, a good number collapsed unconscious, and some died. There was also a stampede,'' said the witness, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said he helped carry victims to the ambulances waiting by the tunnel's exits, but that he did not know how many of the stricken were dead and how many were simply unconscious. The pedestrian walkway runs under part of a mountain, but sometimes cars use it as a shortcut, filling it with choking fumes, sources said. As the scope of the disaster became apparent, ambulances and security forces rushed to the tunnel, which joins Mecca and the pilgrim tent city of Mina. ``Thousands of the pilgrims thronged through the tunnel of Mo'essem, causing severe congestion within the tunnel as the pressure was beyond its capacity,'' state-run Riyadh radio said. The official Saudi Press Agency quoted King Fahd as saying the pilgrims had failed to follow safety rules ``issued in good time ahead of the (pilgrimage) season.'' But he pledged to work for better safety. ``God willing, we will see no tragedies in the coming years,'' he said. The tunnel is part of $15 billion development plan for the holy sites, including other tunnels and overhead bridges, to move pilgrims in a more orderly fashion. The king said the disaster caused grief to Moslems everywhere. ``But I reiterate that it is the inescapable will of God,'' he said. An estimated 2 million Moslems, including 800,000 visitors from around the world, come to Islam's holy sites in and around Mecca for the hajj. The celebration climaxed Sunday with prayers on Mount Arafat, about eight miles from Mecca. The rituals being celebrated Monday _ the Eid Al-Adha, or the Feast of Sacrifice _ commemorate the Prophet Abraham's offering of his son in sacrifice to God. Before Monday, only a small fire at Mina and a few cases of heat fatigue had disrupted the pilgrimage season. Terrorism blamed on Iranian or Shiite Moslems has occurred in the past three years. The worst incident was in 1987, when Iranians clashed with security forces, leading to the death of more than 400 pilgrims. The year before, the Saudis confiscated large quantities of explosives from members of the Iranian contingent. The Saudis have since set a quota of 1,000 pilgrims per million residents of each Islamic nation. Iranians, angered by the quotas, have boycotted the hajj since 1988. Last year, some small bombs went off during the hajj, killing one pilgrim and injuring 16. The Saudis tried and convicted Kuwaiti Shiite Moslems and beheaded 16 of them.

DOC.HEAD: Greek Orthodox Patriarch Pays Tribute to Turkey
DOC.TEXT: Patriarch Dimitrios I of the Eastern Orthodox Church praised Turkey on Tuesday as a bridge between East and West. The patriarch, born in Istanbul 75 years ago, spoke at a lunch given in his honor by Ambassador Nuzhet Kandemir of Turkey. Dimitrios is a Turkish citizen. The patriarch's visit to the United States, the first by any Orthodox patriarch, is politically sensitive because of the historic tensions between Greece and Turkey. Orthodoxy is the official religion in Greece; the patriarch usually speaks in Greek, and Olympic Airways, the Greek national airline, put one of its planes at his disposal for the trip. Dimitrios, offering a toast at the luncheon, said: ``Turkey forms a bridge between Asia and Europe, between East and West, and as the world of today more and more discovers its oneness and unifying bridges are being built everywhere, Turkey's contribution to the shaping of this new world will prove substantive.'' The traditions of the Orthodox church go back to St. Andrew the Apostle, believed to have founded it in Byzantium, later called Constantinople and now Istanbul, in A.D. 36. When Moslem Turks conquered the city in 1453, they allowed the headquarters of the church to remain there. Dimitrios' toast emphasized his role as a religious leader. ``As the church, we always leave politics to the political and diplomatic community, confining ourselves only to those things which can secure man's well-being and above all his salvation,'' he said. He toasted Turkey as ``our beloved country'' and President Turgut Ozal as ``the beloved president of our democracy.'' ``Our contribution as the (Greek) minority in Turkey and as the religious leadership of that minority, and many other Orthodox faithful in America, Western Europe, Australia and elsewhere _ our contribution is that of prayer,'' he said. Dimitrios is the spiritual leader of 250 million Orthodox believers worldwide, most of them in the Soviet Union and eastern Europe. An estimated 6 million live in North and South America.

DOC.HEAD: East Germans Investigating Border Deaths
With AM-German Capital, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Military authorities are investigating the deaths of 11 people who tried to flee across the Western border during the shoot-to-kill policy of East Germany's ousted Communist regime, an official said Tuesday. The policy and the activities of the former security police have raised a public outcry for prosecutions of former officials. A murder inquiry is under way against ousted Communist Party chief Erich Honecker for his part in the shoot-to-kill policy, but the ailing 77-year-old is not expected to stand trial. In his announcement Tuesday, chief military prosecutor Col. Karlheinz Boesel said he would only investigate whether the guards involved had obeyed orders under a law on dereliction of duty. Relatives have pressed homicide charges in all 11 cases. The military prosecutor told the West German television network ARD that he refused to regard the soldiers as ``violent criminals'' if they merely used their firearms according to orders. A total of 192 would-be escapees are known to have perished since the Berlin Wall went up in 1961. It was thrown open only last year as the pro-democracy revolution swept the country. The military prosecutor also argued for a general amnesty for border guards who had fired at refugees so that ``they are offered a way out and a chance to make themselves known.'' The shoot-to-kill command was signed in 1961 by Gen. Heinz Hoffmann, who was East Germany's defense minister until his death in 1985. East Germans are seeking to deal with taints in their Communist past as they rush toward reunification with West Germany. The East German government late Monday proposed all-German elections on Dec. 2. Although the West German government hasn't officially responded, government sources in Bonn said they welcomed the idea. The two nations merged their currencies and economies Sunday. One hurdle to formal unity is the future military alignment of what will be one of Europe's mightiest military powers. The United States, France and Britain insist that Germany must be a member of the West's North Atlantic Treaty Organization, perhaps with both Soviet and American troops deployed on its soil. But Moscow has insisted the new German nation be neutral. West German Defense Ministry sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said in Bonn that their government was willing to consider a Soviet proposal to limit troops of a united Germany to about 400,000. The two German states now have combined forces of about 600,000.

DOC.HEAD: Fighting Rages in Liberia; US Officials See Early Demise for Doe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3 grafs for 5th graf pvs, Meanwhile, a, to update. Moved previously as AM-Liberia, a0610.
DOC.TEXT: As heavy fighting raged northeast of the Liberian capital of Monrovia on Tuesday, U.S. officials said they believed that the government of President Samuel K. Doe could collapse in a matter of days. The officials, asking not to be identified, said that there had been a number of desertions from the elite unit that protects Doe and that his hold on power was becoming more precarious by the day. Two officials said Doe's demise could come before the weekend. He has ruled Liberia for more than a decade. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said there was fighting on both sides of the St. Paul River in addition to the combat northeast of Monrovia. The fighting was inhibiting communications out of Liberia. Meanwhile, sources in Monrovia told reporters that Doe has agreed in principle to resign. The sources said he was under pressure from close associates in addition to the advancing rebels. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Doe agreed to step down only on the condition that his safety and that of his minority Krahn tribe are guaranteed. And a rebel source, reached by telephone from neighboring Ivory Coast, said about 800 rebels of Liberia's National Patriotic Front have begun an attack on Monrovia and several thousand more were approaching to ``put an end'' to Doe and his government. That source, based near the Liberian border, said rebel leader Charles Taylor was at the front directing attacks on the Liberian capital. Taylor launched his rebellion last Christmas eve, reportedly with help from Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi. It is not known whether Gadhafi has provided any assistance recently. At the Pentagon, spokesman Pete Williams said a Navy task force was standing ``over the horizon'' off Liberia ready to evacuate the estimated 795 Americans in Liberia if requested to do so by the State Department. ``We're considering all options, but a decision to evacuate has not yet been made,'' said Boucher at the State Department. There were no reports of injury to any Americans. Officials have said that the U.S. government is prepared to evacuate Doe if it is asked to do so. They said Togo, also in West Africa, has agreed to receive Doe if he is forced out of Liberia. Boucher said Monrovia was without water, electricity or telephone service. All main roads out of the capital were cut. Most of Doe's Cabinet and other senior administration officials have fled. Liberian and diplomatic sources said army chief of staff Lt. Gen. Henry Dubar resigned during the weekend. A dusk to dawn curfew was in effect. Boucher said a Voice of America transmitter is located behind rebel lines, but the rebel forces have not interfered with its operations. The new U.S. ambassador to Liberia, Peter De Vos, met with Doe on Sunday. On Monday, he met with the Vice President Harry Moniba and three other senior legislators, Boucher said. U.S. policy has been to support the formation through political negotiations of an interim government that would oversee a transition to democratic rule. Doe has offered a national unity government with participation by Taylor's group but the rebel leader has rejected the proposal. Taylor has repeatedly demanded that Doe resign before he and the rebels will stop their advance. There also have been official U.S. contacts with Taylor, a former Liberian government official who infiltrated the country six months ago with a small band of followers. Taylor has informed the U.S. envoys that if his movement ousts Doe, he will promote democracy and respect human rights. But officials have said they are not certain that Taylor will abide by those pledges. Taylor also has offered assurances that his forces will not harm Americans or other foreigners in Liberia, Boucher said. Other officials have said that U.S. envoys have called on Taylor to exercise maximum restraint because a bloodbath could have an impact on U.S. aid to Liberia, historically the largest recipients of American assistance in sub-Saharan Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts From Shevardnadze's Speech
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts of the speech by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze at the 28th Communist Party Congress on Tuesday, as translated by The Associated Press.
_ I am prepared not to get nominated for the party's leading organs. There is no need for a minister to be a member of the Politburo, Presidential Council and Defense Council.

_ My life was determined by several feelings, including a feeling of injustice for the striking discrepancy between the proclaimed ideals and slogans and reality. In the last quarter of the 20th century, international developments are no longer determined by the struggle of two opposing systems, that it is no longer subordinated completely ... to the dynamics of the conflict of class interests. Having come long ago to the conclusion about deadlocks into which we are pushed by dogmatism and ideological schemes that kill living ideas, I actively supported and practically implemented the idea of the priority of human values to class, group or any other interests. I realized quite clearly that false ideology _ besides distorting goals and substituting concepts _ has also weight, aims, clear material incarnation.

_ I am more than convinced that our state needs strong armed forces. But we can be armed to the teeth and live in fear ofan attack, or you can be sure no one will attack you because policies can create conditions when the country will have no opponents or enemies. If we continue as we did _ to spend one-quarter of gross national income on military spending _ we will ruin the country and we will simply not need any defense anymore. A ruined country and poor people do not need an army. It does not make sense to defend a system that has led to an economic and social devastation. It is up to politics to create security with cuts in defense expenditure.

_ Is Eastern Europe a failure of our diplomacy? Yes, if our diplomacy has never and could not set itself the aim to oppose the elimination in other countries of forced and alien administrative-command systems, totalitarian regimes. Even if events in Eastern Europe had not been in our interests, we would have not interfered in their affairs. We recognize, not in words but in deeds, the equality of nations, sovereignty of peoples, non-interference into their affairs, their right to free choice. Any other position is chauvinism, imperialism. The fact that democratically elected leaders of our allies came to the meeting of the highest body of Warsaw Treaty Organization does not seem a failure, but an expression of respect of our perestroika. We diplomats expected the changes in Eastern Europe, but we could not interfere. We forecast this. We sensed that if there were not changes, there would be tragedy. It bitterly hurts me to see that there are people whose assertions lead one to believe that the Soviet Army didn't liberate some Eastern European countries but all but captured them as war trophies. Chauvinistic statements insulting the dignity of sovereign states are permitted by some. I see it as my moral obligation to apologize before the peoples of East European states for such insulting and unacceptable escapades on the part of my fellow countrymen.

DOC.HEAD: Pioneering `Hit Parade' Regular Dies
LaserPhoto NY20
DOC.TEXT: Snooky Lanson, the smiling crooner of ``Your Hit Parade,'' television's pop music show of the 1950s, has died at age 76. He died Monday night at St. Thomas Hospital, where he had been a patient since Saturday, said hospital spokeswoman Elise Shelton. The hospital did not release the cause of death. Lanson sang on ``Your Hit Parade,'' a spinoff of radio's ``Lucky Strike Hit Parade,'' from 1950 to 1957. The TV show featured elaborate production numbers of the week's seven most popular songs, with No. 1 always presented last. ``I sang `Mona Lisa' 13 straight weeks because it was a man's song and I was the only man on the show then,'' Lanson recalled in a 1979 interview. He later was joined by Russell Arms. Other singers on ``Your Hit Parade'' included Dorothy Collins, Polly Bergen, Gisele MacKenzie, Eileen Wilson and June Valli. ``The show didn't have any stars per se and we all got along well,'' Lanson said. ``It was very clean and there was no suggestive dancing: a 5- or 6-year-old could watch it. ``And of course a lot of people watched it to see what song was No. 1 that week.'' Lanson, whose real name was Roy Landman, was born in Memphis. He was nicknamed ``Snooky'' at age 2 after the Irving Berlin tune ``Snooky-Ookums.'' Lanson began singing in a church choir as a boy. He moved to Nashville after high school and got a job with band leader Francis Craig at Nashville radio station WSM. In 1940, he was hired by the Ray Noble Band. A year later, he recorded the hit record ``By the Light of the Silvery Moon'' with the band. In the late 1940s, he sang ``The Old Master Painter,'' a hit which helped him land the spot on ``Your Hit Parade.'' The Saturday night show's popularity waned when rock 'n' roll began dominating the pop charts. Lanson and other regulars were replaced in 1957 by younger performers, and the show left the air two years later. Lanson went on to perform in nightclubs, to be a host of TV variety shows in Atlanta and Shreveport, La. He also had a syndicated radio show, and sold cars and outdoor advertising at various times. He is survived by his wife, Florence, two sons, a daughter and eight grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Says Farm Spending Rising
DOC.TEXT: Farmers spent an estimated $124.1 billion on production expenses last year, up 4.9 percent from $118.4 billion in 1988, according to a preliminary report by the Agriculture Department released Tuesday. But that was still far below the record level of $131.8 billion spent in 1981, just before a general financial crunch that stalled expansion in the nation's agricultural sector. In 1986, annual spending by farmers dropped to less than $106 billion, reflecting massive cutbacks in capital investments as land values plummeted and debts weighed heavily on so many. The last report by the department's National Agricultural Statistics Service showed 1989 expenditures rose for all major categories farm and land improvements, which dropped 6.3 percent, and fuel, which declined slightly. Farm services, which include rent, comprised the largest expenditure by farmers at $26.7 billion, up 0.7 percent from 1988. These services accounted for 22 percent of overall production expenses. Feed expenses were estimated at $18.2 billion, up 1.7 percent, accounting for 15 percent of the total 1989 expenditures. Overall, last year's production expenditures averaged $57,478 per farm, an increase of $2,522 from 1988. The analysis dealt only with production expenditures and did not include figures for net income or profits.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Physicians Walk off Jobs in Wage Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of physicians walked off their jobs Tuesday, shutting clinics and disrupting hospitals in a one-day strike against a court-ordered cut in government overtime payments. Israeli media said the job action involved 12,000 doctors, but many of them were expected to keep treating emergency cases and critically ill patients. The strike was expected to have a widespread effect, since most doctors work in clinics or hospitals under Israel's system of socialized medicine. Nationwide doctors' unions called the strike to protest a court ruling last week that declared illegal the nearly two-year practice of giving physicians overtime payments instead of negotiating wage increases. The strike came amid heightened labor unrest organized by the Labor Party-dominated Histadrut Labor Federation, following formation of a right-wing government in early June led by the right-wing Likud bloc. The previous government had included the center-left Labor Party. As the doctors launched their 24-hour action, electric workers, defense industry employees and workers in other public sectors threatened similar action over wage disputes. The overtime arrangement was reached in November 1988 to bypass complicated wage negotiations and to reduce a waiting list of tens of thousands of Israelis needing operations and other medical care. But the arrangement was designed to last only until March of this year, and the government brought suit to challenge continuation of the system. On Thursday, a Tel Aviv court ruled that under the law, the overtime system could not serve as a permanent replacement for a wage agreement. There are few private doctors in Israel. Most Israelis pay small fees for treatment in hospitals and clinics, which are heavily subsidized by the government. The system dates to the country's socialist origins. It has suffered financial difficulties in recent years because of inefficiency and Israel's wider economic troubles, such as double-digit inflation. Doctors' basic salaries start at about $600 a month, with overnight duty shifts adding up to several hundred dollars more to the wages of many attending physicians. With the overtime payments, many doctors have earned an additional $200 to $300 a month.

DOC.HEAD: Welcome to The Donald Zone
DOC.TEXT: Stargazers and Spy magazine have seen the future, and its name is _ what else? _ Donald Trump. The August issue of Spy, the Trump-bashing monthly that dubbed The Donald a ``short-fingered vulgarian,'' features an eight-page spread foreshadowing Trump's fortunes from September 1990 through April 1996. By then, the magazine predicts, David Geffen will own Trump Tower and Yoko Ono will run The Plaza. The final word: Donald reconciles with Ivana, and they become co-hosts of the hit TV show ``Lunch With Ivana and Me.'' That's the good news; the bad news is Trump has put on 50 pounds and lost much of his hair. Astrologically speaking, the future doesn't look much brighter. ``The real problem right now is he has Mercury, Saturn and Venus all in the sign of Cancer,'' astrologer Joyce Jillson told the Daily News. Thanks, Joyce. Jillson predicts one of Trump's Atlantic City casinos is going to shut down and become a Cadillac dealership. Star-gazer Jeanne Dixon warns Trump can expect more losses and more money problems by the end of 1990. But at least he has his health, you say. Uhhhh, not so fast. Jillson forecasts that the Donald can expect an ulcer in the near future.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Money: $7 Million and Counting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 12th graf, `Income in ...' to UPDATE with statement from national spokeswoman.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON1, LaserGraphic NY7
With AM-Mandela Money-List
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela raised more than $7 million for the African National Congress in his eight-city U.S. tour, and Americans paid millions more in tax dollars for his police protection. While no total for donations was available from national organizers of the 11-day trip that ended Saturday, organizers in each city had rough counts as of Monday. Many said money still was coming in. Similarly, no sum of government costs for Mandela's protection was available. In New York City alone, municipal expenses were put at $2.6 million. Another big spender was the State Department, which oversaw security. ``There isn't even the remotest guess yet'' as to the federal expense, said Frank Matthews, spokesman for the State Department's Bureau of Diplomatic Services. ``It's big, but I don't know how big.'' Mandela, freed in February after 27 years in prison, is a leader of the ANC struggle against apartheid. Fund-raising was a focus of his tour, and he called for help at events ranging from stadium rallies to celebrity cocktail parties. He fell considerably short of fund-raising goals in some cities but far exceeded them in others. In Boston, planners raised only about half the $1 million they sought. In New York, donors may double their $1 million goal. ``When we first heard he was coming to New York, we were delighted,'' said fund-raiser Suzanne Dubose. ``We knew we could do a million. But you always think, in the back of your mind _ can the town pull it together?'' It did, she said: The Mandela tour has raised $1.75 million in New York, and late-arriving income makes $2 million a possibility. The national total thus far was less than the $1 million per city that some organizers said was set as a target. Other participants, however, said they had never adopted a $1 million goal for their cities. While Mandela spent three days in New York, they noted, he had only a half day in Atlanta, where projections were for roughly $400,000, and one day in Miami and Miami Beach, where he addressed a union whose members raised about $300,000. In Boston his largest rally was free, unlike the paid events elsewhere. In Washington, most of his appearances were private meetings with political leaders. Mandela raised about $150,000 there, much of it from a stadium rally, said spokeswoman Lisa Alfred. Income in Detroit was estimated at $1.4 million and rising, with help from brisk sales of a videotape account of Mandela's visit. Preliminary numbers from Los Angeles were $1.7 million, and from Oakland, Calif., $900,000. Leila McDowell, spokeswoman for the tour's national organizing group, Democracy for South Africa, said it was shocked at the figures provided by the local committees and called it premature to release them. ``We don't know that they're inaccurate or that they're accurate,'' she said. ``You get a check, you don't know whether it's bounced or whether it's real. You get a pledge, you don't know whether it'll come through or not. They haven't had a chance to do a full accounting yet.'' Expenses were yet to be subtracted from the income. But because much of the facilities and equipment used by the tour were donated or supplied at a discount, organizers said most of the cash should reach the ANC. In Detroit, for example, expenses were not expected to exceed $250,000. In Boston and New York, local expenses were estimated at roughly $150,000 apiece. However, expenses of the national tour organizers, including air travel and some accommodations, were not yet available. Proceeds _ including sales of T-shirts and buttons _ are to be deposited in a fund for the ANC. The fund is controlled by the U.S. directors of the tour, led by Roger Wilkins, a professor at George Mason University and the trip's chief planner, Alfred said. The money will be used to finance 14 offices in South Africa for the newly legalized ANC, she said. The remainder will go toward housing and education there. As the tour counted its take, municipalities were totaling their costs, mostly for police overtime. Boston's Metropolitan District Commission police needed $110,000 in overtime pay; Atlanta police, an estimated $100,000; Miami police, $20,000. Figures were not immediately available in other cities. New York was the most specific: The city racked up $2 million in police overtime, $250,000 in Transportation Department charges and $210,000 for cleanup, and had other assorted costs for a $2.6 million total. The city said it would seek reimbursement from a State Department fund set up to help New York pay for protecting international leaders visiting the United Nations. The State Department has resisted, saying Mandela's visit did not meet the fund's guidelines because he is not a head of state. New York officials have found a silver lining nonetheless: Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch said the combined TV coverage of Mandela in the city would have cost $720,000 a minute if it were paid advertising for New York City. He said: ``We could not have bought this promotion.''

DOC.HEAD: Audit Critical of Wisconsin's Experimental Welfare Program
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, ``In general, ...'' to restore Cattanach's first name and title
DOC.TEXT: A Wisconsin program that cuts welfare benefits of families whose children skip school suffers from serious administrative problems that unfairly penalize some recipients, a state audit says. The findings released Monday drew strong responses from critics of the experimental Learnfare program, who contend Gov. Tommy G. Thompson has touted it while hiding its problems. ``By all accounts, the Learnfare program has been an administrative nightmare,'' said state Rep. Peter Barca, ``I'm very skeptical at this point.'' Learnfare, authorized by the Legislature in 1987, allows the state to cut a family's monthly Aid to Families with Dependent Children benefits if a school reports a student has been consistently absent without excuse. The program applies to teen-agers, but Thompson wants it expanded to include elementary-school pupils. The federal government has authorized the expansion but the Legislature still must approve it. Barca said expansion is ``out of the question'' given the audit findings. The audit said attendance measurement practices throughout the state are inconsistent and errors in paperwork by county social workers has resulted in some families being penalized without reason. Thompson had not seen the report and had no immediate comment, his office said Tuesday. Learnfare requires cooperation among the state Department of Health and Social Services, the state Department of Public Instruction, county social service agencies and school districts, which keep attendance records. ``Unfortunately, cooperation among these agencies has fallen short of what is needed to ensure adequate program management,'' the report said. Students ages 13 to 19 who don't attend classes regularly see their family's monthly benefits reduced by about $100 until schools report truancy has ended. The state's average monthly AFDC payment is $517. ``In general, we found that significant weaknesses in administration of Learnfare lead to some students being sanctioned who should not have been and other students, who had too many unexcused absences, not being sanctioned,'' said state auditor Dale Cattanach. In a review of 151 cases in Milwaukee County in February 1990, it said, 13 cases were inappropriately sanctioned. There were three instances in which students were truant without their families being penalized, it said. Milwaukee School Superintendent Robert Peterkin said Monday his district, the state's largest, will design a computerized reporting system to improve attendance monitoring. Thomas Brophy, director of Milwaukee County Social Services, said in a response letter than his agency ``will make every effort to correct this problem so that no one is sanctioned incorrectly.'' Brophy also said he doesn't believe significant improvements can be made unless his agency receives more money. Of the 30,000 students subject to Learnfare, 48 percent live in Milwaukee County, where 75 percent the sanctions have been imposed, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Hot in Central U.S., Cooler Up North
DOC.TEXT: A massive high-pressure zone kept the weather hot and dry in the central United States on Tuesday. Temperatures topped 100 degrees in some states. Showers and thunderstorms fell mainly over the Southeast, from Florida and southern Georgia to southeastern Louisiana. In Jacksonville, Fla., thunderstorms dropped an inch of rain in the six hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation. A few showers fell in northern Maine, upper Michigan, New Mexico and Arizona. Skies were mostly sunny from California to Montana, from Texas and Louisiana to South Dakota and Iowa, and from Mississippi and Alabama to West Virginia. The high-pressure center kept out clouds, rain and cooler air to the north. By afternoon, temperatures were in the 90s across the southern and central Plains and the lower and middle Mississippi Valley. Readings of 100 degrees or above were reported in South Dakota, Minnesota, Nebraska, Kansas, Oklahoma and Arkansas. At 2 p.m. EDT, it was 104 degrees in Wichita, Kan., and 103 in Mitchell, S.D. Strong southerly winds prevailed from the southern High Plains to the middle and upper Mississippi Valley. More seasonable temperatures were forecast for much of the northern High Plains.
