Afternoon temperatures were only in the 70s from Montana and northern Wyoming to central North Dakota. Afternoon temperatures were mostly in the upper 70s and 80s in the Great Lakes region and the eastern United States. Temperatures were in the 60s in Washington state and Oregon and along the northern and central Pacific Coast. But readings in the southwestern deserts were in the 90s or above 100. Three cities in the West and one in the South tied their record low temperatures for the date. It was 39 degrees in Yakima, Wash.; 40 in Boise, Idaho; 42 in Spokane, Wash.; and 56 in Bristol, Tenn. The low for the Lower 48 states was 37 degrees at Baker, Ore., and Redmond, Ore.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Says Report Misstates Osprey Costs
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney stands by his opposition to the purchase of V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft for the Marine Corps despite a new study indicating it would be a good investment, a spokesman said Tuesday. ``The secretary has concluded that the decision that he made last year remains valid,'' spokesman Pete Williams told reporters. ``That is, that the V-22 is an excellent aircraft, but is simply too expensive to buy.'' The Institute for Defense Analysis, a Pentagon-sponsored research group, said in a report to Congress on Friday that the Osprey could perform better on military missions and do so at less cost than helicopter alternatives favored by Cheney. Williams said Cheney disagrees with assumptions on which the report is based. The Osprey would be built jointly by Boeing Helicopters of Philadelphia and Bell Helicopter@Textron of Fort Worth, Texas. It is designed to rise and hover like a helicopter and then fly like an airplane. It would be used largely for military-transport missions. Williams said Cheney still believes ``the Marine Corps medium airlift requirement can be met by alternatives that cost less.'' The institute said costs could be reduced by slowing the rate of production of the Ospreys. Even at the reduced rate, however, Williams said the Ospreys would cost about $3.7 billion more, during fiscal years 1991 through 1997, than Secretary of the Navy H. Lawrence Garrett III recommended be spent on medium airlift. The report also assumed that the Marine Corps could get by with fewer of the Ospreys than originally proposed by flying more sorties at higher speeds. Williams said it was not known whether the aircraft could carry equipment slung under it at the proposed speed of 200 knots, or whether the vehicles and other equipment would survive being carried at this speed. Williams also said the study appeared to overestimate the near-term investment cost of helicopters. The Pentagon had once hoped to eventually buy about 650 Ospreys. Members of Congress from Texas and Pennsylvania, with jobs at stake in their states, have been among strong backers of the aircraft. Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., said on Sunday, ``Once this report is in hand, with these conclusions, it is no longer possible for Cheney to say credibly that the V-22 is more expensive than alternatives.''

DOC.HEAD: `George Bush' The Monkey Found
DOC.TEXT: George Bush was back on his leash and wolfing down bananas Tuesday after taking an unscheduled two-day vacation. This George Bush, however, is a 3-year-old white-faced Capuchin monkey used by Joe Bush, a 49-year-old Willingboro organ grinder who is not related to the president. The monkey broke his leash while his owner showed him off during a vsit Saturday with friends. The escape set off a two-day search by at least 100 residents in the southern New Jersey township for the 16-inch-high, 6-pound namesake of the president. ``One guy told me he was trying to catch him and George was flying from treetop to treetop like he had been doing it all his life,'' Bush said Tuesday. George's stomach finally overcame his urge for freedom when he emerged from the woods Monday morning to eat some tomatoes in a yard. About 30 or 40 residents surrounded the monkey and Bush caught him. ``It was a traumatic experience,'' Bush said, noting that George in September replaced another monkey that he had used for 16 years. ``But he's acting like nothing happened. ... He was like a young teen-ager getting freedom.'' As for the monkey's ties to the man at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, Bush said, ``I just say it's a distant cousin.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says NATO Allies Receptive to Nuclear Revamping
With AM-West to the Rescue, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Tuesday NATO allies are expressing ``wide acceptance'' for his pre-summit proposals on nuclear strategy changes. His plans include an alliance commitment not to use nuclear weapons except as a last resort, other officials said. Bush leaves Wednesday for the two-day NATO summit beginning Thursday in London, and he has been telephoning leaders of the alliance's other countries in advance of the meeting. The president, blending work with golf and other relaxation during a five-day break at his oceanfront summer home, planned to take in the local fireworks Tuesday night from the deck of the U.S. Coast Guard training barque Eagle. NATO's basic doctrine since 1967 has been that it would not rule out using nuclear weapons first if confronted with an invasion by superior conventional forces from the Soviet Union or its satellites. However, National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft said Tuesday ``the collapse'' of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact justified changes in that ``flexible response'' policy. Scowcroft, with Bush in Maine, said the president had sent a letter to NATO leaders trying to line up support for the changes. He gave few specifics, but administration officials aid privately that the Bush plan would commit the 16-nation alliance to ease their nuclear-weapons stance at least to the extent of calling for use only as a last resort. Bush also steered clear of details as he met with reporters outside his vacation home. But he said, ``The general approach that we're proposing seems to be getting wide acceptance.'' Scowcroft, at a later news briefing, said the summit takes place ``at a moment of significant historic transition'' in Europe. The overriding issue is how to adapt the Western alliance to ``the changing security environment in Europe,'' including ``the collapse ... of the Warsaw Pact, the changes in Eastern Europe (and) the turmoil that's going on in the Soviet Union,'' Scowcroft said. He said NATO's strategy must recognize that ``shortly'' there will no longer ``be armies facing each other directly across a boundary.'' Instead, he said, the United States is looking for the Soviets to withdraw their troops from Eastern Europe. He added, ``It's a very different matter to attack a few hundred yards across a border than it is to move forces up several hundred miles into Eastern Europe to be prepared for an attack.'' ``One has to look at the issues of forward defense, flexible response, all the kinds of strategies that NATO pursues now to see how they might be modified to fit those new circumstances,'' said the national security adviser. He said Bush's proposals are not ``bombshells, but they are significant because this is a significant time.'' Scowcroft said the United States already has gotten favorable reactions from ``five or six'' NATO allies. Bush conferred at his oceanfront home Tuesday with Vice President Dan Quayle, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, Trade Representative Carla Hills and other senior officials to prepare for next Monday's economic summit in Houston. Bush will fly to Texas from Europe late Friday. Bush said he hoped the economic summit, bringing together the leaders of the world's seven largest industrialized nations, would bring progress on trade. Before that, the NATO allies are holding their third summit in the past year as the alliance prepares to welcome a new, united Germany into its ranks _ a move that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev staunchly opposes. Bush said he hopes the NATO summit will help persuade the Soviets that a unified Germany in NATO is no threat to the Soviet Union. He said, ``If there are certain things we can do to expand NATO's role that drive that point home, so much the better.'' While sympathetic to Gorbachev's problems at home, Bush reiterated Tuesday that he remains opposed to Western economic aid for the Soviet Union, a subject sure to come up at one or both of the summits. Scowcroft said, ``I think the Soviets will be looking at this summit very carefully.'' ``It's a difficult issue for the Soviet Union. Not only is their alliance collapsing and the kind of defense barrier to their west that they count on for 40 years, but the sort of crown jewel of that defensive barrier is now being proposed to join the core of an alliance that I'm sure they tell their little children is evil incarnate,'' Scowcroft said. In addition to agreeing to use nuclear weapons only as a last resort, administration officials say Bush has suggested other moves to overcome Soviet anxieties, including eventually scrapping the 1,470 U.S. nuclear-tipped artillery shells now based mostly in West Germany, reducing or eliminating an arsenal of 1,560 U.S. nuclear bombs deployed in seven NATO countries and pulling back troops from forward deployment.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Aquino Isolated on Marcos Ban
With AM-Marcos, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino found herself politically isolated Tuesday, as congressional leaders urged her to let Imelda Marcos return home after a U.S. court acquitted her of looting this nation's treasury. Longtime Aquino supporters joined Marcos loyalists in calling for the former first lady's return. But Mrs. Aquino refused to relax the ban and accused Mrs. Marcos of supporting a coup attempt in December. On Monday, a federal jury in New York cleared Mrs. Marcos on charges that she used $222 million in Philippine government funds to buy real estate, art and jewelry. She fled the country with her husband, former President Ferdinand Marcos, after the 1986 ``people power'' revolution toppled his regime and propelled Mrs. Aquino into the presidency. ``The acquittal does not alter the national interest and security grounds on which we have premised our decision not to allow the return of Mrs. Marcos at the present time,'' Mrs. Aquino said. That effectively rules out for now prosecuting Mrs. Marcos in the Philippines because the nation's constitution forbids trials in absentia. In a second statement Tuesday, Mrs. Aquino said intelligence reports showed that Mrs. Marcos ``encouraged and supported those who wanted to grab power'' during the Dec. 1-9 military coup attempt, in which 113 people were killed and more than 600 injured. ``The return of Mrs. Marcos would enable her to mobilize the underground network of the Marcos dictatorship which is designed to overthrow this government and endanger our democratic gains and economic momentum,'' Mrs. Aquino said. In a telephone interview with Manila radio station DZBB, Mrs. Marcos said: ``I am not opposing Mrs. Aquino. I am not going to fight her. What I will do is just pray to the Lord that I be allowed to come home. I know that He will grant me this, just like my acquittal.'' Despite Mrs. Aquino's stand, most key leaders of the Senate and House of Representatives said Mrs. Marcos should be allowed to return, if only to stand trial. House Speaker Ramon Mitra said Mrs. Marcos should never have been tried abroad and that ``it is important that the arm of the law gets hold of her and she gets her day in court.'' ``In my view, Mrs. Marcos should be allowed to present her defense before Philippine courts,'' said Senate President Jovito Salonga, who was jailed by Marcos. ``This would be a good test of our judicial system and its ability to render speedy, impartial justice.'' Senate Majority Leader Teofisto Guingona said ``unless I am shown specific proof that there is really danger to national security, I would back allowing Mrs. Marcos to defend herself personally here.'' The government has frequently accused the Marcos family of supporting moves to oust Mrs. Aquino but has offered little proof. In February, Brig. Gen. Alejandro Galido claimed he asked Mrs. Marcos to finance the December coup attempt but she declined because of financial problems. On Tuesday, officials said they were ready to prosecute Mrs. Marcos and were simply waiting for a go-ahead from Mrs. Aquino. ``We can still proceed with (charges) insofar as violations of Philippine laws are concerned,'' said Justice Secretary Franklin Drilon. ``This is a political decision. This means President Aquino decides on this.'' The Aquino government claims Marcos and his associates stole $10 billion dollars during his 20 years in power. But the government has never charged any member of the Marcos family with criminal offenses for fear they would demand their right to return from exile to face their accusers. Marcos died in September in Hawaii, but Mrs. Aquino cited national security in refusing permission for the former president to be buried in his homeland. She also refused to allow members of Marcos' immediate family to return. Some people suspect that personal bitterness between the two women plays a more important role than national security in the decision to bar Mrs. Marcos. Mrs. Aquino's husband, Benigno, was slain upon returning home in 1983 to challenge Marcos. In addition, allowing Mrs. Marcos to return home now could be perilous for Mrs. Aquino, whose own popularity is at a low ebb. Despite calls for prosecuting Mrs. Marcos here, it seems unlikely that a trial could be completed by June 1992, when Mrs. Aquino's term expires. The trial of 40 people in the Benigno Aquino assassination began in April 1987 and is still in progress. Ordinary criminal trials often take years to complete.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Stage Anti-Communist Rally
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
LaserPhoto MOSB12
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of rain-soaked protesters chanted ``Down with the Communist Party!'' at a rally Tuesday evening across town from the ruling party's congress in the Kremlin. Dozens of red, white and blue flags of czarist Russia waved in the crowd of more than 4,000 people who gathered in a steady rain outside the main gate of Gorky Park. They listened to radical politicians and artists _ such as poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko and theater director Yuri Lyubimov _ denounce Communism. ``Down with the bandits who captured power in 1917!'' shouted Moscow City Council member Valery Fadeyev, to the cheers of the crowd, which arrived in a steady late afternoon rain that turned into a muggy summer evening. Progressive magazine editor Vitaly Korotich compared the pro-democracy rally to the crucial 28th Communist Party Congress meeting in the plush Palace of Congresses. ``One is under a nice roof and under air conditioning in the Kremlin and another one is under the rain here,'' said Korotich, editor of the popular magazine Ogonyok. ``If we will be able to collect and support one another in the rain, we'll be stronger than the others, who want to put fear in us.'' The crowd cheered lustily at any mention of Boris Yeltsin, the radical president of the Russian republic, who was not present. It whistled derisively at references to the KGB secret police and conservative leaders. Besides the czarist flags, a Lithuanian and Ukrainian banners also waved, as did the all-black standard of the anarchists. Not one hammer-and-sickle was present _ except on a placard that showed the Communist symbol evolving into a swastika with the skulls of the dead below it. Fadeyev drew shouts of ``Well done!'' as he noted the Moscow City Council had removed a bust of Lenin from its chambers. ``We also put up the tri-color Russian flag, and hope that this flag _ our own flag _ will become the symbol of free Russia.'' Yevtushenko drew laughter when he read a poem that ridiculed the Communist system and compared it to a ``little piglet that sucked on the breast of the nation and bit it.'' Lyubimov told the rally: ``I think these are horrible times and we are not really aware of the depths we have fallen into.'' He paraphrased Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel, saying, ``that for 40 years, we served a totalitarian regime and each of us is guilty. We served this horrible machine. And we have become like beasts, all of us.'' Lyubimov said the Communist leaders have ``not a shadow of intellect'' in their faces and ``cannot even speak Russian.'' To the crowd's delight, he then mocked the southern accent of Soviet leaders since Stalin _ including Mikhail S. Gorbachev _ and especially made fun of the wheezing of the late Leonid I. Brezhnev, who in his final years slurred his words badly. Drawing some of the biggest cheers of the rally was Oleg Kalugin, a former KGB agent who has joined the Democratic Platform reform movement. On Saturday, it was announced that Gorbachev stripped him of his rank of major general two weeks after he told Western reporters that the KGB still is tapping telephones, infiltrating religious and union organizations, and carrying out dirty tricks. Kalugin said at the rally that during his years assigned to the United States, he learned to respect activists in the civil rights movement and protesters against the Vietnam War. ``Yes, America affected me to the extent that I witnessed the revelations about the CIA and FBI, which, like the KGB, oppressed the people, suppressed dissent, used criminal methods,'' he said. ``And I saw the American people struggle against it without fear of possible losses.'' Of being stripped of his military rank by Gorbachev, Kalugin said: ``I am still a soldier _ of the army of freedom.''

DOC.HEAD: Federal Panel Blames Pilot For Sliding Airliner Into East River
DOC.TEXT: The National Transportation Safety Board said Tuesday that the pilot of USAir Flight 5050 probably caused his jetliner to skid into New York's East River, killing two passengers. The board, ruling 4-0, said pilot Michael Martin made several mistakes while attempting to take off from LaGuardia Airport last Sept. 20 and then in aborting the takeoff. Among the errors, the NTSB said, were: _Martin's failure to detect an improperly positioned rudder trim control. Correctly set, the control sets the rudder to a neutral, or straight back, position. The knob on Martin's Boeing 737 had somehow been set to full left rudder. _His failure to realize that, even with the knob incorrectly set, he could have taken off by adjusting other controls. _His failure to carry out standard precautions and procedures for aborting a takeoff. The plane skidded off the runway and landed in the river, splitting apart. The 61 survivors were rescued from the river. The Air Line Pilots Association called the board's determination of probable cause in the crash ``a total travesty'' and said it would ask the NTSB to reconsider its finding. The union said the design of the knob itself was to blame. NTSB board member John Lauber said investigators had been reluctant to lay all of the blame for the crash on Martin. But Lauber said the pilot's performance on the LaGuardia airport runway showed so many lapses that the decision was justified. While the NTSB said investigators could not determine how the trim control had been improperly set, the board in the past has found 90 incidents on 737s in which the knob had been incorrectly set. Boeing and safety officials have determined that the knob could be accidentally moved by cockpit visitors putting their feet on the console between the pilot and copilot or by laying a book or other object on the console. Boeing and the Federal Aviation Administration have called for changes in the trim control knobs on all of the more than 600 Boeing 737s in use. The NTSB also said Martin used poor judgment in letting copilot Constantin Kleissas attempt the takeoff on a dark, rainy night, even though he was certified to fly the plane. Kleissas had never before had the controls of a commercial 737. Martin also failed to follow the standard procedure of calling out air speeds to his copilot as the plane moved down the runway. As the plane's speed increased, it began drifting to the left, at which point Martin told Kleissas he was taking the controls and aborting the takeoff. But the NTSB said Martin had not made himself clear and Kleissas wasn't sure what was happening. Once the decision to abort was made, the board said, Martin improperly tried to control the plane by steering with the nosewheel instead of the rudder. In addition, investigators said the pilot had failed during preparations for the flight to ensure that the plane's automatic braking system was set to engage in the event the takeoff was aborted. In summary, the board said, ``The probable cause of this accident was the captain's failure to exercise his command authority in a timely manner to reject the takeoff or take sufficient control to continue the takeoff, which was initiated with a mistrimmed rudder.'' Bob Benzon, the NTSB investigator in charge of the crash, said simulator tests had showed that with proper pilot decisions the plane could either have stopped safely on the runway or could have taken off, even with the rudder trim error. Martin and Kleissas both had their licenses suspended by the FAA, which was critical of their failure to appear for drug tests after the crash. Both, however, have dropped their appeals of the suspensions and can fly again if they pass recertification tests. Board member Jim Burnett joined in the 4-0 vote but filed an additional assertion that USAir's failure to assign ``an adequately prepared and seasoned flight crew'' was a contributing factor in the crash. Burnett said the board did not cite design of the control knob as a factor because the pilot had so many chances to discover and correct it and because Boeing and the FAA already had ordered changes to be made on all 737s to correct the problem.

DOC.HEAD: Sullivan Tells Aides to Curtail Dealings with Activist AIDS Group
DOC.TEXT: Health Secretary Louis Sullivan said Tuesday he is asking officials to avoid all but ``necessary and productive'' dealings with the AIDS activist group ACT UP. Members of the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power (ACT UP) led a noisy demonstration that drowned out Sullivan's speech at an AIDS conference in San Francisco last month and pelted him with wads of paper and other objects as he spoke. Through a spokesman, Sullivan repeated that he will not deal with ``people who behave as ACT UP did.'' ``Whatever dealings that other parts of the department have, we just want to make sure that they are necessary and productive. We will not let the department be used as a punching bag by ACT UP or any other group. We are determined to work together in the fight against AIDS,'' his statement said. James Brown, a spokesman for the Public Health Service, which oversees the bulk of the AIDS research and education efforts in the department, said he could not give an example of the kind of communication that might be cut off. ``It would have to be determined issue by issue,'' he said. Much, however, will remain the same, he said. For example, ACT UP members who sit on department advisory panels will not be removed and ACT UP's advice will be sought when ``necessary and productive,'' Brown said. Larry Kramer, founder of ACT UP, said in a telephone interview from his New York home that Sullivan's response only inflames already bad relations between him and the group's members. ``To Dr. Sullivan I say this: Your presence has been so negligible and you have done so little for us that whether you decide to work with or us or not with us is irrelevant.'' Kramer said the group has been assured that its relationship with the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, which does most of the government's AIDS research, ``is still a productive one.''

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Pleads for Cut in Infant Formula Prices
DOC.TEXT: A congressman called Tuesday for infant formula makers to reduce their prices by 30 percent to prevent thousands of women and babies from being dropped from a federally-funded feeding program. Infant formula prices have skyrocketed by nearly 150 percent in the last 10 years, surpassing milk price increases of 36.4 percent, grocery increases of 50.8 percent, and the 59.1 percent rate of inflation, said Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore. ``The manufacturers of infant formula are gouging mothers who desperately need to feed their babies,'' said Wyden. About a third of the formula sold in this country goes to mothers enrolled in the Special Supplemental Feeding Program for Women, Infants and Children. Wyden said he wrote to the chief operating officers of the five leading formula makers asking fr price reductions. They are Ross Laboratories, makers of Similac; Mead Johnson, makers of Enfamil; American Home Products, makers of SMA; Carnation, makers of Great Start; and Worthington Foods, makers of Soyalac. Wyden said the two largest companies, Ross Laboratories and Mead Johnson have raised their prices 12 times since 1981. Spokesmen at American Home Products, the third largest infant formula maker, and Ross Laboratories said they had not seen Wyden's letter and would not comment. ``The letter is dated July 3. It was received this afternoon at about 4:45 p.m. The person to whom it was addressed is not here. We have not read it and are not able to comment beyond that,'' said Jerry Parrott, spokesman for Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., of which Mead Johnson is a subsidiary. Congress voted last week to allow states to borrow 3 percent against next year's appropriation. Advocates said the move was necessary because rising costs of food have caused states to start cutting participants. Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, said that even with the borrowing capacity 15 states will have to eliminate participants. ``To be sure, these states will remove significantly fewer participants than would have been the case if the legislation had not passed,'' said Greenstein. ``However, some tens of thousands will still be dropped _ perhaps as many as 100,000 overall.''

DOC.HEAD: Air Controllers' Strike Hits France
DOC.TEXT: Air traffic controllers, complaining they are overworked and underpaid, began a three-day strike Tuesday that forced cancellation of about two-thirds of all flights in and out of Paris at the start of the summer vacation season. About 90 percent of the controllers at France's largest flight control center, Athis-Mons, south of Paris, reportedly joined the strike. The Dutch airline KLM and Swissair were among the foreign carriers that announced they were either canceling all flights into Paris for the duration of the strike or reducing them drastically. British Airways said it canceled 14 services between Heathrow airport and Paris. Air France and the French domestic carrier, Air Inter, said they were reducing short and medium-haul flights by 60 percent. Air France said it would maintain its long-haul flights. Officials warned that delays should be expected. The strike disrupted some other flights over Western Europe because Athis-Mons controls the air space over northern France used on those routes. Strikers cited increased air traffic, understaffing and the high cost of living in the Paris area in demanding compensating bonuses. In a letter to controllers, Transport Minister Michel Delebarre expressed his ``profound disagreement'' with the strike, saying it would ``seriously penalize French and foreign users, and notably those going on vacation.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says He has Authority to Bar Muslim Leader From Barry Trial
With AM-Barry Trial a0635
DOC.TEXT: The judge in Mayor Marion Barry's drug case argued Tuesday that he is entitled to bar Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan and a dissident Roman Catholic priest from the trial because their presence probably would intimidate witnesses and jurors. The Justice Department, in a separate filing, supported Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's contention that neither Barry, Farrakhan nor George Augustus Stallings is legally entitled to ask for relief from the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. The American Civil Liberties Union, which brought the suit on behalf of Barry, Farrakhan and Stallings, will respond Wednesday to the Justice and Jackson filings, said local ACLU legal director Arthur Spitzer. When he barred Farrakhan from the courtroom last Wednesday, Jackson said that the Muslim leader's presence ``would be potentially disruptive and very likely intimidating.'' He cited the same reasoning in denying Stallings entry to the proceedings. In his submission to the appeals court, the judge wrote, ``Farrakhan and Stallings, by reason of their extraordinary publicity and their widely known and highly controversial views on matters directly pertainting to the ongoing trial, would be likely to send an impermissible `message' to, and to distract, disrupt and intimidate, both jurors and witnesses.'' Barry can take up the matter with the appeals court if appeals a conviction in his drug possession and perjury case, the judge wrote. ``Revs. Farrakhan and Stallings are not parties to any case or proceeding in the District Court,'' Jackson wrote. ``It follows that, because there is no proper jurisdiction in this court for (them) ... there is no valid basis for any requested `relief.''' ``District courts posess considerable discretion to exclude specific spectators in order to ensure that jurors and witnesses are free of distraction, disruption, and intimidation,'' the judge added. Jackson concluded that his actions were ``well within (my) discretion under the unique circumstances'' that Barry's trial has produced. The judge announced his decision to exclude Farrakhan and Stallings while the jury in Barry's case was outside the courtroom. In both instances, Barry had sought to give one of his special guest passes to the men. In his initial filing, Spitzer argued that Jackson must present proof that Farrakhan and Stallings would disrupt the trial. He also claimed that Jackson's order violated the mayor's constitutional right to a public trial. But the Justice Department wrote that since ``the press and members of the public are allowed to attend all proceedings, ... defendant Barry's right to a public trial is preserved.'' About a dozen of Farrakhan's followers have protested Jackson's actions outside the courthouse this week, while Stallings has decried Jackson's decision as well. The story has become a sidelight in Barry's case; both Farrakhan and Stallings, who are black, claim that they have been excluded from the proceedings because of their race. Barry and his backers have been suggesting for months that the case against the mayor was racially motivated. Thirteen of the 18 jurors are black. Jackson, who is white, has refused to comment on the matter outside his legal filings.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's Comrades Shatter Kremlin Unity With Attacks on His Policies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to recast lead, move up reference to Biryukova resignation, insert background; Picks up 7th graf, `When the ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB2,4,6,7, MOS23
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's hard-line Kremlin colleagues on Tuesday sharply attacked his reforms of the ailing Soviet economy, politics, the military and diplomacy. ``There are forces in our country fighting against socialist order, against the Communist Party,'' warned conservative Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev, rejecting attacks on party hard-liners and their allies in the army. His remarks drew thunderous applause from the 4,657 delegates at the 28th Communist Party congress. Gorbachev, the party general secretary and president, sat stone-faced behind the speaker's platform in the Kremlin Palace of Congresses. Opponents, Ligachev said, ``applaud things that are directed toward the breakup of socialism in our country, toward undermining the party, presenting them as innovations, as real perestroika.'' Gorbachev told the delegates that four top party officials submitted their resignations, further undermining the traditional public unity of the collective Kremlin leadership. Gorbachev increasingly has been the target of public criticism by his colleagues. The four officials included non-voting politburo member Alexandra Biryukova, the highest-ranking woman in the leadership. She was responsible for consumer goods, and Gorbachev gave no reason for her resignation. Gorbachev's critics did not mention him by name, in keeping with tradition. But the resignations and the abuse heaped on his policies raised doubts that he has enough support at the top to push further reforms. When the 10-day congress is over, it will have elected a party leader and Central Committee, and will have approved a new platform and party rules. The harsh speeches by Gorbachev's colleagues on the ruling Politburo _ the first allowed at a congress of this type since 1921 _ were televised nationally after a delay. A Gorbachev ally, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, praised the reforms, and countered conservative criticism that he had signed unfavorable arms control treaties with the West and too much was cut from the military budget. Gorbachev appeared unperturbed by the criticism. Acting as congress chairman, he cracked jokes and laughed. After Communist leaders aired their differences, about 4,000 reformers gathered across the Moscow River and gave the congress a bad review. Braving a steady rain, they rallied at the main gate of Gorky Park, shouting, ``Down with the Communist Party!'' and ``Down with the KGB!'' Many waved the red, white and blue flags of czarist Russia. Inside the red brick walls of the Kremlin, the 69-year-old Ligachev railed against three of Gorbachev's reforms: his plan to put factories and farms in private hands, his farm investment policy and his anti-alcoholism campaign, which has been abandoned. Ligachev also said Gorbachev's 5-year-old perestroika reform program was marred by ``limitless radicalism'' and ``improvisations'' that have brought little good. KGB Chairman Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, in a speech laden with Marxist-Leninist ideology, criticized economic reforms he said have produced ``property stratification'' among the population and ``a whole layer of millionaires.'' He said some people want to import capitalism, bringing with it the many ills of that system. ``We hear assertions that in the West, everything is good and here everything is bad. We are drawn to Western experience. ... But can we allow that along with useful experience, the negative in the world of capital has also been transferred into our life?'' He listed the ills as mass unemployment, rampant crime and drug abuse. Gorbachev repeatedly has praised Western economies, especially during his trip to the United States last month, for providing incentives to workers and fostering high living standards. Another conservative, Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov, rejected demands by Communist reformers to eliminate party cells in the armed forces. ``That would be very harmful,'' he told the delegates, including some military officers. Yazov wore his green marshal's uniform emblazoned with several rows of medals. Shevardnadze made a spirited defense of perestroika, and rejected charges of ``concessions in the security arena.'' ``If we continue as we did, to spend one-quarter of the gross national income on military spending, we will ruin the country and we will simply not need any defense any more,'' the white-haired diplomat said. ``A ruined country and poor people do not need an army.'' Shevardnadze praised Soviet policy in Eastern Europe, where since last August new governments have replaced what he called ``forced and alien administrative-command systems, totalitarian regimes.'' ``We sensed that if there were not changes, there would be tragedy,'' he said. Ligachev later told reporters in the lobby that the loss of Eastern Europe ``doesn't strengthen our position, but weakens it.'' Shevardnadze was applauded, but not nearly as much as Ligachev. In a remark that ran counter to Soviet tradition, Shevardnadaze said he did not see why the foreign minister should sit on the Politburo. Some changes in the Politburo were already in the works. In addition to Biryukova, two full Politburo members, Nikolai N. Slyunkov and Vitaly I. Vorotnikov, have submitted their resignations, Gorbachev announced. Gumer I. Usmanov, who sits on the party secretariat, also signaled his intention to resign. Gorbachev said Usmanov and Slyunkov were ill. Vorotnikov recently lost a job that carried nearly automatic inclusion on the Politburo, that of President of the Russian Federation. The resignations have not yet been accepted.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says He has Authority to Bar Muslim Leader From Barry Trial
With AM-Barry Trial
DOC.TEXT: The judge in Mayor Marion Barry's drug trial told an appeals court Tuesday that he is entitled to bar Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan and an excommunicated Roman Catholic priest from the courtroom. ``District courts possess considerable discretion to exclude specific spectators in order to ensure that jurors and witnesses are free of distraction, disruption, and intimidation,'' U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson wrote in court papers supporting his decision. The Justice Department, in a separate filing, supported Jackson's contention that Barry, Farrakhan nor George Augustus Stallings could legally seek relief from the U.S. District Court of Appeals. The bar against Farrakhan and Stallings, whose break with the Roman Catholic Church has brought him widespread publicity, has become a sidelight of Barry's three-week-old trial. Barry supporters have called it evidence that the mayor is being persecuted by the government because he is black. The American Civil Liberties Union, which brought the suit on behalf of Barry, Farrakhan and Stallings, will respond Wednesday to the government and Jackson filings, said local ACLU legal director Arthur Spitzer. Farrakhan was barred from entering the courtroom as Barry's guest last Wednesday. The judge said the Muslim leader's presence ``would be potentially disruptive and very likely intimidating.'' He cited the same reasoning in denying Stallings entry on Thursday. In his court papers, Jackson wrote that Barry could take up the matter with the appeals court if he is convicted in his drug and perjury trial and then appeals. And he said he was using his authority to keep the courtroom proceedings moving smoothly. Jackson announced his decision to exclude Farrakhan and Stallings while the jury was outside the courtroom. In both instances, Barry had sought to give one of his four special guest passes to the men. Jackson concluded that his actions were ``well within (my) discretion under the unique circumstances'' that Barry's trial has produced. Barry has appeared to prolonged applause at public events recently with both Farrakhan and Stallings, who contend they have been excluded from the courtroom because they are black. In his initial filing, Spitzer argued that Jackson must show proof that the men would disrupt the trial. He also claimed that Jackson's order violated the mayor's constitutional right to a public trial. But the Justice Department wrote that since ``the press and members of the public are allowed to attend all proceedings, ... defendant Barry's right to a public trial is preserved.'' About a dozen of Farrakhan's followers have protested Jackson's actions outside the courthouse this week, and Stallings has also decried Jackson's decision. Jackson, who is white, has refused to comment on the matter outside his legal filings.

DOC.HEAD: Witness: Barry Vetoed Contract After She Vetoed Sex
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout; Moore's testimony concluded; detail on alleged sex request; DELETES last 5 grafs to tighten
DOC.TEXT: Rasheeda Moore testified at Marion Barry's drug and perjury trial Tuesday that she lost a city contract in 1988 because she refused the mayor's request for oral sex. She said Barry told her ``You refuse, therefore you refuse the contract.'' Finishing five days of testimony, the woman who aided the FBI sting against Barry said the contract had been speedily approved in 1986 ``because the mayor told me it would be.'' Moore answered prosecution questions seeking to counter Barry defense attempts to show the mayor was illegally enticed into smoking crack cocaine the night of his arrest. Moore said she turned Barry down at a downtown Washington hotel where they and another woman, Maria McCarthy, had been using drugs and discussing Moore's contract for a program to build self-esteem in city teenagers. After she rejected the mayor's sexual advance, Barry told her ``because I refused, `I can't promise you the program this year,''' Moore testified. ``My contract had not been signed'' and approved by city officials, Moore said of her conversation with the mayor. ``I asked him if he could make some calls.'' ``He did ask me to have oral sex with him,'' Moore testified later in the day. ``Did you comply?'' asked Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin. ``No,'' said Moore. Barry then told Moore, ``You refuse, therefore you refuse the contract,'' Moore testified. The $180,000 contract for Project Me was not renewed that year, said Moore. She said the incident took place in the summer of 1988 at the Vista Hotel soon after she ended her sexual relationship with the three-term mayor. The hotel was later the site of Barry's Jan. 18 arrest for allegedly using crack cocaine. Barry lawyer R. Kenneth Mundy brought out earlier grand jury testimony in which Moore said she had been heavily involved with drugs in the summer of 1988 and was in no condition to carry out the program. But she also testified about the sex aspect to the grand jury. Barry, 54, is facing 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge, and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use. Moore has said the two used drugs together more than 100 times between 1986 and 1988. Moore also recanted earlier testimony that she had violated FBI instructions in the sting operation that led to Barry's arrest. She had admitted to Mundy last Friday that she ``overcarried'' FBI instructions by steering her conversation with Barry to drugs and that she twice invited Barry to come up to her room. But on Tuesday, she said Barry was eager to meet with her at the hotel and that he brought up the subject of drugs the minute he walked in her hotel room. ``Is it still your testimony that you went beyond your instructions,'' asked Retchin. ``No, it's not,'' said Moore. Mundy, attacking Moore's motives and credibility, said she has received more than $32,000 in aid from the government. But that allowed Moore, under later prosecution questioning, to tell jurors she was in the Justice Department's witness protection program because the government contends it has evidence a $100,000 contract has been put out on her life. The jury was told that Barry had nothing to do with that threat against Moore's life. And Retchin, countering Mundy's suggestion that Barry was merely led along by Moore, asked her in a series of questions whether she helped Barry use crack cocaine during the sting. ``No, I did not,'' Moore said. Moore also told jurors that before the sting, she told the FBI the mayor used code words for drug use, including the phrase ``mess around.'' Moore has contended Barry raised the subject of drugs the night of his arrest when he asked her whether an undercover FBI agent posing as a friend of Moore's would ``mess around.''

DOC.HEAD: Leak Tests Scheduled for Later This Week for Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: Engineers on both coasts will begin tests after the Fourth of July to find the mysterious fuel leaks that have grounded America's space shuttle fleet for an indefinite time. ``We don't expect the stand-down to be extensive,'' NASA's space flight chief, William Lenoir, said Tuesday. But he conceded that, ``We don't know exactly how long it's going to be.'' A 17-inch fuel line removed from the shuttle Columbia was brought to shuttle builder Rockwell International in California for the tests, along with the complicated hardware that connects the line to the orbiter and its huge tank. The shuttle Atlantis still is on the launch pad at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida awaiting a sequence of tests being worked out this week. Both shuttles leaked supercold liquid hydrogen as their tanks were being filled recently, causing their launches to be postponed. The fuel transfer system also includes a four-inch pipe used to pressurize the tank and a two-inch line that pumps helium early in the fueling process. The pipes are in two parts, one half attached to the orbiter, the other to the fuel tank. They are connected until eight minutes into a flight when the tank is empty and jettisoned. The half on the orbiter is reused; the other half is destroyed with the tank. Engineers have detected leaks in both the 17-inch and 4-inch lines, but don't know exactly where, Lenoir said. The leaks show only when the liquid hydrogen, is flowing through the pipes at minus 431 degrees Fahrenheit. ``On the 4-inch side, there is a leak but it may be within specifications, which means we don't have a concern with it,'' Lenoir said. ``It would appear there is a more significant problem with the 17-inch and that's where we ought to focus our attention.'' The tests in Downey will be conducted first with gaseous helium, then gaseous nitrogen, then gaseous hydrogen, Lenoir said. If that doesn't reveal the leak, engineers will use liquid nitrogen and finally liquid hydrogen. The fuel lines and fittings from the tanks on Columbia and Atlantis are numbers three and four in a batch of eight that failed acceptance tests in 1983, then were passed in a subsequent procedure. The first two were used in March and November last year to get Discovery into orbit. Lenoir said, however, that about 20 such units had failed when they were first tested, only to pass on a retest and ``we didn't change procedures in order to pass these.'' On NASA's other big problem, the out-of-focus $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope, the space agency said that some fuzzy images may be improved through the same computer process that cleaned up photos taken by the Voyager spacecraft. But, said Ed Weiler, a Hubble project scientist, the pictures will still be less clear than scientists originally expected. Weiler said a team of experts was being selected to determine how much of the ``fuzz ball'' now being seen by the space telescope can be turned into crisp pictures through computer techniques. He called the improvement of pictures through computers ``something of a black art.'' But he said other experts in the field are certain they can improve some of Hubble's views. ``I'll believe it when I see it,'' Weiler told reporters. ``We'll let the experts play with the images. People in the field say there is a lot of hope there.'' Weiler emphasized, however, that the computer-enhancing technique is only an effort to salvage some good from a fundamentally flawed telescope.

DOC.HEAD: Ruling Junta General Says Power Will Be Transferred to Civilians
DOC.TEXT: The general who heads Burma's military junta said Tuesday that he will hand over power to a civilian administration government only after a new constitution is drafted. Gen. Saw Maung, the chairman of the State Law and Order Restoration Council, also said the nation's military rulers are willing to help draft the constitution. In a speech to the council and military commanders, the general said: ``We are prepared to give suggestions in drafting the constitution that will be of benefit to the country. ``The constitution should not be drafted in a haste just for speedy transfer of power but it should be drafted to satisfy the interests of all national races, national unity and rehabilitation of the country,'' he added. Burma's military brutally crushed a pro-democracy uprising in 1988. The country's leading pro-democracy party, the National League for Democracy, scored a massive victory in general elections in May, but there has not yet been a transfer of power. Saw Maung also said though law and order prevails in the country, there is no political stability yet. The general took power in a military coup in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Angola's Ruling Party Says Multiparty Democracy Possible After War Ends
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Marxist party pledged Tuesday to establish a multiparty democracy, but said it could take place only after the 15-year-old civil war with U.S.-backed rebels ends and a new constitution is adopted. A spokesman for the rebels criticized the declaration as vague. In Luanda, the capital, the central committee of the ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola issued its statement after five days of often heated discussions. ``The People's Republic of Angola will evolve toward a multiparty (political) system, within a framework of a new constitution to be submitted to a popular referendum,'' the statement said. But the shift away from single-party rule would only come ``once peace, stability and internal security (exist),'' it added. The statement also reaffirmed support for President Jose Eduardo dos Santos to ``overcome obstacles that continue to block'' a peace settlement with rebel National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or UNITA. The rebels, led by Jonas Savimbi, have been fighting the government since Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975. In Washington, a rebel spokesman said the declaration ``falls short of our expectations.'' ``They are talking about a possibility, after a referendum ... nobody knows when,'' said Jardo Muekalia, UNITA's Washington representative. ``We had expected them to come out with concrete terms for a cease-fire and multiparty democracy,'' he said in a telephone interview. Since the collapse of last year's truce, government and rebel officials have met twice this year for Portuguese-sponsored peace talks. Dos Santos has been under pressure from hard-line party officials to scrap peace efforts and push further military action. Some rebel leaders have also opposed the peace talks. After the last round of talks in mid-June, Portuguese officials said the two sides were close to a lasting cease-fire agreement. Points of contention are how to monitor a cease-fire and terms for Angola's political future, diplomats said. Savimbi, visiting the African nation of Togo on Tuesday, demanded a cease-fire before resuming negotiations. He said he was optimistic that talks would proceed because ``the natural allies of our antagonists are no longer in a position to aid them.'' Luanda has received massive amounts of Soviet military equipment, and Moscow has pledged to continue supplies despite its economic problems. The war once pitted South African forces backing UNITA against some 50,000 Cuban troops in Angola to support the government. South African aid to the rebels officially ended with regional peace accords signed with Angola and Cuba in December 1988, but UNITA still receives U.S. military assistance. Cuba has already sent home more than 33,000 soldiers under the agreement, but Soviet military aid continues.

DOC.HEAD: Walker Lundy Named Editor of Saint Paul Pioneer Press
DOC.TEXT: Walker Lundy, a general news executive with Gannett newspapers who has held key positions at several newspapers, has been named editor of the Saint Paul Pioneer Press, the newspaper announced. Lundy, who succeeds Deborah Howell, begins his duties July 9. In May, Howell was named Washington bureau chief for Newhouse newspapers and editor of the Newhouse News Service. Lundy's appointment was made by Mary Junck, publisher and president of the Pioneer Press. The appointment was announced Monday. Lundy, 47, has been with Gannett newspapers in Washington for the past two months. Before that he spent two years as editor of the Arkansas Gazette in Little Rock. He has also worked as managing editor of the Fort Worth (Texas) Star-Telegram, executive editor of the Tallahassee (Fla.) Democrat, city editor of the Detroit Free Press, and metropolitan editor of The Charlotte (N.C.) Observer. Lundy will direct the news staff at the Pioneer Press, a Knight-Ridder paper. The staff of the editorial pages will report to Junck.

DOC.HEAD: Imelda Celebrates, U.S. Attorney `Guaranteed' Conviction
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3-6, `Khashoggi, whose ...,' with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Mrs. Marcos going to Doris Duke home, aide saying she may stay in New York; pick up 7th graf, `The jury ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY26
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos, acquitted of federal charges that she helped her husband loot the Philippine treasury, celebrated at a noisy party with co-defendant Adnan Khashoggi. Marcos spokesman Willie Padrone said Mrs. Marcos hasn't decided to return to Hawaii, where she has lived since she and her late husband, President Ferdinand Marcos, fled a popular revolt in the Philippines in 1986. Another aide to Mrs. Marcos, Roger Peyuan, said Mrs. Marcos might stay in New York for a while to do things she wasn't able to do while she was on trial. Khashoggi, whose acquittal freed him of restrictions on his movements, headed for Palm Beach, Fla. The 54-year-old financier said he would fly to France, then to his native Saudi Arabia to visit Islam's holiest shrine at Mecca. Mrs. Marcos slept in Tuesday after Monday night's party. Early Tuesday evening, she left Manhattan for the Hillsborough, N.J., home of her friend Doris Duke, the tobacco heiress, Peyuan said. Mrs. Duke lent Mrs. Marcos her Manhattan apartment and reportedly paid legal fees including $5 million for her main defense attorney, Gerry Spence. Peyuan said Mrs. Marcos might stay at Duke's home overnight or possibly for several days. Don Robinson, an attorney who represents Miss Duke, quoted her as saying: ``When I posted the bail for my friend Imelda a year and a half ago, I did it because I knew she was innocent. Now that 12 good citizens, after hearing all the evidence, have agreed with me, I am overjoyed. God Bless America.'' The jury on Monday rejected the government's allegations that Mrs. Marcos had helped her husband loot their country's treasury of $222 million to secretly buy New York buildings and other luxuries. It acquitted Khashoggi of charges he faked documents to show that he, rather than the Marcoses, owned the properties before a federal court order froze their assets in 1986. In post-verdict interviews, jurors made clear they felt the pair shouldn't have been tried in the United States. One juror, Thomas O'Rourke, called the case ``totally silly.'' Ironically, a State Department memo which surfaced after the acquittal showed that U.S. Attorney Rudolph Giuliani, who initiated the charges against the Marcoses, ``guaranteed'' that the case would end in conviction. Giuliani, the memo said, believed the evidence was so strong that there was no reason to offer Marcos a plea bargain, because he would be ``more likely to settle'' after being indicted. The State Department disagreed. ``Marcos should be given a last chance, prior to indictment, to reach a voluntary plea agreement ... that should enable him to avoid being sentenced to prison,'' the State Department urged in the September 1988 memo. The memorandum was written by Abraham D. Sofaer, the State Department's chief legal expert, shortly before a federal grand jury indicted the Marcoses, Khashoggi and several others. It is part of the record of the trial. It did not mention Mrs. Marcos or Khashoggi, but focused entirely on Marcos, who the Justice Department said was ``continuing illegal activity'' while living in exile in Hawaii. After Marcos' death last September, U.S. officials chose to continue the case against his widow. Giuliani left office in January 1989 and was defeated as the Republican candidate for mayor of New York last November. He is with a private law firm, and did not return a phone call to his office. A secretary said he has made it a policy to decline comment on cases left over from his time as U.S. attorney. The office of Giuliani's successor, U.S. Attorney Otto Obermaier, said it could not estimate the cost of the three-month trial. Speculation that Mrs. Marcos might mount a political challenge to President Corazon Aquino, who replaced Marcos, was snuffed when Mrs. Aquino said Mrs. Marcos is a ``security threat'' and would not be allowed to return. Mrs. Aquino said intelligence reports also showed that Mrs. Marcos ``encouraged and supported those who wanted to grab power'' during a Dec. 1-9 coup attempt in which 113 people were killed and more than 600 were injured. In Washington, State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said Mrs. Marcos' return was a matter for the government of the Philippines to determine. But he added that the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service's June 16, 1989, ``departure control order'' prohibiting Mrs. Marcos from leaving the country remained in effect. He said the ban was based on the potential for ``destabilizing activity'' should she return to Manila as well as the legal problems here.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Police Break Art Smuggling Ring, Recover 1,500 Items
DOC.TEXT: Police uncovered an international network of art smugglers and recovered more than 1,500 ancient vases, coins, statuettes and other items worth millions of dollars, news reports said Tuesday. The antiquities, many in near-perfect condition, had disappeared from archeological digs in Tuscany and southern Italy, the state RAI television network reported. In an investigation that started in November, police traced a network of thieves who were sending the ancient artworks to Switzerland, where several companies restored them and issued false documents on their authenticity and value, the Italian news service ANSA reported. Some of the items, most of which dated from the ancient Etruscan civilization of central Italy, were sent back to Florence and sold to private buyers, ANSA said. Other items were sold directly to museums throughout the world, it said. Forty Italians, Swiss and West Germans have been accused of criminal association, receiving stolen goods and violation of the law on cultural patrimony, ANSA reported. The 1,500 objects were recovered in house searches throughout Italy and the confiscation of a train shipment in Florence, according to the agency.

DOC.HEAD: Albanians Rush Embassies By Hundreds to Leave Hard-line Nation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4 grafs for 7-8 pvs, `Large numbers ...' to UPDATE with crisis atmosphere in Tirana. Pickup 9th pvs, `Turkish Ambassador...' EDITS to conform and trim
DOC.TEXT: Rioting broke out in the Albanian capital of Tirana, and diplomats said Tuesday that hundreds of people stormed foreign embassies there trying to flee Europe's last bastion of hard-line communism. Italy's Foreign Ministry, in a statement in Rome, said Albanian security forces used firearms to try to turn back the refugees. A Greek government communique reported shooting and unconfirmed accounts of ``victims among the population.'' The Albanian government confirmed the rioting and acknowledged people were wounded at one embassy. A statement by the official ATA news agency said 300 to 400 people, including ``vagabonds, former prisoners ... as well as some deceived adolescents,'' tried to storm the unspecified embassy Monday night. The statement, telexed to The Associated Press in Vienna, said the crowd threw stones and bricks at police, blocked traffic and broke shop windows. It said security forces restored order and detained people. It said some people were ``slightly wounded.'' Diplomats said about 200 Albanians sought refuge in at least a dozen embassies since late last week. The greatest concentration, 86, appeared to be in the West German compound. Hanns Schumacher, deputy West German Foreign Ministry spokesman, said in Bonn the refugees' motives were not completely clear, but he assumed ``this is the outbreak of dissatisfaction with the existing political realities in Albania.'' Security forces patrolled Tirana in strength on Tuesday, and 150 officers guarded the West German and Turkish embassies, the Austria Press Agency said. It quoted Western diplomats as saying anti-government demonstrations had hit Tirana in the last few days. Austria Press Agency reporter Wilfried Seywald reported from Tirana that authorities canceled all Tuesday appointments. The mood was reported as somber, with security forces everywhere. Turkish Ambassador Teoman Surenkok said 26 of the 32 Albanians who fled to his embassy left after the Albanian government allowed them to leave the country, the Anatolia News Agency reported. The Czechoslovak news agency CTK said representatives of the Czechoslovak Foreign Ministry began talks with Albanian authorities to try to resolve their embassy occupation. One Western diplomat in Tirana said the surge of refugees started last week when 25 Albanians entered the Polish Embassy. A host country cannot legally violate embassy premises. The developments were reminiscent of events last year, when East Germans crowded Western embassies in Eastern Europe and touched off the popular revolution in their country. Albania has vigorously resisted the pro-democracy movements that have radically altered other Eastern European nations. The Albanian government has made only modest reforms in that country of 3.2 million. Greece's government released a statement Tuesday saying, ``According to other reports which have been impossible to confirm up to now, shots were heard last night and it is rumored that there were victims among the population.'' The Albanian news agency said that ``with the immediate interference of the forces of order and the working people of the capital, the persons who violated order and tranquility dispersed. There were slightly wounded on both parties. The people kept a number of them for the necessary investigations.'' The agency called Monday night's disturbance ``an alarming situation'' aimed at impairing ``the good relations existing with the friendly states represented in Tirana, and to distort the image of Albania in the world.'' A Foreign Ministry spokesman in Bonn, speaking on condition of anonymity, said 86 refugees were in the West German Embassy as of Tuesday night. Guards fired on one group of four who fled into the compound Sunday night, wounding one man in the leg, said Schumacher. Seventy-nine people fled to the embassy Monday night and early Tuesday, West German diplomats said. One group crashed their truck into the German compound's walls, others fled in through that hole and the final group crashed their truck into the Greek compound next door as Albanian guards fired on them, West German diplomats said. In the confusion, some Albanians fled into the Greek compound and some into the West German Embassy, said a ministry spokesman. ``I heard more than 50 shots when they were trying to get into the West German Embassy,'' the Western diplomat in Tirana said. Three more refugees gained entry into the West German Embassy later Tuesday, the German spokesman said. Asylum seekers also used a truck to break into the Italian Embassy, said the Western diplomat. An Italian Foreign Ministry spokesman said about 20 refugees were seeking asylum there. West Germany summoned the Albanian ambassador to the Foreign Ministry to protest ``the brutal behavior'' of Albanian authorities. Italy made a similar protest. Hungary's MTI news agency said four Albanians were in Hungary's embassy. Refugees were also reportedly holed up at embassies of France, Algeria, Bulgaria, China and Egypt.

DOC.HEAD: Chernobyl Hero Dies; Soviet Physician Says He Got Best Possible Care
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet helicopter pilot hailed as a hero for trying to douse the 1986 fire at the Chernobyl nuclear plant despite intense radiation died at age 53 after developing radiation-related leukemia. Anatoly Grishchenko died late Monday at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center. The final cause of death was listed as heart failure brought on by a lung infection. Doctors said Tuesday that Grishchenko may have been doomed by delays in getting him treatment. Still, Grishchenko's Soviet physician said the treatment he received at the center was the best anywhere, and said she could not fault it. ``I'll try to tell my chief and all the Soviet people and all the Soviet physicians that patient Grishchenko had the best treatment he could have here at this center,'' Dr. Eugenia Margulis told a news conference Tuesday. ``Everybody was taking care of him. Not only the physicians and the nurses and the staff, but all the people from Seattle.'' She said Grishchenko, the only Chernobyl victim to be treated in the United States, received more than 100 cards and letters daily from around the country. Seattle Mayor Norm Rice ordered flags on city buildings to fly at half-staff Tuesday in Grishchenko's honor. In April 1986, Grishchenko repeatedly flew his helicopter through the intensely radioactive gases above the smoldering Chernobyl plant, dumping sand and cement to entomb the crippled reactor after it exploded. He was among a handful of participants designated heroes of the Soviet Union, that country's highest honor. When Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev visited America in June for summit talks with President Bush, he sent a top aide to give Grishchenko a handwritten note praising his bravery. After the disaster, Grishchenko suffered acute radiation sickness. He was found to have leukemia last year. He was flown to Seattle April 11, and a bone- marrow transplant was performed later that month. Doctors thought his chances of recovery good, and Hutchinson Associate Director John Hansen said he was out of bed doing exercises after the transplant. But a lung infection flared up, and Grishchenko underwent surgery June 12. His condition worsened, and on June 15 he was placed on a respirator. Hutchinson Dr. Finn Petersen, who assisted in the transplant, said a combination of Soviet red tape and difficulty finding a marrow donor contributed to the infection, which he said developed when Grishchenko got pneumonia in January and persisted until it cut off oxygen to his bloodstream. ``He probably would not have developed this infection if we didn't have the wait,'' Petersen said. ``We should have done the transplant last fall,'' Hansen added. Grishchenko's initial response to treatment showed promise for others, said Dr. Patrick Beatty, director of the center's Unrelated Transplant Program. ``Despite his heavy radiation exposure in the past ... he actually did extremely well in the transplant,'' Beatty said. Margulis did not know how many people in the Soviet Union suffer from similar conditions, and neither she nor Hansen could say if others are trying to get treatment at American facilities. Margulis said a new medical center is planned for Gomel, about 300 miles southwest of Moscow, near Chernobyl. ``It is better to build a new center in the Soviet Union than to send them here,'' which is ``very expensive to our government,'' she said. Grishchenko's treatment is estimated to have cost about $180,000. Margulis said she learned a lot about treating radiation cancer, but was frustrated at having to wait to apply that knowledge at home until the Gomel center is built. Margulis will accompany Grishchenko's body back to Moscow with his widow, Galina. ``Mrs. Grishchenko is a very brave, strong, courageous woman and she is handling this very well,'' Hansen said.

DOC.HEAD: Saudis Confirm More Than 1,400 Dead in Tragedy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3 grafs for grafs 10-11 pvs, `Prince Najef...' to UPDATE with survivors' account; pickup 12th pvs, `Islam prescribes...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LON3,6, NY16, LaserGraphics
DOC.TEXT: A frantic stampede that killed more than 1,400 Moslem pilgrims inside a pedestrian tunnel was prompted by the tumbling of seven people from a bridge overhead, the interior minister said Tuesday. Prince Nayef put the death toll at 1,426, making it the worst pilgrimage tragedy in recent history. There were no further details immediately available on the pilgrims who fell from the bridge. Reporters were barred from the General Hospital at Mina, the tent city connected by the tunnel to Mecca. Officials said the government had ordered that journalists not be allowed to interview or photograph victims. The tragedy shattered what had been a peaceful observance of the annual pilgrimage, or Hajj, for the first time in four years. In previous years, the celebration was marred by terrorist attacks and riots. The Mo'essem pedestrian tunnel, which is under part of a mountain, is 500 yards long and 20 yards wide. It was built under a $15-billion development project launched by the government at holy sites two years ago. The air-conditioned tunnel was packed ``multiple times beyond its capacity, with some 50,000 people inside,'' Prince Nayef said. The temperature outside soared to 112 degrees. ``The fall of the seven (from the bridge) spread terror, and the tremendous throngs of the pilgrims caused them all to tumble onto each other,'' he said on state television. ``Old people first began falling under the feet in panic and terror,'' an aide to Prince Nayef said. ``No one could go back or forth ... the pilgrims were falling on each other, the bodies piling on each other ... there was a mad rush and screaming.'' Witnesses said the panic began after power inside the tunnel was suddenly cut off. Most victims died of suffocation or were trampled in the ensuing stampede. A Sudanese survivor told state TV: ``We were stuck inside unable to move back or forth. Rescue men were throwing sacks of ice-cold water which we grabbed to overcome the heat and thirst ... there was no ventilation and the number of hajjis (pilgrims) in the tunnel was growing bigger by the second.'' Prince Nayef, who is the Saudi monarch's brother, said a number of pilgrims fainted at were treated on the spot, but he did not say how many people were injured. He also did not give the nationalities of the victims. Asian and Middle Eastern diplomats told The Associated Press on Monday night that there were 1,400 victims, including Egyptians, Indians, Pakistanis, Indonesians, Malaysians, Turks and Saudis. Islam prescribes quick burial of the dead, but in case of accidents of great magnitude, bodies are allowed to stay in morgues until governments or relatives decide whether they should be flown home or buried in the holy cities. Most families were expected to decide to bury their next of kin in Mecca, sources said. In Malaysia, the daughter of one victim was quoted as saying her father had mentioned before going to Mecca ``how wonderful it would be if he were to die among holy people in the sacred city.'' Roslina Mat Taib told the national news agency Bernama her family was grateful her father's wish had come true, especially because there would be thousands of pilgrims to pray for him and the others who died. King Fahd said Monday that the incident ``was God's will, which is above everything. ``It was fate. Had they not died there, they would have died elsewhere and at the same predestined moment,'' he said. In Kennebunkport, Maine, President Bush sent condolences to the pilgrims' families. Outside the Mina hospital Tuesday, pilgrims waited for word on missing relatives and friends. Four Egyptian men said they were looking for a missing friend. One said the group had been a few yards from the tunnel when the stampede occurred. Their friend was two yards ahead of them and had entered the tunnel. ``He did not come back,'' the pilgrim said. He refused to give his name. About 2 million Moslems gathered in Mecca for this year's pilgrimage, which climaxed Monday with Eid Al-Adha, or the Feast of Sacrifice. The three-day holiday commemorates the prophet Abraham's offering of his son as sacrifice to God. Pilgrims milled through Mecca on Tuesday, carrying on with religious rituals and almost oblivious to the tunnel accident. They chanted: ``Allahu Akbar Kabira, Al-Hamdulillah Katheera,'' Arabic for ``God is most great, many thanks be to God.'' Tuesday's rituals included the symbolic stoning of the devil at Mina. They also circled the Kaaba, in the Grand Mosque, which is Islam's holiest shrine. Many pilgrims also headed for Medina, the second-holiest city, to visit the prophet Mohammed's tomb. Mecca is where the 7th century prophet Mohammed, founder of Islam, was born. In 1986, security officials found large quantities of explosives in Mecca, indicating some kind of sabotage was planned. The following year, the city was shaken by its worst bout of violence ever. Saudi riot police clashed with pilgrims, who defied a government ban on political rallies during the religious event. More than 400 people, most of the Iranians, were killed. Last year, one pilgrim was killed and 16 wounded when two bombs exploded in the holy city. Sixteen people, tried and convicted of the attacks, later were beheaded.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Allies at Odds Over How To Signal Peaceful Intentions
DOC.TEXT: NATO plans to signal its peaceful intentions toward their former adversaries in Eastern Europe at this week's summit but is at odds over issuing a non-aggression declaration, officials said Tuesday. ``The idea of sending some kind of sign to the East that we really mean it when we say we're non-aggressive ... has a good deal of support,'' said a senior official at NATO, who spoke on condition of anonymity. But he said there was ``good deal of debate'' about how it should be done. ``This is completely up in the air,'' said another diplomat, who also demanded anonymity. One official said it was among the most controversial issues leading up to the Thursday-Friday summit of President Bush and other NATO leaders in London. The leaders are expected to kick off a formal review of the alliance to give it a more political, less military tone. They want to make the North Atlantic Treaty Organization appear less threatening to the Soviet Union. In doing so, the allies hope Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will drop his objections to full and immediate membership for a united Germany in NATO. West Germany belongs to NATO. East Germany is a member of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. More than 380,000 Red Army soldiers are stationed in East Germany. NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner says the summit will offer ``a very clear message about the peaceful intentions of our member nations ... and also about the non-aggressive character of our alliance.'' The Soviets last month floated a vague proposal for some kind of a political accord between the two alliances, which has led to the current controversy over the shape of a non-aggression declaration. A statement could be arranged between NATO and the Warsaw Pact, although the Western allies appear hesitant to do anything that might prop up the collapsing Eastern military alliance. As an alternative, a ``declaration of good intentions'' could be worked out among the 16 NATO and seven Warsaw Pact nations, a NATO diplomat said. Or the declaration could be as simple as a unilateral statement by NATO. The United States does not feel it necessary to draw up a formal, separate document as has been suggested by West Germany and others, officials said. An official said Washington favors ``as little as possible'' because NATO has asserted the non-threatening nature of the alliance before.

DOC.HEAD: One Killed, 20 Injured When Military Plane Runs Off Runway
DOC.TEXT: A military transport plane carrying 100 soldiers veered off a runway and crashed Tuesday at an airport near the Venezuelan border, killing a pilot and injuring 20 soldiers, civil aviation officials said. The Hercules C-130 plane had left Medellin and was landing at the airport of Ocana when the accident occurred, the officials said. The crash damaged a motor and a wing of the plane, the civil aviation office said. Officials said they did not know the cause of the accident. Hundreds of police and soldiers have been assigned to Medellin, a cocaine trafficking center that has often been the battleground in the government's war on drugs, to maintain order.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Declared Controlled as Victims Face Mammoth Task of Rebuilding
DOC.TEXT: The huge Santa Barbara brush fire that burned hundreds of homes was brought under control Tuesday as scores of fire victims across Southern California began the formidable job of recovery. The declaration was issued at 6 a.m., 5{ days after the blaze was set by an arsonist in San Marcos Pass and blew down the foothills of the coastal mountains through hundreds of homes on the outskirts of Santa Barbara. A small crew of firefighters backed by a helicopter and two engines watched for smoldering hotspots, but the blaze was considered controlled because no flames showed within 300 feet of fire lines cut through the brush. But while victory over the 4,500-acre fire took less than a week, people burned out of more than 450 dwellings were only beginning a long process of rebuilding and emotional recovery. It was the same story in the Los Angeles suburb of Glendale, where 66 hillside homes were damaged or destroyed in a arson blaze June 27, and in the aftermath of a 6,640-acre blaze that straddled the Orange-San Bernardino county line and destroyed 14 homes last week. Both fires were caused by arson, officials said. In Santa Barbara and Glendale, the Federal Emergency Management Agency and state Office of Emergency Services opened centers to take applications for low-interest loans and grants. Fires also continued to burn in Colorado and Texas. In California, organizations like the Red Cross and Salvation Army continued supplying victims with immediate essentials, including clothing, medicine, and in some cases psychological aid. ``The stress and emotional trauma is paramount right now. We have many severely traumatized people,'' said Red Cross spokeswoman Elizabeth Quirk in Santa Barbara. More than 340 families were registered with the Red Cross in Santa Barbara and the number was expected to top 600. Six shelters that housed more than 1,000 people during the fire were closed, and efforts focused on finding regular housing. Red Cross, which already has committed $200,000 in direct services to victims, will provide the first month's rent and security deposit. The question will be whether there is enough housing in the area, Ms. Quirk said. On the rebuilding front, Santa Barbara County was in its second day of issuing demolition permits. On Monday, 280 people began the permit process, said spokeswoman Jayne Brechwald. Residents also will need permits for temporary housing, electrical poles and similar fixtures that must be in place before construction can start. Permit fees were waived for the time being. A private relief center was established at the Goleta Youth Sports Center to help people reach contractors, architects, and real-estate and insurance agents. Despite the breadth of help coming to the region, experts predicted a very lengthy recovery. ``We'll probably still be taking care of fire victims for at least a year,'' Ms. Quirk said. Red Cross had on hand 650 local volunteers and was ready to supply victims with some furnishings, occupational supplies like uniforms and tools, and personal items like eyeglasses, prescription medicines and dentures. Four roving food trucks have served 4,000 meals in the fire area since the blaze began. Help has come from across North America. A Robinson's department store gave Red Cross $50,000 for direct dispersal to victims.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Killer of Wife, Three Children Gets New Trial
DOC.TEXT: A man who was convicted six years ago of hacking and bludgeoning his wife and three children to death was granted a new trial Tuesday by the Illinois Supreme Court.
