The court, reversing a decision it made in 1988, ruled that David Hendricks' 1984 trial was tainted by prosecutors' use of testimony about his alleged extramarital sexual interests. At the trial, female models employed by Hendricks in his back-brace business testified that he fondled or kissed them while they were partially nude. Prosecutors said the testimony backed their theory that Hendricks killed his family with an ax and butcher knife to escape a ``sexually frustrating'' marriage. But the Supreme Court ruled the testimony was irrelevant. The court also said prosecutors shouldn't have been allowed to present testimony on the beliefs of the fundamentalist Christian sect to which Hendricks belongs. Prosecutors contended Hendricks feared he would be ostracized by the group if he tried to divorce his wife. Hendricks, 35, is serving four consecutive life prison sentences at the maximum-security Menard Correctional Center for the killings of his wife, Susan, 30, daughters Rebekah, 9, and Grace, 7, and son Benjamin, 5, in their Bloomington home in November 1983. He has insisted that he was out of town at the time of the killings and could not have committed them. Although the Supreme Court upheld his conviction in December 1988, it took the unusual step last year of agreeing to reconsider the case. The court offered no explanation for granting the second hearing. The prosecutor who would be responsible for a second trial, McLean County State's Attorney Charles Reynard, declined to comment immediately. He said he would make a statement Thursday after reviewing the Supreme Court's decision. But the man who prosecuted Hendricks, former State's Attorney Ronald Dozier, said last year that Hendricks might go free if a new trial were ordered because of the likely difficulty of persuading the models to repeat their testimony. Dozier, now a circuit judge, would not comment Tuesday. Hendricks' attorney, Richard McLeese, said he was ``very, very pleased'' by the court's decision, but declined to comment on the next probable step in the case. Hendricks remarried while in prison, and has been supported throughout his appeals by family members, including Nadine Palmer, the mother of his slain wife. ``Now I hope they can turn their attention to whoever did it and prosecute them,'' Mrs. Palmer said in a telephone interview after the ruling. Hendricks, described by friends as a mild-mannered, devoted family man, was convicted after one of the most publicized trials in recent Illinois history. Prosecutors had no physical evidence or witnesses against him, and he said he was out of town on a business trip at the time of the killings. The prosecution case was based on his alleged sexual motives and on evidence indicating the children died before the time Hendricks said he left the house. After Hendricks was convicted, Circuit Judge Richard Baner denied the state's request to impose a death sentence, saying he did not personally believe Hendricks had been proved guilty beyond a reasonable doubt. Last August, in a brief filed with the Supreme Court, Hendricks asserted that his former brother-in-law, Jon Lewis, committed the crimes. Lewis denied it. Prosecutors said Lewis was ruled out as a suspect because he passed a lie-detector test, which Hendricks refused.

DOC.HEAD: Five Lawsuits Later, Bettor Still Thinks Dog Won Upside Down and Backward
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last 2 grafs to CORRECT spelling of name to `Alchediak,' sted `Alchendiak.'
DOC.TEXT: A man who claims he won a $1,304 bet at the dog track has gone to court five times trying to collect on a dog that crossed the finish line tail-first and upside down. ``I'm like David fighting Goliath. I'm gonna win this thing,'' said Alfred Alchediak, 70, whose lawsuit against Tampa Greyhound Track, its officials and the state parimutuel board was rejected by a judge Friday for a fifth time. In 1988, Alchediak bet $140 on a Tampa Greyhound Track trifecta, picking K's Broadway to finish first, Ari Cannon second, and Oshkosh Zest to show. That's how they crossed the finish line. Unfortunately, Oshkosh Zest bumped Ari Cannon from behind, nosedived into the track, flipped, and flew across the finish line upside down and backward _ but ahead of the fourth dog. Track judges ruled Oshkosh Zest ineligible because of the fall. Alchediak cites the racing rules, which say judges ``shall consider only the relative position of the respective noses of such greyhounds.'' Alchediak says he'll appeal the latest decision. Meanwhile, he's been back to the track only once since since the night Oshkosh Zest was disqualified. And he says he has a new hobby: garage-sale shopping.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Immigrant Praises Life in America
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf to ADD that interview took place last week in Las Vegas.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Emigres-Fourth, Bjt
LaserPhoto VG1
DOC.TEXT: After more than 12 years, Soviet-born comic Yakov Smirnoff returned as a U.S. citizen on a nostalgic visit to his homeland. What a country. ``I can live another 12 years without going back,'' Smirnoff said. ``It's a very depressed country,'' Smirnoff said. ``People are in a survival mode. There are still long lines for food, although the lines are even longer now. ``And if there are no lines, it's because there is no food. The problems are still overwhelming.'' Smirnoff, 39, who emigrated to the United States with his parents in 1977, returned to the Soviet Union in April to tape a TV special. It was part of a world tour that began in Moscow and ends Thanksgiving day in Moscow, Idaho. He joked to Soviet audiences about the demise of the Berlin Wall, but admits he was apprehensive: ``What if they were just remodeling?'' An unapologetic salesman for the United States, Smirnoff has headlined in Las Vegas and performed at the White House for Presidents Reagan and Bush. That's not bad for a comic who started in $8 gigs in Odessa, his hometown. ``I'm in love with America. It's my home, and I feel very much at home.'' Smirnoff was trained to be a teacher. Comedy, his first love, was hardly a promising career in the Soviet Union, but by his mid-20s he was earning $200 a month, more than doctors or lawyers. But his family had no car, no phone, and lived in a communal apartment building. He began performing on cruise ships on the Black Sea, where he met his first Americans. ``They had a special spark in their eyes that nobody else had, even Western Europeans,'' Smirnoff recalled in an interview in Las Vegas last week. ``I liked that. Suddenly all of those stories they were telling us, that Americans were bad, they were warmongers who would kill their mothers for money, didn't make sense.'' Smirnoff and his parents lived a year in a two-room, $180-a-month apartment in New York City. Learning to speak English was one of his toughest challenges. ``I locked myself in a room for three months with a TV set, determined I'd learn the language. Then I discovered I'd been watching a Spanish station.'' He worked as a bartender in the Catskills, then headed for Los Angeles and a job as doorman and part-time performer at Mitzi Shore's Comedy Store. He became a U.S. citizen on July 4, 1986, at a special Statue of Liberty ceremony. He's perplexed over issues like burning the American flag. ``The issue doesn't come up very often in Russia,'' he said. ``It's not something you debate.'' He likens the fate of communism to the fate of the Berlin Wall. ``They didn't go in and just bulldoze the wall; they're chipping away at it bit by bit,'' he said. ``That's what's happening to communism. They're chipping away at it, bit by bit.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Says End of ANC Armed Struggle Likely By Year's End
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Mandela saying end of ANC armed struggle likely by the end of the year. Pickup 3rd pvs, `Mandela's replies...'
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela said Tuesday night it is very likely the armed struggle of the African National Congress in South Africa will be over by the end of this year. Speaking on the British Broadcasting Corp.'s ``Newsnight'' television program, the ANC leader said he had discussed the issue with South Africa's president, F.W. de Klerk. ``We have agreed on the removal of the obstacles to negotiations, and I have no doubt that in our second meeting we will achieve this,'' Mandela said. Mandela said a cease-fire in the armed struggle was ``very likely'' to occur by the year's end. De Klerk and Western leaders, including President Bush and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, have urged the ANC to give up violence. The ANC's armed campaign has been largely dormant in the past year, but ANC leaders said they could not end it until police and troops quit firing on unarmed black protesters. Mandela and other black leaders plan to meet with South African officials on his return from a 14-nation world tour. Earlier Tuesday, Mandela struggled to untangle himself from the Northern Ireland conflict and focus attention on Britain's opposition to sanctions against South Africa. He denied having called on Britain to negotiate with the Irish Republican Army, insisting he was just expressing his belief that all conflicts should be settled peacefully. British officials have refused to hold talks with the IRA, saying it is a terrorist group. Mandela's replies to questions on the IRA at a Dublin news conference on Monday made front-page headlines and continued to dog him at meetings Tuesday with members of Parliament and Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd. Hurd said Mandela, the deputy president of the ANC, ``cleared up the position as far as he was concerned.'' ``I expressed the strong feelings of everyone here, that the IRA are rejects of the political system,'' he said. ``Having failed to persuade people in free elections they turn to murder and destruction.'' Britain is promoting negotiations between the main Protestant and Catholic parties of Northern Ireland, and has suggested the IRA can be drawn in if it disavows violence. The IRA has waged a campaign of bombings and shootings in an effort to force British troops out of Northern Ireland. The IRA wants to unite Northern Ireland with the Irish Republic and set up a socialist state. Mrs. Thatcher, who narrowly escaped an IRA bomb in 1984, was expected to reiterate Britain's position when she meets Mandela on Wednesday. Even before the IRA issue arose, Britain was already expected to be the most difficult stop on Mandela's world tour. Mrs. Thatcher openly opposes sanctions against South Africa, and wants those imposed by the European Community relaxed as a reward for President F.W. de Klerk's reform program. Mandela insists the ANC alone should decide when sanctions can be lifted. But their talks signify the about-face in British policy since 1987, when Mrs. Thatcher branded the ANC ``a typical terrorist organization'' and said she wouldn't talk to it. Mandela said ``the possibility is always there'' that his talks with Mrs. Thatcher might narrow their differences. Mandela, 71, arrived from Dublin, the Irish capital, nursing a severe cold, and canceled some of the engagements on his two-day London schedule. Meeting 200 members of Parliament assembled by the all-party Southern Africa Committee, Mandela insisted he was not trying to interfere in the Northern Ireland conflict. ``I expressed no opinion whatsoever on the actual conflict between the IRA and the British government,'' Mandela insisted. ``What I said was to point out that our approach as the ANC is that all conflicts, wherever in the world they are from, should be settled peacefully,'' he said. In Dublin, when asked about the IRA, Mandela replied: ``What we would like to see is that the British government and the IRA should adopt precisely the line that we have taken in regard to our own internal situation. ``There is nothing better than opponents sitting down to resolve their problems in a peaceful manner.'' The controversy was one of the few jarring notes on Mandela's otherwise triumphant trip to urge continued international pressure to end apartheid in South Africa. Mandela was freed from prison in February. He had been jailed since 1962 and was serving a life term for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Officer Says Release of Shiite Inmates Possible
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 7 grafs, UPDATING with Shiite leader kidnap comments
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli army officer was quoted Tuesday as saying that some of the 300 inmates held in southern Lebanon may be freed soon, a key demand of Shiite Moslem factions holding Western hostages. Voice of the South, a radio station controlled by the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militia, said the remark was made by Brig. Gen. Zeev Zakharin. It identified him as an officer in Israel's North Front command. A military source in Tel Aviv identified Zakharin as chief liaison to Lebanon. The source, who requested anonymity, said what is under consideration is a ``traditional'' release of inmates on the occasion of Islam's holiday of Eid Al-Adha. The source would give no other details. The radio said Zakharin toured Israel's self-designated ``security zone'' with Maj. Gen. Antoine Lahd, a retired Lebanese army officer who heads the 3,000-strong South Lebanese Army. The broadcast added that Zakharin met on his tour with ``Lebanese notables.'' He told them Israel would soon consider the issue of the inmates at the Khiyam prison, located in the security zone, and ``possibly release some of them,'' the broadcast said. It gave no other details. Israeli leaders have previously insisted that any deal involving the release of the prisoners at Khiyam must include the release of three Israeli servicemen captured by Shiite groups in south Lebanon. Pro-Iranian fundamentalists holding most of the 16 Western hostages have, for their part, demanded the Khiyam prisoners be released before any of the Western hostages are let go. The hostages include six Americans. The longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. The Khiyam inmates are being held on suspicion of supporting guerrillas seeking to oust the Israelis from Lebanon. They were captured in sweeps after Israel carved out the 440-square-mile security zone in 1985. Israel said it took the land to guard against cross-border guerrilla raids. The strip is policed jointly by the SLA and 1,000 Israeli troops. Iranian officials demanded a ``goodwill gesture'' from the United States after mediating the release in April of two American hostages, Robert Polhill and Frank Reed. Tehran said it would work for the release of others if the United States and Western governments pressured Israel to free the Khiyam inmates. In Hamburg, West Germany, Stern magazine on Tuesday quoted Lebanese Shiite leader Hussein Musawi as saying the time was not right to free any of the six Americans, but that West German hostages Heinrich Struebig and Thomas Kemptner could be released at once if two Shiites imprisoned in West Germany are freed. Musawi's Islamic Amal organization is a pro-Syrian group within the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God. Hezbollah is believed to be the umbrella for extremist groups holding most of the missing Westerners. Stern quoted Musawi as saying Struebig and Kemptner, missing since May 16, 1989, are being held by members of the Hamadi family in Beirut. Mohammed Ali Hamadi is serving a life sentence for hijacking a TWA airliner in June 1985 and killing a U.S. sailor on the plane. His older brother, Abbas, is serving 13 years for kidnapping two West Germans in January 1987 to gain Mohammed's release. ``Kidnapping is our means to practice retaliation against the aggression of the Israelis and the Americans,'' Stern quoted Musawi as saying. The magazine also quoted him as saying terrorist attacks and kidnappings carried out against Israel and Western countries were intended to defend Palestinian territory.

DOC.HEAD: Iliescu Backs Government Reform Program
DOC.TEXT: President Ion Iliescu declared his support Tuesday for the government's radical economic reform program, but said introducing a market economy will pose a difficult challenge. Iliescu made his remarks during a ceremony at which he officially confirmed the appointments of Prime Minister Petre Roman's new 23-member Cabinet. He made his first public statement in support of the economic reform program that Roman outlined to Parliament last week. At the time, Parliament declared its backing for the program and Roman's Cabinet nominees. Iliescu's National Salvation Front, which has dominated the government since the December revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, handily won the May 20 elections on a platform that promised a slower pace of change that would avoid economic upheaval. In his speech to Parliament last week, Roman said that only radical reforms aimed at transforming the centrally planned socialist system to a market economy could overcome the country's economicy crisis. While avoiding specifics, Roman pledged to present an initial package of reforms to Parliament within six months. Iliescu told the new ministers that ``all social groups and political forces cannot but adhere to such a program.'' But he warned that the ``transition from a super-centralized structure ... toward a market economy based on natural forces'' will be a difficult task. ``To govern under the present conditions of our country and remove it from the profound economic and spiritual crisis will not be easy,'' Iliescu said. Unlike Roman, Iliescu stressed in his speech that the reforms must be accompanied by ``a wide-ranging social protection program.'' The ceremony, which was attended by Romanian journalists but closed to the foreign press, was held at Iliescu's new headquarters at Cotroceni Palace, the former headquarters of the scout movement. Last week, Roman blamed the foreign press for distorting the events of June 13-15, when security forces broke up a 53-day opposition demonstration that had blocked Bucharest's main downtown square. Roman said Romania's image had been ``inadmissibly damaged'' by the reporting on the disturbances in the capital that left six people dead. The foreign ministry on Tuesday issued a protest to Hungary for its official criticism of the violence. The ministry said the Hungarians were only considering the events of June 14-15 when thousands of miners responded to a government appeal for support and beat up students and other government opponents in Bucharest. It said the Hungarians were ``knowingly forgetting'' the events of June 13 when demonstrators attacked several government buildings after security forces broke up the demonstration on University Square. The United States reacted to the government's role in the violence by suspending all non-humanitarian aid to Romania. On Tuesday, Iliescu sent President Bush a message for the Fourth of July expressing the hope that ``relations between the two countries develop along new lines in a spirit of faith and mutual respect.'' In Bucharest, various student groups concluded a two-day congress with an appeal to the government to release jailed student leader Marian Munteanu. Munteanu, the president of the Bucharest University Student League, was an organizer of anti-government demonstrations. He was among those beaten by miners and was arrested from his hospital bed. In their appeal, the students said Munteanu ``had become a symbol of the non-violence of the student movement for democracy and liberty.''

DOC.HEAD: Bensonhurst Defendant Acquitted of One Murder Count; Hung Jury on Second
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead.
DOC.TEXT: A jury acquitted a young white man Tuesday of intentionally murdering a black teen-ager in a racial attack in Bensonhurst. But the jury failed to resolve a second murder count and a riot charge against him. The jury, in its ninth day of deliberations, convicted John Vento of two counts of unlawful imprisonment and four counts of menacing for his role in the attack that inflamed racial passions in New York City. Two other young whites have been convicted in the assault on 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins, who was shot to death Aug. 23. Hawkins had come to the predominantly white Brooklyn neighborhood to buy a used car. Vento, who reneged on an immunity deal to testify against his co-defendants, faces a September retrial on the unresolved charges, including a charge of murder by depraved indifference, prosecutors said. He could be sentenced to a year and four months to four years on the unlawful imprisonment counts and 90 days on each menacing count. The sentencing will be Aug. 14. The 21-year-old sat silently, flashing an occasional tight smile, as the verdicts were read. He was acquitted of intentional murder, a weapons possession charge, one count of unlawful imprisonment and five counts of discrimination. ``There's a difference between racism, which is not illegal, and discrimination, which is,'' said juror Lee Levin. Levin, one of the two holdouts for a murder conviction, said that the disagreement on that count was over Vento's mental culpability. Juror Irwin Ziegler said the deliberations were ``not very nice. ... It was very tense, very emotional, a lot of yelling and screaming.'' Vento was the trial defendant to be tried in the attack. Five other Brooklyn youths face trial in the case. Joseph Fama, 19 _ identified by Vento as the triggerman _ was convicted of murder in the first trial and sentenced to 32 and two-thirds years to life. Keith Mondello, 19, received five and one-third to 16 years for his convictions on lesser charges. Last Friday, the mothers of Vento and Hawkins had an emotional meeting at the courthouse in which Maria Vento offered condolences to Diane Hawkins, New York Newsday reported Tuesday. The families would not discuss with reporters details of the private meeting. But Hawkins' father, Moses Stewart, said it was ``the beginning of the healing process'' between blacks and whites in New York. ``That doesn't take any guilt away from their son, but we have a mother who understands what it's like to have a son who's been murdered,'' Stewart said, gesturing toward the Vento family. ``We have a mother who knows what it's like to have a son on trial for murder,'' he added, motioning toward Diane Hawkins. Vento fled upstate the day after Hawkins' murder, but later called prosecutors to confess. He agreed to cooperate and testify against his friends in exchange for immunity. At an appearance before a grand jury in September, Vento provided a graphic account of the attack. He said he watched from just several feet away as Fama pulled an automatic pistol and fired into Hawkins' chest. But he later fled the city again, just two months before the scheduled start of the first Bensonhurst trial. He surrendered to FBI agents in Dayton, Ohio, in March, but announced he would no longer cooperate. He was indicted a week later.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers Say Hundreds Exposed to Detergent May Have Been Harmed
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys for a woman who will get $3.75 million from a chemical company after claiming their detergent caused her leukemia say the detergent may also have harmed hundreds of others. Fawna Wright, 23, of Mound City, Ill., reached the settlement with BASF Wyandotte Corp., of Michigan, on Monday, the day a civil trial was to start. Wright's 1985 lawsuit claimed her illness was linked to exposure to toxic chemicals in Loxene, a detergent once produced by BASF and used to launder diapers and bed linens at Booth Memorial Hospital here, where she was born in 1967. ``Wyandotte continued to manufacture Loxene despite repeated warnings of its potential danger and continued to market it to hospitals after it had twice promised the USDA that it would not,'' one of Wright's lawyers, Robert Bogard, said Monday. ``Therefore, we now have hundreds of persons exposed at Booth or other hospitals using Loxene during the 1960s who may be suffering from problems ranging from learning disabilities to cancer, and they don't even suspect that their illnesses are linked to the diapers they wore in the hospital.'' Wright, whose leukemia is in remission and who plans to attend nursing school in the fall, said she hoped the settlement would send a message to chemical companies to be more responsible. ``I want this to reach to this chemical company and shake them up a bit, to make them realize that they are negligent,'' she said. ``I can never go back to 12 and start all over again.'' Wright's lawsuit centered on two chemicals in Loxene: a pesticide known as trichlorocarbonilide, or TCC, and pentachlorophenol, a substance known as penta that is more widely used as a pesticide and wood preservative. Despite being warned as early as 1955 that penta was unsafe because it caused skin irritations, BASF Wyandotte, then Wyandotte Chemical Corp., instructed Booth Hospital how to use Loxene in final laundry rinses to kill mildew, the lawsuit contended. The Salvation Army, which operated the now-defunct Booth Hospital for unwed mothers, previously agreed to pay Wright $5,000, and Dow Chemical Co. settled for $60,000, Bogard said. Dow and Monsanto Co. were accused because they manufactured penta and TCC. Monsanto was dropped as a defendant. In a statement, BASF said it ``is not directly responsible for her (Wright's) condition'' because the hospitals ``disregarded clearly stated use instructions and warnings.'' Wright became gravely ill when she was 5 days old but recovered and was later adopted, her suit says. Often ill in early childhood, at age 12 she was diagnosed with acute myelogenous leukemia, an often fatal bone marrow cancer. Because of sealed records, her lawyers said they were able to trace only eight other babies born at Booth during the time the hospital used Loxene. The lawyers said those babies also became severely ill, with high fevers and profuse sweating. Two died as infants and a third suffers from a learning disability, the lawyers said. In 1966, an outbreak of illnesses attributed to Loxene at Pembina County Hospital in Cavalier, N.D., left one infant dead, they said. Bogard said Wyandotte Chemical should have removed Loxene from the market following the North Dakota episode instead of waiting until the product's registration was revoked more than a year later.

DOC.HEAD: Iran, Iraq Hold First Talks In Nearly Two Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout, UPDATING with optimistic comments by U.N. chief, technical talks to follow, other. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The foreign ministers of Iran and Iraq on Tuesday held their first direct talks since a cease-fire was declared in the Persian Gulf War nearly two years ago. The U.N chief described the talks as a ``pschological breakthrough.'' Iraq's Tariq Aziz later described his hourlong meeting with Iran's Ali Akbar Velayati as ``cordial and constructive.'' The two sides agreed to the direct meeting at the U.N. Geneva headquarters after separate discussions with Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar Monday night and Tuesday. Perez de Cuellar called Tuesday's meeting ``very promising and an excellent omen'' for the success of future negotations to secure a lasting peace. He told reporters no substantive issues were discussed but said the meeting's friendly atmosphere marked a ``psychological breakthrough.'' He said agreement by the two foreign ministers to talk directly was a clear sign that both governments want a resolution of their bitter conflict. Although both Velayati and Aziz were present in the four rounds of peace talks held since 1988, the two men did not speak directly to each other, instead relaying their comments through Perez de Cuellar. Peace talks have been deadlocked ever since they started Aug. 25, 1988, just five days after a U.N.-sponsored ceasefire ended the eight-year Persian Gulf War. Perez de Cuellar said contacts with both delegations were expected to continue this week. Both ministers were scheduled to leave Geneva Wednesday and no date for a next ministerial meeting was set. The U.N. chief said highly technical negotiations would follow and that he did not know whether the ministers would like to take part in these. He also said he was considering a visit to the area but no time had been fixed. The negotiations have bogged down in disputes over implementation of a resolution calling for a withdrawal to internationally recognized boundaries. Two particular sticking points are the continued presence of Iraqi troops on 1,000 square miles of Iranian territory, and the strategic Shatt-al-Arab waterway on the southern border of the two countries. Tariq Aziz said preparations were continuing for a proposed summit between presidents Saddam Hussein of Iraq and Hashemi Rajsanjani of Iran, but no date had been fixed. Perez de Cuellar said plans for a summit featured strongly in his ``constructive'' discussions with Iran's Velayati late Monday. He said of Tuesday's meeting: ``The meeting was not supposed to be substantive. It was intended to create a different atmosphere as compared with the previous atmosphere. And from that point of view I am extremely pleased to have had the two foreign ministers together in a very friendly, relaxed atmosphere.'' He declined to speculate about when a final agreement might be reached, saying very complex problems had to be resolved.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Opens Higher in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Gold rose $3.44 an ounce on Hong Kong markets Wednesday, opening at $361.97. It closed at $358.53 Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Finland Ready to Start Transferring Soviet Jews
DOC.TEXT: The foreign minister said Tuesday that Soviet Jews could begin next week to emigrate to Israel via Finland. The operation would make Finland the fourth major route for Jews emigrating from the Soviet Union, along with Hungary, Romania and Poland. Finnish and Israeli officials confirmed plans last month to transfer thousands of Soviet Jews to Israel through a small airport near the Finnish-Soviet border. Then the plans appeared to stall because Israel refused to guarantee that the immigrants would not be settled in occupied territories. Israel last week said it would not settle Soviet Jews in the occupied West Bank or Gaza Strip. At a news conference after a special Cabinet meeting, Finnish Foreign Minister Pertti Paasio said the government ``sees no obstacles to he transit of Soviet Jews to Israel or any other country via Finland. I think the transfer could begin early next week.'' Paasio indicated Tuesday that Finland, although now ready to go ahead with the transfer of Soviet Jews, was still concerned about the issue. Israel has ``no right to settle its citizens in Palestinian or Arab territories occupied after 1967,'' Paasio said. He said Finnish authorities would allow one transit flight a week until Oct. 24, and would give permission for flights in batches of four at a time. Each flight was expected to carry up to 200 Jews. Paasio said El Al, the Israeli airline, has applied to begin flights from Finland. He hinted that the flights could be stopped if Israel did not ``follow its policy of . . . not settling Soviet Jews in these areas.'' The foreign minister said Soviet Jewish emigrants would be given Finnish transit visas that could be extended ``if they want to change their plans and travel elsewhere (than Israel).'' ``They can also settle in Finland if they want to,'' he said. Under the plan, convoys of Finnish buses will shuttle emigrants, mainly from the Leningrad area, to Lappeenranta, a town with an airport 12 miles from the Soviet border. The Finnish government is also continuing talks with Soviet officials on direct flights from the Soviet Union to Israel.

DOC.HEAD: FEC Opens Foreign PAC Issue to Comment
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Election Commission wants to know whether U.S. subsidiaries of foreign companies should be able to run political action committees in this country. The commission voted 4-1 last Thursday to instruct its general counsel to draft a list of questions on which public comment should be sought. Political action committees, or PACs, are organized by companies, unions, trade associations and interest groups of all kinds to solicit money from their members and give it to candidates. Contributions from such PACs long have been controversial. Federal election law bars citizens of foreign countries from making donations to congressional and presidential elections. But foreign corporations with wholly owned American subsidiaries are allowed to have their subsidiaries establish PACs just like any other company, soliciting from their employees who are American citizens. Critics contend that allows foreign interests to influence elections. The proposal to seek public comment was offered by Commissioner John McGarry, one of three Democrat appointees to the panel. The two other Democrats and Republican Thomas Josefiak voted to open the issue to comment. But Josefiak said his vote should not be taken as an indication he favored a ban on such PACs or any changes to existing laws, just that he wanted to see what comments would come in. Observers of the FEC believe the panel would split 3-3 if a commissioner sought an outright ban on such PACs, but the commission believes it does not have that power and over the years has asked Congress to deal with the issue. Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, the Democratic nominee for vice president in the 1988 election, recently wrote a ``Dear Colleague'' letter suggesting it was time for Congress to determine whether PACs of foreign-owned U.S. companies should be restricted or banned.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Army Finds Ton of Dynamite Set To Explode on Highway
DOC.TEXT: The army found about a ton of dynamite that it said drug terrorists planned to use to blast part of the highway between Bogota and Medellin, Colombia's two largest cities, a general said Tuesday. Elsewhere, leftist guerrillas blew up a section of Colombia's main oil pipeline Tuesday, temporarily halting pumping of about 230,000 barrels a day, the state oil company Ecopetrol said. The 2nd Division discovered the dyamite along the highway about 100 miles northwest of Bogota. Division commander Gen. Jose Guzman said in a communique that ``narco-subversive'' elements planted the explosives with the intention of destroying a stretch of highway and civilian and military vehicles traveling on it. In the past 11 months, Colombian drug lords have been blamed for killing more than 400 people, including around 150 policemen in Medellin. Rebels of the leftist National Liberation Army, the ELN, used dynamite Tuesday on the Cano Limon oil pipeline in northeast Colombia. A spokesman for Ecopetrol said the bombing caused 4,000 barrels of crude oil to spill out of the pipeline. The ELN, Colombia's most active guerrilla group, has bombed the pipeline scores of times since 1986, causing estimated losses of around $520 million. It says it is trying to pressure the government to reduce the presence of foreign oil companies in Colombia. Tuesday's attack was the 11th this year.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Firm Proposes Oil Terminal and Pipeline System
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to CLARIFY why environmentalists oppose pipelines, CLARIFY that cost would be 40 cents a barrel more than transporting by tanker, sted 40 cents a barrel; picks up 7th graf, `Trans Mountain ... ADDS 2 grafs at end to give details on pipeline route.
DOC.TEXT: An oil pipeline company Tuesday proposed construction of a $500 million terminal and pipeline system to take oil through Puget Sound without tankers. The proposal, which revived a decade-old idea, immediately met opposition from some environmentalists, who fear moving oil through the sound by pipeline or tanker risks spills. Trans Mountain Pipe Line Co. Ltd. of Vancouver, British Columbia, said it wants to build a terminal at Low Point on the Strait of Juan de Fuca, which runs between the United States and Canada. The company would lay two partly submerged, parallel pipelines that would carry millions of barrels of crude oil about 80 miles to upper Puget Sound. One of the proposed pipelines would carry oil coming in from Alaska and Asia for processing. The other would meet an existing pipeline from the Canadian province of Alberta that carries crude oil bound for export. Trans Mountain's first hurdle will be convincing Puget Sound refiners _ British Petroleum, Atlantic Richfield, Texaco and Shell Oil _ to use the pipeline at a cost Trans Mountain estimates at about 40 cents a barrel more than the average cost of transporting the oil by tanker. Trans Mountain President Richard Stokes said initial discussions have been encouraging. Arco and British Petroleum spokesmen said they were willing to consider the proposal. Stokes said agreement would be needed in order to secure the $500 million needed for the project. Trans Mountain also would need approval from the state Energy Facilities Site Evaluation Council after a long public review process, Stokes said. The announcement came several hours after the release of a report by a regional oil-spill task force that recommends serious consideration of an offshore terminal and pipeline system to reduce the risk of oil spills in Puget Sound. The States-British Columbia Task Force said the risk of oil spills under current circumstances can only increase with expected rises in tanker traffic in the region. Crude oil shipments into Puget Sound, which total about 161 million barrels annually, are expected to increase by 5 percent a year this decade, the report said, with accompanying increases in the traffic of refined oil. Shipments from Canada to Asian markets also are on the rise, the task force said, and can be expected to increase more than fivefold this decade. Gov. Booth Gardner, who would have the power to veto the pipeline project, considers the proposal worthy of study, said gubernatorial spokesman Dick Milne. Environmentalists dismissed it. ``Here we go again,'' said Jeff Parsons, a spokesman for the Washington Audubon Society, recalling the bitter fight a decide ago over a similar proposal. That plan was ultimately junked by then-Gov. John Spellman in 1982. Parsons said neither pipelines nor tankers are good options for hauling oil in the sound. ``The best option is to establish a national energy policy that severely reduces our reliance on oil,'' he said. ``The only way to really prevent spills is to leave oil in the ground.'' The task force said a terminal and pipeline system, combined with other spill preventative steps, would reduce the threat of a large sound spill by 66 percent. The proposed pipelines would run by land from the terminal about 12 miles west of Port Angeles on the Olympic Peninsula to Admiralty Inlet. From there, the lines would run underwater to Whidbey Island in the sound, cross the island, then go underwater again until reaching the mainland near Stanwood on the eastern side of the Puget Sound. The lines then would run north to connect with an existing pipeline system at Burlington.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Princeton Eating Clubs Must Admit Women
DOC.TEXT: Two male-only eating clubs at Princeton University must end a century-old tradition of excluding women and open their doors to the opposite sex, the state's highest court ruled Tuesday. The state Supreme Court rejected arguments by the Ivy Club and the Tiger Inn that they were private entities separate from the Ivy League university and not subject to the state's anti-discrimination laws. ``It would be disingenuous for the clubs to assert that they could ever exist apart from Princeton University,'' the seven-member court said in a unanimous opinion. ``The clubs gather their membership from Princeton and, in turn, provide the service of feeding Princeton students.'' ``Because of this, the clubs lack the distinctly private nature that would exempt them'' from discrimination laws, the court said. The ruling stems from an 11-year-old sex discrimination case brought by Sally Frank, a former Princeton student who is now a professor at New York Law School in New York City. ``I'm really thrilled,'' Ms. Frank said from Washington, D.C. ``I'm glad that the court decided to stop discrimination at Princeton.'' Stockton Williams, 22, undergraduate president of Tiger Inn, said the ruling would be appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court. ``We feel that all of the affairs of the club should be decided by the members, including who we allow in,'' Williams said. Barbara Strapp Nelson, a lawyer for the Ivy Club, said the club ``strongly disagreed'' with the court's ruling, which she said overlooked the constitutionally protected right of freedom of association. ``I think this case has often been viewed as an emotional women's rights type of case, whereas it's really a case involving ... whether the government should be intervening in decisions made by individuals as to who they socialize with,'' Ms. Nelson said. She said the Ivy Club's governing board would examine its choices before deciding whether to appeal. In 1979 Ms. Frank sued the Ivy Club and the Tiger Inn, the only two among the university's 13 private eating clubs that exclude women. Princeton began admitting women in 1969. Most juniors and seniors pay membership fees to eat at the clubs, housed near the Princeton campus. Both clubs voted earlier this year to admit women, but two more rounds of voting must be conducted next year before any can join. ``It is undisputed that the clubs had a general policy that excluded females from consideration as members,'' the court said. ``It is also undisputed that the clubs applied this policy to Frank'' when she tried to join. Attorneys for the two clubs maintained that as private entities, they had the right to choose their membership. But Ms. Frank argued that the university has promoted the clubs in its publications, and that Princeton has relied on the clubs since they feed more than 75 percent of upper-class students. Tuesday's ruling upheld a 1987 decision by the New Jersey Division on Civil Rights, which ordered the clubs to begin admitting women. That decision was overturned by the Appellate Division of Superior Court, which granted the clubs' request for a new hearing because of procedural errors. But the Supreme Court said the clubs already had been afforded their administrative due process and said it did not see any disputed facts. Ms. Frank had sued a third eating club, but that club began admitting women in 1986 and settled with Ms. Frank for $20,000. The university also was named in the lawsuit but settled in 1986, paying Ms. Frank $27,500 in legal fees and pledging to dissociate itself from sexually segregated clubs. Under Tuesday's ruling, the two clubs must pay Ms. Frank a total of $5,000 plus legal fees to be determined by the court.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaragua Declares Strike Illegal
DOC.TEXT: The government has declared a strike by government employees illegal and said Tuesday the walkout had attracted little support among the country's 100,000 public workers. Leaders of the pro-Sandinista National Workers' Front called the strike on Monday to protest firings and demand a say in national economic policy _ a role the union contends it is guaranteed by the constitution. Government officials said that as of Tuesday, only about 800 employees in three ministries were on strike. At the Managua mayor's office, 1,200 workers who had joined the walkout on Monday reached an agreement with the mayor and returned to work Tuesday. Union officials, however, gave vastly different figures. Lucio Jimenez, leader of the Sandinista Workers' Center, another union federation, called the strike ``a full success'' and said a total of 42,000 employees had stayed away from their jobs in government ministries, the customs service at Managua's international airport and various state-owned industries _ including construction, textile, metalworking and beer plants. An airport customs employee and workers at some of the state-owned companies, including the Milca bottling plant, contradicted Jimenez and said they were working normally. Telecommunications and postal workers stopped service, including international telephone service, for one hour Tuesday in support of the strike. Service then returned to normal. Bus transportation, electricity, banking, water or other services continued uninterrupted. Riot police and patrol cars cordoned off President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's offices, keeping away vehicles and pedestrians, and police were on duty outside state offices to guarantee entry for the public and employees who wanted to work. Labor Minister Francisco Rosales declared the strike illegal late Monday, saying it was ``strictly political'' and aimed at ``sabotaging the recovery program.'' The National Workers' Front has sought an injunction from the appeals court against the decree and protested the banning of pickets by the Interior Ministry. If the court agrees that the strike is illegal, the government can fire strikers outright, something it would like to do to trim the bureaucracy. The government's economic plans include returning most state-owned companies to the private sector and reorganizing the government _ both moves expected to involve job cutbacks. The strike differs sharply from a walkout by 65,000 government employees in May that paralyzed activity across the country, including international flights and telephone service. In May, the demands focused on salary increases and a Sandinista law protecting government workers' jobs and benefits. That strike ended after the unions won 100 percent pay hikes and a promise that the government would not retaliate, a provision union leaders say has been violated. The Chamorro government, they say, has fired more than 800 employees, most of them Sandinistas, since it took office April 25, two months after winning general elections. The new government views the current walkout as a move by the Sandinistas to assert themselves as an opposition power. While most government employees are holdovers from the previous government, many would rather try to hold onto their jobs than give open support to the Sandinistas. ``Very few are going to support the strike because no one wants to risk being fired,'' said a telephone operator at the Construction and Transportation Ministry who asked not to be identified. Unemployment is officially estimated at 34 percent of the work force of 1.2 million. With the end of the nine-year war by U.S.-backed Contra rebels against the Sandinistas, the number of jobless is growing.

DOC.HEAD: Rash of Airplane Crashes Hits Alaska
DOC.TEXT: A dozen airplanes crashed in Alaska over a 30-hour period ending Tuesday, killing two people, causing tens of thousands of dollars in damage and overwhelming investigators. ``We've had so many crashes in the past two days, it's awesome,'' said Jim Michelangelo, a spokesman for the National Transportation Safety Board here. ``Call me (next month) and we'll have them analyzed and we may know the causes.'' Pilot error, mechanical problems, bad weather, impatient passengers and pilot unfamiliarity with terrain and weather are most commonly cited as the cause of Alaska's airplane accidents. Since June 1, 35 airplanes have crashed in Alaska. Ten people have died in four separate accidents, Michelangelo said. Five were killed in a June 25 crash of a Cessna 207 on what was to have been an 80-minute sightseeing trip out of Seward. Ten of the accidents involved air-taxi operators; 25 involved private aircraft, Michelangelo said. There are 219 air-taxi operators in Alaska and more than 9,000 private airplanes and registered pilots, said Paul Steucke, spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration here. That translates into about eight times as many pilots per capita _ and 15 times as many aircraft per capita _ as the rest of the United States, the FAA says. Most pilots and air-taxi operators in Alaska are conscientious about safety and do a good job, Steucke said. He said their clients sometimes unwittingly play a role in accidents by pressuring pilots to take risks. Tourists typically are on a tight schedule and sometimes reluctant to wait out bad weather, he said. ``Sometimes they go down the street looking for another carrier after one pilot tells them it's too dangerous to fly,'' he said. There were a dozen crashes within 30 hours starting Sunday evening and ending early Tuesday. In the only fatal wreck, the private pilot's lack of familiarity with local wind patterns may have contributed to a crash at Iliamna Lake Sunday that killed two people, said Bob Cusack, a lodge owner who helped rescue the four survivors. Cusack, a guide and pilot himself, said gusty winds that evening had dissuaded him from flying some clients back to Anchorage, about 200 miles away.

DOC.HEAD: Maker Recalls Duck Pull Toys
DOC.TEXT: A New York toy manufacturer recalled more than 54,000 duck decoy pull toys Tuesday because the toy may pose a choking and sharp-point hazard to young children. The screw holding the duck's wing in place separated from the 10-inch decoy in tests, said the Consumer Product Safety Commission. The ducks, made of yellow and orange plastic by Artsana of America Inc. of New York, have been sold nationwide since 1987. The toys have four wheels, movable feet, wings, eyes and beak and make a quacking sound when pulled. The name ``Chicco'' is printed in blue just above the duck's right wing and the packing box is labeled in part: ``No. 63002.0 Decoy Duck Made in Italy,'' said the agency. There have been no reports of injuries. Consumers are advised to return the ducks to the store where purchased for a refund.

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds Older Women Skip Mammograms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf, ```This relatively ...,' to ADD recommendation for when to have mammograms.
DOC.TEXT: Many women over 50 years old don't get mammograms because they mistakenly think they don't need them, according to an American Medical Association study released Tuesday. The study found that while more than 90 percent of the women polled in various surveys visited a doctor regularly, just 25 percent to 41 percent received X-ray breast examinations during the previous year. Most of the women who didn't receive a mammography said they skipped the breast cancer screening procedure because they didn't think it was necessary or because they didn't have any breast problems, the study found. The next-largest group said their doctors never recommended the examination. ``This relatively low utilization of breast cancer screening may help to explain why breast cancer mortality rates have not declined over the past three decades,'' the report says. The American Cancer Society recommends women have one mammogram between the ages of 35 and 39, one every to two years between 40 and 49, and one annually after that. The National Cancer Institute and the National Health Interview Survey interviewed 7,011 women from 50 to 74 years old across the country in different studies between 1987 and 1989. The combined results were reported in this week's edition of the Journal of the American Medical Association. Less-educated and poorer women were even less likely to receive breast cancer screenings, the survey found. Doctors are hesitant to recommend the procedure because they feel patients are reluctant to get mammograms or will object to the costs, the study indicated. But few women surveyed said they failed to get one because of the cost or because of radiation fears.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Envoy to Egypt Quits in Policy Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Israel's ambassador to Egypt, Shimon Shamir, announced his resignation Tuesday over policy differences with the right-wing government formed last month. ``There is too wide a gap between my views and that of the new government,'' his letter of resignation letter said, according to Israel radio. Shamir said on the radio his action had nothing to do with the stalemated Middle East peace process, in which Egypt has tried to mediate between Israel and the Palestinians. ``My decision to resign came the day the new government was installed. It is a question of my overall world view compared to the overall platform of the existing government,'' he said. He was the third Israeli ambassador appointed to Cairo since a peace treaty was signed in 1979, and the first to quit because of political disagreement. Shamir was named to the post in August 1988 by then-Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of the center-left Labor Party. A new government led by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir _ no relation _ of the right-wing Likud bloc was formed June 11 after a Likud-Labor coalition collapsed in March over differences on peace moves. The Haaretz daily noted that since the new government took office, friction had emerged between the ambassador and a top political aide to Prime Minister Shamir over the government's harder line in diplomatic contacts with Egypt. Ambassador Shamir said he would stay on until a replacement is found, but planned to return to his research and lecturing job at Tel Aviv University.

DOC.HEAD: City Bucks History, Moves Holiday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with fireworks in Pittsburgh.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Mr Fireworks, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The rockets' red glare burst through the air Tuesday night in Pittsburgh, where the Fourth of July fell on July 3 as tradition took a back seat to the budget. It was calculated the move would cut down on police overtime and save the city $20,000. It's all part of what it shaping up to be an entire week of July Fourths across the United States as people accommodate themselves to a holiday that officially falls smack in the middle of the week. George Zambelli Jr., a vice president of Zambelli Fireworks Internationale of New Castle, Penn., sees a trend. ``People are thinking of the Fourth of July in terms of three to four days before and three to four days after,'' Zambelli said in a telephone interview from Portland, Maine. ``To me, it's immaterial what day it's on. I love fireworks.'' He would have loved the ``Celebration of the Century'' in Boise, Idaho, which at least had the benefit of historical accuracy. Tuesday's celebration had nothing to do with the nation's independence _ it was to celebrate Idaho's centennial as a state. ``This is as close as Boise can get to Mardi Gras,'' Idaho Supreme Court Justice Larry Boyle said as the celebration got under way. Idaho was admitted to the union on July 3, 1890. The events included picnics at four Boise city parks, a motorcade of vintage cars, a 43-cannon salute, a jet flyover, a huge birthday cake _ and fireworks. The Zambellis didn't produce the Idaho celebration, but they had their hands full elsewhere. On Monday, they presented fireworks at Detroit's International Freedom Festival. On Tuesday, they were scheduled to present Pittsburgh's show and a performance for President Bush at his vacation home in Kennebunkport, Maine. They were scheduled to produce shows Wednesday in Philadelphia and Thursday in Washington, D.C. Philadelphia, the birthplace of the Declaration of Independence, had an especially elaborate celebration planned for Wednesday. It was to begin with the presentation of the second annual Philadelphia Liberty Medal to former President Carter. Later, Carter was to join Philadelphia Mayor W. Wilson Goode in cutting ``America's Birthday Cake,'' which is big enough to serve 25,000 people. Other events include the ``Liberty to Liberty Triathlon,'' the ``Great American Liberty Parade'' and a concert at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. And, of course, fireworks. Two of the more unusual July Fourth events involve flag-burning, which was recently upheld as constitutional by the U.S. Supreme Court. In Pensacola, Fla., Boy Scouts and veterans will burn American flags _ out of reverence, not protest. The flags are old and worn out, and are being ``retired.'' Walter O'Neal, president of the Northwest Florida Veterans Roundtable, said some veterans initially had reservations about the ceremony but now are statisfied it will be properly respectful. ``As long as it's a solemn ceremony, and with the Boys Scouts involved it will be, we're happy,'' O'Neal said. In Little Rock, Ark., a black activist intends to burn the U.S. flag on the steps of the state Capitol while about 100 state and local police keep members of the Ku Klux Klan from interfering. Activist Robert ``Say'' McIntosh of Little Rock wasn't clear about why he wanted to burn the flag. ``It is my right, so I'll do it,'' he said Tuesday. In Pittsburgh, an aide to Pittsburgh Public Safety Director Glenn Cannon said the decision to celebrate Independence Day on July 3 was intended to save overtime pay for police, paramedics and parks workers. Aide Craig Merritt said city employees typically draw pay 2{ times their normal rate on holidays. They were to receive no bonus Tuesday if they were already scheduled to work. Those called in to work overtime were to be paid at 1{ times the normal rate. ``The administration thinks the most patriotic thing to do is not to raise taxes,'' said Al Neri, a spokesman for Mayor Sophie Masloff. ``History tells us the actual document was signed July 2 ... so we've picked a middle ground.''
