DOC.TEXT: The United States tightened its grip on the title of world's largest debtor nation in 1989, ending the year with a net debt of $663.7 billion, up a sharp 25 percent from the previous year. The Commerce Department said U.S. holdings of overseas assets rose by $146.9 billion last year to $1.412 trillion, a gain of 11.6 percent. But foreign holdings in the United States climbed at an even faster pace of 15.6 percent, rising by $279.6 billion to $2.076 trillion.

Takeover specialist Forstmann Little & Co. will acquire General Instrument Corp., a leading producer of cable television equipment, in a cash deal valued at $1.6 billion. The agreement Monday marked the latest evidence of a mild resurgence in the takeover business, languishing for months largely due to lack of interest in junk bonds, the high-risk securities used to finance many deals in the 1980s. General Instrument's products include cable TV subscriber terminals, cable and scrambling equipment.

The construction industry remained in a slump in May as spending dropped 0.4 percent for its second straight monthly decline, the government said. The Commerce Department reported Monday that residential, non-residential and government construction spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $445.6 billion after falling 2.2 percent in April.

Rising incomes and falling mortgage rates and prices boosted the typical American family's ability to buy an existing single-family home in May, a real estate trade group said. The National Association of Realtors said Monday its housing affordability index was 105.6 in May, up from 104.3 the previous month. That means a family earning the national median income of $34,142 had 105.6 percent of the income needed to qualify for conventional financing covering 80 percent of the median-priced home costing $94,800.

The nation's manufacturing economy grew for the third consecutive month in June, according to an influential survey of corporate purchasing executives. The National Association of Purchasing Managers said Monday its index rose slightly in June to 51.1 percent from 50.7 in May. A reading above 50 indicates the economy generally is expanding; below 50, that it generally is contracting.

Investors defrauded in a massive 1988 insider trading scheme may be entitled to compensation from $19 million in alleged illegal profits surrendered by one of the defendants. The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a proposed plan in a New York court Monday for distributing the money allegedly obtained in what at the time was the second-largest insider trading case in U.S. history. In 1988, the SEC accused Fred C. Lee, a Taiwanese national living in Hong Kong, and Stephen K. Wang, a junior analyst in the mergers department at Morgan Stanley & Co., of engaging in a scheme that allegedly netted Lee $19 million.

West Germany's biggest union gave a glimpse of its power to mobilize East Germany's anxious work force by orchestrating a series of strikes by thousands of factory workers. One day after East Germany merged its economy with the West and opened its borders to the free market, about 3,000 workers staged a one-hour warning strike at the giant Locomotive Electronics Works in Hennigsdorf near Berlin.

Britain's largest jewelry chain, Ratners Group PLC, announced a friendly $328 million offer for Kay Jewelers Inc. that would make it the second-largest jewelry retailer in the United States. Kay, a 494-store retail network based in Alexandria, Va., said Monday its board of directors endorsed the offer and would recommend that shareholders accept it. The board controls about a third of Kay's shares. Ratners said it eventually wants to operate 1,500 U.S. stores, representing 10 percent of the fragmented American market. The addition of Kay's stores will increase the current number of Ratners' U.S. outlets to 967, Ratners said.

The Coca-Cola Co. announced key management changes, including the appointment of M. Douglas Ivester as president of the soft drink maker's U.S. operations. Ivester has been with Coke since 1979 and president of the company's European Community Group since June 1989. He succeeds Ira C. Herbert as president of Coca-Cola USA. Herbert will continue as executive vice president of Coke and will have corporate responsibility for Coca-Cola USA as well as the company's Canadian subsidiary.

The stock market opened the second half of 1990 with a moderate gain Monday. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 18.57 points to 2,899.26. The German mark rose in foreign exchange, the first day of trading after the monetary union in East and West Germany over the weekend. Bond prices closed virtually unchanged. Forecasts for sizzling temperatures in the Midwest sparked sharp gains in soybean and pork futures prices; moat grain futures advanced; cattle futures were mixed; oil futures mostly were lower; and precious metals rose modestly.

DOC.HEAD: Rykodisc: Small CD Music Label Attracts Big Names
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: When the founders of Rykodisc formed the small recording label in 1984, they took the name from the Japanese word ``ryko,'' meaning ``sound from a flash of light.'' The name reflects the company's niche as a label specializing in compact discs, which use lasers to play distortion-free digital recordings. The company borrowed more than its name from the Orient. Rykodisc's slogan is ``we're only in it for the music,'' and the owners stress quality over quantity. That philosophy has made the company a minor power in the music industry, attracting artists such as David Bowie and Frank Zappa. In an era of giant music conglomerates and generic packaging, Rykodisc may be the wave of the future. ``We use our size to our advantage,'' said Don Rose, 35, one of the founders and partners in the company. ``People ask us how we can compete with the major labels and we tell them we don't compete. We're in a position to make a bigger splash on a smaller scale.'' Rykodisc specializes in re-releasing significant titles and digitally remastering them when possible, adding extra tracks and elaborate packaging. The eclectic label includes rock music, so-called World music (King Sunny Ade, Hamza El Din), reggae, folk and jazz. The company is expected to gross $20 million in sales this year, up from $4 million in 1987. Rykodisc began as a CD-only label and rode the success of CDs. Business boomed, and it now issues cassette tapes and LPs. The company's two biggest coups came when it acquired the lucrative compact disc rights to the back catalogs of Frank Zappa and David Bowie. Rykodisc proposed deluxe re-issues on CD of their past hits, which their own record companies had neglected to do. After two years, Zappa agreed to go with Rykodisc. Since then, more than 20 Zappa CDs have been issued, selling more than 1 million units and resulting in Zappa's first Grammy and first international tour in years. The company signed Bowie last year, after months of negotiations. Rykodisc's release of ``Changesbowie,'' an update of Bowie's original greatest hits collection, was its first title to go gold. ``It was a fantastic opportunity for us,'' said Rose, a soft-spoken yet intense man whose office includes piles of CDs, cassettes, a digital audio tape recorder, DAT tapes, a television and VCR. ``Bowie's stature as a innovator is really second to none.'' In overflowing offices that overlook Salem Harbor, Rose oversees a staff of 15, most of whom are in their late 20s and early 30s. The atmosphere of the company's headquarters is quiet and casual. The walls are decorated with music posters and CD boxes. ``We view ourselves as music fans and our product comes from the fan@collector point of view,'' said Rose. Rose has telephone conferences daily with his three partners based in Philadelphia, Minneapolis and Los Angeles. He has been working in the music industry since the age of 18, when he bought the first of several record stores in the Midwest. After moving to Boston's North Shore in 1979, he formed a small label called Eat Records. Rykodisc hopes to acquire the back catalogs of other established artists. It also has signed new talent, like Australia's Screaming Tribesmen, in the hope of finding a breakthrough smash group that can make a record company. Rykodisc also founded the pro-environment ``Ban the Box'' movement calling for elimination of the elaborate, 10-inch-long boxes CDs are sold in. Rose said the U.S. is the only country to package CDs that way, primarily to discourage shoplifters and allow retailers to use their old LP shelves. The ``Ban the Box'' movement advocates the sale of CDs in their small cover boxes.

DOC.HEAD: Forstmann Little to Acquire General Instrument
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Forstmann Little & Co. plans to buy cable television equipment maker General Instrument Corp. for $1.6 billion in the latest sign of a mild resurgence in corporate buyouts. The takeover business has been languishing in recent months largely due to lack of interst in junk bonds, the high-yield and high-risk securities sold to finance many of the deals of the 1980s. Several recent deals, however, have been announced by companies drawing on their own cash or more conservative bank loans to finance the takeovers. Half the money for the General Instrument buyout, announced Monday, will come from Forstmann Little's $2.3 billion acquisition fund, whose investors are mainly large corporate pension funds, Theodore J. Forstmann, general partner of the investment firm, said. The rest will will come from a group of banks led by Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co., he said. ``Because of Forstmann Little's ability to employ a uniquely conservative capital structure, all of the companies it has previously acquired have been able to continue to invest in their future,'' Forstmann said in a prepared statement. The General Instrument buyout would be the second for Forstmann Little this year and the 17th in its 12-year history. Since it got into the leveraged buyout business, Forstmann Little has acquired about $10 billion worth of companies. About four months ago it was a partner in the $825 million acquisition of Chrysler Corp.'s Gulfstream Aerospace Corp. Forstmann said hopes to strengthen its acquisition fund this summer, which could mean even more acquisitions later in the year. ``We're in an extremely strong position,'' he said. News of the General Instrument deal sent the company's stock over the $44.50 per share offer price to close at $45.25, up $8.75, in active composite New York Stock Exchange trading Monday. Forstmann Little officials and stock market analysts said they didn't see the runup as a sign that a competing bid might surface. ``I'm not sure with the drying up up of the junk bond market who else will be able to put something like this together,'' said Jay Samstag, an analyst with Duff & Phelps Inc. General Instrument has agreed to amend its shareholders' rights plan, or ``poison pill,'' and to pay Forstmann Little $33 million in the event that its board of directors accepts a higher bid. Under the terms of the merger agreement, set to expire Aug. 13, Forstmann Little will assume or refinance General Instrument's existing debt in addition to acquiring the outstanding common shares. General Instrument Chairman Frank G. Hickey said the board was urging shareholders to sell their stock because ``this all cash offer provides an excellent value.'' Forstmann said there were no immediate plans to reorganize management or sell any portions of General Instrument. Forstman said his firm was particularly attracted to General Instrument's Broadband Communications division, which provided 60 percent of the company's revenue last year. General Instrument's products include cable TV subscriber terminals, cable and scrambling equipment. The company ``has a very strong dominant core business with both reasonably predictable cash flow and growth potential,'' Forstmann told a news conference. Forstmann said re-regulation of cable television was likely to take place soon, and that could prove helpful for the industry. General Instrument, which employs 14,200, also produces aircraft surveillance equipment and semiconductors through its data systems and components products divisions. General Instrument earned $23.2 million, or 84 cents a share, in the first quarter, on $379.5 million in revenue. Earnings were 29 percent higher the previous year's quarter, largely due to gains from the sale of discontinued operations _ the remaining portion of a major restructuring.

DOC.HEAD: Sells Control of U.S. Newspapers after Missing Junk-Bond Payment
DOC.TEXT: To the likes of Robert Campeau and Donald Trump, add Ralph Ingersoll II. The publisher, like the developers, built an empire with high-yield junk bonds and got into trouble when the massive interest payments started to catch up with him. On Monday, Ingersoll agreed to trade his U.S. interests and their troublesome debt burden to his investment partners. He gets control of a smaller group of European newspapers. Ingersoll said the deal was driven by a desire to get more involved in European publishing. But bankers and investors with knowledge of Ingersoll's business said the publisher's buying spree of daily and weekly newspapers left him with too much debt to weather the nationwide slump in advertising revenue. ``He has an unworkable balance sheet,'' said James Rubin, an analyst at M.D. Sass Investors Services, a New York investment firm. M.D. Sass successfully urged bondholders to reject Ingersoll's bid to work out his debt troubles this spring. Ingersoll is relinquishing his stake in three companies that publish dozens of daily and weekly newspapers _ including the New Haven Register and the Trentonian of Trenton, N.J. _ to the New York investment firm E.M. Warburg, Pincus & Co. The two had been joint owners, although Ingersoll had voting control. Warburg, Pincus gains full control of Ingersoll Newspapers Inc., which publishes nine dailies and 53 weeklies; New Haven Acquisition Co., publisher of the Register; and Community Newspapers Inc., which has newspapers in Ohio and on New York's Long Island. Ingersoll will gain control of a group of British and Irish newspapers that he controlled jointly with Warburg, Pincus. The announcement came as Community Newspapers said it would not make a July 1 interest payment on its $125 million in 13 percent junk bonds. Ingersoll had been trying for months to buy back the bonds at a steep discount to alleviate his debt burden. A banker involved in the buyback negotiations said the deal might not help bondholders because Warburg, Pincus isn't obliged to cover Community Newspapers' debts, and has said it won't. If no payment is made in 30 days, bondholders can force the company into involuntary bankruptcy. Warburg officials did not return repeated calls for comment. In a statement announcing the deal, chairman and chief executive Lionel Pincus said only that he hoped Community Newspapers would be able to work out its problems with bondholders. In a telephone interview, Ingersoll said the three U.S. companies were on track to make $100 million in profits before taxes and interest this year on revenue of $400 million. ``We are having a record year despite the economy,'' he said. The companies could have serviced their debt if not for the collapse of the junk bond market, which hit bonds like Community Newspapers' especially hard, Ingersoll said. The company issued its bonds in 1987 with a relatively low interest rate by promising to set a new rate this year that would guarantee the bonds would trade at 101 cents on the dollar. The bonds were quoted at about 50 cents on the dollar on Monday, down about 9 cents. To push the price up to 101 cents suggests the company would have to pay a new interest rate of near 30 percent. That burden ``would choke any company,'' he said. Community Newspapers said Monday it would not reset the interest rate on July 7, as it was scheduled to do. The announcement comes a little more than two months after Ingersoll folded the St. Louis Sun, a new tabloid that he hoped would revolutionize the slumping newspaper market by using new technology and marketing strategies. The British and Irish newspapers Ingersoll is gaining have combined circulations exceeding 1 million and annual revenue of $178 million. Europe offers great opportunities because of the planned dropping of trade barriers in Western Europe and the spread of free-market economics in the East, Ingersoll said. ``The new Europe will grow very, very quickly,'' he said. ``It's the new frontier.'' Ingersoll said he planned to expand onto the European continent in 1991, probably in Italy. He also said he wasn't giving up on the United States and planned to start or acquire a magazine here in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Lotus Files Copyright Infringement Suits Against Two Companies
DOC.TEXT: Lotus Development Corp. has filed copyright infringement lawsuits involving its popular 1-2-3 software against two California companies. The suits come after success with a similar suit against another firm last week. In the actions filed Monday, Lotus charges that software marketed by Borland International Inc. of Scotts Valley, Calif., and the Santa Cruz Operation Inc., of Santa Cruz, Calif., violate Lotus' copyrights on keyboard commands and on-screen images. The products named in the suits are Quattro and Quattro Pro from Borland International and SCO professional from SCO. Borland filed suit in U.S. District Court in San Jose, Calif., on Friday seeking declaratory relief, according to Borland spokesman Dick O'Donnell. O'Donnell said the suit seeks confirmation that Quattro and Quattro Pro do not infringe on the copyrights of Lotus. A U.S. District Court judge ruled Thursday that copyright protection on the 1-2-3 software extends beyond the computer program's inner workings to keyboard commands and on-screen images. Both Paperback Software International and subcontractor Stephenson Software Ltd., the defendants in the case, said they would appeal last week's decision.

DOC.HEAD: Possible $19 Million Payback for Victims of Insider Scam
DOC.TEXT: Federal securities regulators have unveiled their plan to distribute $19 million to alleged victims of what the Securities and Exchange Commission charges was a massive 1988 insider trading scheme. The SEC filed a proposed plan in a New York court Monday for distributing the money allegedly obtained in what at the time was the second-largest insider trading case in U.S. history. Fred C. Lee agreed to pay the money, but neither admitted nor denied any wrongdoing to settle a civil suit brought by the SEC. In 1988, the SEC accused Lee, a Taiwanese national living in Hong Kong, and Stephen K. Wang, a junior analyst in the mergers department at Morgan Stanley & Co., of engaging in a $19 million insider trading scheme. At the time the charges were filed, the case was second only to the $100 million settlement of disgraced stock speculator Ivan F. Boesky. Both have since been eclipsed by the settlements of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and junk bond financier Michael Milken. Wang, who was 24 at the time, pleaded guilty in September 1988 to one count each of securities, wire and mail fraud for taking about $200,000 to funnel confidential information to Lee about at least 25 takeover deals that Morgan Stanley was handling. There was no allegation of wrongdoing by Morgan Stanley, which suspended and later fired Wang. Wang was sentenced to eight months in prison. Although he agreed to settle civil charges with the SEC, Lee has not answered a criminal indictment stemming from the SEC investigation. As part of his settlement last August, Lee agreed to pay $19 million into a fund to reimburse investors defrauded by the scheme. He also agreed to pay the government $1.5 million in fines and $4.5 million in back taxes with interest. As of April 16, the receivership fund, plus accrued interest, totaled $20.3 million, according to the SEC. In papers filed at federal court in Manhattan, the SEC proposed reimbursing investors who sold securities in 18 different companies on the same day the defendants bought those securities. The trades in question took place between July 1987 and April 1988. The SEC proposal is subject to a federal judge's approval. Securities of the following companies were involved: Utah Power & Light Co., Manpower Inc., Savannah Electric & Power, IC Industries Inc., E.F. Hutton Group, Outboard Marine Corp., Chi-Chi's, Richmond Hill Savings Bank, Catalyst Energy Corp., E-II Holdings Inc., Stanadyne Inc., American Standard, Federated Department Stores, Stop & Shop Cos. Inc., Firestone Tire & Rubber Co., Sabine Corp. and Staley Continental Inc. Editor's Note: Those wishing to comment or object to the plan should write the court-appointed receiver, Margaret A. Bancroft, at the Manhattan law firm of Dechert Price & Rhoads or the the SEC's chief litigation counsel, Thomas C. Newkirk, at 450 Fifth Street, N.W. Stop 4-2, Washington, D.C. 20549.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Seeks 2nd Delay in Multiple Listing of Options
DOC.TEXT: Most of the nation's five options trading exchanges say they will comply with federal securities regulators' request for another delay in plans to list stock options on more than one exchange. It was the second delay requested by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which last January asked the exchanges to voluntarilly hold off on multiple listings until June 30. A stock option is a contract giving the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell a certain security at a specified price by a certain date. Options are traded on stocks listed on exchanges or traded over-the-counter via computer. Unlike stocks, options provide no voting rights in running a company or dividends _ only the potential to profit from the stock's price movement. Traditionally, an option could be listed at only one exchange. But under multiple listing, all the options exchanges could deal in any option. In a letter to the five options exchanges, SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden asked them to hold off until Oct. 1 on listing options that are already being traded on another exchange. The SEC hopes the exchanges can come up with a joint plan for linking the exchanges electronically by Sept. 21, Breeden said. Last week, Breeden said the SEC has the authority by law to order the exchanges to accept any linkage system, but the agency prefers to have the exchanges develop the system. The June 29 letter to the heads of the Chicago Board of Options Exchange and the American, New York, Pacific and Philadelphia stock exchanges was disclosed Monday by the SEC. Officials at the Philadelphia, American, New York and Pacific stock exchanges said they would honor Breeden's request. But the Chicago Board of Options said it would be ``inappropriate'' to comment publicly before informing the SEC of its stance. Until January, most options on stocks listed on an exchange were traded exclusively in one marketplace. The privelege for trading a specific option was assigned to an exchange by lottery _ a system the exchanges favored but the SEC felt was uncompetitive. But a rule passed by the SEC last year to ensure customers would get the best possible price abolished the limitations on multiple trading of options. All new options, those listed for trading after January, can be traded on any options exchange. Last week Breeden said a system linking the exchanges was feasible and that four of the five exchanges had agreed to operate a system called PIPE, for Public Investor Privileged Express. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange supports a different system: the Auction Intermarket System, which is similar in most instances but has the added factor of time priority. If more than one exchange shows the same price for an option, the Philadelphia system would send the order to the exchange that posted that price first. The PIPE version would allow the exchange where the order was first directed to match that price. ``We've suggested a compromise to the other exchanges and the SEC,'' said Nicholas Giordano, president of the Philadelphia exchange. Under the plan, the PIPE system could be used as long as it lists only post Jan. 22 stock options and can evolve into a time-price system. Giordano said that if PIPE turns out to be more competitive than the Auction Intermarket System, the Philadelphia excahange will go along with the others.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Stocks Also Rise
DOC.TEXT: The dollar edged up against the Japanese yen today after a sharp two-day fall, and share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange also rose moderately. The dollar closed at 151.68 yen, up 0.28 yen from Monday's 151.40-yen close. It opened trading at 151.35 yen and ranged between 151.32 yen and 152.12 yen. The dollar had fallen a total of 3.02 yen in the previous two trading days, and closed in New York on Monday at 150.90 yen. It recovered somewhat today on market players buying dollars to cover short positions, said Masato Hayashi, chief customer dealer for the Bank of Tokyo. In general, ``these days, the dollar is declining day by day,'' Hayashi said. It started down after closing at 155.62 yen on Monday last week. He said the yen has been helped by rumors that the Bank of Japan was considering raising the official discount rate, the interest it charges on loans to commercial banks. Higher interest rates tend to make a country's currency more attractive. ``For the rest of the week, the dollar will fluctuate within a narrow range,'' he said, adding that the release of U.S. unemployment figures on Friday will set the trend for next week's trading. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues rose 254.37 points, or 0.79 percent, closing at 32,414.60. The index had gained 219.99 points on Monday. Estimated volume for first section stocks was 450 million shares. The yen's recent strength, rising interest rates and arbitrage program trading all contributed to the Nikkei's climb on Monday and today, said Toshiaki Kakimoto, general manager of the economics department at Sumitomo Bank. A massive increase in Japan's public works budget over the next 10 years, agreed on in trade talks with the United States last week, will have a long-term impact, said Kazuyuki Suzuki, a trader for Daiwa Securities. ``The effect will last about a month,'' he said. Investors have been buying shares in construction, machinery and high-technology companies. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose slightly from Monday's close of 86.53 to 86.64 by 5 p.m. The yield stood at 7.265 percent, down slightly from Monday's 7.290 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Execs Get Stock Options
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp., struggling with an erosion of its executives, has granted some top managers stock options to keep their compensation packages competitive, a company spokesman says. The nation's No. 3 automaker granted the options last week to about 1,800 executives. ``People were moving on because their package was noncompetitive,'' spokesman Lee Sechler said Monday. Since May 1, Gerald Greenwald has quit as Chrysler's vice chairman and Michael Hammes has resigned as vice president for international operations. Vice President and Treasurer Frederick Zuckerman is expected to leave later this summer and Chrysler Motors Chairman Bennett Bidwell is expected to take early retirement at the end of the year. Chrysler also is amid a $1.5 billion cost-cutting program that has resulted in at least 2,500 salaried employees retiring early or leaving the company. Company officials declined to reveal the number of options granted or their price. Chrysler stock closed Monday at $15.50, down 25 cents. The United Auto Workers union criticized granting the options. ``This violates the spirit of camaraderie and the sharing effort that they've been talking about,'' said Aaron Taylor, president of UAW Local 7, which represents laid-off workers at the company's closed Jefferson Avenue assembly plant. ``When the company is in a downward spiraling mode, they're still rewarding executives,'' he said. ``It leaves a bad taste in the workers' mouths.'' Chrysler and the UAW begin national contract negotiations July 20 to replace an agreement that expires Sept. 14.

DOC.HEAD: Campbell Sells Juice Bowl Business
DOC.TEXT: Campbell Soup Co. says it has sold its Juice Bowl Products Inc. because it no longer fit in with the soup company's plans for improving its performance. Campbell announced Monday that Juice Bowl was sold to ABA Holding Inc. of Cranbury for an undisclosed amount. ABA Holding plans to retain the Juice Bowl name, plant and staff, Campbell said in a statement. ABA Holding is the U.S. arm of Looza NV, a Belgian fruit juice company. Juice Bowl is one of several businesses Campbell has put on the block as the food company tries to improve its sluggish performance by focusing on its more profitable businesses. Campbell put Juice Bowl up for sale in January after acquiring the Lakeland, Fla.-based fruit juice operation in 1982. It generated annual sales of about $60 million. Last week, Campbell put its U.S. and Canadian fresh foods and fresh produce businesses up for sale. The companies have annual sales of more than $300 million and employ about 3,000 workers worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Coca-Cola Names New USA President, Makes Other Management Changes
DOC.TEXT: In a preview of who might be running The Coca-Cola Co. in a few years, the soft drink giant has given some of its rising executive stars new jobs. Coke also announced Monday that its president and chief operating officer, Donald R. Keough, will remain in his job until fall 1993, two years beyond the company's customary retirement age of 65. This decision had been announced to Coca-Cola management about two months ago and ``was widely known within the company,'' said spokesman Randy Donaldson. The company said M. Douglas Ivester would become president of Coca-Cola USA, the soft drink maker's U.S. operation. Ivester, 43, has been with Coke since 1979 and has been president of the company's European Community Group since June 1989. He succeeds Ira C. Herbert as president of Coca-Cola USA. Herbert will continue as executive vice president of Coke and will have corporate responsibility for Coca-Cola USA as well as the company's Canadian subsidiary. The company also announced that John Hunter, currently a senior vice president at Coke and president of the company's Pacific Group, will be given additional responsibilities as deputy to John W. Georgas, who heads the International Business Sector. And Ralph H. Cooper, currently president of the Northwest European Division, will succeed Ivester as president of the European Community Group. The changes are effective Aug. 1. Industry observers said Ivester, Hunter and Cooper are among Coke's brightest stars, and they could rise higher in the next few years. ``I think that's the issue with Coke over the next five years _ who will rise to the upper echelon. Some of the very senior guys at Coke are getting older,'' said Hugh S. Zurkuhlen, an analyst who follows Coca-Cola for Salomon Bros. in New York. ``We now know with some degree of definitiveness who are the key players for the future president and even chairman of the Coca-Cola Co.,'' said Jesse Meyers, publisher of the industry newsletter Beverage Digest. The management changes are part of the company's natural evolution, Coke's Donaldson said. ``We have a very talented group of senior management, and that gives us the latitude to make changes like this,'' he said. ``When you have people that capable, you want to broaden their experience.'' Meyers said Ivester was instrumental in improving Coke's European distribution system and has been one of the company's top young executives. Ivester's European Community Group, which accounts for nearly one-quarter of Coke's international gallon sales, recorded 11 percent gallon-sales growth last year. ``Any objective analysis will show you this man is on a heady track at the Coca-Cola Co.,'' Meyers said from his office in Greenwich, Conn. ``His financial background is excellent and now his operational skills are excellent.'' Hunter also has had success at Coca-Cola, Meyers said, running various division since joining the company in 1967. Hunter, 52, ``is clearly marked as one of the major international executives who in a relatively short time will be a key corporate executive,'' Meyers said. Zurkuhlen said he did not expect to see any significant changes in Coke's operations after Monday's announced changes. ``The company hasn't changed from an operational standpoint all that much'' in the past decade, he said. ``The focus is on increasing consumption of soft drinks around the world.'' The news that Keough was sticking around until 1993 was welcome news, said Zurkuhlen. ``From most people's perspective, Keough is a class act who understands just about every aspect of the company,'' Zurkuhlen said.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Makers Dominate Power Survey
DOC.TEXT: The owners of Japanese cars were the most pleased with the quality of their 1990 vehicles, according to a survey by J.D. Power and Associates. The only U.S. nameplate in the top five of the list released Monday was General Motors Corp.'s Buick Division, according to the Agoura Hills, Calif., research company. Power said 26,000 new-vehicle owners responded to the Initial Quality study, which looks at their evaluations of the 1990 models after three months of ownership. Toyota's year-old Lexus division topped the list, with reports of 82 problems per 100 vehicles. Following were Mercedes with 84, Toyota with 89, Infiniti with 99 and Buick with 113. In Power's model-by-model ranking, the Buick LeSabre was the only domestic car among the 10 most trouble-free. This was the sixth year Power conducted the survey. It sells the results, mostly to automakers, some of whom make use if them in advertising. Power does not publicly release the full rankings of the approximately 33 auto nameplates and more than 200 models studied, said David E. Whiteside, publisher and editorial director.

DOC.HEAD: Specialty Retailer Buys Toy Store Chain
DOC.TEXT: Melville Corp. on Tuesday announced an agreement to buy the assets of Circus World Toy Stores Inc. for about $95 million in cash. The purchase of the 330 Circus World stores from Greenman Bros. Inc. will expand Melville's position in toy retailing. Circus World will become a part of its Kay-Bee division, which operates 770 toy stores in 50 states. The acquisition will be financed from operating cash flow and is not expected to dilute earnings, Melville said. From its headquarters in Rye, N.Y., Melville oversees a collection of specialty retailers ranging from the off-price apparel chain Marshalls to Thom McAn shoe shops, Linens 'n Things and This End Up furniture stores. It also owns the CVS drug and beauty aids chain and last week announced plans to buy Peoples Drug Stores Inc. for $330 million. Companywide sales totaled $7.6 billion last year.

The stock market moved ahead in early trading today, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average above the 2,900 mark. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which gained 18.57 points on Monday, was up another 9.65 at 2,908.91 after the first half-hour of trading. Advancing issues led declining issues by a margin of about 10 to 7 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 508 up, 344 down and 588 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 21.38 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street, compared with 17.64 million shares at the same point in Monday's session. Some late computer-driven program buying and takeover speculation were credited for Monday's gain. But the advance came on relatively light trading, which was expected to persist today on the eve of Wednesday's observance of Independence Day. The U.S. financial markets will be closed on Wednesday. In early dealings this morning in the credit markets, prices of some actively-traded 30-year bonds were down by about $1.25 for every $1,000 face value, pushing their yields up slightly to 8.41 percent. Among active issues on the NYSE early today, Philip Morris was up } at 47~, American Express was up [ at 31] and General Electric was up ] at 70~. General Instrument was up | at 45}. It agreed Monday on a buyout at $44.50 a share by the investment firm Forstmann Little & Co. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was up 0.26 at 196.48. DOC.TEXT: An investor group today dropped its $700 million offer for Talman Home Federal Savings and Loan Association, Illinois' largest S&L. Talman said in a statement that Chicago area banker Harrison I. Steans, leader of the investment group, abandoned the buyout because the S&L's revised earnings projections fell below his original expectations. Talman and Steans announced in May a preliminary agreement under which the Steans group would have bought the S&L for $400 million and invested another $300 million after the acquisition to bring Talman into compliance with federal capital standards. Talman, based in Chicago, has assets of $6 billion. Federal regulators in March ordered Talman to stop paying dividends on its common stock until it meets new government requirements on capital.

DOC.HEAD: Southland Proposes Stock Swap As Part Of Restructuring
DOC.TEXT: Southland Corp., owner of the 7-Eleven convenience store chain, has revealed details of a proposed restructuring it hopes will enable the company to avoid bankruptcy court. In a filing Monday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company proposed swapping one share of common stock for 10 shares of new stock issued to current bondholders through the restructuring. ``We feel that would be a key point to the bondholders, who would like to see some liquidity in the shares they receive,'' Southland spokeswoman Cecilia Norwood said. Southland has been staggering under debt accumulated in a $4.9 billion leveraged buyout and increased competition in the convenience store business. The company already has missed $69 million in interest payments and could be forced into bankruptcy on July 15. In March, the company proposed a restructuring that included a $400 million infusion of money from Ito-Yokado Inc. and 7-Eleven Japan Co. in exchange for 75 percent ownership of the company. Holders of about $1.8 billion in bonds also would new securities worth about $550 million. Bondholders objected, however, in large part because the founding Thompson family retained about 15 percent ownership in the restructured company. A revised proposal was presented last month, decreasing Thompson holdings to about 6{ percent and raising bondholders' share from about 10 percent to about 18{ percent. The revision also increases interest paid on the new securities and shortens the maturities. Monday's filing details how the new bonds and common stock would be parceled out to current bondholders. Southland said it did not begin negotiations with the bondholders until Monday but believes an agreement will be reached by the July 15 deadline. The restructuring must be approved by holders of 95 percent of the value of the bonds and other creditors. ``Over the next 10 days, there will be a lot of discussions, and I think's we'll reach an agreement,'' said John Gordon, chairman of the bondholders' steering committee. But David Glatstein, president of a Dallas investment firm that owns some of the Southland bonds, disagreed. ``I don't know a bondholder who's willing to accept this deal. This thing is going to bankruptcy court. The only thing that'll keep it out is if the company decides to make its interest payments.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with close in Europe, midday rates in NY; AMer planned by 5:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar fell Tuesday against most major currencies as interest among European traders shifted to the British pound. Gold prices were sharply higher. Dealers said the dollar's fall was driven by strong movement into British pounds following widespread speculation that the pound would soon enter the European Monetary System's exchange rate mechanism. Sterling rose against the dollar to levels last seen in February 1989. The latest interest in the pound was prompted by a statement Monday by Karl Otto Poehl, president of the West German Bundesbank, during a speech at London's Institute of Economic Affairs. Poehl was reported as saying he expected Britain's entry into the mechanism soon. The word appeared in an advance version of the speech released to the press, although Poehl chose to delete the time reference in his address. Instead, he said the timing of Britain's entry would be ``the decision of the British government.'' Michael James, head of corporate dealing at Midland Bank, said: ``There have been attempts to take profit (in sterling) a few times today. It hasn't worked. It looks like sterling still wants to go higher.'' In London, the British pound rose to $1.7800 from $1.7635 late Monday. In New York, sterling was quoted at $1.7794 at midday. James said he expects the dollar to trade within a narrow range until after Friday's release of U.S. employment data, the next key indicator for the currency. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 151.68 Japanese yen from 151.40 yen at Monday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 151.15 yen, and in New York, it was quoted at 151.16 yen at midday. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.6509 West German marks, down from 1.6580; 1.3930 Swiss francs, down from 1.4030; 5.5400 French francs, down from 5.5635; 1.8578 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8650; 1,210.50 Italian lire, down from 1,217.00; and 1.1622 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1616. DOC.HEAD: Northwest Exploring Possibility of Buying Eastern
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines Chairman Alfred Checchi has requested a meeting with the International Association of Machinists to discuss the possibility of Northwest buying Eastern Airlines, a union spokesman said today. ``Everything is just exploratory at this point,'' said Jim Conley, a spokesman for the machinists union in Washington. Officials at Eagan, Minn.-based Northwest would not comment on whether Eastern is a possible takeover target. Checchi repeatedly has made public his intention to expand the carrier, possibly by buying an entire airline or parts of one. Two weeks ago, Checchi made his most direct public comments on the issue. ``It's fair to say we have our eyes open and maybe our mouths a little bit open as we see what opportunities are there,'' Checchi said June 20 at a news conference announcing Frederick B. Rentschler as Northwest's new chief executive officer. He declined to identify possible targets. Conley said machinists union officials met Monday in Washington to discuss the problems of integrating the Eastern employees into the Northwest operation. He said the meeting was a prelude to a meeting with Checchi, but said he does not know when that meeting will take place. ``There probably won't be an announcement'' on when the meeting will occur, he said. Eastern spokesman Robin Matell said the possibility of merging with Northwest has come up before and noted Eastern employees received a ``briefing note'' in late June. He said the employees were told: ``Eastern's desire is to create a successful, independent airline, but it's impossible to rule out a merger or buyout.'' The employees were told in the memo that Pan Am and Northwestern had shown interest, but meetings and discussions would not indicate an imminent takeover. Matell said he did not know of any Machinists meetings with Northwestern. The leader of the machinists' union at Eastern, Frank Ortis, said a Northwest-Eastern merger ``would be a great marriage. ``It's speculation. But in our opinion, it would be a great merger and a great buy,'' said Ortis, president of IAM Local 702. ``Northwest is a great airline. Mr. Checchi appears to be very good with public relations and labor relations. All of the people I've talked to, IAM people at Northwest, really think highly of Mr. Checchi.'' The machinists union is the largest union at both Northwest and Eastern, representing 20,000 workers at Northwest and 8,500 at Eastern. Northwest is the nation's fourth largest domestic carrier and Eastern is No. 7. Machinists at Eastern went on strike March 4, 1989, in a pay dispute. Pilots honored the strike but called off their sympathy strike last November, as did flight attendants. The work stoppage last year was followed by a bankruptcy filing, and a court-appointed trustee took over in April. Ortis said machinists would go back to work ``with open arms'' if a settlement could be negotiated with the trustee, Martin Shugrue, or with Northwest. ``We're ready to go back to work,'' Ortis said.

DOC.HEAD: Hot Ice on the Horizon
DOC.TEXT: Here is an icy thought that, oddly, might make a hot summer seem even hotter: The savings and loan bailout, which could cost taxpayers $300 billion, may be just the tip of the iceberg. If the tip is equal to a sum of that size, the single most expensive governmental cost in peacetime, then how massive must the bulk of the berg be? Conceivably, in the trillions of dollars, says economist Ronald Utt, who points out that financial obligations of agencies underwritten by the federal government now total $5.8 trillion. ``And much of that obligation is in bad shape,'' says Utt, vice president of the U.S. Chamber Foundation, a former employee of the White House Office of Management and Budget and a former Heritage Foundation fellow. Potentially, he says, these financial obligations represent a staggering breakdown of government. And, a growing number of critics are saying, the lack of public information on the matter represents a communications breakdown. Most people, it seems safe to say, cannot imagine that other financial breakdowns are threatened, reasoning that if that were so they would have heard of them. But that logic breaks as throroughly as the communications. The obligations Utt refers to are spread among deposit insurance programs, loan and pension guarantees, direct loan programs such as those administered by the Small Business Administration, and debts of five government enterprises. Utt's chilling observations are contained in a paper written for Heritage, a conservative think tank whose opinions sometimes have been influential in the Bush and Reagan administrations. The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp., says Utt, is by no means the only federal credit program confronted with huge losses. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and Federal Housing Administration lost money in 1988 and 1989 and seemed destined to lose again in 1990. The FHA, he says, has seen the level of claims against its shrinking reserves rise nearly three times in three years. Further, he states, ``Half of the farm loans made by the Farmers Home Administration are in default, and half of these defaulted loans have been in that condition for more than three years.'' On and on it goes. The federal government, he notes, stands behind nearly $500 million in guaranteed Veteran's Administration and FHA mortgages, $48 billion in guaranteed student loans ... ``... and a host of other guarantees ranging from rural electrification to shipbuilding loans, and from small business disaster loans to loans for building plants to convert grain to ethanol.'' All together, he estimates, the contingent liability associated with loan and deposit guarantees totaled $3.5 trillion at the end of fiscal 1988. And other insurance programs _ flood insurance, for instance _ add $500 million more. How could such massive obligations not rise to the surface and break more forecfully into the media? How can such dangers lurk so near and not cause more concern? Utt doesn't have an answer to those questions, but he does suggest that both Congress and taxpayers played a role. Most lawmakers, he says, ``tried to convince Americans that the crisis was just an isolated incident, and that the vast bulk of the government credit programs are well-managed and pose little risk to the taxpayer.'' And for their part, many taxpasyers have wished this to be so. It isn't, says Utt, who advocates passage of an Omnibus Credit Solvency Act ``to fundamentally restructure these many programs in order to reduce taxpayer exposure to costly program failures.'' Before it is too late, he adds.

DOC.HEAD: Shareholders Sue Fleet@Norstar Over Problem Loans
DOC.TEXT: Five shareholders are suing Fleet@Norstar Financial Group Inc. for allegedly concealing the extent of problem loans at the company's banks. Three lawsuits filed in U.S. District Court in Providence allege that the company failed to make timely disclosure of its loan problems, thereby artificially inflating its profits and the price of its stock. The shareholders also allege Fleet did not adequately supervise its loan officers, failed to reserve enough money to cover loan losses and concentrated too much of its loan portfolio in speculative commercial real estate, The Providence Journal-Bulletin reported Tuesday. Fleet spokesman Charles T. Conway Jr. declined to comment on the lawsuits, citing the bank's policy against commenting on pending litigation. Fleet said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it ``intends to defend the actions vigorously.'' Fleet's problem loans grew from $398 million on Dec. 31, 1989, to $928 million at the end of the first quarter, resulting in the company's first quarterly loss since 1974. Many of the loans were shifted into the problem category as a result of a federal bank examination. Each of the suits, filed April 4-6, seeks to represent all shareholders as a class action. The defendants include Terrence Murray, Fleet's chairman, president and chief executive.

DOC.HEAD: Staloff to Lead Trading Firm
DOC.TEXT: Arnold Staloff, past president of the New York Commodity Exchange, on Tuesday was named president and chief executive officer of Bloom Staloff Corp., a Philadelphia securities trading firm. As president of Bloom Staloff, formerly known as Bloom & Co. Inc., Staloff will own half of the firm. James Bloom, its founder and former president, has become chairman. Staloff was a senior executive at the Philadelphia Stock Exchange until he left in 1989 to head the Comex. He resigned in April. Bloom and Staloff said they want to expand operations and enter new areas, such as consulting for large financial institutions and developing new trading and risk-management products. Bloom & Co. was founded in 1985, and grew to be one of the largest specialist firms on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Company Plans Pipeline in Juan de Fuca Strait; Environmentalists See Fight
DOC.TEXT: A Canadian oil pipeline company said Tuesday it will seek to build a pipeline under the environmentally sensitive waters of Puget Sound to keep tanker traffic out of the narrow, rocky channels. Trans Mountain Pipe Line Co. Ltd. revived an idea rejected a decade ago by environmentalists and the state after a bitter fight. Friends of the Earth Director Dave Ortman said the new proposal likely will draw the same powerful opposition. The announcement, made in Vancouver, British Columbia, followed by hours the release of a regional oil-spill task force report that recommends serious consideration of an offshore terminal and pipeline to reduce the risk of oil spills in Puget Sound. Trans Mountain proposes building a $500 million offshore terminal and connecting pipeline at Low Point, which is about 12 miles west of Port Angeles on the Olympic Peninsula. The company said the terminal would service 350 tankers and barges annually, allowing them to unload there instead of entering the Rosario Strait and the Strait of Georgia. The terminal also could be used to load tankers with crude oil piped from Canada. That oil currently is hauled by tanker from Vancouver, the company said. A new pipeline from the terminal would connect with existing pipelines to refineries in northern Puget Sound and also with existing pipeline at Burlington, Wash., the company said. The pipeline would run underwater for part of its route. Trans Mountain first proposed an offshore terminal near Low Point in 1981 as part of a proposal to transport Alaska crude oil to Midwestern states. The plan finally was killed as environmentally unfeasible. Trans Mountain will use much of its earlier environmental analysis to support its new endeaver, spokesman Dick Stokes said. Ortman, a veteran of the earlier environmental fight, said environmentalists would fight the new proposal, too. ``It's time to think about not accommodating the oil industry in Puget Sound either by pipeline or tanker,'' he said. But a regional task force said that given increasing traffic of crude oil in the sound, a solid way to reduce the risk of spills may be to move crude oil by pipeline instead of tankers.

DOC.HEAD: Du Pont Markets Herbicide to Attack Weeds in Corn Fields
DOC.TEXT: The Du Pont Co. has begun marketing an herbicide designed to attack weeds that destroy corn crops. The product, Accent, is aimed at controlling weeds that had been impossible to curb _ shattercane, Johnson grass and rhizome Johnson grass. Of the approximately 67 million acres of corn planted last year in the United States, about 9 million acres had problems with the weeds. Don Weir, Du Pont product manager, said Accent could help cut down on farmers' annual corn crop losses of $223.5 million. Du Pont began marketing the product in the United States on Monday. Sales had been delayed pending approval from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, which was granted Friday. Weir said the herbicide is also being sold in Argentina and will be marketed in other countries. The herbicide is applied to corn crops after the weeds sprout, allowing farmers to assess the extent of the weed problem before applying the herbicide. Most other herbicides are applied to the soil before weeds sprout. The United States produced about 42 percent of the world's corn in 1989, according to the National Corn Growers Association.

DOC.HEAD: GE Forms Partnership for New Engine Development
DOC.TEXT: The General Electric Co. has formed a partnership with SNECMA of France to develop a high-thrust jet engine, the companies announced Tuesday. GE's Aircraft Engines division said it has signed a formal agreement givinggg SNECMA a 25 percent share in the development and production of the GE90 engine. GE expects the engine to be the most powerful commercial engine ever developed. The company hopes to have the engine in use by the middle of the decade. SNECMA will provide about 40 percent of the GE90 assembly and test work, and will help design and make various parts of the engine. GE and SNECMA already have a 50-50 partnership in CFM International. ``The foundations upon which we and SNECMA are building this program are solid as a rock,'' said Brian H. Rowe, senior vice president of GE Aircraft Engines. Talks are being held with other companies interested in joining the partnership, Rowe said.

DOC.HEAD: Whiskey Tasters Sip, But Don't Drink On The Job
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Spelling of ``Whisky'' in 4th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Sharon Goodwin doesn't exactly get paid to drink on the job _ just sip. ``There's always plenty to be tasted,'' said Goodwin, supervisor of the sensory evaluation department at Brown-Forman Corp., one of the nation's leading makers and wholesalers of alcoholic beverages. The Louisville-based company produces or markets such brands as Bolla wines, Korbel champagne and Southern Comfort liquor. The company also owns Jack Daniel's Tennessee Whiskey and Early Times Old Style Kentucky Whisky, the nation's second- and third-best selling bourbon-type whiskeys. Brown-Forman's sensory lab is jammed with expensive gadgets that measure, analyze and evaluate various aspects of the spirits. But company officials seem to agree that the human taste bud is in no immediate danger of being replaced by a machine. ``Flavor has been an art over the years, and they're trying to make a science out of it,'' said Wes Hazel, Brown-Forman's analytical lab manager. ``They're trying to replace the tasters, but I seriously don't think we can ever do that.'' Daily production of Early Times and Old Forester bourbon at the company's Louisville distillery runs about 450 55-gallon barrels. The Jack Daniel's distillery in Lynchburg, Tenn., produces about 1,500 casks daily. ``We taste every day's product,'' said Dr. John E. Bujake, Brown-Forman's vice president of research and development. ``So there's a lot of tasting going on.'' To ensure consistency, Goodwin's 10 expert tasters oversee the progress of the whiskey through each stage of production. They sample the liquor from the ``white product'' _ the pure distillate before aging _ to the mature bourbon, which spends between three and five years in charred, oak casks. A separate group of tasters in the quality control department tests the product several times during blending and after bottling. Almost all of the 1,000 employees _ except machine operators _ at Brown-Forman's Louisville campus are potential tasters. But apparently not all of them are whiskey lovers. Goodwin has had to use innovative ways to entice people into her tasting booths, including raffling off china, tickets to sporting events and even free parking spaces. Goodwin said it takes about three months to train someone to rate the product. Once the tasters are trained, the company wants to keep them ``forever,'' she said. But the term ``taster'' is a bit misleading. ``The smell is about 95 percent of what someone's going to give you your rating on,'' she said. ``Their goal is to describe what they're smelling.'' To help the workers describe the aromas, the department is working on a series of standard keywords. They range anywhere from ``Juicy Fruit'' _ for a taste resembling the chewing gum _ and ``woody'' to ``urine'' and ``cow manure.'' The samples are 125 proof, or about 63 percent alcohol. Goodwin said they are watered down to 20 percent alcohol for the tastings. Tasters aren't supposed to swallow the product, but some do, she said. Goodwin acknowledged that she swallows some of the product, but if she drank everything she tasted, ``I'd never make it home.'' Goodwin said she is a bourbon drinker on her own time, but many of the tasters don't drink outside the office. ``I've worked here a year and a half, and I've never gotten drunk while I'm here,'' said Dave Dafoe, a product development specialist and one of the expert tasters. ``I appreciate good bourbons, but I don't enjoy them.''

DOC.HEAD: Striking Miners Begin Talks with Government Officials
DOC.TEXT: Some 2,000 Hungarian miners ended a two-day strike Tuesday after some of their demands were met by the noncommunist government, Hungarian Television reported. The announcement came after a delegation of the miners met with the minister of industry and trade. The miners had refused to enter the pits at the Markushegy unit of the Oroszlany mines on Monday and demanded a meeting with government officials. In a statement issued by the miners' Workers' Council, a loose leadership body, the miners said they were ``paid starvation wages.'' A delegation of 10 miners traveled to Budapest for talks with Akos Peter Bod, the minister of industry and trade, the state MTI news agency said. After the talks, Workers Council Chairman Ignac Czako told Hungarian television, ``We are going back down this evening. We now know this government is willing to listen to workers' grievances.'' Said Bod, ``We do not want to create a precedent with this. These conflicts ought to be solved on the local level.'' The news report said some of the miners' demands were met, including provisions allowing a miner to retire after 25 years of pit work. The miners had demanded a 50 percent wage increase, better benefits and changes in the tax law. They also wanted the mine's administrative staff cut and managers to resign. Mihaly Barabas, mine general manager, said the average wage for miners was $400 per month, compared with a national average salary of $130.

DOC.HEAD: Coors Completes Purchase of Stroh's Memphis Brewery
DOC.TEXT: The sale of Stroh's Memphis, Tenn., brewery to the Coors Brewery Co. was finalized Tuesday, a deal under which Coors will make beer outside of Golden for the first time in its 117-year history. Stroh will continue to operate the 500-employee facility through August, and Coors will assume responsibility for operations Sept. 1, officials said. Coors plans to retrofit packaging operations as soon as possible. Packaging of Coors products at the plant will begin next spring. The purchase price of the plant was not disclosed. Coors currently brews all of its beers at the Golden brewery. It ships some of its brewed beer to its satellite packaging facility in Elkton, Va., which has a packaging capacity of 2.5 million barrels.

Stock prices moved higher at the outset and managed some modest gains today in sluggish trading in advance of the July 4th holiday. The market's best known indicator finished above 2,900 again for the first time in eight sessions. Trading was relatively light as the U.S. financial markets are going to be closed Wednesday in observance of Independence Day. Analysts attributed the rise in stocks to seasonal readjustments of investment portfolios along with the start of the third quarter. Institutional investors such as pension funds, they said, were looking for good values among blue-chip stocks as part of mid-year reallocations of funds. In economic news, the Commerce Department said orders to factories for manufactured goods rose 2.1 percent in May, offsetting a revised 2.1 percent decline the previous month. But market watchers said the report had minimal impact on the stock market as the increase had been widely expected. They said traders are more interested in the employment figures for June which are to be released on Friday. The monthly reports on employment give the markets their first official glimpse of economic activity in the preceding month and often contain information that affects stock and bond prices.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Up Slightly in Light Trading
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices rose slightly Tuesday in light pre-holiday trading. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond rose 5-32 point, or about $1.60 per $1,000 face amount. Its yield fell to 8.38 percent from 8.40 percent late Monday. Financial markets and many businesses will be closed Wednesday in observance of the Fourth of July. Market participants shrugged off government announcements that a large supply of bonds would be sold into the market. Concerns that abundant supplies will depress prices have been on traders' minds for weeks. The Resolution Trust Corp., the government agency in charge of bailing out the savings and loan industry, said it would sell $5 billion of 30-year bonds on July 10. Separately, the Treasury Department said it would sell $18 billion in three-and six-month bills and $8 billion of seven-year notes on July 11. Kathleen Camilli, chief economist for Ramirez Capital Consultants Inc., said fears of oversupply in the market have been ``overridden by expectations that the Fed will ease.'' No announcement was made after a meeting in Washington of the Federal Reserve Board's open market committee, though economists have been predicting the Fed will lower interest rates to try to stimulate the economy. Traders ignored a Commerce Department report showing orders to factories for manufactured goods rebounded 2.1 percent in May. The figure was considered old news because it reflected economic activity two months ago. By contrast, the June unemployment report, due Friday, is widely awaited because it will furnish the first glimpse of how the economy performed last month. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments rose 3-32 point, intermediate maturities gained 3-32 point to 5-32 point and long-term issues rose [ point to 5-32 point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 1.10 to 1,163.67. Yields on three-month Treasury bills sold Monday fell to 7.94 percent as the discount slipped 3 basis points to 7.69 percent. Yields on the new six-month bills issued Monday declined to 7.98 percent as the discount dipped 1 basis point to 7.58 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 7.98 percent as the discount fell 5 basis points to 7.43 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 5-16 percent, down slightly from 8] percent late Monday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 91 31-32, up 5-32 point. The average yield to maturity fell to 7.46 percent from 7.47 percent late Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Down, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended mostly lower Tuesday in quiet pre-holiday trading, while the British pound continued to gain strength on worldwide markets. Gold prices rose here and abroad. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery traded at $362.10 a troy ounce, up $3.30 from late Monday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $361 an ounce, $3.15 higher. Currency dealers said trading was thin on the eve of Independence Day, when U.S. financial markets will be closed. They attributed the dollar's decline partly to technical factors as well as sterling's strength. Demand for the British pound has increased in recent days amid widespread speculation that the currency would enter the European Monetary System's exchange rate mechanism. During a speech at London's Institute of Economic Affairs on Monday, Karl Otto Poehl, president of the German Bundesbank, said he expected Britain's entry into the mechanism soon. Sterling rose to $1.7800 from $1.7635 in London, and to $1.7765 from $1.7715 Monday in New York. The German mark also gained against the dollar. The dollar fell to 1.6509 marks in Europe from 1.6580, and to 1.6505 from 1.6515 Monday in New York. The mark has remained firm in foreign exchange following the monetary union in East and West Germany over the weekend. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.3930 Swiss francs, down from 1.3965; 5.5400 French francs, down from 5.5450; 1,211.00 Italian lire, down from 1,212.75; and 1.16245 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16175. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Monday: 1.6509 West German marks, down from 1.6580; 1.3930 Swiss francs, down from 1.4030; 5.5400 French francs, down from 5.5635; 1.8578 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8650; 1,210.50 Italian lire, down from 1,217.00; and 1.1622 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1616. Earlier, in Tokyo, where the trading day begins, the dollar rose to a closing 151.68 Japanese yen from 151.40 yen Monday. It was quoted at 151.15 yen in London, and at 151.00 yen in New York, up from 150.905. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $361.75 an ounce from $357.55 late Monday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $361 an ounce from $357.80. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold was up 15 cents to close at a bid $358.54 an ounce. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.919 a troy ounce, down from $4.935. Silver rose in London to $4.96 an ounce from $4.95.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Prices Mixed; Crude Slightly Higher
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures finished mixed Tuesday as wholesale gasoline prices retreated after a modest advance. A pre-holiday atmosphere prevailed and trading activity was subdued on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Financial markets and many businesses will be closed Wednesday in observance of Independence Day. The contract for August delivery of West Texas Intermediate rose 8 cents to settle at $16.80 per 42-gallon barrel. The contract tumbled 35 cents on Monday. Contracts for later delivery of the key U.S. crude oil were mixed. Brokers said continuing uncertainty over production and labor problems in the Norwegian North Sea encouraged crude buying. A day-old strike by Norway's oil workers ended Monday when the government issued a back-to-work decree. Among refined products traded on the exchange, unleaded gasoline for August delivery lost 0.59 cent, falling to 56.09 cents a gallon after rising 0.47 cent on Monday. Later contracts posted more moderate losses. Gas prices bobbed up Monday on the assumption that demand would increase as the peak summer driving season got into full swing. The price decline Tuesday came as brokers sold to collect profits. Wholesale home heating oil for August delivery fell 0.10 cent to 48.46 cents a gallon following Monday's decline of 0.06 cent. The September through November contracts also settled lower. In natural gas trading, the August contract advanced to $1.525 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.519, the level at which it had settled on both Monday and Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Leaders Raise $33 Million to Launch New Biotech Firm
DOC.TEXT: Three leaders in the biotechnology industry have formed a new company to develop products to treat chronic inflammation disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis, multiple sclerosis and asthma. Icos Corp. said it had attracted $33 million in startup funds from private investors, including Bill Gates, billionaire founder and chairman of the Redmond, Wash.-based Microsoft computer software company, who holds 10 percent of Icos' equity. The founders of Icos are Robert Nowinski, who helped found Genetic Systems of Seattle, then sold it to Bristol-Meyers Co.; chairman Christopher Henney, a founder of Immunex Corp. of Seattle; and executive vice president and scientific director George Rathmann, founder of California-based Amgen Corp. Icos was launched because ``all of us wanted to get back in the creative process,'' and that's best done in a small company, said Nowinski, Icos' president and chief executive. Icos plans to open a laboratory by late summer and build a corporate headquarters and its own laboratory within two years.

DOC.HEAD: Foremost Taken Off the Selling Block
DOC.TEXT: The nation's largest insurer of mobile homes and recreational vehicles has abandoned its five-month attempt to find a buyer. Monday's decision by Foremost Corp. of America came after FAI Traders Insurance Co. of Australia said it was no longer interested in buying the Grand Rapids-based company, said R. Robert Woudstra, Foremost's chief financial officer. The decision does not settle who will control the company. Several major blocks of shares may still be available to the highest bidder. In December, descendants of company founder Edward J. Frey Sr. announced they planned to sell all of their 4.5 million shares, amounting to 37.4 percent of the company. Family members hoped to fetch the highest possible price by selling their shares in a block. Shortly after that announcement, Foremost's board decided to explore selling the entire company. Foremost's profits have suffered during the past year as it struggled with losses from Hurricane Hugo, investments and from discontinued insurance products. Foremost stock, which closed at $30.12{ on Monday, fell Tuesday to close at $25.62{ in over-the-counter trading.

DOC.HEAD: Gold's Gains Grow With S. Africa Tension
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices advanced for the fifth straight day Tuesday on New York's Commodity Exchange in light trading stimulated by South African labor tensions and talk of buying interest from the Middle East. On other commodity markets, coffee futures advanced while energy futures, livestock and meat futures and grain and soybean futures were mixed. Trading in most markets featured late position-squaring ahead of the Independence Holiday, which tended to flatten out price changes. Gold futures settled $3.30 to $3.50 higher with the contract for delivery in July at $362.10 a troy ounce and the most-active August contract at $364.10. Silver futures finished 1.6 cents to 2 cents higher in New York with July at $4.919 a troy ounce. The gold market continued its slow recovery from last month's tumble below $350 an ounce, although analysts said investors remain cautious. Bette Raptopoulos, senior metals analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities, attributed some of the buying interest to labor unrest in South Africa, where organized labor had partial success Monday with its call for a nationwide general strike. Although the strike attempt had little effect on gold production, ``the threat that there might be a more severe disruption is a bullish factor,'' she said. The market also was buoyed by talk of Saudi Arabian bullion purchases. The Saudis' recent sales of large quantities of bullion has been a major depressant in the market. Coffee futures advanced on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange amid indications Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer, might be willing to consider reinstatement of export quotas to boost prices. The International Coffee Organization voted Tuesday in favor of Brazil's request for a special July 23 meeting to discuss its position on an international coffee agreement. The organization was effectively gutted of its price-control powers a year ago, partly due to Brazil's opposition to a continuation of export quotas. Coffee futures finished .15 cent to 1.85 cents higher with July at 86 cents a pound. Near-term crude oil futures rose slightly on the New York Mercantile Exchange but other energy futures slipped ahead of the American Petroleum Institute's weekly stocks report. The report, released after the close, showed an unexpected 429,000-barrel increase in U.S. stocks of crude oil, which is likely to prompt selling of futures on Thursday. Traders had expected a 1 million-barrel drop in crude stocks. Gasoline supplies fell by 920,000 barrels, which was near expectations. Distillate stocks showed a smaller-than-expected increase of 253,000 barrels. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 5 cents lower to 8 cents higher with August at $16.80 a barrel; heating oil was .01 cent to .14 cent lower with August at 48.46 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .10 cent to .59 cent lower with August at 56.09 cents a gallon. Livestock and meat futures ended mostly lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, led by losses of 2 cents a pound _ the permitted daily limit _ in the pork belly market, erasing Monday's gains. Live cattle settled .03 cent to .30 cent lower with August 72.77 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .30 cent lower to .05 cent higher with August at 83.25 cents a pound; live hogs were .48 cent lower to .40 cent higher with July at 61.67 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .75 cent to 2 cents lower with July at 57.67 cents a pound. Grain and soybean futures settled mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade as pre-holiday profit-taking offset buying linked to forecasts for soybean-stressing hot weather in the Mississippi Delta region. Wheat futures finished 2 cents lower to 5 cents higher with July at $3.23{ a bushel; corn was 2 cents lower to 1 cent higher with July at $2.94\ a bushel; oats were { cent lower to } cent higher with July at $1.40 a bushel; soybeans were 4 cents lower to 5 cents higher with July at $6.48{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Post Modest Advance

DOC.TEXT: The stock market's best known index posted its fifth consecutive gain on Tuesday to finish above 2,900 once again as prices in the broader market also moved higher on the eve of the Independence Day holiday. The gains came in typically sluggish pre-holiday trading, however. The U.S. financial markets will be closed Wednesday and many traders got a head start. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which rose 18.57 points on Monday, added another 12.37 to close at 2,911.63. It has risen in each of the past five sessions and its closing level surpassed the 2,900 mark for the first time since it finished at 2,901.73 on June 21. The record Dow Jones close was set June 15 at 2,935.89. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 8 to 7 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 834 up, 650 down and 503 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 130.05 million shares, down from 130.20 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 161.23 million shares. Analysts attributed the rise in stocks to seasonal readjustments of investment portfolios along with the start of the third quarter. Institutional investors such as pension funds, they said, were looking for good values among blue-chip stocks as part of mid-year reallocations of funds. ``We have some seasonal factors at work here,'' said Newton D. Zinder, a veteran market analyst for Shearson Lehman Hutton. He cautioned against readung too much into the advance. But Gene Jay Seagle, a top technical market analyst at Gruntal Financial Inc., said he was encouraged that the Dow Jones industrials managed to stay above 2,900 without prompting program-driven selling by professionals trying to make a profit on price differences between stocks and stock futures. ``I would expect a resumption of the up move and a test of the highs,'' he said, referring to post-holiday trading. The market appeared to shrug aside the Commerce Department's report that orders to factories for manufactured goods rose 2.1 percent in May, offsetting a revised 2.1 percent decline the previous month. The rise was widely expected and market watchers said traders are more intent on employment figures for June which are to be released on Friday. The monthly reports on employment give the markets their first official glimpse of economic activity in the preceding month and often contain information that affects stock and bond prices. Philip Morris was the most active issue on the NYSE, rising ~ to 48. Several utility issues were also actively traded, evidently to capture dividends. It agreed Monday on a buyout at $44.50 a share by the investment firm Forstmann Little & Co. Among blue chip stocks, American Telephone & Telegraph lost \ to 38| and International Business Machines dropped 1[ to 117|. But General Electric rose } to 71\, Ford Motor rose | to 45 and Alcoa rose ~ to 64}. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market rose $5.68 billion, or 0.17 percent, in value.
