DOC.HEAD: Securities Analyst, Fired for His Opinion
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Marvin B. Roffman says he learned as a child how to read stock tables at his grandmother's knee and later loved his job as a stock analyst so much that he stood up to Donald Trump and lost. The securities analyst was fired by the investment firm Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. after he told a newspaper that Trump's new casino could encounter trouble because the economics of it were flawed. What Roffman already knew, Trump's lenders eventually found out, and the flamboyant developer had to renegotiate his enormous debts. But that didn't mean Roffman got his job back. ``An analyst has to be independent and be allowed to express an opinion, even if it's negative,'' Roffman said. The 50-year-old Janney Montgomery vice president was terminated March 23 over his critique of Trump's Taj Mahal Casino Resort in Atlantic City, N.J., one of the most extravagant structures into the gaming business. The analyst told the Wall Street Journal the casino would flourish for awhile after opening in April, but ``once the cold winds blow from October to February, it won't make it. The market just isn't there.'' Trump threatened Janney Montgomery with a lawsuit unless Roffman publicly retracted the comme a matter for the government of the Philippines to determine. But he added that the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service's June 16, 1989, ``departure control order'' prohibiting Mrs. Marcos from leaving the country remained in effect. He said the ban was based on the potential for ``destabilizing activity'' should she return to Manila as well as the legal problems here.

DOC.HEAD: Will GM's Saturn Succeed, or Will Japan Run Rings Around It?
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: It began as a secret project to create an affordable, durable subcompact with 60-mile-per-gallon efficiency that would leapfrog the Japanese and vault the nation's biggest automaker into the 1990s and beyond. Eight years later, General Motors Corp.'s Saturn has transmuted into a significantly larger, pricier car with a lower mileage rating, a less ambitious production schedule and an audience of skeptics. GM's showcase Saturn project has in many respects become a test of whether American industry can adapt and beat the makers of Hondas and Toyotas at what they do best: luring American consumers. Just how GM intends to convince the buying public that Saturn is superior remains to be seen. GM Chairman Roger Smith, Saturn's most enthusiastic supporter, has said he plans to be at the wheel of the premiere model when it rolls off the assembly line at the Saturn complex in Spring Hill, Tenn. later this summer. But GM officials have declined to specify a date for the world's first good look at a mass-produced Saturn, or whether they even plan a rollout ceremony. Models are supposed to arrive in dealer showrooms by fall. The Saturn saga began in June 1982, when GM put its best brains to work on a hush-hush project aimed at revolutionizing carmaking in the United States. They code-named it Saturn after the U.S. rocket that helped overcome the Soviet lead in space exploration. About 2{ years later, Smith formally established Saturn Corp., calling it ``the key to GM's long-term competitivness, survival and success.'' Since then, curiosity and publicity have been diluted by impatience, cynicism, setbacks and design alterations. The 60 mpg, $6,000 subcompact prototype wonder that Smith flaunted became a 35 mpg, $10,000 compact with no obvious advantages over foreign rivals. GM's initial investment of $5 billion shrank to $3 billion. It halved the number of workers to 3,000 and the annual production from 500,000 to 250,000. There also have been suggestions of infighting between GM executives and their subordinates at Saturn, who originally were given wide latitude to move more quickly and responsively than at their fat, lumbering parent in Detroit. Nonetheless, the goal has remained basically unchanged _ build and sell a car that can recapture a market GM has lost to its competitors, mainly the fiercely efficient Japanese. ``It's a lot more than just another 250,000 units,'' said Joseph Phillippi, who follows the automotive industry for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., the New York investment firm. ``It's the whole process, the completely integrated manufacturing nature.'' Saturn's underlying premise is a ``clean sheet'' approach to carmaking. Nothing in GM's manufacturing past was required for use in Saturn. Design and engineering approaches for the car were to be all new. If successful, the Saturn project holds tremendous potential for the U.S. auto industry. One of Detroit's main frustrations, which Saturn presumably will overcome, is the lengthy time it takes to bring a new car to market, especially when consumer tastes can shift rapidly. Japan is seen as the leader in what the industry calls quick product turnaround time, usually three years or less. Some Saturn critics have said quick turnaround is exactly what Saturn lacks: it's taken eight years to produce a three-year car. But Saturn President Richard G. LeFauve has said that time was needed to be sure the car was right for import-conscious buyers. ``We had to make constant adjustments to make the car more responsive,'' he said. ``Most people think of it as a domestic product. This car is not really a domestic in that it is not designed in a domestic sense.'' The Saturn complex that now occupies the rolling horse-farm country of Tennessee is an experiment in automotive self-sufficiency. The plant has its own stamping plants, powertrain assembly and foundries. But perhaps the most far-reaching innovation is Saturn's labor agreement with the United Auto Workers union. Workers are organized into teams with broad decision-making powers and responsibilities. They receive hundreds of hours of training and are expected to understand the economics behind each car. ``It leapfrogs the Japanese structure and the European structure,'' said Mike Bennett, president of Saturn's UAW Local 1853. ``If there is a new direction for the UAW, it's in Spring Hill, Tennessee.'' Saturn's factory laborers come from GM plants or layoff lists in 32 states and 136 GM locations, but they are working under a contract that their 500,000 fellow autoworker unionists would find alien. The chief differences: _The contract has no specific expiration date. Exactly one year from the date of Job 1, management and labor may begin modifying the contract, if necessary, on a day-by-day basis. _Saturn workers have a hand in design of the vehicle and the factory itself. _Job classifications, which number in the dozens in traditional automobile factories, have been pared to a few. _Saturn workers get paid 80 percent of the wages other UAW members receive, but are eligible for bonuses depending on the car's success. Elements of the contract could spread to other auto plants if Saturn proves successful. ``If we see other plants adopt less job classification categories, that would be a mark of success,'' said automotive analyst Scott Merlis of Morgan, Stanley & Co. in New York. GM's most immediate concerns are whether Saturn sells and who buys it. The car's current estimated price hurls it against some of the toughest competition in the U.S. car market, in which GM will not only be battling with other automakers but itself as well. GM's most popular models, the four-door Chevrolet Corsica and two-door Beretta, are in the same price range. That means GM must attract the import buyer. The company has said it hopes 80 percent of Saturn buyers will be import owners. ``The bottom line is that if you are driving a Honda or (Toyota) Corolla today, you are going to feel very comfortable in a Saturn car,'' LeFauve says. ``If you're driving a (Chevrolet) Cavalier or something else in that area, you aren't going to feel that comfortable.'' But many automotive analysts remain skeptical about Saturn's ability to change an entrenched preference for imports. GM's passenger car market share has shrunk from about 44 percent to 33 percent just in the time since the Saturn project was conceived, while the Japanese share has risen from 19 percent to about 25 percent. Moreover, industry studies continually show a growing American preference for the reliability of Japanese cars. Just this past week, for example, J.D. Power and Associates, a respected industry research firm, said its study of 1990 buyers found that owners of Japanese models were the happiest. David Healy, who follows the auto industry for Barclays Bank in New York, said he would consider Saturn successful if it were able to derive less than half its market from would-be buyers of other GM cars. Otherwise, Healy said, Saturn ``may be an artistic success and a financial failure.''

DOC.HEAD: BUSINESS SAGES: Detroit Investors Found Value in Compounding
With BC-Sages-Investment Club
LaserPhoto
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Over the past 25 years, John Cunniff has written more than 5,000 columns and interviewed hundreds of business and financial newsmakers in his role as AP business analyst. In an occasional series, he revisits some of the people whose old-fashioned wisdom has withstood the test of time.

Thomas O'Hara was a good student at Wayne State University, but he didn't graduate near the top of his class, which meant he was lucky to land an accountant's job at $15 a week. Those were the gray days of 1936, in the midst of the Great Depression and just before the Great War, a time when communism seemed on the way up and American spirits on the way down. O'Hara's spirits didn't succumb. ``Better red than dead'' was a common slogan at the time, but it made no sense to him. ``My goal was to catch the fast movers, the guys making $18 a week,'' he said. Fred Russell, a young fellow with little cash and big hopes, provided the opportunity, an investment club to be guided by George Nicholson, Jr., a stockbroker not long out of Harvard Business School. Russell's hope was that each member would invest $10 a month and that the total would be invested in stocks. It was 1940. Fifty 50 years later, O'Hara and his wife Eleanor were among two dozen kitchen-table investors who gathered earlier this year to dine on filet mignon and celebrate the golden anniversary of the Mutual Investment Club of Detroit. In the 600 months since 1940, club members have invested $227,877. Their joint portfolio now is worth $1,801,255.92. That appreciation is even more dramatic considering club member withdrawals over the years _ more than $1 million to finance businesses, homes, college educations, travel, retirement. The story of the Mutual Investment Club, reflected in the fruitful lives of O'Hara and his co-investors, is a lesson in the wisdom of old-fashioned thrift, which fell far out of fashion in the booming 1980s. The investment club is a mix of old and young. Don Danko, president, is 43, Bob Bilke a mere 28, and Ken Janke, Jr., just 32. O'Hara's two sons are members, too. In contrast, 10 of the 22 members are 70 or older. The combination works well. If youth has dreams, age has experience. Where younger members sparkle with hope, older ones glow with knowledge. They complement each other. The Detroit club became the nucleus of the National Association of Investors Corp., of which O'Hara is chairman and Ken Janke, Sr., president. Based in Royal Oak, Mich., it has 126,000 members _ 14,631 as individuals, the rest in 6,933 clubs. Most follow simple rules. Members make small monthly contributions, usually between $10 and $50, and they reinvest all dividends. Withdrawals are allowed if contributions continue. Nicholson, 83, now revered as the founding father of the international investment club movement, laid down the rules back in 1940: _Invest regularly, usually each month. _Reinvest all dividends. _Invest in growth companies, those growing faster than their industries and the general economy. Other principles were developed. Diversifying, because stocks ripen at varying times. And ``biological testing,'' to determine whether management is young enough to maintain performance for at least five years. Club members propose stocks for study, and after the reports are in, they vote. Typically, shares are assigned to members on the basis of their total contributions, and each month the share values are determined. Underlying the investment club's way of doing things is the conviction that economic fluctuations, the kind that cause so much excitement on Wall Street, are of little concern to long-term investors on Main Street. America's growth is strong, they reason, and when all the ups and downs are averaged out, the arrow still points up. When markets are up, club assets rise. When markets are down, the same amount of money buys more shares. Investors who try to outguess the market aren't likely to win, says O'Hara, a quiet man whose logic speaks profoundly. He puts it this way: ``The stock market is not important; it's the businesses. The business effort might not be reflected in the stock market immediately, but eventually it will. ``Look at individual companies, and have confidence the market will recognize value. It always has.'' Most of the time the gains are more steady than spectacular, but sometimes a stock takes off. The Detroit club bought American Cement, later to become Amcord, at about $2.75 a share, and sold six years later at $32. With the proceeds it bought Kennecott Copper at $25 and sold two years later at about $63. More recently, the club has become a large holder in American Family, an insurer selling now at more than $15 a share. The club's average acquisition price was about $1 a share. Soon after joining the Detroit club, O'Hara was drafted and sent to Iceland. With little to buy, he doubled his contributions to $20 a month and continued to do so throughout the war. Russell, rejected for service by a heart condition, invested the money of O'Hara and other members. By the end of 1946, the record read: Contributions $5,080, withdrawals $2,519, holdings $15,354. Not bad for wartime, and the not-so-certain prospects for the postwar period. MORE

DOC.HEAD: DETROIT: postwar period.
DOC.TEXT: After a slump, the value rose to $33,222 by 1952. Despite withdrawals, the value nearly doubled again by 1955, once more by the end of the decade, and again in 1965, when it reached $246,738. By the end of 1969, after deposits of $75,327 over the years, the portfolio was worth $535,604. A critical mass had been assembled. The dividends, always reinvested, now totaled more each year than member contributions. Bad times severely tested the club's philosophy early in the 1970s, however. Brokers went broke, investors lost fortunes and many clubs like Detroit's disbanded. Inflation raged. Keeping the faith, Detroit club members maintained contributions, at a rate exceeding $7,000 a year. Even so, their portfolio suffered. Its value fell more than $140,000 from the 1969 peak to just $393,434 a year later. After recovering to $430,000 in the next three years it fell again to $387,959 in 1974. The club still bought, confident of a rise to come. It did. By 1979, the portfolio was valued at $759,038, and by the end of 1982, when the market rediscovered fundamentally sound stocks, it topped $1 million for the first time. Of course, it continued to grow. Over 50 years, O'Hara's monthly contributions amounted to a total of only $12,000. The club records show he withdrew $186,000 over the years but that he still had $183,000 left in the portfolio. Considering the small sum invested _ a person might have saved that amount by foregoing cigarettes _ the return seemed bountiful. It didn't make millionaires of everyone, but did allow them to realize some dreams. A $3,000 withdrawal in 1950 helped Russell buy a Howard Johnson restaurant franchise. Eventually he owned three, along with other food outlets, and left his widow a comfortable inheritance. Bob Burger, who joined in 1946, withdrew $5,000 years ago to found a business that developed into Chemetco, a mini-conglomerate. John Biscomb indulged an intense interest in William Shakespeare, went to England and studied the bard on his own grounds in Avon and London. Norman Hill, an original and wily investor, allowed his contributions to accumulate to a current $346,000, a pillow of comfort in his retirement. O'Hara and his wife traveled widely, bought their dream house, sent their sons to private schools and colleges, and convinced them to buy into the club. O'Hara became a New York Stock Exchange governor, and still serves as a consultant on issues affecting individual investors. Persistence is both the secret and the scourge of club investors. ``The hardest thing is just to stay in the business,'' O'Hara said. ``In bad times it's easy to quit.'' With dedication compounding works wonders, although it isn't easy to explain this to those of a modern, get-rich-quick mentality. Begin with a penny and double its value each day, and 10 days later it still amounts to only $5. But keep doubling, and you have $5 million in about a month. The Detroit club amassed its fortune at a modest annualized rate of 12.2 percent, doubling its assets each five to six years. Can the Detroit experience be repeated in these times of instant gratification? Yes, if you have the motivation and the patience, club members say. Modest goals help. Remember, half a century ago, O'Hara's goal was simply to offset the $3 a week shortfall in his paycheck.

DOC.HEAD: Mutual Investment Club of Detroit: Riches from Humble Beginnings
With BC-Business Sages
DOC.TEXT: The story of the Mutual Investment Club of Detroit is a textbook example of the wisdom of investing for the long term. Below, at a glance, are some facts about the club and commentary from AP Business Analyst John Cunniff, who first reported on the club in the 1960s:
ORIGIN: The club was organized in 1940, when some young men tried to put the Great Depression behind them and concentrate on better times.

LEADERSHIP: Fred Russell, a fellow with little cash but big hopes, had the idea for a club to invest in stocks. George Nicholson, a young broker, drew up the guidelines, becoming widely recognized as the father of the investment club movement. Thomas O'Hara, a young accountant, made investment clubs his career.
GUIDING PRINCIPLES: Invest small amounts regularly, usually each month. Reinvest all dividends. Invest in growth companies, those growing faster than their industries and the general economy.

MEMBERSHIP: As the Detroit club succeeded after World War II it gave birth to the National Association of Investors Corp., which now has 126,000 members _ 14,631 as individuals, the rest in 6,933 clubs.
PORTFOLIO GROWTH: $10 and $20 investments built assets worth millions.

SAMPLE INVESTMENT: The goal was to double the investment within five years, but sometimes the results were better. For example, the purchase of American Cement at $2.75 a share and its sale six years later for about $32.
WITHDRAWALS: More than $1 million was withdrawn over the years to buy houses, finance businesses, pay tuitions, provide retirements.

COMMENTARY: There are many messages in the Mutual Club's experience. _Have patience. Recognize that time is a silent ingredient as important to a portfolio as yeast is to bread. _Do your homework; know your investments. Invest in individual stocks, not in ``the market.'' _Invest for the long term. Don't try to time, trade or outguess the market, and forget about trying to fathom the short-term ups and downs of the economic cycle. _Recognize that ``down'' markets are temporary, to be followed by better times. _Be confident that America's economy continues to grow, even if it develops a cold from time to time.

DOC.HEAD: A Look at Saturn Project At-A-Glance
With BC-Saturn Rising
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures about General Motors Corp.'s Saturn Corp. and its products. HEADQUARTERS: Troy, Mich., about 15 miles north of Detroit. FACTORY COMPLEX: On 2,400 acres in Spring Hill, Tenn., 35 miles south of Nashville. About 4.4 million square feet. On-site facilities to manufacture engines, transmissions and components, which frequently are made elsewhere and shipped to an assembly plant. Paint and final assembly operations also are on site. COST: About $3 billion, two-thirds of it at the factory. EMPLOYMENT: About 3,000 at full production. MANAGEMENT: Richard G. LeFauve, president. UNION: United Auto Workers Local 1853, Mike Bennett, president. VEHICLE: Likely to be two- and four-door versions at the start, with a hatchback station wagon in the future. Conventional and multi-valve engines and standard and automatic transmissions will be available. PRODUCTION TARGET: About 250,000 units annually by the end of 1991. MARKET: Saturn's principle market is likely import car buyers. BASE PRICE: $10,000 to $12,000. DEALERS: A network of dealerships separate from GM franchises nationwide. The first cars will be available this fall in the Southeast and California.

DOC.HEAD: Year-by-Year with Saturn
With BC-Saturn Rising
DOC.TEXT: Here are major events in the development of the General Motors Corp.'s Saturn Corp. subsidiary:

July 1982: ``Saturn'' is chosen as the code-name for a new GM small-car project. October 1983: GM Vice President Al Warren and United Auto Workers union Vice President Donald Ephlin agree to explore a new way to build cars in the United States. Nov. 3, 1983: GM Chairman Roger Smith officially announces the project, saying work began 18 months earlier. Dec. 19, 1983: Ephlin and Warren announce establishment of the GM-UAW Study Center to look into the Saturn project. July 5, 1984: Then-President Ronald Reagan visits the Saturn project housed at the GM Technical Center in Warren, Mich. Sept. 15, 1984: The first Saturn vehicle is assembled for testing. Jan. 7, 1985: GM's board authorizes the formation of Saturn Corp., a wholly owned GM subsidiary, to produce the car. Joseph Sanchez is Saturn's first president. Jan. 8, 1985: Smith announces the corporation's formation at a news conference in Warren, Mich., and shows off a running prototype of the car. Smith says the automaker would invest $5 billion in Saturn and employ about 6,000 people. The original plan called for 500,000 subcompact Saturn cars to be built a year. Jan. 10, 1985: Two days after Smith's announcement, Illinois Gov. James Thompson asks GM to put the plant in his state. Two dozen governors other governors ask for the same thing. Jan. 26, 1985: Sanchez dies at Sparrow Hospital in Lansing, Mich. Feb. 4, 1985: William E. Hoglund is appointed president of Saturn. February-July 1985: The site search goes on amid dozens of reports of rumors and indications of potential site selections. July 26, 1985: GM and the United Auto Workers union agree to a unique labor agreement including an elimination of job classifications and joint management-labor teams. July 30, 1985: Spring Hill, Tenn., is chosen as the site for the Saturn manufacturing complex. Oct. 3, 1985: Saturn corporate offices are dedicated in Troy, Mich. Feb. 3, 1986: Richard G. LeFauve succeeds Hoglund as president of Saturn Corp. April 8, 1986: The plant site is formally dedicated in Spring Hill. May 1986: Spring Hill site preparation begins. Oct. 30, 1986: GM announces it has halved the size of the project, saying it would employ about 3,000 people and produce about 250,000 cars a year. Early 1987: Construction continues at the Spring Hill site. Dec. 7, 1987: GM's board approves a $1.9 billion for construction and equipment at the Saturn manufacturing complex. Jan. 27, 1988: Saturn's first building, the powertrain facility, is completed, but not equipped. February 1988: Saturn begins recruiting first of 3,000 workers. March 1988: First production equipment arrives at Spring Hill. July 23, 1988: The new Spring Hill City Hall is completed. The project was paid for through Saturn. Mid- to late-1988: Construction and equipping of Saturn manufacturing buildings continues. Jan. 29, 1989: Twenty-six businesses sign Saturn franchise agreements, becoming the first dealers for the new car. July 31, 1989: Saturn donates 50 acres of land for a new Maury County, Tenn., High School. Nov. 1, 1989: The first engine is produced at the Saturn complex. Nov. 6, 1989: GM's board of directors visits the Spring Hill site for the first time. Jan. 13, 1990: Dedication of the first Saturn dealership site in Santa Ana, Calif. March 13, 1990: First Saturn dealership groundbreaking in Memphis, Tenn. Spring 1990: Pre-production Saturn cars are assembled at the plant to test manufacturing systems. These vehicles will be used in training, crash testing and other research programs. Summer 1990: Production of cars destined for dealers begins. Autumn 1990: Saturn cars scheduled to go on sale as 1991 models.

DOC.HEAD: Buyout Group Picks Former Northwest Exec For UAL Finance Officer
DOC.TEXT: The employee group trying to buy United Airlines' parent company has hired a former Northwest Airlines chief financial officer, the buyout group said Tuesday. John A. Edwardson, 40, would become chief financial officer of UAL Corp. and the airline if its unionized pilots, machinists and flight attendants succeed in their $4.38 billion bid. Edwardson will leave his job as executive vice president and chief financial and administrative officer of IMCERA Group Inc., a Northbrook-based chemicals firm, on Friday. Edwardson would succeed John C. Pope, who announced last month he would resign as UAL's chief financial officer if the buyout succeeds. The buyout group has already hired Gerald Greenwald, a former vice chairman of Chrysler Corp., to be chairman and chief executive if the deal goes through. Greenwald, trying to convince potential lenders to help finance the sale, has said he would surround himself with airline industry veterans in a new UAL management structure. Edwardson was chief financial officer of Northwest Airlines from 1985 to 1988. The employee group has until Aug. 9 to secure financing for their $201-per-share offer.

DOC.HEAD: G-24 Meet to Discuss Extending Aid to More East European Nations
DOC.TEXT: Foreign ministers from 24 industrialized nations meet Wednesday to discuss extending their aid program for Poland and Hungary to four other new democracies in Central Europe. On the ministers' agenda is a recommendation from the European Community's executive commission to include Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Yugoslavia in the year-old aid program. The program, known by its French initials as PHARE, would supply food aid, provide training and financial assistance, help clean up the environment and contribute to economic reconstruction and investments. The four countries have asked to be included in the program, which has already raised $310 million for Poland and Hungary. An additional $62 million is due to be committed by the end of this year and diplomats said another $248 million has already been earmarked for Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Yugoslavia. The EC leaders delayed making a final decision to give financial or other help to the Soviet Union at their June 25-26 summit in Dublin, Ireland. They have agreed in principle to support President Mikhail Gorbachev's attempts at economic reform by giving him some kind of assistance. Aid to the Kremlin will likely be debated at this week's summit in London of the leaders of the 16 nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and also next week at the economic sumit of the seven largest industrialized nations in Houston, Texas. The ministers originally included Romania in their recommendation but then dropped it from the list because of concern over political developments there, notably the government crackdown on civilian demonstrators in June.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stocks Rise In Tokyo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, dollar, comments
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose slightly in morning trading against the yen Tuesday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange also edged upward. The dollar started trading at 151.35 yen, down 0.05 yen from Monday's close of 151.40 yen. The U.S. currency finished the morning session at 152 yen with a morning low of 151.32 yen. The dollar finished at 150.90 yen in New York, down from 152.10 yen Friday. Tsuyoshi Yamamoto, a dealer with the Industrial Bank of Japan, said shortly after the dollar opened that trading companies and securities firms bought the dollar to cover short positions. The dollar then retreated slightly before posting its modest gain. Toru Kanai, of New Japan Securities, said there wasn't much in the way of news to affect the dollar. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues rose 59.37 points or 0.998 percent, ending the morning session at 32,219.60. The index gained 219.99 points on Monday, and was up again by 322.19 by the morning market close. ``Public works spending was the central reason for the rise,'' said Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst for Nomura Securities. Last week, Japan promised the United States to boost public works spending over 10 years. Construction and housing stocks were high, as were industrial machinery and high-tech stocks, he said. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell slightly from Monday's close of 86.53 to 86.48. The yield stood at 7.30 percent, almost unchanged from Monday's 7.29 percent.
